DIV1.P: An IMPARTIAL HISTORY OF THE LIFE and ACTIONS OF PETER ALEXOWITZ, THE PRESENT CZAR of Muscovy: From his BIRTH down to this present TIME.

Giving an ACCOUNT of his Travels and Transactions in the several COURTS of EUROPE; with his ATTEMPTS and SUCCESSES in the Northern and Eastern Parts of the WORLD: In which is intermix'd the HISTORY of MUSCOVY▪
Written by a British Officer in the Service of the CZAR.

LONDON: Printed for W. CHETWOOD, at Cato's-Head in Russel-Street, Covent-Garden; J. STAGG, in Westminster-Hall; J. BROTHERTON, at the Bible, near the Royal-Exchange, and T. EDLIN, at the Prince's-Arms over-against Exeter-Ex∣change in the Strand. MDCCXXIII.
[Price Bound 5 s.]

DIV1.HEAD: A HISTORY OF THE CZAR of MUSCOVY.
DIV1.P: PETER ALEXOWITZ, his present Czarish Majesty; Emperor, or Caesar, or King, or Grand Duke of Muscovy, call it which we will, whose glorious Life and Actions are the particular Subject of this Undertaking, was the youngest Son, tho' at present, the only surviving Son of the late Czar Alexis, or Alexyea Michaelowitz, his Father left one elder Son, and one Daughter, by a former Venture; which Daughter was living, till about the Year 1715, and something of the Hi∣story of both Son, and Daughter, may be briefly understood, in their Management of Affairs.

THE eldest Son a weak Prince, and ncapable of any great Undertaking, was however at first possest of the Government, and reign'd about six Years; dying, as some have said by Poison, by
the instigation of some of the Trayterous Boyars, and in Confederacy with the Princess Sophia his Sister.

AFTER his Fathers Death, the present Czar Peter, tho' Evan or John, his elder Brother was then living, took Possession of the Government, being then on∣ly twelve Years of Age; but afterward there was a terrible Conspiracy, carry'd on by the General of the Strelitzs or standing Forces, and underhand by the said Princess Sophia, which threw the Go∣vernment into great Covulsions, during which, many of the Nobility, or Boyars who were in the Interest of the Czar Peter, were Sacrificed in a most bloody manner to the fury of the Soldiers, and the Person of the Czar preserv'd, but with in∣finite difficulty by Prince Gallitzen, or Golloffken, as some write him, who snatching the young Prince, as it were by Violence out of the Hands of the enrag'd Soldiers, hurried him in the Night out of the Palace, and happily secur'd him in the Monastry of Trotski, above fifty Miles from the Court; and then drawing together such Forces as were at Hand, and such of the Strelitzes as con∣tinu'd faithful, and making a kind of an Accom∣modation; the two Princes were Proclaim'd equal in the Government, and the Administration car∣ried jointly in both their Names.

THIS kind of Government had perhaps conti∣nued longer, had the Czar Peter been of as soft and easy a Disposition, and as willing to be manag'd by his Sister Sophia, as the Czar Evan apper'd to be; but the Czar Peter appearing to be of a manly Genius, an enterprizing gallant Temper, and a Spirit fited by Nature for Em∣pire. The Princess Sophia easily foreseeing the Terminaion of her Authority in the ripening
Age of her younger Brother, fill'd the State with continual Plots and Conspiracies, which at last Ended, as such things generally do, in establishing the Authority of the present Czar, and in her own Ruin, as shall appear in its Place.

AS to the Czar, Evan or John, he dyed a∣bout the Year 1691, and left the present Czar Pe∣ter sole Governour of the greatest Dominion in Europe, and in whose Reign those Dominions have received such Additions of strength from an altera∣tion of the Conduct of the Prince, as the like can∣not be shewn in the History, of any Country in the World, especially considering that it has been generally brought to pass, without any conside∣rable Conquest of other Princes Dominions, but chiefly by altering the Oeconomy, the Customs, Manners and Commerce of his own People.

BY this Means, he has brought a Nation, who were before the most blind and ignorant, and the greatest contemners of Knowledge, and of all manner of Learning, to be Searchers after Wis∣dom, studying Sciences and eagerly bringing Home Books, Instruments, and Artists, from the most learned parts of the World for their Instruction.

BT this Means, he has brought his Soldiery, who were before the most Scoundrel undisci∣plin'd Crowds, Rabbles, rather than Soldiers, and just good for nothing to be regular Disci∣plined Troops, Cloath'd, Arm'd and Paid like other Nations, and behaving on all Occasions in a manner sufficient to make them formidable to those who us'd to Dispise them.

BY this Means, he has reduc'd his People in ge∣neral, to a legal kind of Obedience to their Go∣vernors; not the same blind kind of Homage they us'd to pay to their Princes, who they rather
worship'd than obey'd; but, a more polite Re∣gulation, so that now the Czar endeavours to convince their Reason, of the real Advantages which his new Laws are to them, at the same time that he exacts their Obedience.

BY this Means, he has regulated their Com∣merce, shew'd them the Profit of a vast Expor∣tation of their own Product to other Countries, and of the Importation of the Product of other Countries to them; by which their Wealth daily encreases, their People who before had little Business, now begin to get Employment, and their Lands encrease in Value.

BY this Means, he has brought his People to be acquainted with the Sea, and they who had be∣fore scarce a Ship of any Consequence, either for Trade or War in the World, are now able to ap∣pear in the Baltik with a Royal Naval of near 30 Men of War of the Line, Six and Twenty Fre∣gats, and 300 Galleys, such they had in their great Expedition against Sweden, in the Year 1719, besides Transport Ships, and on board of all, which as I have been inform'd were employ'd 18000 Seamen, besides Soldiers, which Fleet are since ve∣ry much encreas'd, as shall be shewn it its Place.

THE former part of this Princes Reign, was taken up, either in the Quieting the intestine Troubles of his Subjects, the Factions of his Cour∣tiers, and the Rebellions, and Conspiracies of the Nobility and Soldiery, who were continually rendred Unquiet, and Uneasie to him, by the Conspiraies of his Sister, the Princess So∣phia, and her Creatus, OR in reducing the en∣croaing Tartars, on the side of Astraan, and the Countr of Circassia, who several times gave him great Disturbance, ravag'd the Country, and
carried off great Numbers of his People into Sla∣very; but in all his Encounters with these Peo∣ple, he was follow'd with a Series of continual Success, his Rebels were every where not only Conquer'd, but entirely Subdu'd, and almost uni∣versally fell into his Hands, and so were either cut off by the Hand of the Executioner, in which Cases, tho' the Severities us'd were terrible, yet they were no other than the Custom of the Coun∣try made lawful; or else, were banish'd to Siberia, where they are at full Liberty, and yet rendred entirely uncapable of ever returning to disturb the Government.

THE utter impossibility of any Persons, ex∣cept such as are at the Head of every Action, gi∣ving any Account of things in Muscovy, where no Records are kept, or History written of publick things, makes it not to be expected that I should be able to give Journals of the March of Armies, and exact Accounts of the several Expeditions of his Czarish Majesty to the Southern part of his Do∣minions, either against his own Rebellious Circassi∣ans, the Calmuck Tartars, or any other, except such as those, the Accounts of which we have from the History of the other Countries he was engag'd with, of which I shall give as full an Account as the best Intelligence of those times will permit.

THE enterprizing Genius of the Czar, and his early attempts to put his Empire in a posture of Defence against the Potent Neighbours who surrounded it, was not at all agreeable to the com∣mon Notions of the Muscovites; Building Ships of War, Entertaining Foreign Artists and Engineers, and laving Schemes according to the Manner of the other Nations of Europe, whose way of making War is so eminently improv'd, were all things
disagreeable to them, who as they had no Know∣ledge of Arts and Sciences, no Mathematical un∣derstandings, or Sense of Improvement, so they Ha∣ted and Dispised all those who knew more than themselves.

NAY, so eminently were they carryed out in the Esteem of their own Ignorance, that they made it a Point of Religion, and thought it a breach of the Laws of God to mingle their Cu∣stoms with those of other Nations, or to bring the Usage of Foreigners among them; as if Wis∣dom and Knowledge were not to be search'd af∣ter to the Ends of the Earth, and it were no loss to them to be the most blind, and uninform'd Nation in the World.

BUT the Czar saw with other Eyes; it was easy to him who had a Penetrating Judgement, and a Mathematical Head, tho' uninform'd by the Knowledge of Art, to be sensible of the want of it; and when he saw the readiness of Foreign Artists, how they acted their Part by Scale and Rule, and had a whole System of things in their Heads, there needed no more for a Prince thus a∣ble to see the Defect of his own People, and the Advantage which Neighbouring Nations had o∣ver them on that account; I say there needed no more than a Sense of this, to cause him to resolve upon a general Application to the great Work of informing himself, and by degrees his People also in the useful Knowledge which flourish'd among the other Nations of Europe; and to bring them to receive such Notions, and such Customs as might in time render them equal to their Neighbours: If any Man were to have a true Account of the former obstinate Ignorance of the Muscovite Nation; how they dispis'd and refus'd all Information,
how they made it Criminal to suffer any of their People to travel Abroad, much less to pretend to bring Home any experimental Knowledge, or a∣ny Customs, however good in themselves, from other Nations; one wou'd first wonder how the Czar came, as it were alone, among his whole Na∣tion, to resolve upon being better inform'd; and much more how he has been able to Conquer the obstinate Ignorance of his People.

NOT that he has Effectually done it yet, or per∣haps ever will; and if his late Son, the Prince of Muscovy had liv'd, 'tis certain he had so little Tast of those things, tho' he had been Abroad, that he would have unravell'd all that his Father had done, and brought the Nation back to their Native stupidity again.

BUT that obstacle is remov'd, and so are many other; the Czar lives still, and proceeds to bring all the European Customs and Usages into Fashion with his People; and in a few Years more it may happen, that there will be so many Men of Learning and Judgement found in Mus∣covy, that they will never return again to the bru∣tal Life, which they formerly led; especially, if the Successor to his Czarish Majesty should hap∣pen to be some German Prince, who may Marry his Daughter, or that the present Heir apparent should live to have a foreign and learn'd Education.

IT has been said, that this insight which the Czar had so early receiv'd, into the Deficiency of his Countries Customs, and the Impressions of his own Ignorance, in those things, which a Prince ought to know, were first formed by Conversing early with one Monsieur Le Fort a French Gentleman, of excellent Parts and Learn∣ing, who he had Entertain'd in his Court, while
he (the Czar) was very young, and whose Con∣versation he was extremely Fond of: That this Gentleman first exited him to Great and He∣roick Actions, fill'd his Mind with generous and gallant Principles, and at last recommended to him to take that happy step of Travelling in∣cognito thro' all the polite Parts of Europe, that there he might see whether what he Le Fort had intimated to him of the exquisite Management of things in other Countries were true or not; and that he might from thence return furnish'd with Knowledge of all things relating to Peace, War and Government, and make himself Master of what ever was Necessary to make him truly Great, and so be in time an equal Match for his (at present) more powerful Neighbours.

IT is the hardest thing in the Worlds for Man to be Convinc'd of his own Defects, and till he is so Convinc'd, 'tis impossible to make him apply to Improvement; for who submits to be taught what he believes himself to know enough of.

Q.L: If Fools could their own Ignorance discern,
They'd be no longer Fools, because they'd Learn.

DIV1.P: BUT here was a Prince arriv'd to the Perfe∣ction of Knowledge, (viz.) to know that he knew nothing; and from this original Sense of his own, and of his Peoples Deficiency, he first resolv'd to Travel, that he might Learn every thing, and then return to be the general Teacher of his own People.

HAPPY Humillity! he Travel'd in quest of Knowledge, that he might be qualified to be the Great School-Master of his Subjects; and we shall soon see the Success in a Manner, such as the
whole World can show not One Example of the like.

BUT to return to his other Enterprizes, before the great Undertaking of all, which takes up so much Room in all the Histories of the Age. The first of his Undertakings was the reduction of the Circassian Tartars, who in the infancy of this Reign had Revolted, or rather made War against the Muscovites, had pass'd the Wolga, and seiz'd upon Astraan, where they committed unheard of Cru∣elties, and Barbarities upon the Inhabitants.

THE Muscovite Army was not in this War Com∣manded by the Czar in Person, but by his Fa∣vourite Prince Gollofkin, and under him by some foreign Officers, who carried on the War at first with Success, but made no great Progress till the Czar coming in Person with some additional Troops, push'd the Tartars with such Vigour, and used his Victrory so effectually, that he brought the whole Country of Circassia to his Obedience: And some of his Troops Ravaged the Crimmee, and struck a Terror even into the several other Nations of Tartars, up to the Borders of the Boristhenes.

THIS War brought on another of more Weight, and indeed of more Danger, and that was a War with the Turks, which it must be con∣fess'd, the Czar shew'd his Pollicy in adven∣turing upon at that Time; because the Turks were just then Embarrass'd in a War with the Emperor of Germany, the King of Poland, and the State, or Common-wealth or Venice all together; so that they were in no Condition to send any Number of Men to make their Arms formidable to the Czar.

UNDER these fair Prospects, the Czar of Muscovy broke with the Turks in the Year, 1694, and then follow'd a Series of Successes, which rais'd the Fame of the Muscovite Arms above what they ever reach'd before; but especially, gave the World a taste of the personal Valour and Conduct of his Czarish Majesty, of whom they had heard very little till now.

THE Tartars who had so long been the Terror of Muscovy, were miserably Defeated by the Mus∣covite Army in Three very considerale Actions; of which however, Intelligence coming very slow and uncertain from Places so Remote, and from Nations who held so little Correspondence with the rest of the World; we had no particular Ac∣count till some Years after, when we were be∣holding to the Relations given of them from the Memory of some Scots Officers who serv'd in the Muscovite Army.
THE first thing done in this War, was to clear the eastern Banks of the Wolga from the Tartars, and drive them effectually into their own Bounds.

THIS had in part been done before, when Prince Gollofkin the Elder, had recovered Astra∣can from them. But they still remain'd in great Numbers on the Calmuck side, and frequently made Incursions into the Countries possess'd by the Muscovites, and Ravag'd far and near, accord∣ing to their usual Method, making an inexpressi∣ble Desolation wherever they came.

THE first Troops the Czar sent this way upon his new Scheme of this War, effectually drove the Calmuck Tartars over the Wolga; at the same time the Cossacks, such of them as were Subject to the Czar, had fallen upon a great Body of the Crim-Tartars, who had made an Attempt to fall
into the Czar's Dominions on the side of Circassia, and gave them a great Defeat, killing 15000 of them upon the Spot.

BESIDES this, the Czar's General Gordon a Scots Gentleman, and an Officer of great Experi∣ence entered into Circassia itself, and after giving the Tartars several Defeats, reduced that whole Country under the Obedience of the Muscovite Government, as it remains to this Day.

IT should have been observ'd here, that tho' the Muscovite Militia were not yet brought to the happy Regulation and Discipline, they are ince by the Czar's Application and Management arriv'd to; yet they had been much Improv'd, and were in a much better Condition than they had formerly been in; and this by the Manage∣ment and Direction of the late Czar Alexis Mi∣chaelowitz, the present Czar's Father, who indeed began to alter several things in the former un∣polish'd Method of the Muscovite Government; and particularly that of the Army; and remark∣ably in this, that he resolv'd to introduce the German Military Discipline among his Troops; and to have the Soldiers taught the Exercise for the handling their Arms, Marching, Counter∣Marching, Wheeling, drawing up, Forming and Embattleing, &c. after the German Manner. And to this purpose, he Entertain'd a great Number of foreign Officers in his Army, who he Encourag'd to come out of the Service of all the Princes near him, by Promises of large Pay and good Usage, with Preferments according to their Merit, and which Terms they found very punctually Com∣ply'd with; and his Son the present Czar persu∣ed the same Method.

BY this means he had at the time of his Un∣dertaking the War I am now speaking of, two Generals (viz.) Monsieur le Fort, and Mr. Gordon, the first a French Man, the second a Scots Man, and above 3000 inferior Officers of several Na∣tions in his Pay, besides Engineers, Cannoniers, Bombardiers, and Firemen in abundance.

AND this was the great Reason why his En∣terprizes in this War were carry'd on with great Regularity; his Sieges managed, and Trenches open'd according to Art; his Batteries, Mines, Attacks &c. well serv'd; and every thing done as it ought to be done. Things which in former Times the Muscovites knew little of.

I am oblig'd to pass over the first Actions of his Czarish Majesty's Generals in this War, in a summary Method, not being able to come at the particular Days of the Month, or the particular Circumstances of every Action, nor any Diary of the March of the Armies, in a time when as before, scarce any thing was done with that Re∣gularity, which has been usual in such Cases in other Countries, and which has since been better Manag'd there: Besides, this was a kind of a Tumultuary War, the Tartars being a People that made only a kind of Camp Volant in all their Marchings; and in every thing they did, it might be only said, that it was by way of Excursion, and Incursion; Plundering and Burning, when they Advanced, and Runing or rather Flying, when they Return'd; so that they were only to be Fought, with by the way of Intercepting them, and by Surprize; and when at any time they were brought to Fight, it could never be call'd a pitch'd Battle, but rather a runing Fight, their whole Army be∣ing
always on Horseback, for as to an Infantry, they know nothing of them.

HOWEVER, as the Cossacks were likewise Horse, tho' not so well Mounted, they, often met with and routed the Tartars too; and that ra∣ther, because the most Soldiery part of the Tar∣tars were at that time Engag'd against the Po∣landers, or in Hungary, against the Imperial Ar∣mies, in Conjunction with the Turks.

BUT to come back to the Person and Conduct of the Czar, it was in persuit of his Conquests on this side, that his Czarish Majesty found how fair a way lay open to him to make himself Power∣ful by Sea; a thing which had long lain upon his Thoughts, but which till now he never had so much as room to find feazible, or indeed possi∣ble; having no Out-let into any Sea where his Power might exert itself: As to the Wolga, tho' it be a very great River, and of a prodigious extended Course, having run above 2500 Miles, including the Windings and Reaches of its Course, yet there is no depth of Water in the Channel at the Mouth or Influx of it into the Sea; but the Sands and Flats of the Shore in the Caspian Sea on the Russian side choking up the River, makes it un∣capable to carry Ships of any Force, except at the time of the Winter Floods; and even then, the Caspian Sea itself for some Leagues, has no depth of Water answerable for a Royal Navy of Men of War, such as the Czar had Projected to Build.

ON the other hand, had the Caspian Sea been deep and every where Navigable as wou'd be suf∣ficient, yet this respected only the Shores of Per∣sia, Armenia, Georgia, and those Countries, which rendered the Czar no Prospect of Glory, or Con∣quest.
But his Designs lay another way, that is to say, to open to himself a Navigation into the Black Sea, where he might either extend his Con∣quest or his Commerce, or perhaps both, into the lesser Asia, and even to the Gates of Constanti∣nople; and either by Force or by Treaty, might obtain a Passage thro' the Straits of Hellespont, and the Thracian Bosphorns into the Mediterrane∣an Sea, and so might establish an open Trade be∣tween his Country and the Ports of Italy, France, and Spain, and consequently with all the known World.

THIS open'd a Scene of Glory fit for a Prince, and suited to the great Enterprizes which his Czarish Majesty had formed in his Mind: In a word, here was a Field of Action large enough to gratifie the Ambition of a Sovereign, Born for great Things, and who possessing an Empire Su∣perior to any of his Neighbours, wanted nothing but an Entrance upon the Stage of Greatness, that he might Act like himelf.

HE saw at once all the great Things which might be the Consequence of this Conquest in many Ages to come; and it was from this Judgment that he had made of Things, that he had purposed to Build a large Fleet of Men of War, even while the World stood Amaz'd at the Mystery of it; see∣ing they were Built many Leagues up the Coun∣try, on the bank of a River, (viz.) The Don or Ta∣is, whose Out-let into the Sea was not in his Possession, but Blck'd up by the Turks with in∣numerable Obstacles; such as strong Fortrcsses, narrow Straits, great Batteries, Ships of War, and the like, particularly, the City and Forts at Asoph, the Lines at the Mouth of the River Don, and Works at the Straits of Caffa, which last is,
the only Entrance into the Black Sea, out of that Sea call'd the Palus Meotis.

BUT his Czarish Majesty's designs were not to be Diverted with the Prospect of those Difficul∣ties; and therefore even before he seem'd to aim at opening the Passage of those Places, or Enga∣ging in any War to bring it to pass, he employ'd Agents into Holland, and into England, to furnish him with experienc'd Ship-Wrights, and Builders, in order to build a Royal Navy of Men of War, even when no Body could foresee in what Part of the World they should be Employ'd; his Czarish Majesty having then not one Port in the Baltick Sea, the Euxine Sea, or any where else, except that of Arch-Angel opening to the North Seas, in the Latitude 72 degrees, where he could have no occasion to use them.

BUT the Event soon discover'd the Sagacity of the Design, for the same Year the Czar having before been long Solicited by the Confederates, came into the War with the Turks, which was solemnly proclaim'd the twentieth, of February, 1694.

IN pursuance of this War, and of the Mea∣sures concerted with the Allies, the Czar appear'd with two Armies in the Field, the beginning of the Year 1695, the one consisting of 90000 Foot, and 20000 Horse and Dragoons, Commanded by his Czarish Majesty in Person, and with which he march'd into the Russian Circassia, and entering the Turkish Dominions, sat down before Asoph, an im∣portant Fortress upon the Banks of the Tanais, near the Mouth of that great River, where it em∣pties itself into the great Lake, or Sea call'd the Palus Meotis; and the other Army consisting of 24000 Foot and 36000 Horse, the latter being
all Coassacks, and was therefore call'd the Cossack Army, Commanded by Lieutenant General Prince Czeremetoff, of whom we shall often have occasi∣on to speak hereafter in the Course of this Hi∣story. This Army march'd by the Way of the Ukraine, and keeping the Course of the great Ri∣ver Boristhenes, or the Neiper to the Mouth of the said River, sat down before the strong Town of Kasilkermeen, a Tartarian City, Situated on the South Bank of the said River Neiper, and within two Leagues or thereabouts of the Black-Sea.

THESE Towns were equally considerable, as Situated at the two great Enterances into the Pontus Euxinus, nearest to his Czarish Majesty's▪ Domi∣nions; and most conveniently Seated, both to fa∣cilitate his Designs for the Commerce of his Sub∣jects in those Seas, and equally Advantageous to him for carrying on his farther Design against the Turks.

IF the Christian World were agreeable sur∣pris'd at the Czar's breaking with the Turks in a Juncture so very Momentous, and so Seasonable to the Confederates, they were even amaz'd to find a Prince, of whose enterprising Genius they had yet form'd no Notions, begin a War with such apparent Proofs, both of an exquisite Fore∣knowledge, and also of a perfect Understanding of the Weight and Consequence of what he had Undertaken; on the other Hand, the manner of his Entrance into this War, and the formidable Power with which he began it, gave the Turks a terrible Alarm, especially considering how their Affairs were at that time Embarass'd in a heavy War with the Emperor, the King of Poland, and the State of Venice, all at the same time, and in which they had receiv'd several terrible Over∣throws,
and had already lost almost all the King of Hungaria, all the Morea, and several conside∣rable Fortresses in Dalmatia, and other Places, be∣sides having their Millitary Power, broken both at Sea and Land, by innumerable Defeats of their Armies and Fleets; but we shall see them farther Alarm'd in the process of this War, by the Success of his Czarish Majesty in the Prosecution of it.

IT was now too late, that the Turks saw their Mistake, in that having for many Years the City of Asoph, in their Possession, if they had consi∣der'd it as one of the most important Frontiers of their whole Empire, they would have made it as impregnable, as the Consequences of such a Place requir'd, and as the Situation of it very well allow'd; for it was most advantageously Si∣tuated on the North Bank of the River Don, with a low Marshy Ground opposite to it, which was capable of being so Fortify'd, as appear'd after∣wards, and to be so surrounded with Water, as not to be any way attack'd, otherwise than by a Bombardment, or to be taken, but by a strict Blockade.

ALL that the Turks could do, upon the sudden approach of the Czar's Army, was, to supply the Want, or Weakness of the Fortifications, with a bold resolute Garrison of ten thousand Janisaries, all old Soldiers; besides Tartars; and under chosen Officers, well furnish'd with all things for a vigo∣rous Defence; and this they plac'd the more Confi∣dence in, by how much they had the Muscovites still in the utmost Contempt, as to their Military Capacity of attacking such a Place.

NOR did the Garrison disappoint their Masters, or fail in doing their Duty, and in such manner,
that altho' the Czar attack'd the Place in Form, and that his Engineers made their Approaches with the utmost Skill, and Batter'd and Bombard∣ed the Place with a 100 Pieces of Cannon, and 40 Mortars; yet the Garrison so Harrass'd them with Continu'd bold and desperate Sallies, and so ply'd them with a numerous Artillery from the Walls, so often levell'd the Trenches of the Besiegers, Nail'd their Cannon, and ruin'd their Works; that the Winter coming on, and Provisions growing Scarce, the Czar tho' he was in Person at the Siege, was oblig'd to give it over, after having lost as some have reported above 30000 Men before the Place, and half ruin'd his Calvalry for want of Fo∣rage.

BUT Prince Czeremetoff had better luck be∣fore Kasikermeen, which tho' it was better Forti∣fy'd, was not so well Defended; and the Cossacks pushing on their Attacks with a desperate Fury, they carried the Place Sword in Hand, the Gar∣rison having but just time to retreat into two large Forts, which cover'd the City on the side of the River, where beating a Parley, they had good Conditions granted by the Besiegers, and so the whole City was taken.

THERE was a complaint made against the Muscovite General Prince Czeremetoff, for suffer∣ing the Cossacks to Plunder the Garrison after the Capitulation was Sign'd; and that Princes Dis∣grace happening soon after, was assign'd to that Cause; but I do not take upon me to say, this was the Cause of it, and as that Prince has been receiv'd into his Masters Favour since, that, with very great Reputation, 'tis generally suppos'd, that he acquitted himself of that Accusation.

IF the Turks committed an Over-sight an their, not fore-seeing the Importance, and Fortifying in time the City of Asoph, they were now guilty of the greatest and most inexcusable Neglect and O∣mission, in not taking the opportunity of the Win∣ter, when the Czar's Troops were with-drawn, to send a powerful Succour to the Garrison, that they might have Defended the Place another Year, as they had done the Year before.

ON the contrary, the Muscovites left a Body of Forces in the Country, who as it were, effect∣ually Block'd up the Place by Land; and the Turks neither supplyed the Magazines with Provi∣sions, or reinforced the Garrison with fresh Troops; both which it was very easie to have done by Sea; the Muscovites having then no Naval Strength at all: Of both these there was an absolute Necessi∣ty, for the Magazines were not only Empty, the Ammunition being extremely lessen'd in the fre∣quent Sallies and continued Fireings during so long a Defence, as that of the last Siege, but the Garrison was reduced from ten Thousand, to two Thousand eight Hundred Men.

IN this distress'd Condition, they were oblig'd to sustain the second Siege, having long sollicited for Succours but in vain, till it was too late to re∣ceive them, as will appear in the Sequel of the Story.

DURING the Winter, the Czar was not Idle; the prodigious Preparations made in all Parts of his vast Dominions, for Recruiting his Army, Remounting his Cavalry, and supplying the Ma∣gazines with all necessary Stores of Ammunition, &c. Intimated plainly, that the Attempt upon Asoph was not laid aside; but that which was most considerable of all, was the Expedition
with which his Czarish Majesty furnish'd himself with a Fleet in one Winter; and that odd and extravagant Manner in which some of the Vessels were Built, several of them having been Built in the River Occa, and carried over Land to the Dona, and most of the rest at Voranowitz, a Town on a River of that Name, which emplies itself into the Dona above 300 Miles above A∣soph.

THE Detachment of Troops which the Czar had left to Block up the Place during the Winter, had maintaind their Posts upon the Neighbouring Hills, and so well scour'd the Country, that the Garrison of Asoph had no opportunity of reccive∣ing any Relief or Supply by Land; and early in the Spring the Muscovite Troops began to arrive, so that they were actually Besieg'd again, before they had received the least Recruit.

THE Preparations for this second Attack, were so much greater than those of the first Siege, that the Garrison had much more need to have been doubled than lessen'd, the Violence they had to sustain, being so much the greater; for the Artil∣lery the Czar had prepar'd for this Attack, were 400 Pieces of Cannon, and 150 Mortars.

THE Expedition us'd in all these Preparations was such, that the Body of the Army arriv'd be∣fore Asoph, in the End of April; but the Rivers not being open for bringing the Vessels loaden with Artillery, Bombs, &c. and for the Ships from Veranowitz, till the middle of May, it was the beginning of June, before the Siege was actu∣ally form'd; all which time the Turks had fairly before them to have relieved the Place; which however, as if an Ill-fate attended them, they o∣mitted till about the middle of July, when their
Squadron began to appear in the Black Sea, and when they found to their Cost that they were too late, as we shall see presently.

THE Czar came in Person to his Army the be∣ginning of May, and the Siege begun with the utmost Vigour; the Garrison, tho' extreamly re∣duced, and in want of many things, yet defended themselves with a desperate Valour, rejecting the Summons sent them in his Czarish Majesty's Name, by General Gordon, with offers of an honourable Capitulation, and another Summons after that, threatening them that they should have no Quar∣ter, if they were taken by Storm.

THE Muscovite General Gordon found that the Ground did not admit of Carrying on Trenches, so well as could be wish'd, and the Garrison ha∣ving near 300 Pieces of Cannon upon their Works, made such a continual Fire, as ruin'd the Muscovite Batteries; for the said Batteries being made of a loose Sandy Earrh, which would not bear the Weight of the Artillery. When the Shot of the Town had but beaten them a little in the Front they fell down; so that the Guns were dismounted by the Enemy, with the greatest ease immaginable: Upon this, the said General Gordon undertook to carry on a rol∣ling Trench, or rather a rolling Parapet, which by the help of a multitude of Hands, and near six Weeks labour, he brought to such perfection, that it terrify'd the Besieged more than all the Bombs and Cannon in the Army.

THIS Work was begun at a good distance from the Place, and as there were above 30000 Men continually employ'd in it, who reliev'd one another every four Hours, the Work came gra∣dually rowling forward, the Men behind it still throwing the Sandy Earth from the bottom, up
to one another upon Stages, till the uppermost threw it quite over the Top, so that at last they brought it within half a Musquet Shot of the Town, and the height so great, that it overlook'd the highest part of the Wall, and all the Bastions, to the great astonishment of the Besieg'd.

DURING all this time, the Batteries for Mor∣tars, which were so effectually cover'd from the shot of the Ramparts, play'd so incessantly upon the Town, throwing Bombs Night and Day; that the whole Town was reduc'd to Ashes, and the Garrison continually Harrass'd with the fury of the Bombs, no Place being secure for them; nor could they appear upon their Works, but they were immediately knock'd down with small shot from the Top of the rowling Trench, which over∣look'd them like a big Mountain, commanding the Town!: While this was doing from the Land∣side, the Czar, who took upon himself, the Di∣rection of the naval Part in particular, brought his Gallies down by a different Channel of the River Don, which as it was out of the reach of the Cannon of the Town; so there was so little depth of Water in that part of the River, that no Ves∣sel of bulk were ever known to pass that Way before, except in Cases of great Freshes, or Land Floods, which were all now over and gone.

THUS the Czar appear'd with a Fleet of Gal∣lies below the Town, to the astonishment of the Besieged, who believ'd it impossible they should pass any way, but in the Mouth of their Guns, which would have been altogether impracticable, there being above 150 Pieces of Cannon mounted to defend the Passage.

BESIDES this, his Czarish Majesty caused se∣veral Batteries of Cannon to be Planted on the other side of the River Donn, on a small Island, which is very properly Situated to prevent Suc∣cours from coming to Relieve the Place; and behind this Island he placed all his Arm'd Sha∣loups and Brigantines, as in an Ambuscade, to be ready to show themselves as occasion shou'd present.

IN this posture, both the Besiegers and the Be∣sieged expected the Turkish Fleet, which at length appear'd, bringing Succours for the Garrison; the Fleet consisted of 12 large Gallies, 30 arm'd Brigantines, and about 60 Transport Vessels, ha∣ving on Board 8000 Soldiers to Reinforce the Garrison, a vast Quantity of Ammunition of all sorts, Stores of Provision, and Cloths for the Garrison, and 50000 Ducates in Money for the pay and Encouragement of the brave Fellows, who had so well behav'd themselves as above.

IT was about the 24th of July, that they ap∣pear'd in the Palus Meotis, standing in among the Islands in the Mouth of the Donn, so to enter the Place; the first thing they had to Encounter, was the Czar's Gallies, who drawing less Water than the Great Gallies of the Turks lay farther up the River, where the other could not come.

IN the mean time the Turkish Saicks and Bri∣gantines to shun those Gallies, kept among the said Islands in shoal Water, which the Czar per∣ceiving, he took a sufficient Number of Troops into his Shalloups and Brigantines, and resolv'd to Attack them where they lay, which they did with such Bravery and Success, himself ap∣pearing in Person in the hottest of the Action, that the Turks were entirely Defeated and Di∣spers'd, and the whole Convoy of Provisions,
Ammunition, &c. taken even sight of the Gar∣rison, not one Vessel being able to reach the Town.

THIS Overthrow of the Turkish Fleet, with the Succours was follow'd with the Surrender of the Town; the Garrison Capitulating the 28th of Ju∣ly, the Czar granting them very honourable Con∣ditions, in Consideration of that Bravery they had shewn in Defence of the Place: It was said, that when they Surrendred, there was not above 1300 whole Men left of them, who were upwards of 12000 at the beginning of the Siege.

THIS glorious Victory of the Czar's surpris'd all Europe, and fill'd every Bodies Mouth with the Per∣sonal Fame of his Cazrish Majesty's Valour and Con∣duct, which was the more talk'd of, because it had not been often, that the World had heard of the Musco∣vites good Conduct, much less of a Warlike Emperor at their Head: On this Account and that I may be sure to leave a full Account of this great Action, I shall give it in the very Words, in which it was publish'd to the World in the several Countries, from whence we had then an Account of it; For Example; one Account, and back'd with good Authority, which came by the way of France, is as follows.

HIS Czarish Majesty having before-hand re∣ceiv'd Intelligence of the approach of this Suc∣cour, had caus'd seven of his largest Gallies of a hundred Foot in Length each, besides several lesser, and a great Number of Brigantines to pass into that small Branch of the Don, which issues forth a little above the Town. As the Water is very Shallow in this Channel, so it was not without a great deal of difficulty, that the largest Gallies could be brought along that Way, and would in all likelihood not have succeeded, if the Czar by his
Presence and Encouragement, had not animated the Workmen to surpass all the Difficulties, which at last they did, to the no small Astonishment of the Besieged.

THIS Obstacle being happily surmounted, his Czarish Majesty judg'd it of very great Consequence, for his purpose to plant good Store of Cannon up∣on the little Island we have mention'd before, because the Shoar being very Low, the Cannon-ball would strike even with the Surface of the Water; besides that the greatest part of the Isle being cover'd with Wood, did prevent the Enemy from discovering the Design.

THE same favourable Disposition of this Island, furnish'd the Muscovites, with an opportunity of putting some of their lightest Gallies and Brigan∣tines for a Reserve behind the Isle unperceiv'd by the Enemy, whom they intended thus to attack both in the Front and Flank as they passed by that Way, which succeeded according to Expectation.

FOR all these Precautions having been made before, when the Enemies Fleet came in sight, the biggest Muscovite Gallies, with many Brigantines were sent out to meet them, making a show as if they intended to Engage the Turkish Fleet; but no sooner were they come within Cannon-Shot of one another, but the Muscovites eigning to dread the Ottoman Fleet, as superiour to them in Num∣ber, made a running Fight, making the best of their way towards the Shoar, and posting them∣selves below the Island: The Turks perceiving the Enemy to fly before them, and not in the least fore∣warn'd of that Plot laid behind the Island, thought themselves, by the small Number of the Musco∣vite
Gallies that appear'd in Sight, assur'd of the Victory.

FLUSH'D with these Hopes, they made all the Sail they could to fall in among the Musco∣vites, but no sooner were they come within reach of the Cannon from the Isle, but they receiv'd such a warm salute from thence, that they saw their Gallies torn to pieces on all sides, by the Enemies Cannon in an Instant, with a great Slaughter of many of their Men; but this was only the Fore∣runner of what was to ensue.

FOR his Czarish Majesty, who had a watchful Eye on all Sides, and who was sometimes upon the Isle, sometimes on Board the Fleet of Reserve that lay behind; having soon observed the Con∣sternation the Turks were put in by this unexpect∣ed Salute, and willing to improve their Confusi∣on to his Advantage, got on Board in Person one of the lightest Gallies, Mann'd only with forty Men, giving the Signal for the rest to follow him, with all the Oars they could. Thus the Enemy found themselves surrounded on all Sides by the Muscovites, who Attack'd them with great Brave∣ry; the Czar himself Boarding the Turkish Admi∣ral, and being successfully Seconded by the rest, the Victory was almost as soon compleated, as be∣gan. The Turks being Routed so entirely, that not one Galley escap'd, but what was either Sunk or taken; and it must be confess'd, that the Czar shew'd so much Conduct during the whole Action, that no more could have been expected, from the Prudence and Valour of the greatest Captain of our Time.
ANOTHER Account of this Affair expresses it self in these Words.

AT length it is agreed on all Hands, that the City of Asoph, which the Turks and Tartars had in vain attempted to Relieve; both by Sea and Land was Surrender'd to the Muscovites, upon Articles the 28th, of July; in pursuance of which, the Gar∣rison consisting of three Thousand Men, besides Tartars, March'd out with their Arms and Bag∣gage; 300 pieces of Cannon were found in the Town, together with a great quantity of Ammu∣nition: But want of Provision hasten'd the Sur∣render of the Town; this Town was formerly call'd Tanais, as being Seated upon the River Ta∣nais, now call'd Don, the ancient Bounds of Asia and Europe to the North-East: It is a Town of great Trade, especially in Furrs, lying not above 15 Miles from the Mouth of the River, upon the consines of Muscovy; but that which makes it more Considerable is, that it affords the Musco∣vites and Cossacks a fair Opportunity to become Masters of the Euxinus or Black-Sea, and gives an Entrance to the Victor, to penetrate as far as Constantinople itself, for which Reason, it has been more than once Contested for by the Turks, and Muscovites.

THE News of this Loss was known at Constan∣tinople, upon the 7th, of August, which put the City into a great Consternation, for fear of losing those Supplies of Provisions that come to that City by the Black-Sea. They tell us also, of a Victory obtained over the Turks and Tartars, by the Mus∣covites near Precoop; which Successes as they re∣vive the Reputation of the Muscovite Arms, and render formidable an Enemy; that for several Years has hardly been thought worth taking No∣tice of; so the Confequences of their Prosperity,
may chance to prove more Fatal, then was at first expected to the Ottomen Empire.

THE Muscovites have lain untalk'd of a great Time, and the Turk has look'd upon them, as a de∣spicable Enemy for many Years: But 'tis scarce to be imagin'd how soon the change of the Monarch's Genius, alters the Manners and Conditions of a Nation; the Warmth and Vigour of Martial Princes, infuse the same warlike Motions into the Breasts of the People, as the voluptuousness of a dispirited Sovereign effeminates them, and o∣verwhelms them in Sloath and Cowardice. The Muscovites are now another sort of People; they have a Valiant, and politick Leader, under whose Conduct they have wrested one of the chief Barri∣ers of the Ottoman Empire, from the Turks, who were Vanquish'd first by Sea, and then by Land: Encouraged thus by Prosperity, what may not the Muscovites do? they want neither Numbers or Strength of Bodies; and there are few Princes that can resist the Temptations of Success, so that it is high time for the Sultan to call to his re∣membrance, how often these Northern Deluges, have proved Fatal to the Empires of the South.

THESE accounts shew the Sentiments of the rest of Europe, concerning the Czar of Muscovy, and his Affairs at that Time; and the Advantage which the Czar was represented with to the rest of the Princes of that Age. The Turks in particular, were under a just Consternation, and indeed, they had Reason, when they came to understand that the Czar had Built Men of War at Veranowitz, which carried 700r 80 Guns each, and which would in Time, be able to Cope with the best Ships the Port was able to fit out. This gave them a just Allarm, even at Constantinople itself, which City
would be but ill able to Subsist, should the Free∣dom and Commerce of the Black-Sea be taken from them, or even Disputed with them; and there∣fore the Turks are not to be blam'd at all, for the great Conditions which they Granted the Czar of Muscovy afterwards, when they had him as it were in their Power, for the Recovery of this impor∣tant Place out of his Hands.

WHEN the Czar had made this Conquest, he was far from contenting himself with letting it remain in the Condition he found it in; but know∣ing of what Consequence it was to the Turks, as well as now to himself, he immediately order'd it to be Strengthned with new Fortifications, and that of such a Kind, as render'd it the most impreg∣nable Place in those Parts of the World; he not only repair'd the old Works, and added two new Bastions to the Body of the Place, but he caused a new Counterscarp, with a cover'd Way to be drawn round the whole, and the Ditch to be Se∣cur'd with half Moons, Lunettes, Tenailles, and all such necessary Out-works, as might render it Inaccessible; bringing the River Donne so into the Ditches, as that it might be said, not that the Ri∣ver supply'd the Ditches with Water, but rather, that the River ran round the Town.

ON the other hand, in the low marshy Grounds on the South-Side of the River, which the River u∣sually over-flow'd, and which was a meer Bog, his Czarish Majesty caused first, a firm solid Founda∣tion to be made with Timber, Stones, Gravel, and the like Materials; and having rais'd the whole Surface to a considerable height, above the usual Flux of the Water: He Built a Royal Fort upon it, containing six Bastions, with their Cavaliers Courtins, and Counterguards, with some Out-Works
where it was needful; joyning the whole afterwards to the main Land, with a prodigious Stone-Bridge of thirty Arches, reaching over the whole Morass.

THUS he made the Place truely Impregnable, there being no Attacking the said Fort by any of the usual Methods of Approach, the whole Ground round it being to be laid under Water by Sluices appointed for that purpose, when ever the Garri∣son found it convenient.

IN this posture the Czar left Asoph, at the lat∣ter end of the next Year (viz.) 1697, and the Turks had as littles hopes of over Recovering it again, as any Prince could desire; he also left it well stor'd with all manner of military Provisions, having above 400 pieces of Cannon mounted up∣on the Works, and Ammunition in proportion; and left in it besides, a Garrison of 15000 Men.

AND now it was, that his Czarish Majesty re∣solv'd to furnish himself with a Royal Navy, not of Gallies and Brigantines, Saiks and Armed Barks, such as was the usual Vessels for those Seas: But of capital Men of War, of 60 to 80 Guns each, the Magazine and Center of which, and of the Stores belonging to them, should be always laid up at Asoph, and the Ships themselves be pre∣serv'd in the River Donn at proper Places, of which I shall give a farther Account; waiting till a convenient Port might be possess'd in the Black-Sea, where they might be laid up and Secur'd.

WITH these vast Thoughts, the Czar left the Place, and ceased not after he was gone, to go immediately forward with the Execution of it; and here may be said to be laid one of the first Foundations of that Resolution this Prince took to go Abroad; not only to furnish himself with
Skill in all the mechanick Parts of Know∣ledge, necessary in carrying on such Undertakings; but likewise to furnish himself with able Instru∣ments, Men of Knowledge and Capacity for such Things, that might not only do the Work for him as Occasion requir'd, but Instruct also his own People to do it after them.

AT his Czarish Majesty's return from this Con∣quest, he took a Resolution to make a publick triumphal Entry into his capital City of Muscow, and that with all-the Pomp and Splendor that was possible to be Devised; but it is worth observing, that this was not founded upon the Vanity of Temper, which Princes have often been subject to upon such Occasions; but from the true Roman Principle of provoking Emulation in Vertuous Actions among his Nobility, and for acquainting his People with the Value and Importance of the Victory he had obtained.

IN this triumphal Entry it was observ'd, that there was one of his Officers whose Name was Ja∣cob, had in the first Siege of Asoph, not only De∣serted to the Enemy, but Nail'd up some of the Czar's Cannon, and thereby encourag'd the Garrison to make a desperate Sally on that Side, in which they ruin'd the Works, and so Discourag'd the Muscovite Soldiers, as was one great Reason of raising the Siege: This Jacob was at the second Siege surrender'd by the Turks, the Czar having refused to Grant any Terms to the Garrison, un∣less he had this Traytor deliver'd up to him.

THIS Wretch made Part of the Triumph of the Czar; he was carried Naked and Chain'd on a Stage in an open Waggon, with a Gibbet over his Head; on which, after he had been three times Tortur'd, he was publickly Hang'd for the Terror
of Traytors; some said he was broken first alive, which however, I do not affirm.

AT this Triumph of the Czar, there was an o∣pen Court, and all the Boyars or Noblemen of Russia, were admitted to come and Kiss the Czar's Hand, and pay their Complements on the Occa∣sion, which was a Favour they were not admitted to formerly, but as the Czar resolv'd to acquaint his People with the Customs and usuage of other Countries, so he began already to make the open free Conversation of the French, and British Na∣tions Familiar to them.

AFTER this, the Czar call'd them all to an Assembly, where he open'd and explain'd to 'em, the Nature and Advantages of his Conquests on the Black-Sea; and how he intended to improve it to the welfare of his own Dominions, in se∣curing the Navigation of the said Black Sea to them, by a powerful Navy, and perhaps to obtain a Commerce even thro' the narrow Chanels, at Canstantinople into the Levant.

To this purpose, it was easie to convince them of the Necessity of building a good Fleet of ca∣pital Men of War, such as should be always a Match for the Grand Seignior's Fleet, and should maintain the Commerce if need were by strong Hand: And at the end of this Discourse, he ac∣quainted some of them, that he resolv'd to Tra∣vel in Person to some of the Maritime Courts of Europe, to make himself compleat Master of the Measures of those Nations, who were so Superior to the rest of the World by their naval Strength; and withal, to bring back with him the best Ar∣tists that could be found; not only to undertake the Building part for his first Fleet, and for the present Occasion, which admitted no delay; but
also to instruct his own People in all the necessa∣ry Arts, Handicrafts, and Workmanship which might be wanting; that so in time none but his own Subjects might be employ'd, and they might be capable, in time to come, to make Muscovy the Terror of all its Enemies. That they had the Materials for building and equipping the greatest Ships in the World, and in such Plenty, that all the Marine Powers of Europe were oblig'd to seek to them for their Naval Stores; and it was an un∣accountable Indolence and Neglect, that they alone should be ignorant of the building of Ships, and of the Sea Service of every kind, who were furnished by Nature and Providence with the principal Funds of all Naval Provisions: That they had Timber for the Hulls and Masts of Ships enough to supply all the World; Hemp and Flax for Cordage, Cables and Rigging; Iron for Anchors, Bolts, Spikes, Nails and Tools; Pitch and Tar for Caulking, Graving, Paying, and for working and preserving the Cordage and Rigging; that all the Nations of Europe were supplyed with those things from Muscovy, and it was very hard that Muscovy alone should not know how to use and apply all these for themselves, but that they should buy and hire Ships of other Nations, and even of those who first fetch'd the materials from Muscovy by which those Ships were made.

THIS was a Discourse too rational not to con∣quer the Judgment of any reasonable Creature, who was not before posseds'd with an invincible Prejudice. But how far it fail'd to answer his Expectation, as to the Impressions it made on the Minds of his People, we shall have frequent occa∣sion to see.

BUT Muscovy is not the only Nation in the World that are to be made Great, Rich, and Happy against their Wills; and in spight of the most o stinate endeavours to ruin themselves; there have been Nations infatuated before them, tho' I think scarce ever in so gross a manner.

FOR instead of receiving just Notions of the Wisdom of such Councils, of the Opportunity that presented to raise the Glory and Reputation of their Country, and to lay a Foundation of Wealth and Opulence for their Posterity, they made this very Discourse a Foundation of Faction, and even of Rebellion and Treason; forming a Conspiracy against not the Government only of the Czar, but against his Life also, and giving those very De∣signs of his for the advantage of his Country, as Reasons for their conspiring his Destruction.

AND that which was stranger stil than all this, was, that in forming these Factions, and o∣menting the Treason I speak of, they brought in the Clergy to insinuate to the People, that it was contrary to the Principles of the Greek Church to oblige the People to converse with Foreigners, and much more to bring Foreigners in among them on any pretence whatever; pretending that they would poison the People with Erroneous Doctrines, and Heretical Opinions, and that it was Dangerous to their Religion; and the like.

IT is to no purpose to exclaim here against the Absurdity of these Things, it is sufficient to my History to relate the Fact as it lies before us, which I shall do in its order as distinctly as possible.

THE Triumph of the Day being over, and the Traytor Jacob executed as above, the Czar ap∣plyed himself with his usual Resolutions and Vi∣gor,
in persuit of what he had proposed to himself as above: First, he ordered the building such Men of War as he had immediate occasion for, and to this purpose tax'd his principal Noblemen with such proportions towards the Expence, as he thought fit, and as by the Custom of that abso∣lute Government he might legally do; allowing them however this alternative, that if any particu∣lar Nobleman did not think fit to advance such sums of Money, and such numbers of Workmen as he was Tax'd at, he might take upon himself the Work, and build such Ship or Ships, or such part of a Ship, or furnish such quantity of Mate∣rials as were equivalent to the proportion of Mo∣he was assessed at.

BESIDES this, his Czarish Majesty obliged such particular degrees of his Boyars and Gentlemen as he thought proper, to send abroad their Sons into Foreign Countries, to study and to improve them∣selves in such arts, as were necessary to qualify them for publick Employments; particularly Ma∣thematicks, Navigation, Engineering, and the like; whose Expence however, the Czar ordered to be supplyed out of the publick Treasury.

WHILE the Czar was thus busied in laying a Foundation of Glory and Greatness for his Sub∣jects, Hard lot of Princes! his Subjects resisting their own Advantages, were Conspiring against his Life, and in a word form'd the most horrid Treason against their Sovereign, and for the cut∣ting off all that were faithful to him, and to the Interest of their Country, that has been heard of in any Age.

It is true the History, if the few and loose ac∣counts that are to be found of this affair deserve the Name of History, of these things, lay the main
part of this Treason upon the Princess Sophia his Czarish Majesty's Sister: But as this turbulent La∣dy was a close Prisoner on account of former Con∣spiracies, and that it was not easie for her to cor∣respond or to carry on any Conspiracy with Peo∣ple without Doors, without, giving ground of suspicion; So tho' she might be made acquainted with the Plot, yet none of the Conspirators, tho' put to the extrenest Torture, ever charg'd that Princess with being the Author of it.

THE first of this Plot as I find it either in the publick Accounts, or from private Intelligence, was founded in the Discontents of the Nobily, at being rated, or tax'd for the building of Ships of War for the Black Sea, after the manner as above: All the other Pretences were brought in as an accumulated Charge upon the Czar, for im∣posing Novelties upon them, such as the send∣ing their Sons abroad to Travel, a thing always not only avoided, but even forbid in Muscovy, and reckon'd or esteem'd to be unlawful; nay, even the very building of Ships was counted Exo∣tic and Absurd, and was rendred as a wicked De∣sign to push at foreign Conquest, and bringing War upon the Country.

THE better and more effectually to embark the Soldiery in the Quarrel, the Strelitzes, that is to say, the standing Forces of the Empire, such as were the Mamalucks in Egypt, the Pretorian Bands in the Roman Empire, and the Janiza∣ries in Turky, were put in mind how hardly they had been treated; how their number was conti∣nually lessen'd by the Executions among them in the former Tumult at the Czar's coming to the Ad∣ministration; how their number was not made up, or their Companys recruited, but as they were put
upon the hardest Services on all occasions, so their Companies being not fill'd up, it was apparent the Czar had a mind to wear them out by De∣grees; that the present Czar had no Affection for them, and had vowed their Destruction; and that his Czarish Majesty had frequently declared he would suppress the very Name of them as a Body; all which, in fact, might be true; for the Czar not only had no occasion for them, but resolved, in time, to sink the Name of them out of the Army.

NOW, much of this might be true (viz.) that the Czar having had terrible experience of the mu∣tinous Temper of the Strelitz, and how they often took upon them to act in a bloody and furious manner; insulting the Government, and even their Prince, pretending to set up or depose who∣ever they pleased, had secretly resolv'd to let them wear gradually out, and by warm Service and hard Duty, to wear away as fast as they could, without suffering them to be fill'd up or recruited, and he had abundant reason to resolve to do so.

THESE Men were therefore the more easie to be brought into any desperate Measures, to pre∣vent the annihilation of their Order, and to keep up the figure they had always made in the Go∣vernment; and as their pretences of Disgust were very plausible and popular, so they were the more easy to be brought into the Design. But still I must leave the dead weight of this Conspiracy up∣on those People, who, as I said before, were pinch'd by the new Order for sending their Chil∣dren abroad, and upon the Boyars who were a∣warded to build Ships of War at their own charge, they and their Vassals as above

THESE Men provok'd at the Severity of the Czar's usage of them, as they call'd it, were be∣ginners of the Treason, but they did not find it so hard as it might have been expected, to engage others in it for the Reasons above-mentioned.

THE building of these Ships, which had not been done in Russia before, and at the same time obliging the Boyars and Gentlemen to send their Sons abroad to Travel, were both look'd upon as a great Grievance, the one being not only to entail a Charge upon them beyond the common Tax, but of bringing in of Foreigners to build and sail their Ships; and the latter, (viz.) the sending abroad their Children, was such an innovation they could not well bear; Besides this, it was insinuated by the Priests, that it would be a means of cor∣rupting them in the Principles of their Religion, and which they held to be a thing that was direct∣ly contrary to the Law of God; adhering to those Texts of Scripture which forbid the Children of Israel to have any Communion with the Nations that were round about them, that they might not partake of their Idolatry; for which Reason even the Envoys which have been sent heretofore to fo∣reign Courts, have been denied to take their Sons with them; and upon pain of Death it was forbid that any Muscovite should go out of the Country without especial leave from the Patriarch; but they now murmured that the Czar wholly adhered to Strangers, went himself daily to their Houses, and freely admitted them to his Conversation, which stirred up the discontents of the Party that were out of favour at Court, and who had been made uneasy at their disappointment since the last Rebellion; who were still in the Interest of the Princess Sophia, and wanted to be themselves
at the head of the Government, they therefore take this opportunity in hopes to give a turn to Affairs, and that they might effectually bring about their Purpose.
BUT to come to the matter of fact, the Con∣spiracy being laid deep as Hell, and cruel as Death, is describ'd by one of the Writers of that time in the following words:

“NOTWITHSTANDING that the whole Empire seemed to take share in the glorious Conquests of their Prince, and that nothing but Feasting and Rejoicing were to be seen in all parts during the whole Winter, there remained nevertheless a certain discontented Party among the Nobility, who being encouraged by the se∣cret Cabals of the Princess Sophia, found means, in spight of her confinement, to keep an under∣hand Correspondence with her for the promo∣ting their designs against the Czar's Person; they were so well prepared for the undertaking of any Enterprize of this nature, that there wanted but little Fuel to kindle the Flame, they could not brook the loss of their beloved Strelitzes, whom they had always looked upon as the chief Supporters of their Authority, which at last made them conceive so implacable a hatred against the Czar, that they entred in∣to a Conspiracy against his Life; to put their Design in execution, they had brought over to their Party four Captains of the first Regiment of Strelitzers; but the difficulty was, in what manner the Attempt was to be made, for they looked upon it as impracticable to declare open∣ly against a Prince, who, besides that he was much beloved by the People, had at his Devo∣tion a good number of the best Troops, com∣manded
by foreign Officers, who were quarter∣ed in and about the City of Muscow, and ready upon all Occasions to Sacrifice their Lives for his Majesty; it was proposed among them, that the Czar was used to go sometimes abroad with very slender Attendance, and to appear in the Streets of Muscow without any considerable Re∣tinue; this was also look'd upon as too dange∣rous, considering the general Love the People bore to the Person of the Czar.”

“AFTER many Debates it was at last resolved, that considering the Czar, who takes share in every thing that concerns his Subjects Welfare, was wont to appear in Person, in case of any accident of Fire, which frequently happens, and makes most terrible havock in the City of Muscow, where most of the Houses are of Wood; they looked upon this as the most proper op∣portunity to encompass their Design; where∣fore it was concluded to set Fire to some Houses in the night time, when they did not question to draw the Czar thither, and during the con∣fusion, to find means to Assassinate him. The next thing to be done was, according to their own Confession, to have joined the Donaick Cos∣sacks with their Party, to have released the Princess Sophia from her Confinement, recalled Prince assily Galickzin out of Siberia, and surren∣dred the Administration of the Government in∣to their hands, who were also to restore the Stre∣litzes to their antient Station.”

THIS was the Substance of the Plot, and to car∣ry it on more effectually, four Captains of the Stre∣lizes, or Troops of the Houshold were brought into it, besides several great Men as well in the Court as in the Army.

THE Attempt was now ripe for Execution, and a great number of the Strelitzes were come pri∣vately into the Town to assist at the horrid work of murthering their Sovereign, and perhaps at that of destroying the whole City; for any one that knows the City of Muscow, how that not on∣ly the Houses, but even the Pavement, as we call it of the Streets, are all of Wood; and what ha∣vock a Fire often makes among them, may easily suppose, that the City being wilfully fired in three places, and the People being put into such a Fright and Confusion, as would have been the case at the murther of their Emperor, and of such bloody and cruel Executions, or rather Butcheries, as would necessarily have follow'd such a thing, the necessary care for extinguishing the Fire would be omitted in a great measure, and perhaps the greater part of the City had been destroy'd, which is horrible but to think of.

THE Day appointed for the Execution was the 20th of Feb. 1697, when the Evening before two of the Captains of the Strelitzers, namely, Cap∣tain Largou Gilisaroski and Captain Greg Siteri, went and discovered the whole Plot to the Czar, who was then at Supper at Monsieur le Fort's, a French Gentleman, of whom mention is often made in this Relation. The account of the Dis∣covery, with the Name and Fate of the Conspi∣rators, take in a few words from another Pen as follows.

“It was on the first Day of February in the Year 1697, when his Majesty was informed concerning this Conspiracy formed against his Life, at the House of General le Fort, were he happened to dine that Day; he appeared very little moved at so surprising a piece of News;
but without any change in his Countenance, arose from the Table, and being followed only by a few Persons in whom he confided most, he went di∣rectly to the House of one of the Conspirators, whose Name was John Sickler, and elevated by the Czar to the chief Dignity of a Counsellor of State. When his Majesty came to the House of this wicked Wretch, he commanded the rest to remain without Doors, and he himself entred, only with three Gentlemen more, and pretending he had occasion to ask his advice in some matter of moment, ordered he should follow him; but no sooner was he come into the Street but he was seized and immediately carried to Prison, as were likewise five more, to wit, the Boyar Alexis Sekonnin, Feodore Puskin, Son of the Boyar, Matfefeoa Puskin, Ten Captains of the Strelitzes, and a Donaick Cossack; they all confessed their Crimes, and being condemned by all the Boyars, were executed on the fifth Day of March in the Year 1697, in the great Market-place before the Castle. First their Arms and Legs were cut off, then they had their Heads severed from their Bodies; their Heads were fixed on the top of a Stone Column erected for that purpose, and their Arms and Legs stuck upon Iron Bars round about it; the Trunks of their dead Car∣casses were left in the Market-place for eight Days after, till the scent became so nauseous to the Inhabitants, that they were forced to be re∣moved from thence.”

“IT having by confession of some of the Con∣spirators been made apparent, that the Boyar Ivan Miloslaski was the chief Head of the Rebel∣lion which happened in the Year 1682, immediately after his present Czarish Majesty's Ac∣cession
to the Crown, his Body was disinterred, which being found very near entire, without any considerable decay, tho' it had lain under ground near twelve Years; several Gibbets were erected, on which were hung the Quarters of the Carcass, which were torn to pieces in an instance by the enraged Multitude.”

THE Severity of the Executions in this Case are excused by their being at Muscovy, where Ex∣perience has taught them, that such Executions are needful; and where if such a severe course had not been taken, it might have been hard to per∣swade the People to believe that the Conspiracy had been real, or the Government in earnest.

WHEN his Czarish Majesty had master'd these Commotions, and all things were calm again, the Czar who was now so resolv'd upon his Design, as that nothing could divert him, I mean as to his Travelling Abroad, began to prepare publickly for his going, and to let the seditious Boyars know that he was not under the least Apprehensi∣ons from any thing they were able to do in his absence, he made it publick also, in whose Hands he resolved to entrust the Government in his ab∣sence: He appointed a good Army to Encamp within a League of the City of Muscow, of whom a strong Detatchment were to do Duty daily at the Palace; and among all these Troops which amounted to 22000 Men, it was especially pro∣vided, that none of the Strelitzers were allow'd, intimating, that the Czar who had resolv'd to sup∣press effectually that body of Men, did not think them worthy to be entrusted with the protection of that Government which they had so often at∣tempted to disturb.

WHILE this was doing, Expresses came fre∣quently in from Asoph, and from General Skeen who commanded the Army there, with News of Advantages gain'd every Day over the Tartars and Rebel Cosacks, of whom great numbers were often cut off; and that General, who is a vigilant Officer, daily extended his Quarters in the Crim Tar∣tary, ravaging the Country and bringing in a great Booty: So that all things went on that side to his mind; and as the Turks had their Hands full in Hungary with the Imperialists, who had beaten them in several great Battels, and continued their Conquests till even Constantinople it self began to tremble at them, they were in no condition to do any thing towards the recovery of Asoph; so that the Czar's Affairs were in a most Formidable Posture on that side.

THE Preparations for the intended Progress of the Czar were now finished; and tho' I cannot say I have a full account of them, neither perhaps was any full account ever published; yet, as I believe, the following Particulars are rather short of, than an over reckoning of the vast Treasure and Expence furnished on this Occasion, I shall transmit it as I find it, leaving the Reader to judge of the Reasonableness and Truth of the Relation by the Particulars they will meet with in the account of the Journey.

IT was for some time unresolv'd in what Ca∣pacity his Czarish Majesty should Travel, and se∣veral Propositions were considered of, as particu∣larly first, that he should go as a private Gentle∣man, and with a small Retinue, which was the first Proposal. (2.) As a Clergy-man of the Greek Church, as had been practised by some of his boyars the Year before. (3.) As an Armenian
Merchant, under which Disguise several Persians and Turks had travelled into Europe; for as to go∣ing publickly, and owning himself to be what he really was, Czar or Emperor of Muscovy, that the Czar himself had resolved against for many sub∣stantial Reasons; as, (1.) The Expence of it. (2.) The losing the opportunity of inspecting per∣sonally into things, which he had with great Rea∣son seen could not be done but in a private Capa∣city. And (3.) Because the whole time would be taken up in Shows and Ceremonies, things below the important Design of the Journey, and utterly inconsistent with it. At length Monsieur le Fort proposed what the Czar immediately approved, a method which as he said would consist both with the Honour and Safety of his Majesty's Person, and yet give him all the opportunity of a Con∣cealment that he could desire, and this was, that a solemn Embassy should be sent from his Majesty to all the Courts to which he had intended to go, with a Compliment of Honour, and Proposals of Amity and Commerce; and Ambassadors to be vested with full Plenipotentiary Powers to enter into Treaties of Alliance and Treaties of Com∣merce with the said Nations respectively; and that his Majesty should Travel Incognito in the Retinue of his said Ambassadors, and under the Protection of the Embassy it self, by which means it would at the same time be known that he was personally present, and thereby his Embassy would be receiv'd with the greater Distinction; and yet as he would be at liberty to receive all possible Ceremony and Honour where he thought fit to accept it, so he would be at liberty to de∣cline it also, as he found occasion.

THIS hit his Czarish Majesty's Thoughts imme∣diately, and was so perfectly agreeable to his whole Design, which was to make himself Master of all the Methods of the Nations he intended to pass thro,' in the management of their Military and Naval Affairs; and particularly of all Ma∣thematical and Mechanical Knowledge, which he presently foresaw he should by this Method be fully able to do.
THIS being therefore resolv'd on, several things remain'd to be done, and were to be fully concerted before-hand.
1. WHO should be the Ambassadors appointed for this Honourable Post.
2. WHO the Government should be committed to in the Czar's absence. what Power should be committed to them in the Administration, and what Forces should be left them.
5. WHAT Nations the Ambassadors should go to, and the Form of their Powers.

4. THE raising a sufficient Sum of Money for the Expences of such an Embassy, and for the ex∣traordinary Service abroad, namely, of purchasing things proper to be brought away, and what Sum would be wanting.

5. PROVIDING such Jewels and Cloths, Li∣veries and Habits as the Ambassadors and their Servants should have occasion to appear in on the occasion of Publick Entries, Audiences, &c. or for presents to carry with them.
6. THE determining who should be appointed to Travel with or after the Embassy.
THE resolving these Particulars took up some time, several of them being of very great Conse∣quence, and we find they were adjusted with a great deal of Prudence and Caution.

THE Choice of the Persons of the Ambassadors fell upon these three; First, General le Fort Captain of the Guards, and at that time Ad∣miral of the Fleet, who, as he was a Frenchman born, had liv'd many Years at Amsterdam, and some time in Italy, so he in the first place was fully acquainted with all the Customs and Man∣ners of those Countries, and capable of advising in the particular Measures to be observ'd in each Country; and of the Ceremonial; as well what Respect was to be shewn, as what was to be ex∣pected where-ever they came; and in the next place, as he knew the Language, so he serv'd the Czar as an Interpreter upon the most important Occasions. The next was Theodore Alexiamvitz Golloffkin, a Grave Majestick Person, and fully ac∣quainted with the Interest and Trade, as well as the Laws and Customs of Muscovy, and how to carry on any Treaty of Commerce, or receive Proposals for the Advantage and Interest of Trade; having been Chancellor of the whole Empire, and the same who formerly made the Treaty of Peace between his Czarish Majesty and the Emperor of China, of which we shall speak in its place, and who had been twice by Land at China in the Qua∣lity of Ambassador and Plenipotentiary to the Emperor there. The third was call'd, Proco∣et Bodgnanovitz Woluitzin, who had been employ'd in several Embassies to the Grand Seignior, and was perfectly acquainted with his Master's Inter∣ests, with respect to the Turks, the settling Limits, the Affair of Asoph, and in any thing else that might happen on that side, especially if at Vienna any Proposals of an Accommodation should be made to the Emperor and his Allies.

THESE were the three Ambassadors to whom the whole Affair was committed; nor were there three Men equally capable to so great a Work in his whole Dominion; and as his Czarish Majesty was always with them, there was no occasion of any delay, or spinning out the Negotiations, as is usual in other cases.

THE General le Fort was made first Plenipo∣tentiary, and consequently was at the Head of this Embassy, being partly qualifyed by his Know∣ledge in the Languages and Customs of Europe as above, to appear at the head of all the Negotia∣tions.

THE second Article (viz.) who the Admini∣stration of the Government should be committed to in the Czar's absence, was soon resolv'd by the Czar himself, who pitch'd upon the Princes Na∣riskin, Procorofski, and Boris Galitzen, all faith∣ful Servants of the Crown, and steady in the Per∣sonal Interest of the Czar; the first being the Czar's Mother's own Brother and prime Minister; the second the Grand Receiver, or Lord Treasurer, an ancient faithful Prince, always steady to the Czar and to his whole Family; and the third a particular Favourite, possessing several high Trusts in the Government, and vastly rich also himself.

THE Military Trust was committed to Gene∣ral Skeen or Scherin, who was made Generalissimo for all that concern'd the War against the Turks and Tartars on the Borders of the Black-Sea, and on the side of Circassia; and to General Gordon, a Scots Man, for what concern'd the Guard of the Palace and Capital City of Muscow, and all the Northern Parts of the Czar's Dominions: The former had under his Command the whole Army
at and in the Neighbourhood of Asoph, or from Astracan to Kaiserkameen on the Boristhenes; and the other had the Command of the rest of the Troops, as well at Muscow as aforesaid, as on the Frontiers of Poland and of Sweden, Courland, &c. and had in particular the Charge given him of Protecting the Administration in the hands of the three Princes above-mentioned.

3. THE third Article was to consider what Na∣tions or Courts this Embassy should be directed to, and this was soon determined; the Rout or Cavalcade being ordered to pass forward thus; First to Prussia and the Court of Berlin. II. To Holland. III. To England. IV. To Vienna to the Emperor. And Lastly, to Venice: These being the Capital places where Military and Naval Knowledge were now to be found in the greatest Perfection; except in France, which for weighty Reasons his Czarish Majesty resolv'd not to go to France, at that time, being engaged in a heavy War against almost all the other Princes of Eu∣rope.

4.
