THE next Head was the Funds for the Ex∣pence of this Journey: This the Czar took up∣on himself to direct; and I am assur'd that his Czarish Majesty set apart for this Work above two Millions of Rubles, which in English Money is near 800000 Pounds Sterling; but I do not positively affirm that so great a Sum was taken: Most of this Money, be the Sum what it will, was ex∣pended in buying Ships, materials for forwarding several Sciences for the publick use in Muscovy, as also for buying Arms, Artillery and Ammuniti∣on to be sent to Muscovy.

5. THE Povision for Presents to be made to such Princes, and States where they were to appear
in Ceremony, and for Audiences, for which purpose twenty large Bales of the richest Furs, such as Sables, Ermins, &c. were provided, and several Bales of rich Cloth of Gold made in Persia and Georgia; and several Parcels of very valuable Jewels, as also some fine Turkish and Tartarian Horses.

6. THE determining who should be appointed to Travel with the Czar; and this Article was ve∣ry Significant, as it intimated that the Czar took with him about Forty Persons of the Prime Rank in his Dominion, or their Sons; This was call'd an Honour done them, but was wisely determined to secure them from Plotting and Conspiring a∣gainst him during his absence: In the mean time such other Noblemen as were Distrusted, or out of Favour, were commanded to retire to their own Seats, and not to come to the City of Muscow, or to Court on pain of Death.

HAVING thus with an inimitable Conduct assur'd things at home to his full Satisfaction, and having taken of the Foreign Merchants in his Dominions Bills of Exchange upon Merchants in Holland and England for a great part of the Trea∣sure he had appointed for his Journey; and all things being ready to depart; the Baggage was sent before with a strong Guard, and having obtained proper Passes for the whole Embassy for Konings∣burgh, a City in the Ducal Prussia belonging to the King of Prussia, then Elector of Brandenburgh, his Majesty set out the second of May, or thereabouts, himself going Incognito at some distance from his Ambassadors and their Train, and the 10th of the same Month be entred the Province of Livonia, at that time belonging to the Swedes.

IT was said his Majesty receiv'd some ill Treat∣ment at Riga, that is to say, they declin'd satis∣fying his Curiosity in letting him view the Works and Forts in the manner he desir'd; and as it was the first Town compleatly fortified after the French manner, his Czarish Majesty was the more pressing to make his Observations, which they not admit∣ting, extremely disgusted him; but he has had op∣portunity to remember it since, to the Cost of the Swedes, from whom he took not that City only, but the whole Province in a few Years after, and remains possess'd of them to this Day; and 'tis observed that the Resentment of the Usage of his Ambassadors, for he does not take notice of his being in Person with them, is mentioned in his Declaration of War against Sweden, as one of the Causes of his breaking the Peace with them.

BUT he found himself treated after a quite different manner at the next Place of Note he came to, which was at Koningsberg the Capital of the Ducal Prussia as above: Hither the Duke of Brandenburgh, since King of Prussia, came with his whole Court to receive and entertain him; and here the Czar resolv'd to show the World the first Specimen of his Glory and Greatness. His Em∣bassy had hitherto a Retinue of Three Hundred persons, several little Troops of Guards arm'd, some with Bows, some with Battle Axes, and o∣thers with Lances; and abundance of the young Nobility, who afterwards were dispers'd to other parts, were at this first Entry.
THE manner of this glorious Entry, as it was publish'd and spread in Print in all the Languages of Europe, take as follows.

“THE Letters are dated from Koningsberg in Prussia May 31. N. S. That the Ambassadors
from the Czar of Muscovy, who are the Lords Francis Jacow Lewits Le Fort, Mexiewits Holo∣win, and Precophei Bodanowitz Wornitzien, being arriv'd upon the Thursday Morning before at Lauterburg, within a Mile of the City, with a train of Three Hundred Persons; the Elector of Brandenburgh immediately sent away M. Dankelmen to compliment the Am∣bassadors in his Name, and to keep them com∣pany After Dinner, Mr. Besser, the Master of the Ceremonies, arriv'd at the same place also, with a great company of Nobility to conduct them to the City, at what time their Excellen∣cies taking Coach with M. Dunkelmen, and M. Besser, in one of the Elector's Coaches, about four a Clock that Afternoon made their Publick Entry into Koningsberg in the following manner, First came his Electoral Highnesses Led Horses, to the number of Forty. Secondly, an Officer attended by the Kettle Drums of the Guards, and Three Troops of the Guards of the Body clad in Red; next the principal Nobility of Ducal Prussia in Twenty Six Coaches with Six Horses, then two of the Elector's Coaches, and One of the Margrave Albert's; after them the Court Pages Two and Two, with a Page of the Ambassadors between 'em in Red Liveries Lac'd with Gold Lace. Sixthly, the chief Ministers and Officers of the Elector's Houshold in Thirty Six Coaches. Seventhly, the first Kettle-Drum, and the first Trumpet belonging to his Electo∣ral Highness, follow'd by the Ambassador's Foot Guards clad in Green, with each a Silver Bat∣tle Axe upon his Shoulder; then Thirty of the Ambassadors Horse-guards in the same Livery, but without Battle Axes. Ninthly, the Coach
wherein their Excellencies rode. Lastly, the march was clos'd with twelve Coaches fill'd with Muscovite Gentlemen and Brandenburghers. Their Excellencies being thus conducted over the Karkerbrug to a magnificent Lodging pre∣pared for 'em in the long Street of Kneiphoff, the Burghers being drawn up in a double File, and lining the Streets all the way, and a trip∣ple discharge of all the great Guns saluting them from their entrance into their Lodging, where the Garrison of the City stood to re∣ceive them: So soon as they alighted they were conducted to their Apartment, which was guard∣ed by twenty Soldiers; and then the Lords of the Court, together with M. Dankelman, and the Master of the Ceremonies left 'em, and were waited on by the Ambassadors to the Stairs of the House.”

“UPON the Fourth of this Instant, N. S. they had their Publick Audience of the Elector, to which they were conducted by M. Dankelman, and the Master of the Ceremonies above-nam'd, with a Train of Thirty Coaches; before the Ambassadors went Thirty Persons carrying the Czar's Present to the Elector; the Ambassadors, who were richly habited in Cloth of Gold and Silver embroider'd with precious Stones, being enter'd into the great Hall of the Castle, where the Elector was seated upon a Throne attended by the principal Lords of his Court, made their Reverences; and after they had every one in their order complimented the E∣lector in short but significant Speeches, they deliver'd him the Present, and a Letter pur∣porting, that the Czar had sent the said Em∣bassy to his Electoral Highness to assure him of
his desire to improve the Affection and good Correspondence which had always been, as well between him, as his illustrious Ancestors. That the same Embassy being from thence to pro∣ceed to the Court of Vienna, in order to farther Consultations and Propositions for the continu∣ance of the War against the Turks and Tartars. His Muscovite Majesty therefore requested the Elector to assist 'em in their Journey, withal returning his Electoral Highness thanks for the Engineers and Bombardiers which he sent him the last Year, and which had been so useful to him in the Siege of Asoph: To all which the E∣lector answer'd, that he was much oblig'd to the Czar for the assurance of his good intentions, and the splendid Embassy he had sent him. And then M. Dankelman return'd an Answer more at large, and very obligingly to the Com∣pliments of the several Ambassadors, who were after that reconducted to their Lodgings with the same Ceremonies, and treated with a splen∣did Dinner at the Elector's Charge. The same Evening they were also entertained with a Shew of Fireworks which lasted till Midnight. Their Present consisted of Sables, Ermins, and other rich Furrs, several fowered Silks and Tis∣sues of Gold and Silver; and other precious Rarities, valu'd in all at Seventy Five Thou∣sand Crowns”

DURING his Czarish Majesty's stay at this Court he receiv'd the News by an Express of the Electi∣on of the Elector of Saxony, now King Augustus, to the Crown of Poland; and as his Majesty had before discovered himself to be in the Interest of that Party, which oppos'd the Prince of Conty's Election; so upon this News he immediately sent
a Minister to the new King, to make his Com∣pliment of Congratulation, and to declare pub∣lickly, that he would support his Pretensions, and would maintain him on the Throne with his whole Power; and particularly, that he would cause an Army of 60000 Men to march immedi∣ately to the Frontiers of Lithuania to be under his Majesty's Orders, for his Assistance in case of need.

ALL the while of the stay of the Embassy, the Elector of Brandenbourgh did every thing that was possible, as well to shew his own Magnificence, as to Honour the Embassy of so great a Monarch; and especially considering that this Embassy, how∣ever glorious in it self to the Court of Prussia, was yet the more so by the addition of this Article, that the Czar, the greatest Monarch of the East, was there in Person, under the shelter of the Am∣bassadors his Servants.

HIS Czarish Majesty had here several Occasions to Converse intimately with the Elector, and that with the greatest Freedom and Openness; communicating to him the Reason of his coming thus out of his own Dominions, and passing Incognito: I have been told that the Elector, a Wise and Polite Prince, exceedingly approv'd and applauded his Intentions,' and said some very fine things both of his Czarish Majesty in his Mi∣nister's ordinary Discourse, as well as personally to him; and at the Conclusion, willingly entred into a Defensive Treaty with his Czarish Majesty's Ambassadors. In a word, the Elector omitted nothing that could either testify his Affection to the Czar in the most obliging manner, or add any Assistance to him or his Retinue, causing them to be defray'd at his own Expence, not at Konings∣berg
only, but all the while he was passing thro' his Dominions.

FROM hence his Majesty went by Water thro' the Pillau and the Freisch Haft, as it is call'd, to Dantzick; the Elector ordering some Yachts to at∣tend his Majesty in the Passage. This Water call'd the Freisch Haft, is an Inland Lake or Wa∣ter which reaches from the Pillau near Koningsberg, to a Branch of the great River Vistula, which passes by Dantzick, and by which Vessels pass from Koningsberg to Dantzick, and is separated from the Sea by a narrow Tract of Land not above three Leagues over, which however lies parallel with the said Haft, and entirely parts it from the main Sea.

HIS Czarish Majesty took great Delight in sail∣ing upon this Water, and in observing the dex∣trous manner of the Seamens working the Yachts, in turning to Windward, and the like; and he spent some Days on purpose to divert himself in that Water with sailing up and down, the Weather also being very pleasant and agreeable at that time.

ABOUT the 20th he arriv'd at Dantzick, where the Burghers and Magistrates treated his Ambassa∣dors, and that is to say his Majesty himself, with all possible Distinction, and caused all the Forts, Lines, Magazines, and Haven or Port, and every part of the Fortifications of that great City to be shown him; which Fortifications far exceeded those of Riga, and which was very much to his Czarish Majesty's Satisfaction. His Embassy made no Entry here, being not directed to say any thing to the Citizens as a Body, and as to their Sove∣reign the King of Poland, that Kingdom was at this time as it were in an Interregnum, the late King
John Sobieski being dead, and the new King Au∣gustus being but newly chosen, and not yet Crown'd.

HOWEVER, the Magistrates of Dantzick re∣ceiv'd several Testimonies of his Czarish Majesty's Favour, and to let them know how well he was pleas'd with their Conduct, assur'd them of his Favour and Protection upon all Occasions; And as his Embassy had been presented with great quantities of fresh Provisions, Wines, and Refresh∣ments, so much as was almost sufficient for their whole Retinue; in return of this the Czar caused his Ambassadors to make the Magistrates a present of Sables, and other rich Goods to a very conside∣rable Value.

FROM hence his Czarish Majesty went direct∣ly thro' the Ducal Pomerania to the City of Berlin, the Court of the Elector of Brandenbourgh, where he was Royally entertained and his whole Em∣bassy and Retinue: They made no Publick Entry here, it being the Court of the same Prince who had receiv'd them with such Splendor at Konings∣berg: But the Czar had here the Occasion of seeing the most splendid Court in Europe, except that of France, and to Converse in the most Polite man∣ner; and was so exceedingly pleas'd with the Gallantry and Magnificence of all he saw here, that he resolved to send his Son the Hereditary Royal Prince to reside there for some time to fi∣nish and polish his Manners for the great things which they then suppos'd him to be born to: But time furnished the Czar with Reasons to take o∣ther Measures, with respect to that Prince, of which in its Order.

FROM Berlin the Czar bent his course towards the Low Countries, where his solemn Embassy was
principally design'd to appear; and it is certain the Dutch, that is to say the States, had made it much of their business to obtain this Honour; intimating to the Czar their desire to form such Treaties of Commerce and Assistance as might be for the mutual Profit of the Subjects of both Nations; and particularly their Resolution to furnish his Czarish Majesty with Workmen, Build∣ers, Shipwrights, and Tradesmen of every kind, necessary for the Building of his Men of War; and as they had obtain'd an assurance that his Czarish Majesty intended to Honour them with his Presence, and with his Embassy, so they were not wanting in all the necessary Preparations, to give him a Reception suitable in some measure to the greatness of his Person and Character.

IT was not till the Month of August that the Ambassadors could set their Foot in the Territo∣ries of the States General: For tho' my business is to write of the Czar, and of him personally, yet I must be allowed to speak here only in the Name of the Embassy and of the Ambassadors. As soon as the States General had notice of their arrival upon their Frontiers, they sent a solemn Deputation to attend them at Nimeguen, from their whole Body; for them, and in their Names, to bid them welcome into their Country, to de∣fray all the Charges of the said Ambassadors and their whole Retinue, to receive them at the first entrance into their Bounds, and to com∣pliment them accordingly.

THUS they were carried thro' all the Towns with the noise of Cannon, and of small Arms on the one hand, and with the Shouts and Acclama∣tions of the People on the other; the States being willing to preserve the Memory of their being
thus honoured by so solemn an Embassy, the most Glorious that had ever been seen in these Parts of the World.

IT would be to omit the most glorious Demon∣stration of the Russian Greatness, if I should fail to give a full Account here as well of the said Publick Entry, as of the great Ceremony of Au∣dience given these Ambassadors afterwards at the Hague, and also of the noble Appearance and Deportment of the Ambassadors themselves; ne∣ver any Men from the Politest Nation under Hea∣ven behav'd better, or made their Speeches with a better Grace, or better became the Character they bore.

IT is certain the States-General, who, as I said before, had earnestly desir'd this Occasion of showing their Respect to his Czarish Majesty, intended to receive his Ambassadors with great Marks of Distinction, and especially knowing that the Czar was in Person with them: But they found themselves a little surpriz'd when they came to see the Ambassadors themselves; their Persons, their Behaviour, and the perfect Know∣ledge they had of every thing that came before them to Discourse of; the Judgment they made of the Interests of Nations, and of the Advan∣tages of Commerce, the manner of extending it, and of what was fit to propose or not to propose in that part; and also the Judgment they were able to make of their being well or ill treated; so that upon seeing what sort of Ministers they had to do with, the States found it necessary to out-do, if possible, what they had at first intend∣ed in the Honours they design'd them.

WE are to suppose them now pass'd thro' the Lower Saxony, and approaching the Frontiers of
the States Country; the States Deputies gone to meet and compliment them in the Name of the Republick, and conducting them to Sourdam, near the Capital City of Amsterdam, and to defray their Charges upon the Way. The next thing is that of their Publick Entry, which was the 26th of August.

THE Magnificence of their Reception here consisted of several parts, that is to say, not only in their meer Entry into the City, which was in∣deed very fine, but in the Entertainment they had there till the time they went to their Publick Audience at the Hague; and also in the Recepti∣on they had at the several Cities which they pass'd thro', as well before they came to Amsterdam, as when they went from thence to the Hague; in all which it is to be observed, that tho' the Czar was a constant Eye-witness to the Reception of his Ambassadors, and had a great deal of Reason to be very well satisfied with the Honours they re∣ceiv'd, which indeed was no more or less than Honours done to himself in the Persons of his Servants; yet his Czarish Majesty keeping firm to his first Resolutions of being conceal'd, and of not appearing in Publick, was never seen in any of the publick Cavalcades; but either went in the Retinue conceal'd in the ordinary Dress of a pri∣vate Person, or had himself placed in some pri∣vate Station to be a Spectator of what pass'd, as we shall find he did at their Audience at the Hague; and if he was at any time discovered, as was on Two or Three Occasions his case, while he was in Holland, nothing gave him more uneasiness, nor would he leave till he found himself so disguis'd to be able to go publickly about and not be known.

THIS, and his desire to view the Yards, the Docks, the building of Ships, and all the parti∣cular Operations of the Carpenters, Caulkers, Anchor-smiths, Black-smiths, Rope-makers, and so of all the rest, I say this, made him for some time Dress himself in the ordinary Habit of a common Seaman with a Monmouth Cap, a short Jacket and wide Breeches, so that it was impossible to discover him; and in this Disguise I have been assured, tho' I cannot affirm it of my own knowl∣edge, that he has suffered himself to be hired in∣to their Carpenters Yards as a Workman, and has both performed a Day's Work, and received his Wages. But I say again, that I rather repeat this from other hands, than say I believe it, or re∣commend it to others to believe.

BUT let that be as it will, certain it is, that in this Disguise he had a compleat liberty, with∣out the Interruption of the Crowding, and Curio∣sity of the People to look at him; I say he had the liberty of seeing every thing that was done, and also, which was the main thing to him, how it was done.

BUT to return to the Ambassadors, the Depu∣ties sent to receive them on the Borders of the Country, having brought them to Sourdam, a Town about Miles from Amsterdam, they were lodg'd there till the Preparations could be made for their Reception in the City, which was done at the Charge of the Magistrates; the Pro∣cession was in the following manner.

IN the Morning early Five Deputies from the States of Holland, and Three from the City of Amsterdam, attended the Ambassadors at Saurdam, to Compliment them on their Arrival, and to In∣vite
them into the City; and the Yacht's of the State were order'd to lye ready to attend them, and take them on Board, with all their Retinue; which was done accordingly, and they arriv'd at the Place appointed for their Landing about ten aClock.

A certain Number of the Magistrates were Deputed to attend them at their Landing, with about fifty Coaches of the Burgomasters, and of the Principal Citizens, and were to Complement them on their Arrival. The Principal young Ci∣tizens form'd themselves into a Troop, and being well Mounted, and with extreamly rich Furni∣ture and Equipage, attended their Excellencies Entry, being to the Number of near three Hun∣dred Horse.
BESIDES these the principal Citizens, and all the Persons of Distinction went to meet them in their Coaches to a very great Number.
AS soon as the Ambassadors landed, and were seated in their Coaches, the Cannon from the Ramparts fir'd round the whole City, and under the Thunder of the said Guns the Cavalcade be∣gan.

IN the first Place march'd a Body of the City Officers to clear the Way, and prevent Disorders from the infinite Throng of People in the Streets; then march'd 16 Companies of the Burghers un∣der Arms, who when they came to the Place appointed for them, form'd two Lines to Line the Street, thro' which the Ambassador and their whole Retinue were to pass, other Bodies of the Burghers under Arms, lin'd the rest of the Way to the Place where the 16 Companies took their Post.

NEXT to these came the Troop of young Gentlemen on Horseback, very richly Dress'd, and their Equipages as before very splendid; and before them went the States Trumpets, and City Musick; then came a small Troop of Circassian Tartars on Horseback, being of the Ambassadors, Retinue, arm'd with Bows and Arrows; then six and thirty Muscovite Gentlemen on Horseback; then twenty Pages of the Ambassadors, clothed in Scarlet lac'd, or rather overlaid with Gold Lace; then came the eldest Burgomaster's Coach of State, in which were the Ambassador Le Fort, and the Muscovite Prince Mezike; then the Grand Pensionary of Holland's Coach, in which were the two other Ambassadors, and another Muscovite Prince: On either side these Coaches, march'd the Ambassador's Guard, on Foot, carry∣ing silver Battle-Axes, and by their Sides large Scymetars; they were Clothed after the Sclavo∣nian manner, with short Doublets, and large Breeches, and over them Scarlet Cloaks, or Robes trim'd with silver Buttons, and large Loops, and Scarlet lac'd with Silver very rich: After these, came the rest of the Coaches mention'd above, in which were the rest of the Ambassadors Retinue; among them the Czar himself, but Dress'd in an ordinary Habit, so as not be distinguish'd; nei∣ther was it possible to Discover him, tho' the People were mighty inquisitive about it.

AFTER these Coaches came 120 Coaches of Citizens, Merchants and Gentlemen, who came to wait upon the Ambassadors; and among these were the Magistrates of the City; the whole Closing with another Body of Burghers in Arms. But the Magistrates did not End here,
for after having thus Conducted the Ambassadors to their Appartments, they treated them in the most Magnificent manner immaginable, for five Days successively, and thus prepar'd a most ex∣traordinary Firework, raised upon Floats, built on purpose in the Water of the Amstel. It would take up too much Room in this Work, to give the Description of this Firework, which was fram'd in the most Exquisite manner, that the best Engineers and Architects could Invent; nor was any Cost spar'd in either, the Device or the Building. In a Word, it was the most Magnifi∣cent that ever was seen in these Parts of the World, and his Czarish Majesty was exceedingly pleas'd with it, as he had a great deal of Reason to be; for it was Executed with all immaginable in Order and Success.

IT is true, this Sight was attended with an un∣happy Accident among the People, for that the Railes of the Bridge over the River, being Crow∣ded with People, gave way, and above 100 Peo∣ple fell into the River, where about thirteen or fourteen were Drown'd; and indeed it was a great Wonder the Night being dark and the Water deep and the Crowd so great, that there were not more lost.

HIS Czarish Majesty was now in the Center of his Business, and had before him the main Thing he came to see; and therefore shunning all publick Appearances, other than those which Necessity oblig'd him to, he took a small House, near the East India Companies Yards or Docks, that is to say, among the Shipwrights and Buil∣ders, and where he could with ease get Admit∣tance in Diguise, to see every thing which he
thought fit to Enquire after, and to take his Ob∣servations at his own Leisure.

IT is true, he was oblig'd to go from thence for sometime to the Hague, to see his Ambassadors admitted to a publick Audience of their High Mightinesses the States General; but he soon re∣turn'd again and remain'd perfectly retir'd for some Months, where he spent his Time in the most useful Studies of Life (viz.) the gaining true Ideas of the most noble Things, and searching the height and depth of Mathematical Knowledge.

I should have observ'd here that the Czar him∣self having receiv'd the Deputies on the Fron∣tiers of Guelderland, and being desirous to Tra∣vel, perfectly undiscover'd, left his Ambassadors and their Train, which was very great, to come leisurely forward with the said Deputies▪ and himself with only four or five Gentlemen disguis'd as ordinary Travellers, came to Amsterdam, four or five Days before them, where he Lodg'd at first in a common Inn, or House of Entertainment, and walk'd freely about the City, view'd the Situa∣tion, the Buildings, the River, the Port, and that infinite Number of Ships, which always are to be seen there; particularly he pitch'd upon the Place for his Retreat, or private Residence, which as I have mention'd above was among the Ship-Yards, Docks and Building-Places, that he might parti∣cularly make his Observations of those things; The enquiry after which was his Delight, and the especial Business of his whole Embassy.

THE Ceremony ended as above, his Czarish Majesty retir'd to the House which he had Hir'd, and went on with his Equipage and Observations; and as he spoke Dutch indifferently well before, so he took occasion to Discourse with all the Work∣men
and Artists that he could find, who he disco∣vered to have any tollerable Judgement in things of that Nature. Nor was his Majesty so retir'd, but that he admitted some of the Merchants of Amsterdam to his Conversation, and especially such as had resided in Muscovy; that is to say at Arch-Angel and Muscow, of which several were then living in Amsterdam, and with these he would be very free and Courteous, and sometimes even Merry only not allowing them to Treat him with too much Ceremony and Distinction.

BY the Conversation of these Men he had several People brought to him, who were most Masters of Science, and who entertain'd his Ma∣jesty very much to his Satisfaction, with the se∣veral Experiments in Nature, in Phylosophy, and in the Mathematicks, which they had made in the Consequence of long Study; and it was to their Aftonishment how soon, and how readily his Cza∣rish Majesty took in the just Ideas, which their Dis∣coveries, and Experiments presented, and how knowingly he would Discourse, even of those things, which he had received no Notion of before.

THE Deputies of the Admiralty also shew'd their respect to his Majesty, in causing every thing that was curious, relating to Naval Affairs to be shew∣ed him, and Artists of all kinds to be presented to him.

IN the mean time the publick Audience of his Ambassadors call'd him away to the Hague, where he had the satisfaction of seeing their High-Migh∣tinesses the States General do him the utmost Honour in the Persons of his Ambassadors, and even to out do themselves, no Audience having e∣ver been known like it in that Country.

IT would be tiresome to relate the Magnifi∣cence of their Reception all the way from Am∣sterdam
to the Hague, whether they and all their Retinue went the latter End of October.

HIS Czarish Majesty also having Intimation of the great Preparations the States-General made for the Reception of his Embassy, and for Gracing their Audience, resolv'd to make a suitable pre∣paration for it on his Side; and therefore caused his Ambassador to make three of the most Mag∣nificent Coaches that could be made for Money, and order'd them to buy Jewels likewise, and Cloths the Richest that could be had, to en∣crease their Retinue with about Forty more Ser∣vants, and to Cloth them and all the rest in new Liveries quite different from those they had be∣fore; in a Word, he directed that every thing should appear in the greatest splendor possible; so that 'tis said the Expence cost above 200000 Dollars extraordinary.
ALL things being ready, and the Audience ap∣pointed, they set out from Amsterdam the 24th of September, and arriv'd at the Hague the same Day.

THEIR publick Entry was infinitely Superi∣or to that at Amsterdam, this being at the Ap∣pointment of the States-General, the other only a Reception of them by the Citizens and Magi∣strates of Amsterdam; and yet the particulars of this part were not so publickly set down as the o∣ther, what I have met with amounts to this.

THAT the Ambassadors were receiv'd at a di∣stance from the Hague, where they had gone on purpose for the Occassion, by five Deputies of the States-General as Introductors of Ambassadors: They were attended by the Reigment of Horse-Guards, and two Battalions of the Guards of Foot, call'd the Blew Guards; with two Coaches of State, drawn by eight Horses each, for the Am∣bassadors,
and forty other Coaches with six Horses each, for their Retinue.

THE Ambassadors were preceeded by forty Gentlemen on Horseback, habited as Cossacks, arm'd with Bows and Arrows, and thirty others as Tartars, arm'd with Lances and Bows; all exceed∣ing richly Cloth'd, but after the manner of their own Countries: They had forty Pages in different Livery, but all cover'd with Gold and Silver Lace as rich as possible. Their immediate Guard were as at Amsterdam, Habited after the Muscovite manner, carrying silver Battle-Axes in their Hands, and Symetars with silver Hilts by their Sides.
THE Ambassadors were in two Coaches of State, and their own new magnificent Coaches follow'd, having Thirty two Footmen in rich Li∣veries walking on the Sides.

THE whole was follow'd with a numerous Train of Coaches belonging to the Nobility and Gentry, and to the foreign Ministers, of which there are always a great many at the Hague, but more especially at that Juncture, it being the time of that Congress for the Peace with France, call'd afterwards the Treaty at Ryswick.

HIS Czarish Majesty was in the Train in Dis∣guise, wearing a plain blew Coat, a large white Perriwig, and a white Feather; and being perfect∣ly well acquainted both with the Person and ex∣traordinary Merits of the Sieur Witsen (who was that Year Burgomaster of Amsterdam) he borrow∣ed his Coach, and desir'd him to Accompany him thitr; which was perform'd with so much Dex∣terity and Secresy, by the said Sieur de Witsen, that his Majesty was not discover'd by any body living.

IT was in the Month of September of the said Year, when there was the greatest show of foreign Ambassadors that ever was seen at the Hague, oc∣casion'd by the Negotiation, as above, at Ryswick: Thither most Courts of Europe, had sent their Plenipotentiaries, who all striving to out vie one another in Magnificence. It was no easie Mat∣ter to add any thing to the Splendor of their Equi∣pages; yet his Czarish Majesty being sensible that the Eyes of the World in a most peculiar manner would be fix'd upon his Embassy; and being in∣vited by a most commendabl emulation to main∣tain, as well on that as other Occasions the glory and lustre of his eminent Station in the World, as claiming the Title of an Emperor, and bearing the Imperial Arms; he was fully resolv'd that this most solemn Embassy, honour'd by his Pre∣sence should bear the Marks of, and be fully an∣swerable to his high Station and Grandeur.

In effect according to the Testimony of all that were Spectators of this solemn Audience, every thing was manag'd with so much order, majesty and gra∣vity, and with so much Magnificence, that nothing could add to the Lustre of this Solemnity, which in all Respects was suitable to his Majesty's De∣sign.

IT is confess'd by all Hands that never any Ambassador appear'd in a more splendid Attire then the General le Fort the first Ambassador did that Day; he was clad after the Muscovite Fashi∣on, in a long Robe of Cloth of Gold, lin'd with the most precious Sables that ever were seen. This Robe as well as the Vest which he wore under it, was cover'd before with Diamonds in the Shape of a Hern's feather, with such Luster as dazl'dthe Eyes of the Beholders; he Harang'd their High and
Mightinesses in the Russian Tongue, with an Air altogether Majestick, and suitable to the Cha∣racter he bore upon so solemn an Occasion. The two other Ambassadors, who appeared likewise in very rich Apparel, made also their Compliments to their High and Mightinesses with a Majestick Gravity; but that which added the greatest Lustre to the Audience, was, that all the Ambassadors of most Princes in Europe, honoured these Men with their Presence; and his Czarish Majesty had the satisfaction to be an Eye-witness of all that pas∣sed from a Closet Window opening into the Au∣dience Room, without being perceived by any Body; and returned the next Day privately to Amsterdam, extremely well pleased with his Jour∣ney; neither did their Excellencies make any long stay in the Hague, they having no other matters to propose to the States, but the confirming of former Treaties.

THE Ceremonies now ended, the Czar not on∣ly applyed himself to the Work he came about as before, but all the Persons of Distinction which he brought with him, dispers'd themselves according to the different Commands he gave them; ap∣plying themselves according as their different In∣clinations led them, to the Knowledge of such things as were needful, according to the Pattern of their great Master.

THIS lessened the Retinue which at first ap∣peared in the Embassy exceedingly; and yet the Ambassadors retain'd an Equipage suitable to the Character they bore, and suitable to the Glory of their Master.

IN the mean time the Czar receiv'd an invita∣tion very agreeable to him, which was to have an Interview with the King of Great Britain at that
time, the Glory of that part of the World, and who had just finished, with Honour to himself, and Satisfaction to all his Allies, a long and bloody War with the King of France by the Treaty at Ryswick.

THE King came to Utrecht, where the Czar, accompanied only with Prince Menzikoff and Ge∣neral Le Fort, but all Incognito, went to see him; these two mighty Monarchs receiv'd a mutual Sa∣tisfaction in this interview, as both of them af∣terwards testified: They continued some Hours to∣gether, Monsieur Le Fort serving as an Interpre∣ter; and here it was that his British Majesty in∣vited the Czar to come and see his Court at Lon∣don; and that his Czarish Majesty accepted the King's invitation, of which by it self.

HIS Majesty now having his full leisure for the perfecting what he came about, he hir'd Ar∣tists in Holland of several sorts, and giving them very good Conditions, dispatch'd them for Mus∣cow, some by Land, the Season not admitting to go about by the North Cape to Arch-Angel, and some were maintain'd and employ'd in making Models and Draughts for Building, 'till the Sea∣son for going by Sea came on: In this manner they were dispers'd many ways, some went to Schools or Masters to learn Navigation and the Elements of Euclid; others Bound themselves for terms of Years to Artificers; in a word, none were Idle, the Czar resolving to furnish himself and all his At∣tendants with a Fund of Knowledge sufficient to answer his End; and indeed considering his Ma∣jesty's View, it was a very great Fund of Human Learning that ought to be laid up, to carry home and instruct a Nation.

IT was an immense Sum of Money that his Czarish Majesty laid out here in buying Tools and Instruments for the Works, and several Trades and Arts which he and his People were to put in Practise; there was not a Handicraft of any Note, that his Czarish Majesty did not acquaint himself more or less with, and with the manner of their Working, no not from the making of a Watch to the builder of a Ship; but it is to be noted, that the Ma∣rine Affairs were those his chief Delight was in, and which suited best with his Genius; and while he was at Amsterdam he bought him a Yacht, with which he diverted himself continually upon the River and the Zuyderzee, till by Custom he learnt to steer and work her as dexterously as the ablest Seamen he could get.
HERE he also hir'd several Seamen and Offi∣cers, and made them Captains and Lieutenants of his Men of War, some of whom are in his Ser∣vice to this Day.
ABOUT the of Septemb. 1698, he re∣solv'd upon his Journey, or Voyage rather, to England, and accordingly he arriv'd here in No∣vember 1698, of which presently.

BUT I should have noted here, that while his Majesty remain'd at Amsterdam, after he had been at the Hague, and was return'd as above, he re∣ceiv'd three Couriers from his Lords, to whom he had left the Administration of the Government at Muscow in his absence; bringing him the welcome News of a great Victory obtain'd by his Army under the Command of General Schein at Asoph over the Turks and Tartars. The Particulars of this Action, as they were then related, were as follows, (viz.)

HIS Majesty first receiv'd an Express from Muscovy, with the agreeable News of this Bat∣tel; the other Accounts came some time after by different ways: The Cham of the Crim Tar∣tars had, in the beginning of the Spring, caused great numbers of his Troops to pass in many small Bodies, and at different times, through Caffa, in order to join them with the Tartars of Circassia, and especially those inha∣biting near the River Cubanoc, knowing that the Muscovite Army was divided into several Bodies, the better to cover the Workmen, who were em∣ploy'd in several places, in compleating the be∣fore-mentioned Fortifications, looking upon this as a fit opportunity to surprize them unawares: For this purpose he order'd the Tartars com∣manded by Sultan Galga, to advance with great and speedy Marches towards the Muscovites: But the Muscovite General Schein having received intel∣ligence of their approach, had just so much lei∣sure given him as to draw down his Troops toge∣ther in an advantageous Place, where he resolv'd to engage the Enemy; these perceiving them∣selves superior in number to the Muscovites, and being encourag'd by the fancy'd fear of the Mus∣covite Army, which did not move from their Post, fell with great Fury upon them, and were received with great Bravery by the Russians, who were contented to defend themselves in their Post, till their General perceiving the first heat of the Tarters slacken, attacked them very briskly, put them first into Confusion, and soon after to the Rout, with a great Slaughter on the Enemy's side, whom they pursued to the River Hagalinc, were many of them were drown'd; this River runs through Circassia, about two Leagues distant
from Asoph; tho' our Maps put this River to the North on the other side of the River Don, above thirty Leagues from Asoph.

THEIR Excellencies the Muscovite Ambassa∣dors made Publick Rejoicings upon this Occasion, and invited the Magistrates of Amsterdam and o∣ther Persons of Quality to a magnificent Enter∣tainment, where they were diverted with Dancing and Musick, Fireworks, and all sorts of other Di∣vertisements: His Czarish Majesty was pleas'd to appear there in Person, and in so pleasant a Hu∣mour, all the Guess were extreamly satisfy'd with his Goodness.

TOWARD the end of the Winter this Victory was seconded by the News of another Advantage obtain'd near the River Boristhenes; for the Crim Tartars, in Conjunction with those of Budziack and Oczakow, having besieged Kasikermeen, had carried on their Trenches to the very Counter∣scarp, and at the same time made themselves Masters of the adjacent small Isle of Tomam; but a Body of Muscovites having joined the Cossacks in∣habiting those Frontiers, came time enough to the Relief of the place, forcing the Tartars to aban∣don the Siege, and that with a considerable Loss on their side; upon which his Majesty gave or∣ders, that the said Island should be strengthened by some regular Fortifications.

ALL these Successes added to his Majesty's Glory; and the more, in that they were obtain'd in his Absence, as it was a Testimony that the Government of his Affairs was left in good Hands, and that he had made a right Choice of his Men, with whom he had entrusted the Command of his Armies, as well as of those to whom he had com∣mitted
the Administration of his Civil Govern∣ment.

THESE Advices were follow'd with other Letters, giving him an Account of the progress of his Engineers, and how well they had secur'd and fortify'd the Places he had won; as well A∣soph as Tuba, Kaisikermeen, and other Places; and that the first of these especially, was put into such a Posture that it might justly be esteemed one of the strongest Fortresses of the World, particularly that part which he had directed to be built in the Morass mention'd above.

THIS was the more agreeable to the Czar, as it was suitable to his wish, for that in a Word, Asoph was the Center of all his vast Designs, and he had as we may say, laid no less than a Scheme for the Ruin of the whole Ottoman Empire in the Gradations he had Projected from that one Place, as will be seen hereafter.

WE are now to suppose his Czarish Majesty on his Voyage to England, his Britanick Majesty sent over several Yatches to bring him over with a Man of War, or two for his Convoy, and he arriv'd in the River of Thames the of October. 1697.

WHEN he came to London, the King omitted nothing to show him that he had a very particular esteem for him; indeed the Intent and Meaning of his thus hazarding his Person in foreign Parts for enabling himself to Government, and People was a thing so inimitably great, and so praise worthy in a Prince of his Rank, that it merited all the regard, and all the Assistance that could possibly be given him.

HIS Britanick Majesty at first offer'd the Czar all the publick Honour due to his Character as a Royal or Imperial Soveraign and Crown'd Head; as particularly, his Majesty offer'd him Somerset-House for his Residence, being a Pallace Royal, and that he should be attended by the Officers of the Royal Houshold, and that all the Expence of his Kitchin, and of his Retinue should be de∣frayed; that he should have a Detachment of the English Houshold Troops for a Guard to his Per∣son, and a certain Number of the King's Coaches to attend him.

BUT the Czar after returning a very obliging Answer, declin'd all those Honours; let his Ma∣jesty of Great Britain know the Reasons of his Resolution to be every where Incognito, and how necessary it was to his Design in coming a∣broad; that he came for Improvement, and had no time to spend in Ceremony, receiving and returning Visits, and the like.

HE therefore desir'd his Britanick Majesty that he would suffer him to be as much conceal'd as possible, and yet that he might have so much of his Royal favour, as should admit him to see what was proper for his Improvement in Maritime Affairs, which was the principle thing that he desir'd to Inspect, and which he found here was manag'd even in a greater Perfection than in any other part of the World.

HIS Britanick Majesty was so extreamly pleas'd with this, and with all the other Testi∣monies, which the Czar gave of his Personal Capacities, and his Genius to the things he came to enquire after; and particularly, the truly no∣ble End and Design of his enquiring after them; that he immediately order'd that all possible En∣couragement,
and Assistance should be given his Majesty; that he should be showed every thing that he had a desire to see, and that all the Men of Art should communicate every thing that his Czarish Majesty should desire to know: In a Word, his Britanick Majesty let him know that nothing should be wanting in England to give all possible Assistance to his Czarish Majesty in so glorious a Search after Knowledge, and Wisdom, and that he would do every thing that was in his power to let him (the Czar) see what esteem he (the King) had for him on that particular Ac∣count.

HIS Czarish Majesty after his letting the King know his Resolution of remaining Private, took a House, as proper, and as happily Situated for such a purpose, as the whole City could hardly have afforded such another, considering its being a well built commodious House also; for as it had a good front Gate to bring a Coach to, in the Great-Row, of Norfolk-street, in the Strand; so it had a pri∣vate pair of Stairs to the River, peculiar to the House only; where Boats could come even at low Water to set him on shore, or take him in, as he thought fit, and so that it was scarce possible to the People to see him go or come.

WHILE he resided here, he had frequent In∣terviews with the King, and made some Visits to the Princess Ann, afterwards Queen; went to see Windsor Castle, Hampton Court, and other publick Places; was particularly shew'd the Tower of London, and all the Varieties there, where he was particularly taken with the Great Armory, and the admirable Order of the placeing the small Arms, and Furniture for Horse and Foot; and epsecially the keeping the Arms so
clean, well fix'd, and ready for Service; and, as we hear, has appointed one to be Built after the same manner at Petersburgh, and to be furnish'd with small Arms for an Hundred Thousand Men.

AT the same time he was accommodated at Deptford with an Apartment which had a private Door into the King's Yard and Wet Dock, and a way also into the Merchant's Yards and Wet Docks, on the way from Deptford to Redriff; by which he had opportunity to see every part of the Builders Art exemplifyed; and which was most delightful to his Majesty, the Master Builders having express, Orders to oblige his Majesty as much as possible, laid before him their Moulds and Draughts, and the accurate Method by which they fitted every piece of Timber, and directed the building of the largest Ships of War.

HIS Czarish Majesty was so extremely pleas'd with that part, whether it was that their Method was not so good in Holland, or that they did not let him so far into the Secret of their Art, I know not; but he was pleas'd to declare, that our Building far exceeded all that he had seen before, and that he was resolv'd to make the English Men of War be the Pattern by which all his own Ships should be built, and to have his Builders instruct∣ed to work their Models the same way; and I am informed, he made himself so much Master of the Method, that he has since drawn the first Draught of his largest Men of War with his own Hand.

AFTER this his Majesty the King of Great Britain ordered Admiral Mitchel to go down to Portsmouth, where there then lay a Squadron of Men of War, and caus'd them to be form'd into
two Fleets, and to show the Czar the manner of an Engagement at Sea, making them draw out and Engage, tho' without firing with Ball.

HERE his Czarish Majesty being on board the Admiral's Ship, was shewed the manner of two Fleet's preparing to Fight, their Unmooring, their Scouts giving Signal to the Fleet, the Admiral giving Signal to draw up in a Line, and when to engage; their striving for the Weather-gage, bear∣ing down upon the Enemy, standing off and on to keep out of the Fight, keeping the Line, putting off of Fireships, and attacking with Fireships; firing Broadsides, clapping one another aboard, lying thwart Hawse, coming up under the Stern, and pouring in Broadsides upon a Ship's Quarter or Bow, and in short, all the ways of taking Ad∣vantage of an Enemy in Fight.

THIS was perform'd with so much Order, so Dexterously, and so without the least Dammage, that his Czarish Majesty profess'd himself exceed∣ing well pleas'd with it; and that much more than he was with something of the same kind offered him in Holland, which being performed also by smaller Vessels, could not so well explain the Par∣ticulars necessary to be known for the ordering a Sea-fight with Capital Ships.

THUS the Czar employ'd his time in England, viewing every thing that was Curious, and enter∣ing into due Enquiries after those things, which he found most necessary for his Purpose, as parti∣cularly, besides what I have mentioned above, he was very curious in his viewing the Mint, and Essaying the Metals, reducing them to the Stan∣dard Value, the Melting-house, the Flatting Mill, the Stamping, and the Dye, or Stamp which makes the Impression. Likewise he went to the
University of Oxford, where he saw the publick Libraries, the manner of disposing the Books and Manuscripts; view'd the Rarities, and particular∣ly the Printing-house, which he was so pleas'd with, that he caused all the Materials, and all the Utensils for setting up the like, to be Bought, with Fonts of Letters of every size, and of every Character, resolving to set up a Printing-house at Muscow and at Petersbourgh, which I am assur'd he has since brought to pass.

HIS stay in England was about three Months, during which time he improved himself so much in all the Parts of those Sciences, which he apply∣ed himself to look into, that a learned Person who convers'd with him freely, said publickly, that an ordinary Proficient would not obtain so much in three Year.

AT his going away his Majesty presented the Czar with a fine Yacht or Frigate built for his own particular use, for his passing and re-passing between England and Holland, being not only a beautiful and finely finished Vessel, but an ex∣cellent Sailer; carrying 24 Brass Guns, and most richly painted and guilded; in which Vessel his Czarish Majesty, after taking leave of the King and the Princess, and with great Professions of mutual Kindness and Satisfaction in what had pass'd, set Sail for Holland, and arriv'd safe at the Brill, tho' not without some hazard, in the Voyage, having had very bad Weather in his Passage.

ALL the while his Czarish Majesty was in Eng∣land, he employ'd some English Russia Merchants to Hire for him, and Contract with as many of the best Master Builders, Caulkers, Carvers, and the like of other Trades, which were generally employ'd in finishing and fitting out Ships in or∣der
to send them to Muscovy, and his Majesty left Commissioners with the same Merchants to Contract with others after he was gone, and to send them after him, which was done to his con∣tent; and 'tis by the help of these very Men chiefly, that the Czar has at this time so many Ships, as well Capital Men of War, from 50 to 96 Guns, as light Fregates, Brigantines, Transport-Ships, and the like; which they have built, and are still ever building at Croonslot and Petersburgh, where the Czar, who at that time had not a Ship, or a Port in the Baltick, has now such a Fleet, and so well Mann'd, as no Prince ever had before him in so short a while; and we have News from thence just at the writing of these Sheets, that his Czarish Majesty has built at the Port of Petersburgh, and other adjacent Place, no less then six Men of War, from 76 to 98 Guns, which are some of them Lanch'd, and the others almost ready to Lanch, and will be ready for the approaching Summers Expedition.

ALL this while his Ambassadors remained at the Hague, except that Monsieur La Fort had been allow'd to go over to England with the Czar, in a private Capacity, and return'd to Hol∣land, again a little before him.

AND now having finish'd his enquires, and having viewed every thing that was curious, and Improving as well in England, as in Holland; set∣tled Amity and a good Understanding between himself, and both those Nations, and having far∣ther Progress to make, especially, resolving to see the Imperial Court at Vienna, the Senate, and City of Venice, and the Antiquities of Rome and Italy he prepar'd to be gone.

I SHALL omit the particulars of his Passage from Holland, thro' Germany to Vienna first, because it would spin out this Work too far in the Affairs of least Consequence, and perhaps straiten us for Room in those of moreweight: And Secondly, be∣cause we have not a full Account of all the parts of the Rout he took come to Hand: It may suffice to say that his Czarish Majesty arriv'd at Vienna, about the 10th of June with his Ambassadors, and all their Train, as before; having been receiv'd, with particular Marks of Respect and Distinction, in all his Passage thro' the Empire: As to France his Majesty distinguish'd himself so much in Favour of the Confederates, as not so much as to set his Foot in any part of France, nor to have the least Intentions of seeing that Court, which values itself so much upon its being the Center, and the Scene of all Peoples curiosity.

HIS Imperial Majesty came immediately into the same Sentiments, as to the Czar's design of Tra∣vel as others had done, esteeming it an Action tru∣ly glorious and worthy a Monarch of the highest Rank in the World, and resolv'd therefore to show to his Czarish Majesty all the Respect, and do him all the Honours the Imperial Court was capable of.

THE Czar and his Ambassadors continu'd in a particular Lodging appointed for them till the 26th, having first notify'd their arrival in form as Ambassadors; they had the Pallace of Gun∣dersdoff, belonging to the Count de Koningsec, where they remain'd till the 26th, when they made their publick Entry with their usual Mag∣nificence.

THE Ambassadors went to a Place call'd Mount Tabor, whence the show was appointed to set out, and Commissioners were sent thither to re∣ceive
them attended by a Party of Dragoons of the Guards.

THE March began with the Trumpets and Kettle-Drums, belonging to the States of the Province, follow'd by two Companies of Dra∣goons, and some Imperial Officers; after them the Ambassadors Trumpets in rich Liveries, as also the Pages and Footmen in the same; thence proceeded a great Number of Coaches and six Horses, of the Lords of the Court, which were fol∣low'd by two of the Emperors Coaches. The first for Princes that came along with the Ambassa∣dors. The second for the Ambassadors themselves, and the Imperial Commissioners; surrounded with Hey-dukes bearing their Maces, and followed by Pages on Horseback, and other domestick Servants, and three noble Coaches belonging to the Ambas∣sadors. Which with a vast Train of Coaches be∣longing to the principal Persons in the Imperial Court, followed by another Detatchment of Dra∣goons, clos'd the Cavalcade.

THE 29th of the same Month, the Ambassa∣dors had a private Audience of the Emperor; and here, tho' incognito, his Czarish Majesty appear'd with his Ambassadors, that is to say, went as one of their Train, after the Audience of the Am∣bassadors, which was matter of Ceremony, the Czar in particular was admitted to an Enterview without them.

WHILE the Ambassadors had their Audience, the Emperor stood for some time cover'd; but af∣terward sat down, and desir'd the Ambassadors to sit also, but they excused themselves which they did more particularly, in regard to the Presence of their own Soveraign, who being near them, must have been standing, while they had sat down,
which the Emperor presently understanding to be the Reason, rose up also himself and receiv'd them standing; Monsieur Le Fort made his Ha∣range here in Latin, which the other two Ambas∣sadors spoke in the Russian Tongue, and the Empe∣ror answer'd in Latin, which by the way, his Impe∣rial Majesty spoke very fluently.

WHEN they were dismiss'd, the Czar and Ge∣neral Le Fort (no more being admitted) went to the Interview with his Imperial Majesty. They went in by a back Pair of Stairs from the Chamber of Audience, when the Czar advancing, his Imperial Majesty receiv'd him at the Door of his Anti-Chamber.

AFTER the first Complements the Emperor put on his Hat; but seeing the Czar refus'd to be cover'd, because he was incognito, his Imperial Majesty uncover'd also; no Body was present at this Interview, but the Count Deichtenstein grand Chamberlain to the Emperor, and the Count de Dictrickstein his Grand 'Squire, with general Le Fort, who serv'd as the Czars Interpreter; and then it was that the Czar took his opportunity to impart to the Emperor the Letters he had re∣ceiv'd, which gave him an Account, how that eight Thousand of his Garrison of Asoph had ta∣ken thirty Thousand Horses from the Tartars, after they had defeated a Body of three Thousand Men that Guarded them.

THE 6th of July, the Count of Staremberg, Camp-marshal General of the Emperor's Ar∣mies, and President of the Council of War, gave the Czar and his Ambassadors a magnificient Collation, accompani'd with a Consort of Musick, and after that a noble Ball; where were present he principal Lords, and Ladies of the Court; the
9th being the Festival of St. Peter, the Name which was given to the Czar in Baptism, the same Prince gave a great Feast, and a Ball in Guntersdorf House, the Emperor sent him his Mu∣sick and order'd lovely Fire-Works to be made ready, which were play'd off in the Evening, to augment the Divertisement of the Feast; the same Day his Imperial Majesty sent a Present of all manner of Mathematical Instruments to the Czar, who two Days after went to see the Armo∣ry, the Libraries, the Pictures, and all the other Rarieties of the Imperial Palace.

UPON the 21st was a great Feast in the Palace de le Favorite, which began with a Ball, and a Con∣sort of Musick, afterwards a splendid Col∣lation; then another Ball, which lasted all Night, till break of Day; every Masker was in the Habit of a different Nation; so that all the most noted Nations of the World were there re∣presented, and every Prince or Lord had a Lady by his Side in answerable Habits of the same Nat∣tion; and the Habits made of rich Stuffs, sparkling with precious Stones; so that in the memory of Man, a Sight so Magnificient had not been seen their.

THE Emperor, who represented an Host, with two and thirty Pages, habited like Butlers, drank in a most lovely Glass, the Countryman of oest Frise's Health, who was represented by the chief of the Muscovite Princes; saying at the same time, that he knew well his extraordinary Zeal for the Czar of Muscovy; and on the other Side, the Coun∣tryman of Oest Frise drank the Host in Disguise's Health; saying at the same time, that he was not ignorant of his inviolable Affection for the Em∣peror; after which his imperial Majesty reply'd that he gave the Glass to the Countryman of Oest
Frese, desiring him to preserve it carefully in Memory of the Healths drank in such good Company.

UPON the 29th the grand Embassy had their publick Audience, to which they were conducted in the following Manner. First march'd a Com∣pany of Foot, follow'd by six Trumpeters belong∣ing to the Embassy, clad in rich Liveries, after the German mode, those were follow'd by fifteen of the Court Coaches, wherein rode the Musco∣vite Lords, in their own Country Habit, and others after the French dress; after these came fifty Burghers, clad in black Velvet, bearing the Presents design'd for his Imperial Majesty, which consisted in a great Number of lovely Ermins and Furs, Sables, Cloath of Gold and Silver, and a Harness enrich'd with Pearl; after this rode a Muscovite a Horseback, carrying the Letters of Credence, follow'd by one of the Emperor's Coaches; wherein the Embassadors rode, together with his Imperial Majesty's Commissioners. This Coach was surrounded and attended by Pages and other in Liveries belonging as well to the Ambas∣sadors as to the Grandees of the Court, who with the Ambassadors Coaches clos'd the March; the Am∣bassadors entering into the Court of the Palace de le Favorite found the Guards in Arms, and were conducted to the Hall of Audience, with the ac∣custom'd Ceremonies, after which they were mag∣nificently Treated at the Emperors Charges, and so Conducted back to the Place where they lay.

THE Czar was just upon his departure for Ve∣nice, in his way to Rome, and had already sent eight Persons of his Train before, but at the very time he was preparing to depart; he was con∣strain'd to alter his Resolution, and to take Post for Muscow, with a Train of between thirty and
forty Horse, upon Advice of a revolt of several Malecontents within his Dominions, and that if he did not speedily return, by his Presence to put a stop to the Current of the Commotion, he might unhappily find all the Passages stop'd.

WE are now come to the End of this unexam∣pled Journey, viz. the Travels of the Czar, and his Ambassadors, in a Circle of near 2000 Miles, not in∣cluding his Czarish Majesty's Trip to England: It is now time to look back to Muscovy: His Czarish Majesty had received several Expresses from his Generals at Asoph, of their successful Encounters with the Tartars, and just before he left the Hague, where his Ambassadors had their Audience of leave, there arriv'd another Courier with an Account, that General Gordon had very happily suppress'd a kind of an Insurrection of 10000 of the Strelitzes, and had kill'd 3500 of them upon the Spot, and taken almost all the rest of them Prisoners; that he had Decimated the Prisoners, and hang'd every Tenth Man upon the Field of Bat∣tle, had retain'd in Prison the rest, with se∣veral of their Ringleaders, and some of the No∣bility who had Fomented their insolence, and in a Word, had effectually suppress'd the Rebellion.

IN the Neck of this came another from Asoph, with the News, that a Detachment of 8000 Men from the Garison of that City had defeated 6000 Tartars, who had been Posted as a Guard to the Tartar's Horses, who were put into the Marshes on the Frontiers of Circassia, and had taken no less than 30000 Horses of which mention is made, as above.

BUT all these good Tidings had their Allay, and the last News his Czarish Majesty receivd, was such as intimated the Danger to be very
great, and that they fear'd a general Insurrection, entreating him to hasten back, not only that by his Presence he might encourage his faithful Subjects, but that he might arrive before the Conspirators should be able to get a Force together, and seize upon the Passes, and Entrances into his Country, and either make it impracticable for him to return, or perhaps make him run the Danger of falling into the Hands of his Enemies in the attempt.

It will easily be granted that his Czarish Ma∣jesty had Reason to use the utmost Expedition in his Return, and indeed upon that Expedition depended his success; for the celerity or swiftness of his Return was such, that the Conspirators saw him in the Castle or Pallace of Muscow, sur∣rounded with his Army, and ready to fall upon them before they thought it had been possible that he could so much as have any Account of their proceedings.

THIS was such a surprize to them as broke all their Measures; for the Czar fell to work with them, the very Moment he arrived, and particu∣larly with those who General Gordon had in Cu∣stody; for first his Majesty order'd that the princi∣pal Contrivers and Encouragers of the said Rebel∣lion should be brought before him, and after he had himself re-examin'd them, they having before been condemn'd in a full Hearing before all the Lords; they were all Sentenc'd to Death, among whom were Prince Colorin, General Romanodos∣lowski, with several Ladies of Quality, and Friars and Priests of the first Rank, some of them were be∣headed, some broke upon the Wheel, others bu∣ried alive, and the aforesaid Strelitzes or Soldiers, whe had actually march'd and fought against the Czar's Arms, and who had ever since the Czar's
first coming to the Crown upon all occasions been in the Plots and Intreagues of the Princess Sophia, and the Party that adhered to her, and had in several Instances shew'd their will and readiness to revolt upwards of 2000 of them were executed, some their Heads taken of in the publick Market-place, others hung up upon Gal∣lowses erected on purpose at the Gates of all the three Walls round the City, with the Crimes writ upon the Gallows: This Execution being per∣form'd in the depth of Winter, their Bodies were immediately bury'd; those that were beheaded, were order'd to lie in the same posture, as their Heads were cut off, in Ranks upon the ground, with their Heads lying by them; and those which were hang'd round the Walls of the City were left hanging, the whole Winter in the same posture to the view of the People, till the warm Weather began to come on in the Spring, and then they were taken down and buried in a Pit together, to prevent the infection of the Air.

THERE was likewise other Gibbets plac'd on all the publick Roads leading to Muscow, at about two Miles distance, where others of these Rebels were hang'd, and a large Monument of Stone erected upon the several Roads, with the De∣scription of their Crimes deeply engraven, and order'd to be repair'd and kept up for ever, and the very Houses wherein they had liv'd were or∣der'd to be raz'd to the ground, and the Name of Strelitzes to be no more made use of in the Army of Russia forever, but being chang'd, from that time they were call'd Soldatee or Soldiers; such of the Strelitzes that were judg'd most Innocent, or not so deeply involv'd in the guilt with the rest, having their Lives given them, were some sent
to Siberia, others banish'd to Astracan, Asoph, and all the out Parts of the Kingdom, with their Wives and Families and others of their near Re∣lations to suffer with them, as it is the way of most of the Eastern Countries.

THUS his Majesty upon his return from his Tra∣vels by the example of so vigorous a Proceeding having surpress'd the Enemies to his Government, it was the more easie for him to go on with these things, which he had resolv'd upon for the reforming his Country; he began first, with establishing his Guards, which were those Regiments that were fix'd in the Place of the aforesaid Strelitzes; then put his whole Army upon a new Foot, form'd a new Dis∣cipline, which he had collected from what he had observ'd Abroad, and he order'd all his Army to be regularly Cloath'd, with some distinction in the Colour and Trimming of the Cloaths like the cu∣stom of other Nations of Europe; this had not till now been done in Muscovy, but every one wore his Claths according to his own Fancy; he order'd also an Account to be brought to him of such Per∣sons of the Nobility and Gentry of considerable Estates, who were not in any Service or Employ∣ment; out of which he commanded a great part to go and serve as Voluntiers in the Army, and others he order'd to attend, and appointed them Duty in several Stations, some in Equipping his Navy, and others order'd to go and reside at the frontier Garrisons, that if they did no good, they might be out of the way of doing any Mischef.

WHEN he had thus dispos'd things in Moscow, with Relation to his Army, he went down himself to Veronize to view those Ships and Gallies that were built there by the Dutch in his Absence, and to hasten the Equipment of his Fleet that was prepa∣ring for the Black Sea, he made those English that he
had brought over with him chief Master-builders, and discharg'd all the Dutch Builders, except what were to finish the Ships which they had begun, and those were left under the Command of the English, Ordering that there should be none but English fa∣shion'd Ships to be built for the future; one of which being a Ship of 50 Guns, his Majesty himself im∣mediately, as soon as he came there set upon the Stocks, by a Draught which he had drawn with his own Hands; and so contriv'd her by an Invention of his own, that tho' the Keel should be knock'd off, the Ship should be Tight as he propos'd; which Ship when he had advanc'd a little way, he left to be carried on by two young Russian Gentle∣men, that had been Abroad with him, and learn∣ed to build Ships along with his Majesty; only he left Orders for them to ask sometimes Advice of the English Builders, when there was any occasion for it; he left also Orders at Veronize with Vice Admiral Cruss, and Real Admiral Raes, together with the Sea Captains, Officers and Seamen that he had taken into his Service in Holland, before he went over to England, and who were now arriv'd in Veronize to get those Ships and Gallies that were built there, rigg'd and ready fitted, to Sail down to Asoph, whither he intended to go with them in the Spring of the Year, together with his Favorite le Fort, who tho' he knew nothing of the Sea, was declar'd Admiral.

WHEN his Majesty had thus settled the Affairs of his Navy, as he had before done of his Army, he return'd back again to Muscow, where besides what he had done at his first coming over, he made a Choice of Lords to be of his Council, and begun to regulate Affairs in Government, both in the Church, and in the State.

AND now we are to Enter in the Course of his Majesty's History on a new Scene of Action, and of a differing kind from what he had ever known before: Hitherto all his Enterprises had been at∣tended with an uninterrupted Course of Success; his Wars with the Turks and Tartars, happening at a time when the Turkish Power seem'd to be in a Crisis, went all to his Content, and Victory at∣tended his Arms upon all occasions.

BUT now his Majesty had another kind of E∣nemy to deal with, I mean the King of Sweden; whose Fume, tho' yet it had made no Noise in the World, yet he was attended with a well disciplin'd Army, a Nation fierce and daring, whose Reputa∣tion in Arms, was equal, if not Superior to the most glorious Nations in the World.

WHEN his Majesty, as I have observed, went from Vienna in haste to Muscow, he was not how∣ever so much alarm'd with the News of his Rebel∣lious Subjects, but that he found room in his Thoughts as well as leisure in his speed, for a short Interview with the King of Poland, thro' whose Dominions he was necessarily oblig'd to pass.

A LITTLE time may contrive what a great many Years may be employ'd to Execute; here in a few Hours they concerted that dreadful War be∣tween them, and the King of Sweden, which pro∣ved at first so fatal to them both, and which in its whole Course was fatal to all the Northern Part of Europe, destructive to the whole Coun∣tries and in which first and last above 500000 People have lost their Lives; nay, I have heard it affirm'd that Sweden alone has by this very War been drein'd of 300000 Men to the irrepara∣ble Desolation of that Kingdom, and we shall find abundant of Reason to believe that Poland and
Muscovy, and the Provinces adjoyning, put them all to gether have lost a much greater Number.

IT was not however till the Year 1700, that the War between the Czar of Muscovy, and the King of Sweden was openly declar'd after there had been a seeming renewing of the Peace between them the Year before.

THIS War they say was concerted between the King of Poland, and his Czarish Majesty at this Interview, and the Measures agreed on; also how the same should be prosecuted, and some Mea∣sures too for the engaging the King of Denmark in the League; which proposal afterwards prov'd Successful, that is to say, Successful to bring the King of Denmark in, but Unsuccessful to all the three in the beginning of it, as will appear in the prosecution of the Story.

IT was now in the Year 1699, when the Czar had spent about eight Months at Home, and News was brought him to Muscow, that his Ple∣nipotenaries had concluded a Truce with the Turks at Carlowitz, where at the same time, the Peace between the Turks and the other Allies, (viz.) the Emperor, the King of Poland and the State of Ve∣nice had been concluded.

IT was suggested that the Czar desir'd that tho' the other Allies made a Treaty for 25 Years with the Turks, that yet his Czarish Majesty's part should be no more than a kind of Truce for two Years; and that he did this, that he might have time in those two Years to compleat the Fortifications of Asoph, Kaisikermeen, and other Places; and to build a power∣with ful Fleet of Men of War at Veroneze, with which at the end of the two Years, he doubted not to be able to dispute the Lordship of the Black Sea with the Grand Seignior, and to bring him to
grant a Passage for his Subjects through the Boss∣phors into the Levant Seas.

BUT this was a bluster which his Czarish Majesty had no Hand in, and 'tis apparent it was the Turks, who declin'd a Truce with Muscovy for any longer than two Years, purposing as it was apparent afterward that when they had got the Hungarian, Venetian and Polish War off of their Hands, they would fall upon the Czar with all their Forces for the Recovery of Asoph, &c. But the Czar, who was sensible how heavy such a War would be upon him, at least till he had brought his Army into all the new Measures he had de∣sign'd, apply'd immediately to the King of Great-Britain, who was Mediator of that Treaty to give Instructions to his Plenipotentiaries at the Treaty, to insist that the Peace with Muscovy, might have the same Duration of 25 Years, as the Peace with the Emperor had, which his Britanick Ma∣jesty did, and obtained it for him accordingly, which we shall see in a little time acknowledged under his Czarish Majesty's own Hand.

ACCORDINLY the Treaty was, I say, conclud∣ed at Carlowitz, and immediately the Czar began the War against the King of Sweden, for the same Day that the Peace with the Turks was proclaim'd at Muscovy, the same Day the War was proclaim'd against Sweden.

I HAVE nothing to do to enter here into a Dis∣quisition of the Justice of this War, or of the particular Causes moving the Czar to engage in it: That his Czarish Majesty was Agressor, that we do not dispute, one of the Causes assign'd was the Affront offer'd his Ambassadors at Riga, which considering that his Majesty himself was in Per∣son
in the Train, was speaking the Language of Princes a very great Indignity to his Czarish Ma∣jesty, and sufficient to demand Satisfaction upon.

IN Consequence however of having declar'd War, it behov'd his Majesty to make suitable Preparations, for that he knew that he had a vi∣gilant and gallant King to deal with, tho' but a young Man, and that he was the Head of a brave People, had a good Army of old, and disciplind Soldiers on Foot, led by some of the ablest Gene∣ral in Europe.

HOWEVER, as the King of Sweden was young, and far off, and that the Alliance was strong, even three-fold, his Czarish Majesty had room to expect he might have made a considerable Progress be∣fore any Number could be brought against him, that would be to any purpose.

THIS was began with the beginning of the Year 1700, and his Czarish Majesty drew toge∣ther such a Body of Men, that had they been well manag'd, would have been sufficient to havewith stood a much greater Force than those they were to deal with; but the desperate Bravery of the Swedes, and the exact Discipline of their Troops struck such a Terror in the Muscovites, that in a Word, there was no Opposing them, nor any bringing the Troops to keep their Array, when push'd with the violence of an Army of Men, that knew how to die, and how to Conquer, but had not yet been taught to fly.

THE Czar's Troops were wonderfully improv'd, and infinitely better than they us'd to be, but, were not yet come to a perfection suitable to the Work they had now before them; or to be a Match for the Swedes; but as they had been put into a Method of improving, yet farther we shall
find them in time be taught by the Swedes the way of fighting, till they came to be a Match for any Body, and at last learn'd to beat their Ma∣sters.

THUS the Romans by often beating the barba∣rous Nations, such as the Gauls, the Goths, the Vandals, and the Huns, taught them the Roman dis∣cipline, and manner of Fighting; till those Na∣tions return'd Instructed how to Fight, and beat their Teachers, not out of their Empire only, but even out of the World.

IN order to Introduce the History of this ter∣rible War in such a manner, as the Reader may be fully inform'd of every Action, and of the na∣ture and reason of things, as he goes along with the Fact; it will be necessary to look a little into the State of Affairs in those Northern Parts of the World in General, at that time, and how it came to pass that those three Powers, the Danes, the Poles, and the Muscovites broke at once with Swe∣den; and how their Interest and Forces came so to be disjointed and separated, that the Swedes had opportunity to attack them singly, and deprive them of the Capacity of Succouring or Assisting one another, and this I shall do as concisely as I can.

AT first his Czarish Majesty did not appear in this Quarrel; but the King of Poland, and the King of Denmark both at once, whether declaring War, or not declaring War, is not the Question, having an Alliance for that Purpose, fell both of them upon the King of Sweden: The King of Poland march'd in Person at the Head of a powerful and experienc'd Army of Saxons, out of Poland direct∣ly for Courland; from whence he continu'd his March, and the 28th of July, 1700 pass'd the
Dwina, enter'd into Livonia, the Dominions of the King of Sweden, and having beaten Count Welling the Swedish General, and the few Forces he had with him, advanc'd towards Riga, and in∣vested the Town, took the Dunamunder Schans, began to Bombard the Town, but was prevail'd, with to spare it, in respect to the Effects of the Foreign Merchants, as was given out, who were his Allies, and so Cantoning his Forces held the Town, as it were Blocked up, resolving to attack it in Form the beginning of the next Year.

AT the same time the King of Denmark ha∣ving attack'd the Duke of Holsteins Fort at Husum; and Bombarded Toningen, made no difficulty to speak openly of a Rupture with Sweden, and to ac∣knowledge that he was engag'd in Alliance with the King of Poland: The Czar all this while lay still, and made a seeming offer of continuing Peace with Swede; but civily demanded the Town and Port of Narva for the Convenience of having a Trade for his Subjects into the Baltick, which at that time was the great thing that the Muscovites desir'd.

WHEN the King of Denmark had openly de∣clar'd himself, and the King of Poland had actually attack'd Riga, then the Czar as had been concert∣ed between them at the enterview I mention'd, re∣solv'd to declare himself also, and accordingly as I have observ'd before; the War against Sweden, was Proclaim'd at Muscovy the same day that the Peace with the Turks was also Proclaimed.

BEFORE I go on here, I must pay a Debt which is the reward of Vertue, and which so much Merit demands from every faithful Histiorian, I mean a Debt to the Memory of that truly great and wise Man General Le Fort; a Man to whom
the Czar owes much of the true Notions of Vertue, and Honour, which he took in at his first Entrance upon his Government, who always gave him just and solid Ideas of things, and who prompted him to all the great Actions of his Life, and who died a little before these new Measures were taken.
