THIS great Man was really treated by the Czar according to his Merit, for he valu'd him a∣bove any of the greatest Men in his whole Em∣pire, and depended entirely upon his Council in the most difficult Cases that came before him; he was the principal Agent in all the Measures the Czar took in his Travels, was his first Ambassador as has been said in the great Embassy, was his Ple∣nipotentiary upon all Occasions of Treaty, and in a Word, he was so at the time of his Death, all which shewed that the Czar knew how to put a just value upon the Merit of those who he employ'd, and that he was a true Judge of Merit in general: I say, he was at the time of his Death chief General of his Armies, Admiral of all his Fleets, and his chief Minister: He had served the Muscovites along time, by which he had advanc'd himself to that degree of Honour, wherein he gli∣ter'd at his Death; the Czar had a particular Love and Esteem for him, and was pleas'd to give the World a demonstration of it by the Funeral which he bestow'd upon him; for Muscovy had ne∣ver seen so much Pomp before upon any occa∣sion all the military Ceremonies of the inter∣ment were the same as in these more civiliz'd Parts of Europe; the Drums and Colours were co∣ver'd with black, the Officers of three Regiments that preceeded the Hearse, had black Scars, and the Pikes garnish'd at the top with Knots of black Ribband; the Ensigns of Honour belonging to the deceas'd, were laid upon black Cushions em∣broider'd
with Gold; five Ministers preceeded the Corps, three of which were of the reform'd Religion, and two of the Ausburg Consession and one Stomnies preach'd the funeral Sermon, taking for his Text the Words of the 8th Chapter Eccle∣siastes, ver. 8. The Czar himself led the Regiments in deep Mourning.

THE place of this Gentleman was fill'd up, I cannot say it was supply'd by Major General Car∣lowitz, and afterwards that of General of the Army was made up, with the Duke de Croy, an Officer of great Experience, and who had served the Emperor many Campaigns against the Turks, but he could never come to be so well esteem'd or belov'd by the Muscovites themselves, and consequently not be so well followed.

THE War being thus resolv'd on, the Czar caus'd his Cavalry to draw together about Novo∣gorod, and particularly the Horse who had done such great Service at Aspoh were order'd by easy Marches, for it is a prodigious long way, to ad∣vance to Muscow, and thence to the Fronciers; his Infantry at the same time were drawn together from all Parts, and were computed to make very near 100000 Men, the Horse were reported to be 25000; but these were not all the Troops prepa∣red for that Expedition, for his Majesty had a considerable Body of Men, which were come to Novogorod, but were not at the Battle at Narva, be∣ing those who the Czar went in Person to bring for∣ward, which was the happy Reason that he was not in the Battle himself; which if he had, he would have run a very great Risque of being taken Pri∣soner by the Swedes.

ABOUT the close of the Month of August, his Czarish Majesty resolv'd upon the War with Sweden,
and in September, his Troops invested Narva, his Declaration of War having been in the mean time published to all the World to the Purpose following.

THAT altho' the Swede had assur'd the Czar that he would maintain Peace with him, and bind it by a strict Amity, and Correspondence; and for that Reason had sent a solemn Embassy to renew his Treaties, nevertheless his Czarish Majesty com∣plain'd and averred, that the King of Sweden had un∣derhand made use of several Intrigues to cross his Designs, and among others had propos'd to the King of Poland a League to act in Conjunction with him against the Czar; and those Intreagues were the Cause in part of the difficulties which happen∣ed at Constantinople in the Conclusion of the Peace between the Czar, and the Port, which his Czarish Majesty cannot forbare to make known to all the World, and particularly to all Christian Princes, in hopes they will acknowledge that he has been oblig'd to make use of those law∣ful Means, which he has in his Power for the Preservation of his Dominions; and that if he has declar'd War against Swedeland, 'its only to prevent her doing him any injury by such unjust Proceedings: The second Motive is, for that the Czar and his Predecessors have always held a strict Alliance with the Kings of Denmark, by Virtue of which, they were oblig'd to the mutual Assistance of each other, and reciprocally to re∣venge the Wrongs done to either; that the King of Sweden had Landed in Person in Zeeland with a strong Army, in the absence of the King of Den∣mark, and put his capital City, and his whole Kingdom in danger; that he had not only con∣strain'd the said Prince to make a disadvantageous Treaty with the Duke of Holstein, but had also excluded the King of Poland, his Czarish Majesty's
Friend and Confederate, that he might have an Opportunity to oppress and utterly Ruin him, that for these Reasons his Czarish Majesty found himself oblig'd to revenge the Wrongs done his Friends and Allies, and to break all the dange∣rous Practice against them.

AFTER this he sent to his Resident in Sweden to make known his Resolutions to that Court, and having his Levies ready, which are re∣ported to consist of five and twenty Thousand Horse, and seventy Thousand Foot, together with a Train of four Hundred and sixty Cannon and Mor∣tars; he took Post for Plesko, to take a review of his Forces; the command of which he had con∣ferr'd upon Aframaon Gosowitz, as General, who has under him Theodore Alexovitz Golovin, as General of the Horse, with General Adan Wyde, and several German Officers. Of these 'twas said that the Czar intended to send between twenty and thirty Thou∣sand Men to Re-inforce the King of Poland's Ar∣my, and that he intended to divide the rest in∣to two Bodies, one of which was to besiege Narva, and the other to Post themselves at some distance from thence, to hinder Relief from coming to the Town.

THE City of Nerva or Narva, stands upon the hither Side of the Gulph of Finland, toward the Pro∣vince of Ingria, upon a River of the same Name, which formerly separated Livonia from Muscovy: On the other Side of the River stands the Fortress of Ivanagrod, formerly built upon a sleep Rock that appears in the River, like a Peninsula; and which was thought impregnable till the Year 1617, that it was taken by Gustavs Adolphus, King of Sweden; at the Foot of this Rock lies a Town call'd Russian, or Muscovite Narva, the City in dispute: This
City is Inhabited by natural Muscovites, but Sub∣jects to the Crown of Sweden; the River of Narva▪ which rises out of the Lake of Peipus, and dis∣charges itself there into the Gulph of Finland, is very rapid, and there is a Precipiece in it about half a League above the City, where the Waters fall with an extraordinary violence and noise, and by accident produces a wonderful effect, for the Sun shining all the Morning upon the falling Water, causes the appearance of a Rainbow, as lovely as that which is seen in the Clouds; by reason of this Fall, the Merchants are forc'd to unload in that Place all their Goods which are sent from Pleskow and Dorpat to Narva, to be there Shipped off upon the Gulpb of Finland: The City of Nar∣va was built in 1213, by Waldemare II, King of Denmark, John Basilides Grand Duke of Muscovy took it in the Year 1558, from the Tuetonick Knights; but the Citizens of Revel, who then in vain implor'd the Succour of the grand Master Bernard Keltier, and Christian King of Denmark, threw themselves at length into the Arms of Eric the IV King of Sweden, who receiv'd them into his Protection upon certain Conditions, and coming to their Assistance, secured them from the destiny of o∣ther Cities, his Successor John III, retook Narva from the Muscovites in 1581, since which time the Swedes have continu'd in possession of it, notwithstanding all the Attempts of the Muscovites to regain it.

THUS the Swedes had at once three powerful Enemies upon their hands; Namely, the Danes, the Poles, and the Muscovites; the King of Poland would have sent 8000 Men, 4000 Foot, and 4000 Horse to assist the King of Denmark, but the E∣lector of Brandenburgh would not let them pass thro' his Country, being resolv'd to observe an
exact Neutrallity between all Parties, and they were afterwards beaten by the Lunenburhger, in passing thro' the lower Saxony. The Czar on his Side prepar'd to send 30000 Men into Lithu∣ania, to the assistance of the King of Poland, which however his Czarish Majesty could not yet do, things for a time, running very much against him, as we shall hear.

IT is not our business in writing of the Czar of Muscovy, to examine what happen'd in every part of this War, any farther than to bring things to the present Case in hand, and to introduce such incidents as relate to the Czar himself.

THE King of Sweden young in his Throne, and not yet above 18 Year old in Person, yet being encouraged by the united Squadrons of Great Bri∣tain and Holland, which appear'd, as (a kind of) Umpire in the Baltick; I say encourag'd by them, he embark'd an Army, and from Schonen joyning the Fleet of the Allies, with his own, comes directly to the sound, lands his Army in the Isle of Zeeland, and lies there ready to, ct ei∣ther one way or other, as the Treaty of Traven∣dal, which was then carrying on by Mediators should direct.

THE King of Denmark surpriz'd, and over∣power'd, hastens up the Peace, and so the King of Sweden, reimbark'd his Troops, and went back to Sweden, very little blood being shed in that Part of the War; this was the well known Treaty of Travendal, sign'd, and concluded the 18th of August.

WHILE these things were transacting, the King of Poland made his Fruitless attempt upon Riga, of which mention has been made already, I call it but an attempt, for altho' he invested the Place the 8th
of August, he spent two Months before it, without any considerable Progress and then left his Army; turning the Seige into a kind of Blockade, and so as if he had waited on purpose for the King of Sweden to come and beat him, did nothing till the next Spring.

IN September, as I have observ'd, the Troops of Muscovy began to move; it was a long step they had to take; but the Czar being at the Head of them, they made long Marches, and the 2d of November they joyn'd the Troops before Narva. Hither the Duke de Croy came, with a∣bout fifty Gentlemen, all Officers of Experience, and who came from Hungary, where they had serv'd the Emperor against the Turks; as soon as he arriv'd, the Czar who had invited him to his Service, gave him the command of the Siege; him∣self commanding the Army; the other Officers which he brought with him, were appointed Com∣mands in different Places, according to their parti∣cular Experience in Service.

THESE Gentlemen joyn'd to the foreign Of∣ficers, which his Czarish Majesty had entertain'd before, brought the Muscovite Troops into the best Method of prosecuting a Siege; caus'd them to En∣trench their Camp, as well with Circumvalations, as Contravallations, and had the Army been al∣low'd a Campaign or two for the Practice of those new Methods, the Swedes would not have had so cheap a Bargain of them; but as the Men might be said to be put out of their old way of Fight∣ing, and not well acquainted, or fully Exercised in the New, between both, they were more easily put into Confusion.

THIS will appear by the General Duke de Croy's Letter to the King of Poland, in which he applauds the readiness of the Muscovite Soldiers in their new Exercises, how regularly they began to Fire, how well they plyed their Artil∣lery, and how soon they hoped to make good Soldiers of them, which conforms with what I have observ'd, as above: The Letter is as follows.

“LIEUTENANT General Hallard arriv'd the 2d of this Month before Narva, where he found the Governor of Novogrod with 8000 Men entrench'd in a square Camp, 2500 Paces from the Town; the first of these two, has view'd the Place and the Fortifications, and has observ'd several Parts very imperfect, and among the rest, two Curtins which are in a ve∣ry bad Condition, which makes us presume, that this important Place cannot hold out long.”

“THE 4th of this Month, the Czar caus'd a Bridge of Boats to be laid over the River Nar∣va, and past it himself at the Head of 22 Ba∣talions, with a half Pike in his hand, and march'd somewhat farther; his Men much re∣semble ours, and are very well Arm'd and Dis∣ciplin'd, they have also 32 brass Field Pieces; 'tis a Pleasure to see the Muscovites fire them, and with what Diligence and Address they ply their Artillery; his Czarish Majesty causes his Men to keep good Orders, and an exact Dis∣cipline, which is the Reason that the Products of the Earth are carefully preserv'd; they are hard at Work in raising the Circumvallations; the besieg'd play very thick with their great Guns; nevertheless we have had but one Sol∣dier kill'd, and two wounded; the heavy Ar∣tillery
will arrive in the Camp within few Days. General Weyde is upon his March with a great Body of an Army, and Marshal General Gollowin who has above 50000 Men with him in Messap∣pa is to follow him with the same Number; and the Prince Loym with 11000, so that in a little time the Army will be about 200000 Men, with a noble Train of Attillery; as for the Lines of Communication his Czarish Majesty has drawn them himself, after he had view'd the Place.”

“A Swedish Officer who Deserted out of Nar∣va, surrendred himself, some few Days ago to his Czarish Majesty, who examin'd him, and we understood that Colonel Horn Commands in Narva, that the Garrison consists of 900 Foot, and 150 Horse, 400 Peasants, and 400 Burghers, that Lieutenant Colonel Stahl commanded the Artillery, and that it was in a good Condi∣tion, there are some Brass Pieces; but all the rest are Iron.”

IT is too well known to conceal it, that the King of Sweden rais'd this Siege with the fatal o∣verthrow of the Musocvite Army; but the Circum∣stances of that Action are so full of the Flattery of the Writers, in their Encomiums upon the King of Sweden, that they totally forget the Decency which the Merit of the Prince, he had at that time the better of demanded; and who command∣ed it from them in some small time after; in the mean time we shall not fail to do the Swedes ju∣stice on all occasions, as well as on this of the Battle of Narva.

HISTORY brings the King of Sweden from Carelscoon to Peruau in Livona, with an Army of
about 20000 Swedes, all choice Troops, about the beginning of August.

ON the 16th of Novem▪ the Swedish Army be∣gan their March towards Narva: The Czar, who foresaw that the King of Sweden, a daring and en∣terprising young Prince, would play the desperate Game, sent some strong Detachments to secure the Passes at Sillajoggi, and on the side of Dorpat; not doubting but that those Troops, which were at least 20000 Men, would give the Swedes some little stop at Places so easy to be defended, and at least Cause them to take a greater Compass about; in the mean time his Majesty went himself for Novogo∣rod, to bring up a Body of 40000 Men, who were by this time gotten thither, and to hasten their March.

BUT the King of Sweden, by a feint of pas∣sing by those Detachments, having gotten between them and their main Army, and thereby cut off their Retreat, caused a strong Body to Face a∣bout and attack them, which Surprize assisted to put them into disorder, so that they made but a faint Resistance, and were soon Defeated. This opened the way to the attack of the grand Army, which the Czar being absent, and those Troops defeated, were extreamly discourag'd.

HOWEVER the Duke de Croy, an old Soldier, and not at a loss what to do, had the Men he Com∣manded been equal to the Work, posted his Troops to all the Advantage the Ground would admit, and did all that the best General in the World could have done to animate them to a vi∣gorous Defence; he posted the Infantry in the Entrenchment, where they fir'd as in a cover'd Way, and a second Line to support them, and the Cavalry behind them to support the Foot,
with proper Intervals for them to Advance; but the Muscovite Foot wanted the Preence of their Master to animate them, which had been better than the 40000 Men he was gone to fetch; and tho' they stood their Ground bravely for several Hours, and made a terrible fire upon the Swedes, from behind their Entrenchment, by which a great many of the bravest of their Men were kill'd; yet the Swedes animated by the Presence of their King, and General Rebinder at the Head of eight Batallions, pouring fresh upon that part of the Muscovite Line, which had been twice before at∣tack'd, there was no resisting the desparate Fury of the Swedish Foot, led on by a general of as much Fame as any in their Army, who fought at the Head of them, like a Lyon, and was kill'd in the very Action, altho' after the Troops were entred: In short, the Line was forc'd in that Place, and the Foot enter'd, and the Pioneers immediately going to Work with the Shovel and Pick-ax, wide spaces were made in the Breast-work for the Horse to follow, who presently Charging in upon the Rear of the Muscovite Foot, which were in the other part of the Line, put all into Confusion, the second Line advancing were then Charg'd by the Victorious Swedes, and driven back upon the Cavalry, who by that Means were put into Dissorder, and had no room to come up to the Charge; and thus the Day was lost: The rest of the Infantry, being straightn'd within the Compass of their Camp, had no room to make an orderly Retreat, but were oblig'd to thro' down their Arms, and take Quarter. The Horse not able to resist the Torrent after their Infantry were thus Defeat∣ed, made off and Retreated in as good order as they could to Novogrod, in the way whether they
were met, and their Spirits a little encouraged by the Troops which were Advancing to their Assi∣stance, and by the Czar their Soveraign.

IT was observ'd, that the Czar shew'd not the least Disorder, either in his Countenance, or in his Con∣duct, when he had the News of the Defeat of his Ar∣my, or any Resentment at his flying Troops; but immediately apylyed himself to gather the scat∣ter'd Troops together, encourag'd the Men, spoke kindly to the Officers, and prepar'd to put a stop to the pursuit of the Conquerers, if their Success should prompt them to follow his Men, and to put all things in a posture of Defence, in Case the King of Sweden should undertake any new Enterprise, or attempt to push farther into the Country.

BUT the Swedes had not their Victory so cheap neither, as to be in Condition for any far∣ther attempt at that time of the Year. They had by their own Confession lost above 3000 Men, besides the wounded, among which were a great many brave Officers, as General Rublinghen, Re∣binder, and several others; add to this, the King of Sweden had the Winter Season before him, which was already far Advanc'd; and as the Snows and Frosts were not yet come in, the ways were unpassable, and no Magazines erected for providing the Army with Forage or Provisi∣ons; so that he contented himself with having relieved the Town, and beaten the Army, as he might very well.

THE Czar advancing to Peskow within twelve Leagues of Narva, made a stand there, to give his Men opportunity to return to their Colours, which many did, who it was, thought had been lost, and here his Czarish Majesty form'd a new Army,
in order to dispute the Ground with the Swedes, if they had offer'd to Advance.

BUT the King of Sweden, as I observ'd, having reliev'd Narva, and gain'd a compleat Victory, put his Troops into Quarters of Refreshment for the Season, and contented himself with boasting of what great things he would do in the Czar's Dominions the next Year, and to give those Ga∣sconades an Appearance of reality, he sent express Orders to Sweden to send over into Livonia, with the first of the Spring, that is, as soon as the Seas were open again, his whole remaining Army, in the room of which they were order'd to make new Levies for the common Guard of their Coun∣try; these Forces were said to consist of about 12000 Foot, and 6000 Horse, and Dragoons, but Heaven and his own Fate found the King of Swe∣den other Work than to enter Muscovy, or to Pro∣secute his Revenge at that time.

IT cannot be denyed, that had, the King of Sweden, when those Forces did arrive push'd the Advantages, which his late Victory had put into his Hand, and persued his Revenge singly against Muscovy, the Czar's Troops, tho' Numerous, be∣ing nothing like to what we find them to be since, or as we may say to what the King of Swe∣den has taught them to be since, he might with a victorious Army of 40000 Men, have bid fair for the Ruin of the Czar, and of all his great Designs; but just Heaven, who knew what a furious inexo∣rable Enemy, the Swede at that time was, tyed up his Hands, till the Czar learnt how to Conquer his Conqueror, and to beat him into a better Knowledge of himself; making him pay for a like desperate Attempt upon the Muscovites, with the loss of the Honour of all his former Victories,
and of two such Armies as he never saw himself Master of afterwards, of all which in his order.

SUCCESS had now made the King of Sweden famous, I will not say it had made him insolent, because a Historian should write in Temper, e∣ven of those Actions, which were not perform'd in Temper, and treat all Sides with an impartial Respect.

THE King of Sweden had also another Call, from the pursuit of his Victory at Narva, and this was the attempt of the Saxons upon the o∣ther side of Livonia, where the King of Poland had, as I said, invested Riga, taken the Dunamun∣der Schans, and had Quartered his Troops in such a manner, as to hold the said City of Riga in a manner block'd up.

THE Saxons were esteem'd by the Swedes a more Soldierly Enemy, than the Muscovites, and at that time, perhaps they were so, but thus it is when Hea∣ven appoints to raise a young King to a pitch of Glory beyond himself; the Saxons at Riga real∣ly behav'd worse a great deal than the Musco∣vites at Narva, and were so shamefully beaten in every Action, and even without Action, that there could nothing be said for them.

THE Muscovite Army posted in their En∣trenchments, and encumber'd with the Lines, and Circumvallations of a Camp, did their Duty till being forc'd in one part, they were driven upon one another and Defeated, meerly for want of Field room, for their Cavalry to act in; for it cannot be doubted, that had the Muscovite Calvalry; which were at least 25000 Horse and Dragoons, had room to act, and to have fallen in, and sur∣rounded the Swedes, as by their Number they were able to have done, the Swedes would have paid
much dearer for their Victory, than they did, if perhaps they had not been soundly beaten.

BUT the Saxons play'd the Poltrons in such an egregious manner, as made even their own King asham'd of them; and as encourag'd the Swedes to push into the Heart of Poland, at that time wretchedly divided into factions and Parties, pro∣secuting mortal Feuds against one another, with such an implacable Violence, that they chose to Sacrifice their Country to the common E∣nemy, and bring a foreign War into their own Bowels, rather than not pursue their private Feuds and Family Quarrels, to the Destruction of one another, and at last to the Ruin of their King and their Country; which they brought into an entire Subjection to the tyrannical Conqueror, the King of Sweden.

I AM oblig'd to give an Account here of the Progress of the War in Poland, because the King of Sweden; having by the impetuosity of his Vi∣ctory brought the King of Poland to the utmost Distress, Reason and Policy of State, as well as the natural Generosity of Friendship, brought his Czarish Majesty into the War, and made Poland the Field, or Seat of the affair, as well between the Czar, of Muscovy, and the King of Sweden, as between the King of Poland, and the King of Sweden, and the King of Sweden, not thinking fit to seek his Enemy, the Czar at his capital City of Muscow, as he had given out he would; his Czarish Majesty was oblig'd to seek him the King of Sweden out, even where he was to be found; as we shall see he did effectually in the Prosecution of this War. This Defeat of the Saxons was a∣bout the beginning of July 1701, by which means the King of Sweden got possession of the Dutchy
of Courland, where in the Castle of Mittau, he seized the whole Magazine of Arms and Ammu∣nition belonging to, and laid up for the King of Poland's Army, valued at 300000 Crowns, and afterwards retook the Fort of Dunamunder, where he found the Train of Artillery of the same Ar∣my, consisting of 90 Pieces of Brass Cannon for Battery, and 20 brass Mortars, which was a most agreeable Booty to a Prince just entring upon a War against two such Potent Nations, as the Muscovites and the Poles.

BUT leaving the King of Sweden, guided by his ill Fate to pursue and embarrass himself in the Affairs of Poland, where first he will cloth himself with Glory and load himself with Lawrels, which must be all taken from him in one Day, by the more glorious Conqueror, the Czar; I say, leaving him there to pursue his Fate, and omit∣ting the only offer that he will ever have of ruin∣ing his first Enemy the Czar of Muscovy, and pushing his Victory in its proper time, which if he had done, the Czar had perhaps never been able to stand before him: I must now go back to his Czarish Majesty's conduct after this capital Blow given to his Forces before Narva.

I HAVE mention'd how his Czarish Majesty as if unconcern'd at the surprizing News, ap∣ply'd himself to comfort and encourage his Offi∣cers and Soldiers, his Cavalry had not really suffer'd much, his Infantry indeed was ruin'd and gone; but every Body knows foot Soldiers are pretty cheap in Muscovy, where the Czar being absolute Monarch, commands as many of his Peo∣ple to the Wars as he pleases.

HOWEVR, this was not his Majesty's case now, for instead of commanding out such and such Num∣bers of Men, for the Summer Service, and let∣ting them go Home again when the Campaign was over, perhaps, calling another Hundred Thousand out the next Year, who never saw the Field or an Enemy before, His Czarish Majesty now took a new Course; he caus'd the Drums to beat for Voluntiers over all his vast Em∣pire, telling the People their Advantages, how they should be new Cloathed, that they should be duly Paid as Gentlemen Soldiers; and that in their due Order, and as they merited by their Behavi∣our, they should be, Prefer'd and Rewarded; so that every Foot Soldier was capable of being not a Captain only, but a General, if he behaved well in his Post.

THIS which was a new Thing in Muscovy, went a great way, and caus'd a vast Number of Men to come in and List, who were immediately encouraged with half a Ruble advance Money, and Weekly Pay, besides sufficient to subsist them, and make them live Easy and Pleasant; besides this▪ his Majesty caus'd all the Boyars or Nobility to end a certain Number of Men, in proportion to the Number of Servants which they kept, and to the Revenue of their Estates.

BY this means, his Czarish Majesty had his Ar∣my prefently full, so that before the next Cam∣paign, he had near 120000 New listed Men ready raised, whom he caus'd to be form'd into Regi∣ments after the manner of Europe; some of four Baltalions, some of two Battalions, and some of but one Battalion, as he found Cause.

AS for the Strelitzes, the Czar had now supprest the very Name, and as much as possible desir'd to rase out the very Memory of them from the Earth; in their Room his Majesty form'd seve∣ral new Reigments of select choice Men; most of them old Soldiers, and a great many of them Germans, or Foreigners of other Nations, tho' none of them were admitted but such as had serv'd Abroad in some of the Wars, either on the Danube or the Rhine.

AS the Czar had leisure thus to raise this Ar∣my; so the King of Sweden being fully engag'd in pursuing the King of Poland, as a particular Enemy, gave his Czarish Majesty full Leisure to make all his new Army, what they never could be said to be before; that is, not only Men, but Sol∣diers, for they had leisure to be fully acquainted with their Arms, and to understand how to do their Exercise after the German method by beat of Drum: He posted them also in great Bodies upon the Frontiers of Livonia, where, tho' the Swedes behav'd with their wanted Bravery and oftentimes were too hard for them; yet in their turn they beat the Swedes too, and oftentimes ut whole Parties of them in Pieces; by which they began to be enured to the War, acquainted them∣selves with the New manner of Fighting; learn'd to look a bold Enemy in the Face, and to find that the Swedes were not invulnerable or invincible: In a Word, they learn't by frequent fighting the Swedes, not to be so much afraid of them, as usual, and thus if they did not always beat the Swedes; yet they continually harrass'd them, and wasted their Numbers, which the Swedes not being easily Re∣ruited with Numbers as the Muscovites were, and the King of Sweden pushing his Resolution of de∣posing
King Augustus with such vigour, that he as it were neglected his own Subjects of Livonia: The Czar improving in the mean time every op∣portunity, and keeping his Troops full, send∣ing constant Supplies of fresh Men to make up the Loss of those that were kill'd, or disabled; his Reigments in Livonia became in two or three Year equal with the Swedes in goodness of the , and infinitely Superiour to them in Num∣r, till the Swedes came to be beaten oftentimes, Hand to Hand with equal Numbers, were push'd from Post to Post, and at last push'd out of the whole Province, as we shall see its in Course.

AT the same time the Troubles of Lithania ope'd a Door for the two Enemies, the Muscovites and the Swedes to enter on that Side. The two great Families of Saphiea and Oginski, had brought their Breach, which was at first but a private Quarrel, to be an open War: Oginski was sup∣ported by the King of Poland, and Saphiea call'd in the King of Sweden to his Succour, and he (the King of Sweden) espous'd the Saphiea's, and made them Superiour to Oginski and his Party; so Ogin∣ski finding the King of Poland not able to sup∣port him, having his handful of the Swedes, he call'd in the Muscovites to his aid; his Czarish Ma∣jesty taking him into his Protection, did not assist him with a handful of Men, as it were on purpose to prolong the War, but at two or three times sent him at least 30000 Men; so that tho' the Swedes had many times the better of him too, yet he always maintain'd himself in the Field, till all went to wreck, and King Augustus himself was Forc'd to abandon them all, and quit the Crown, of which in its Place.

THESE Transactions kept the World in sus∣pence three or four Years, during which time, the Muscovite Troops gain'd every Day new Expe∣rience, and new Reputation in the World, being by the Czar's particular Direction all fill'd, not only with German Officers, but having among them abundance of German, Polish, and other fo∣reign Soldiers, most of them Men of Service, and who had been fully acquainted with the War be∣fore they were entertain'd and as his Czarish Ma∣jesty gave very good Encouragement to all Strangers, who Listed in his Troops, he had a great many Deserters, even from the Swedish Troops themselves.

BUT this was not all, for as he soon after this, Conquer'd whole Provinces from the King of Sweden, and had occasion to act with his Armies in several parts of the Empire, as in Pomeren in the Dutchy of Mecklemburgh in Holstein, and in Den∣mark; so he fail'd not of entertaining all the a∣ble Experience'd Soldiers he could get in all those Countries; by which means many of his Regi∣ments, and particularly his Guards were made up of the choicest Men all that part of the World could affrod: As for the Provinces conquer'd from Swe∣den, the Czar has rais'd all the Men that it was possible to get in Livonia, and in Finland, of whom he has in his Army at this time several whole Regiments; particularly of Finlanders, who being some of the best, the boldest, and most hardy Men of all the King of Sweden's Dominions, are now the Czar's proper Subjects, and the last levey the Czar's Generals made there, was of 3500 Men, which I am told are form'd into one Regiment, and call'd the Royal Finlanders; but 'tis added that the Czar chuses to employ that Regiment in the
remoter part of his Country against the Turks, least when they come to act against their old Master the King of Sweden, they should play Booty, and go over to his Side.

I NEED give no farther Account, either why, or how the Muscovite Troops came to be what we see they are; Namely, equal to other Nations in the Field; but I may take the liberty to add, that if the Muscovite Troops come to be as good as the Swedes, or other Neighbouring Nations; it must be allowed, that their Numbers are so far Superior to them, that there will be no room for the Fu∣ture for that Contempt, with which those Nations have formerly look'd on the Russian Empire.

IT is a speculation worthy the best and greatest Polititians of Europe, how much the masculine Genius of one Prince, may alter the Circumstances not of his own Subjects only, but of all the Nations in the World that are any way influence'd by them; for as they are of Weight in the Ballance of the Nations, so the Interest of the Neighbouring Nations, are more or less concern'd to Support, or Suppress them.

THE Empire of the Czar of Muscovy, extend∣ed as it is from the North to the South, for the length of 2500 Miles, that is to say, from the North Sea, bounding the Coast of the Rssian Laponia, in the Latitude of 72 or from the extream Part of Nova Zembla, in the Latitude of 81, to the Coasts of Carakathay, and the Desarts of the Calumuck Tarters, even to the Caspian Sea is by the Scituation so plac'd, as to be effectually cover'd from all man∣ner of Enemies, either on the East, the North, or the South, and has nothing to regard, but the West∣stern side of its Dominion.

I CAN liken the situation of the Czar of Mus∣covy's Dominion to nothing so well, as to a well chosen strong Encampment, plac'd in a piece of Ground every way inaccessible, but in the Front, and the Front so Fortify'd, as not to be easily attack'd, for Example, the North Ocean is on its Right, the River Wolga, and the Desarts of Tar∣tary on its Left: The unpassable Wast from the River Oby to China in its whole Reer, and no∣thing lying open, but its Front.

THIS Front is guarded on its Right Wing, by the Bothnick Gulph, and the Gulph of Finland, with inaccessible Shores, and a multitude of well fortify'd Ports from Abbo round the latter Gulph, by Wyburg, Cronsloot, Petersbourgh, Narva, and Re∣vel, to Riga, and the Shores of Courland, with the Dutchy of Courland in Possession, as an Out-work, or advanc'd Bastion in a Town, to keep off an E∣nemy from the Body of the Place.

ALL the Left Wing of this prodigious extend∣ed Line, is cover'd with the Caspian Sea, the De∣sarts of Circassia, the Palus-Meotis, and the rapid Boristhenes, till we come to the Russian Ukrania which lyes again like a strong Out-work, guard∣ed with a Hundred Thousand faithful Cossacks, the terror of the Tartars, and a sufficient De∣fence against their Incursions, which they formerly made that way into the Heart of Muscovy.

ALL the middle of this immense Front is bordered by Poland, a Nation so constantly em∣broil'd with itself▪ as to be formidable to no Bo∣dy; and yet a Nation, that as it is not considerable enough to be a terror to Muscovy, or offer the Czar any uneasiness on their own Account, so they are yet too considerable to be forc'd, to suffer an Invasion of Muscovy, thro' their Country; so that
upon the whole, there seems to be no Nation cap∣able of penetrating Into Muscovy, but the Swedes;, and how the Cafe stands on that Side, will be seen in the whole Course of this History.

ON the other Hand, the powerful Czar of Muscovy, if once his Army is prepar'd as I have observ'd, to come Hand to Handwith any of the Nations that lye thus on its Front, is able to Sally out by all these ways, and will be much Superi∣or to them, on Account of the numberless Mul∣titude of his People, of whom he is able to raise as many Thousands, as some of his Neighbours can Hundreds, and that with less Expence than any of them.

BUT I return to the Field of Afion, as the Muscovites were call'd into Litbuania to assist the Sieur Oginski against the Saphieas, and the Swedes; so by this time the King of Poland having lost the Battle of Cracow, and the King of Sweden de∣claring his Resolution to Dethrone him, and as it appear'd, being Powerful enough to bring it to pass, calls aloud to his Czarish Majesty to come to his Assistance also.

THE Czar too well understood his Business, not to make his just Advantage of the obstinate warmth of his Enemy the King of Sweden, in pur∣suit of the King of Poland; and therefore while that Monarch, who was now with his whole Ar∣my, as is said, gotten the height of Cracow, and where his Victory over the King of Poland, had fil∣l'd his Head with new Projects, for reduction of the whole Country, and deposing the King; his Czarish Majest, first sending 20000 to the aid of Oginski in Lithunia, thereby to keep the Swedish Troops on that Side employ'd; and after having caus'd another Army to advance towards Great Po∣land,
to be ready to Succour King Augustus, taking the advantage of the Absence of the King of Sweden, and his following his imaginary good Portune, he caus' Fan Army of 60000 Foot, all Regular, and Regimented Troops, form'd after the new Model, as above, and Commanded by ex∣perienc'd Generals, as well as other Officers, most Foreigners, and 20000 Horse to enter Livonia, and another Army of 30000 foot, and 10000 Horse at the same time to enter Ingria, or Ingermandland, a Province beyond Livonia Eastward, and joyning to Finland; and the only way by which any Troops from that Side of Sweden, call'd Finland, could come by Land to the Succour of the Livo∣nians.

HERE his Gzarish Majesty made himself full Amends, and had his compleat Revenge of the Swedes, for the Loss sustain'd at the Battle of Narvaa; for Prince Czeremet, who Commanded this Army, enter'd Livonia unresisted, and having Ravag'd all the easter Part, call'd Esthonia, as far as Dorpat, met with very little, if any op∣pofition; at length the Swedish General Slipping∣back, having gotten together an Army of about Ten Thousand Men, all Swedes and old Soldiers, and presuming upon the good Fortune of Narva, and the usual contempt they had for the Muscovite Troops, oppos'd himself to the Prince; but he paid for his Ignorance and Rashness, by the entire Defeat of his whole Army, who were over-thrown, and almost all cut in pieces by the Muscovites.

IT is true, the Swedes fought like Lyons, or like Furies rather, and that in the Fight they push'd whole Brigades of the Muscovite Infantry, put them into Confusion, and in that Confusion, they
flaughter'd many of them; and this is doing the Swedish valour Justice, for indeed they were over∣come by meer Numbers.

BUT just the same they would have said of the King of Sweden at the Battle of Narva, if he had been repulsed, that having an Army of 100000 Men to deal with, his Men were overlay'd by the innumerable Multitudes of their Enemies; that they Fought like Lyons, but what could Men do, who had an Army of ix to one to deal with? That Valour gave way at last to Number, and the like, and had the Muscovite Army had Field room in that Action at Narva, and not been Coup'd up in a Camp, where the foremost Troops being put into disorder, the rest were driven one upon another, and made the Instruments of their own Ruins; I say, had not this been the Case, 'tis very like the Swedes had talk'd of the Action at Narva, as they do now of that near Dorpat.

BUT 'tis an answerable return, which is made to this; what an Unsoldierly rashness was it for General Slippenback, to suffer himself to be at∣tack'd, or pretend to Fight with 10000 Men, a∣gainst 60000? for so many the Swedes say the Muscovites were; nay, and if it be true, that as they say, General Slippenback was not above 6000 the presumption was the greater for Rashness, and Temerity in Actons of War, are not to be call'd Valour and Bravery, but Madness and Folly.

BUT to come to the Fact, it was from the Be∣ginning of May, 1702, that the Russians were known to be drawing together; above 70000 Men, lay about Plskow and the Frontiers of the Czar's Dominions, and were encreasing every Day: Now had the King of Sweden, thought his Province of Livonia worth securing, or had
he not flattered himself, that the Russians would not dare to appear in the Field, but that they would be frighted with the Names of the Swedes; that the Scripture Prophesie was to be fulfilled in Livo∣nia, in favour of his Men, That One should Chasfe a Thousand, and Two put ten Thousand to flight: I say, had he not filled his Head with the most despica∣ble Opinion of the Russians, he would never have left such a Province as Livonia to be devour∣ed, and such gallant Troops as the Swedes really were, to be cut in pieces in small Bodies for want of Succour; while he was pursuing his Revenge, and talking upon him the giving a King too, and pulling down a King from the Throne of his Neighbour, the Kingdom of Poland.

BUT thus it was, the Russian Army entred Li∣vonia Commanded by the Prince of Czeremetoff, about the beginning of July. They were not ignorant that the Swedish General Slippenback, lay encamp'd between Dorpat, and Revel, tho' the Prince had not any Account of his Numbers, and if he had, itcould not be depended upon, be∣cause he might be suppos'd to receive Additions every Day from Revel, and Riga, which were in his Reer, and from the Swedish General Myerfield in Lithuania: For this Reason the Prince did not undertake any Siege, resolving to make War in the open Field, and first seek out and fight his Enemy, that he might not have the same Game to Play, as had been fatally play'd at Narva.

To this purpose the Prince march'd on, and the 16th of July, having an Account that the Swedes march'd towards him, he advanc'd di∣rectly forward: The Swedish, General hearing what disparity of Numbers he had to engage with, halted at a Village call'd Stagnitz on the River
Emback, as if he had resolv'd to expect the Rus∣sians There; and so far was he from being sensible of the odds there was between them, that he did not so much as offer to Entrench; but with an Ar∣rogance inimitable, kept his Situation, till the Russians came in view, being in full March to attack him, and in admirable Order of Battle: A little surpris'd with the Sight, he then, when it was too late, put his Men in March, and repass'd the River upon two Bridges, breaking the Bridges behind him; but this only serv'd to bring him to a Ne∣cessity of Fighting afterwards, in a Situation not more Advantagious than the first; for the Russians passing also the River at some distance; and be∣ing drawn up again as before, mov'd directly to∣wards them. Then it was the Swedish General boldly Fac'd about, and resolv'd to Fight. The oonsequence of which was, his being over-thrown, and entirely defeated, and all his Infantry cut in pieces, as I have said; tho' not till after an ob∣stinate and bloody Fight, which lasted almost a whole Day.

NOW that I may not be Partial in the Rela∣tion of this Action, I shall give their own Ac∣count, which they sent to all the Courts of Europe, and which excepting the smallness of their own Number kill'd, we are content to refer to, which is as follows,

UPON July 6, we say the Swedes receiv'd Intelli∣gence, that the muscovites were enter'd into Livo∣nia with a numerous Army, and were advanc'd as far as Crosfort; the next Day our avant Couriers being repuls'd to our Guards, General Slippenback detach'd 300 Horse to observe the Enemy: This Party upon the 18th in the Morning, met with a Body of a 1000 Muscovites, which they attack'd,
and drove to the Body of their Army, but the Swedish Cavalry being surpris'd at the sight of such a numerous Host, durst not make any long stay, but retreated in great Confusion; so that being pursu'd by the Enemy, we lost Major Rose, and some other Officers, who were slain; the Major General being inform'd of what had hap∣pen'd, rod himself to view the Enemy's Army, and presently perceiving they had a design to sur∣round his small Body; he judg'd it convenient by the Advice of a Council of War, to crost the Ri∣ver of Emback, to prevent their Design; which was done in view of the Enemy, and in very good order over two Bridges that were broken, so soon as our Men were over; but the River being then very low, and the Enemy making use of several Pontons to waft over their Artillery, 'twas im∣possible to prevent their passing with the rest of their Army; so that General Slippenback find∣ing that a great Number of the Enemy were al∣ready got on our Side, could not avoid coming to a Battle; all the Advantage at the beginning was on our Side; we beat the Enemy every where, we pursu'd them above a German Mile; we took from them six pieces of Cannon, part of their Baggage, and some Colours, and at length we press'd so hard upon 'em, that they threw them∣selves into the River; but the rest of their Army asham'd to fee their Fellows fly, and mad to be beaten by such a small Number of Men, Fac'd about of a sudden, and put the Finland Cavalry into such disorder, that they fell foul upon the Infantry, and betook themselves to flight, with∣out any possibility of being rally'd, so that our Artillery, as well as that which we had taken, fell
into the Enemies Power, and our Infantry after a tout ressistance was almost cut in pieces: This Action began about six in the Morning, and lasted for ten Hours together; our General would fain have rally'd them again, and posted us at Helmer, but finding it impossible to stop the Horse that were fled and dispers'd, and being no longer a∣ble to stand his Ground with the remains of his Infantry, he was constrain'd to retreat to Perna.

UPON this Occasion, the Swedes loft 7 Captains, 30 Lieutenants, 11 Ensigns, and 25 Subalterns; 37 Drums, and 1916 common Soldiers; we know indeed that the Loss of the Muscovites was much greater, but it was hardly preceptible, by reason of their Multitude: After this Expedition the Muscovites were about to have march'd back, but they were hardly arriv'd at the Lake of Peipus, when they receiv'd Orders to return, and put all Livonia to Fire and Sword, which they have done in a most cruel manner, till within some Leagues of Riga.

THIS is their own Account in which the im∣partial Reader will certainly conclude, that had the Muscovites Number been so great, and theirs so small, as they would represent them, it could scarce be possible that they could defend them∣selves ten Hours, and be Defeated at last too; having no Shelter, no Retreat, no Entrenchments or Defences at all, but their Arms.

BUT the Sum of the Case was, and that appears by the Accounts publish'd at that time, that the Swedes were no lest than ten Thousand Men, o∣thers lay fourteen Thousand, and the publick Papers printed at that Time, as also by Letters from Dantzick, and from Riga at the same time,
both to London, and to Holland, give this Account in few Words, viz. “That Prince Czeremet the Muscovite General at the Head of a numerous Army, had entirely defeated General Slippen∣back, with an Army of 10000 Swedes, not Far from Dorpat, and that the Swedish General with a few Horse, who desperately broke thro' the Russian Army had escaped; all the rest of the Army having been cut in pieces after a gallant Resistance, and a Fight, Which lasted from eight a-Clock in the Morning, to seven a-Clock at Night.”

THE last of these Accounts was certainly well grounded, with this Exception only, that the Swedes were not all cut in pieces, about 1200 be∣ing taken Prisoners, with all their Baggage, Can∣non, Tents and Ammunition.

BUT the particular Reason why I publish here their own Account of this Fight, is to repeat what I have so often mention'd, (viz.) of the dif∣ference between the Russian Soldiers now, and what they were formerly; for now the Swedes found, that after they had broke them several times by the Fury of their Charge, and put them into Confusion, yet that they ralled again by the skill and dexterity of their Officers, and by the aptness, and experience of their Soldiers, and that they returned again to the Charge, after they had been push'd into Disorder; which was what the Swedes did not expect to find among them, and this was the ruin of the Swedish Army.

AFTER this Action, the State of the War took a new Turn; the Swedes were defeated upon all Oc∣casions, and that not only an Livonia, but in Lithu∣ani also; Oginski and his Friends, supported by the Troops the Gzar had sent him, routed the Swedes
twice in a Weeks time, killing 400, and taking 800 Prisoners, in one Action, and killing 1000, and ta∣king 700 in the second Action.

AFTER Prince Gzeremet had thus clear'd the Field of his Enemy, he laid wast the whole Province., as a∣bove; the Reason was, that he found them universal∣ly averse to Submit, even when subdued; and that upon an order from the King of Sweden to the Country, to take Arms, they did so, and fell up∣on his Men wherever they found them.

THIS was what his Czarish Majety does not delight in, nor does he suffer his Troops to Practice it in the other Countries of his Conquests; but he had been treated with such personal Indignity by the King of Sweden on all Occasions, that he found himself oblig'd to shew his Resentment; and on the other Hand he was represented by the Swedes themselves, as an Enemy so contemptible, that no Rules of Honour, or Justice were to be obser∣ved with him; and it behov'd his Czarish Majesty on both these Accounts, to let the Subjects of Swe∣den know, that he was in a Condition to make himself be better us'd, and that they might have Reason to fear him, instead of insulting him.

THERE was also another Reason for this Severi∣ty, viz. that the great Towns of Livonia under whose Protection, the Swedish Forces sheltered, might not be able to subsist them; and also that his Ene∣mies might not fill their Magazines in Courland, and in Lithuania out of the fruitful Provinces of Livonia, and Eastonia.

AFTER this Execution, the Prince sat down be∣fore Dorpat with his whole Army, keeping at the same time great Detachments of Horse to scour the Country to the Gates of Pera, and even to Ri∣ga, to prevent the Swedes gatheringany Number of
Troops into a Body together, to attempt to Re∣lieve the Place.

WHILE these things went on thus prospe∣rously in Livonia, the Russian Army in Ingria were no less Successful, the Fortress of Skansterny after a vigorous Attack was surrender'd to the Muscovites, and the Muscovite General—Slippenbach with a strong Body of an Army being sent to the Edge of Finland, landed not far from Wyburgh with 24000 Men, in 400 Transport Vessels, and in a plain Field gave Battle to the Swedish Forces under Gene∣ral Crooniort, and entirely defeated them, the Swedish General, and a few of his Men making their Retreat, and escap'd to Wyburg.
THUS the whole Province of Ingermania or In∣gria fell into his Czarish Majesty's hand, and his Troops made daily Excursions upon the Enemy in Finland itself (viz.) first Thus
THE particulars of this Action are thus diver∣sly related, first thus.

IN the mean time the Muscovites get Ground in these Parts having lately obtain'd very considera∣ble Advantages over a volant Camp of the Swedes commanded by General Crooniort in those Quarters, the Muscovites, with a Body of 25000 Men, being conducted through by, and impracticable ways, fell upon the Swedes when least expected, and after a bloody Fight, which lasted from six in the Morn∣ing till two in the Afternoon, being much Supe∣rior in Number, put the Swedes to the Rout; how∣ever 'tis said that the Swedish General after a vi∣gorous Resistance, made good his Retreat to Wy∣burg: There is since publish'd a more exact Rela∣tion of this Encounter between the Swedes and Muscovites, which gives the following Account,
(viz.) that General Crooniort having Advice, that the Muscovites had fram'd a Design utterly to destroy his small Army, and for that end had embark'd a great Number of Troops, in 8 Frigats, 400 small Transport Vessels, and two great Floating Machines, whereon Batteries were plac'd, design∣ing to Cannonade the Enemy with their Fleet, while the rest of their Army fell upon them by Land; the Major General thereupon, sent out Parties to observe the Motions of the Muscovites; one whereof return'd towards Morning, and brought Advice that they had discover'd some of their Troops within an hours March of the Swedes Out-guards, who immediately prepar'd to receive them; the Russians contrary to their Expectati∣ons finding the Swedes in a readiness, drew back in order to be joyn'd with more Troops, not far behind; which they had no sooner done, but they return'd and Charg'd the Swedes with great vigour; who, tho' but a handful as it were, defended themselves very well, till General Crooniort came up to them with a Reinforcement of Horse and Foot; but the Pass of Susterback, where the Swedes were posted, being too narrow for the Horse to do any Service, the Foot were oblig'd to give way to the Superiour Numbers of their Enemies, who press'd them close at the Heels, and did not fail to make the best of their Advantage; but the Swedish Horse coming up again, put a stop to their Progress; the Swedish General began then to discover from the great clouds of Dust that arose in several Places, that the rest of the Muscovite's Army was coming up with their Cannon, and not doubting but they were infinitely stronger then himself: His Army not exceeding 4000 Men, the General thought it ad∣viseable to order the Foot to draw off with the Can∣non
and Carriages to Wyburg, on which the Enemy seem'd to have an Eye; and the rather because the General discover'd part of their Troops marching along the Sea side, to get behind him; the Foot retir'd in excellent order, while the General taking the Advantage of the Ground with the Cavalry alone, kept the Enemy in play (with a Bravery not to be paralell'd) four Hours toge∣ther, when the Muscovites retir'd, but threaten'd to return in a short time: By a List of the Prisoners taken and carryed away by the Muscovites upon this incursion, there are three Colonels, two Majors, eighteen Captains, Twenty-five Lieutenants, three Cornets, seventeen Ensigns; a Thousand Soldiers, and a great Number of other Persons of both Sexes.

HERE his Czarish Majesty contriv'd the Scheme, and actually laid the Foundation of a new For∣tress at the Entrance of the Nye or Neva, the In∣let, which opens the Communication between the Lake Ladoga, and the Baltick; which Fortress he called Croonslot and farther up his Majesty has begun to build a Town, which he has call'd after his own Name Petersburgh, or according to some St. Petersburgh.

THIS was at first but a small Place, but since is become a Royal City, and at present contains, besides publick Edifices, Churches, and a Magni∣ficient Pallace, not yet quite finish'd above Thirty Thousand Houses.

HIS Czarish Majesty having now, as has been alledg'd Dispeopled the populous Provinces of Li∣vonia and Ingria, made the poor People some a∣mends by a Proclamation, or Placart, inviting all the Families, not of those Countries, but of
all other Countries to come and Settle in his Do∣minions, and was to the purpose following, (viz.)

TO Invite all Sorts of Artificers, Workmen, and People using Manufactures, and other Per∣sons professing Trades and Sciences, to come and Settle in his Dominions; promising them, that so soon as they arriv'd upon the Frontiers, they shall be conducted where they please to Settle; that they shall have the free Exercise of their Religion, and the convenience of Churches; that they shall have the Liberty to employ themselves in what∣soever they shall think most for their Advantage, without being Subject to any Duties, Offices or Imposts: That as for those who shall find them∣selves capable to undertake any Trade, and shall not have where withal to follow it, his Majesty promises to supply them with Money out of his Treasury, without any Interest; and Lastly, as are at any time unwilling to stay in his Domi∣nions, shall have Licenses to depart, and at their first Request shall be conducted at the Czar's ex∣pences to the Frontiers, or to any Sea-Port.

HIS Majesties Armies rang'd now freely over both these Provinces, only with this Exception, that the great Towns in Livonia, &c. were still in the Hands of the Swedes; but having secur'd all behind him, by the taking of the Places above∣mention'd, as also of Notteburg and of Nyenschans. His Majesty now resolv'd to begin with the other in the next Place, and so finish the Reduction of Livonia.

IN December, 1702, the City of Narva had like to have been surpriz'd; but tho' the Russians miss'd their aim as to the Place, yet they did a great deal mischief to the Suburbs, and defeated a
strong Party of Swedes, which defended them: The Story is told thus,

UPON the last Day of the last Year, accord∣ing to our Account, the Muscovites made an In∣cursion in the Night time, by the Favour of the Ice, and after they had surpriz'd the advanc'd Guards, advanc'd under the very Cannon of the City, and committed great Disorders in the Neigh∣bouring Villages, which they laid in Ashes, making a great Slaughter of the Inhabitants, as al∣so of some Soldiers that were Quarter'd among them; they have also reduc'd into heaps of Rub∣bish several Houses in the Suburbs; two Sawing Mills, several Country Habitations, notwithstand∣ing that the great Guns from the City and the Castle of Ivanagrod, continually fir'd upon them: That they might get more easily into Peoples Houses, they run about the Streets knock∣ing at the Doors, and crying out in the Language of the Country, usa, usa, vendein tules, fly, fly, the Russians are a coming; then upon the People open∣ing their Doors to know what-was the matter, be∣lieving them to be their Friends, the Muscovites rush'd into their Houses and put all to the Sword, not sparing either Age or Sex, that could not e∣scape to the City, the Cavalry of the Garrison sally'd out upon them, but were beaten back to their very Counterscarp; this bloody Execution continu'd six Hours.

THUS the Swedes went to wreck every where, and the victorious Russians carried all before them; the Czar himself pleas'd with Success, and resolv'd to push his good Fortune, came down in Person to the Army, which he had ordered to besiege the City of Dorpat; the Place made a good Defence,
but they found that the Case was altered, the Mus∣covite Engineers proceeded as regularly in their Approaches as any other of the Nations of Europe, and attacked, and assualted as boldly, and as punctually as possible: The Outworks were carried by degrees, being well defended, and well attack'd; In a Word, after about 27 Days open Trenches, the Garrison finding they could not hold out, and that no relief was to be expected, beat a Parly, and had very honourable Conditions; they sur∣render'd the 26th of July, and were conducted to Riga: Hi Czarish Majesty appear'd on Horse∣back with his Sword in his hand, at the Head of his Guard du Corps when the Garrison march'd out, and the Governour saluting his Majesty, he was pleas'd to return it with great Civility, and at the Governours request afterwards granted him leave to go to Narva, tho' the City was then Block'd up by his Forces under General Schein.

THE Affairs of Poland were now come to a strange Crisis, and such as particularly oblig'd his Czarish Majesty to concern himself more than or∣dinarily with them; for the King of Sweden had so far push'd his Conquest as to bring the Poles to an Election of a new King, and carried on his particular Resentments against King Augustus, to that extremity of Rage, as nothing could abate it; no Treaties, no Proposals, no Mediation of foreign Powers could interpose, so as to bring him to any Terms.

NOW was the time for a generous Prince to engage heartily for his Friend; I call Augustus such, because has Czarish Majesty openly professes in his Letter to the States or Republick of Poland, that he had always entertain'd a personal Friend∣ship,
for the King of Sweden, and now I say was the time to show it.

AS for the King of Poland himself, to give due honour to his Merit, he never gave out; he fought his Ground by Inches, he struggl'd with an In∣vincible Spirit against all the Difficulties that sur∣rounded him: He had a terrible Prince in the Bowels of his Country to deal with, a factious divided and unsteady People to govern, who were neither reasonable in their Demands of him, or satisfy'd when they were granted; who were never with him till they were brib'd to it with Money, nor faithful to him when they had it; who when they oppos'd him, ruin'd their Country, and when they joyn'd, ruin'd him; who had Trea∣chery enough to do him Mischief, and not Cou∣rage enough to do him Good; out of Action, al∣ways Insolent, in Action always Cowardly; who when they should run, would always be for fight∣ing, and when they should fight would always run away: Never Man of Honour risqu'd his Life, spent the Blood of a faithful Nation (his Saxons) and such a mass of Treasure as he brought among them, for a such a false perverse unperforming Generation: Take the State of King Augustus's Case, and the Character of his Palish Friends in the Words of a known Writer of that Day, Thus.

HOWEVER nothing discourag'd the King, and the King of Sweden setting up a new King, not only whetted his Courage, but animated those few Poles, that Hood by him, and encreas'd their Number, so that after the Election King Au∣gustus grew stronger than he was before, nor would the King of Sweden have ever been able lo have reduc'd him, had not the unlucky Defeat of a new raised Body of Saxons open'd a Door to the
Swedes to enter Saxony; This brought the King entirely down, and forc'd him to sigh the Chart Blanc to the King of Sweden, and yeild to what∣ever he demanded of him: Some particulars of which were so hard, and so grating to a Man of Spirit, as King Augustus is known to be, that the King of Sweden lost more honour in Imposing them upon him, than the King of Poland did in submitting to them; the former putting them up∣on him, as matter of Triumph over his Misfor∣tunes, and the other submitting to them purely to prevent the intire Desolation of his Country, and the ruin of his People; such were the delivering up General Patkul, the writing a Letter to Stanis∣las giving him the Title of King, and the restoring the Trophies of his Valour, the Stan∣dards and Colours taken at the great Battle of Calisch, where he had defeated the whole united Army of the Swedes and Poles, and gain'd a com∣pleat Victory over them, killing above 12000 on the spot, and taking all their Cannon and Baggage, with a great many Colours and Standards, all which the King of Sweden obliged him to re∣store.

BUT leaving the King of Sweden to make War as never Prince before him did, Namely to gain Victories abroad, and loose his Country at Home; to Conquer for other People, and be Conquered for his own; invade Saxony, which he knew he must quit and loose Livonia East-honia, Ingria, and part of Finland, which he never shall recover; if this be persuit of glory, be that fame peculiar to himself, for he seem'd to be the only Prince in the World that ever sought his Glory, at the Ex∣pence of the Loss of his Dominions, and to cut in pices the worthless Poles, sat still and let his
own Subjects be cut in peices, and his Dominions ravag'd and made a desolation; his Subjects flying, or being carried away, to People the Dominions of the Conquerer.

BUT thus it was with the King of Sweden, for at the same time that he was thus pushing the King of Poland, and spending the Strength and Arms of Sweden, to support a new Boy-King in Poland; he abandon'd his faithful Subjects in Livonia, and quietly let his Czarish Majesty go on with an unterrupted Course of Conquest, not send∣ing the least Relief to his besieged Cities, or to his faithful Garrisons, till they all fell into his Enemies Hands; for the Czar left him not a Foot of Land on the South Shores of the Baltick, and took from him Countries and Provinces, equal in Wealth and Commerce, to his whole Kingdom of Swed∣land.

IT was now that mindful of the Distress that the King of Poland was in, and that the Republick was like to be brought to, his Czarish Majesty, at the same time that with an uninterrupted Course of Victory he rais'd his Glory in the Conquest of the Swedish Dominions, Concern'd himself in a more particular manner for the Interest of King Augustus; and besides the numerous Armies, which upon several Occasions, he sent to his Relief, and tho' his Troops were seldom well Treated in Poland, which made them less Serviceable than they would otherwise have been, yet he continu'd to Succour them by all pos∣sible Methods.

To this End his Majesty wrote that famous Let∣ter to the Republick; the Measures of which had they thought fit to have persued, they had never
fallen a Prey as they did to the cruel Enemy, who Triumph'd over them.

THIS Letter because the Contents of it were dictated immediately from his Czarish Majesty's own Mouth, and because it shows how perfectly he was acquainted with the true Interest of Poland, and with the Methods how their Liberty and Glo∣ry was to be retriev'd, I shall give at large as it was rendred in English at the time it was sent, as follows.

DIV2.HEAD: The Letter of the Czar of Muscovy, to the Repub∣lick of Poland; Printed in Latin and French, by Order of his Ministers, and Communicated to most of the Potentates in Christendom, is as followeth,
DIV2.P: “PETER ALEXEWITZ, by the Grace of GOD most Serene, and most Powerful great Lord, Czar and great Duke of the whole Great, Lesser, and White Russia, Soveraign of Musco∣vy, &c.”

“TO the most Illustrious, most Eminent and most Reverend Lords, Michael Stephen Radzi∣owski, Archbishop of Geusne, Cardinal and Pri∣mate of Poland; and to the most Illustrious ge∣nerous and magnificient Lords, the Senators of the Kingdom, and other Orders of the most Se∣rene Republick of Poland, and great Dutchy Lithuania, Salutation and Prosperity.”

“MOST Illustrious, most Eminent, and most Reverend Lord Archbishop and Cardinal, and Reverend Primate of the Kingdom of Poland, and Great Dutchy of Lithuania, most Illustious generous and magnificient Lords, the Senators, and other Ordrs of most Serene Republick of
Poland and great Dutchy of Lithuania our Friends, and most dear Neighbours, notwith∣standing we have been inform'd a long time since, and the like Reports were spread through most part of Europe, that some of your Republick led by the Motives of a certain inveterate Ha∣tred, and full of wicked Intention, made use of all possible Means to drive from his Throne his sacred polish Majesty, our Brother, and most dear Neighbour, who is in most strict Al∣liance with us, that they may afterwards more Effectually carry on the ill Designs they have contriv'd, and more safely obtain their Aim; yet we had so good an Opinion of your Equity and Justice, that not only we were unwilling to give Credit to those Reports which came from all Parts; but also forbore to consider the same, with the serious Attention that they deserved from our Thoughts, that if that Fury and abominable Passion had crept amongst some of the Orders of your Republick, yet the number of such who think on what they owe to God, and their Country, and to Honour and Virtue, would much exceed the Number of those, who not duly weighing the fatal Consequences of those Designs, have suf∣fered themselves to be blinded by a depraved Passion and their private Interests; we thought also that those great Agitations being Supported by no Christian Powers, would be easily ap∣peas'd amongst your selves; but we have after∣terwards observ'd, and are convinc'd by un∣questionable Proofs, that that Evil was more and more increasing and taking deeper Roots, we thought it was our Duty more than any body else to intervene, and express publickly how much we were concern'd upon hearing of so
pernicious a Design, which does no ways become a Christian Nation: In fine after having matu∣rely consider'd that Point, we have resolv'd to do by our Interposition what we believe every honest Man is bound to do, especially consider∣ing the great Office we exercise upon Earth, and the general Obligation laid upon all Christian Princes, by God and human Society, to expel Violence and restrain Injustice, and such wicked Advices, as tend to the subversions of Laws, and to other ties of human Society, and disturb the publick Peace of Christendom; so that Ju∣stice may be every where administred, and In∣nocence protected, that the common Cause of Princes, and the Rights of Kings may be chiefly preserved entire; that instead of that honou∣rable Liberty allowed by the divine and human Laws, which are deservedly made the Joy of free Nations: People may not be carried away to the Excesses of slighting Princes, and tramp∣pling under Foot crown'd Heads, whose Ma∣jesty is deriv'd immediately from God, that the same may not be exposed to the Fury of such as love Novelties. Lastly, that the fun∣damental Laws establish'd by Nature its self for the Preservation of human Society be not destroyed, and that Men created in the Image of God, may not degenerate into Brutes, and live without any Law; besides all these Rea∣sons we are particularly oblig'd to concern our selves in this Affair, by Virtue of the Peace concluded in the Year 1686, with the Kingdom of Poland; wherein 'tis said in ex∣press terms, that the brotherly Love, and in∣vincible Peace be maintain'd between us and the most Serene King of Poland; that they
mind the good Advantage of each other; that as Brothers they may assist each other, and that their Majesties are as others, bound to show each other all the Duties of Humanity, Friendship, and Brotherly Affection, and e∣very thing else that may tend to their re∣spective Advantage; and take all possible Care to avoid all things which may breed Enmity, or occasion Violence, and more especially such as might create War, and occasion the effusion of human Blood, and the ravage of their re∣spective Countries, as it becomes Christian Princes; and shall take care that no new Wars and Divisions may break out upon any Ac∣count whatever; all these things having been in a solemn manner Sworn to upon the Book of the Gospel, the Successors in both Kingdoms are in∣disputably bound thereto: Grounded upon these Foundations we have contracted a personal Friendship with the most serene King of Poland, now reigning, and Concluded with him an Alli∣ance more strict and particular than the former; whereby above all other things we have pro∣mis'd each other, that as long as Providence would preserve us our Kingdoms, which may God render happy, we should always, and re∣giously maintain a sincere Friendship, and per∣form to each other all the Duties of a good Neighbourhood; that we should never infringe the same, but rather should mutually defend one another against all our Enemies whatso∣ever; moreover, we are oblig'd to concern our selves in this Affair, because of the great Care we are strictly to provide for the Peace and Soveraignty of our Territories situated on the Frontiers of Poland; for while we see a sire
kindled in our Neighbourhood, and threatning to put all in Flames, we ought to think our selves concerned in that eminent Danger, and fear that those Flames may spread themselves into our Dominions, and deprive them of the Conveniences a peaceful Neighbourhood does us∣ual procure; In short, we know what sort of Monster some of you Nourish in your Bosom against us, making no scruple to entertain such pernicious Designs, and being not ashamed to say publickly that after having put in executi∣on what they nave contriv'd against the sacred Person of his Majesty, they wall join our Ene∣my, which is however directly contrary to the perpetrated Peace aforesaid, which was ob∣tain'd with the effusion of much human Blood; for amongst the several Conditions to settle the stability of the Peace between the two Nati∣ons, with the most serene King and Republick of Poland; it is expresly tipulated, that his Majesty, and his Successors who shall be Elected after him; the great Dukes of Lithua∣nia and the whole Republick of the Crown of Poland, and great Dutchy of Lithuania, the Ecclesiastical and secular Orders of each Nati∣on promise to favour no ways our declared or secret Enemies, neither by themselves, nor by others to have any Correspondence with them, and never to suffer them to commit the least Hostility: To the End then, that this fire which lies concealed under these treacheous Ashes may be extinguished in a due time, before it breaks out into a Flame, and that abominable Design abhorred of God and Man, perfidiously to break an Oath, and violate what has been solemnly Sworn to, may be stifled in its beginning; we have
concern'd our selves in this Affair, being satis∣fied that we have sufficiently shown to all the World that it is our Duty and Right to interpose our selves therein, and have thought fit in the first Place to appeal our selves to your most serene Republick, and induce you by this friendly Exhortation to weigh every thing in this ex∣tremity, and to admonish without interruption, such who entertain those pernicious Designs, (detested by all good Men) to reflect upon them∣selves, and consider what they undertake, and that they not only expose their Honour and Re∣putation, but likewise the Security of their Country to an evident Danger.”

“THE Reasons upon which they fancy they may ground the dethroning of a King elected ac∣cording to Law, a re-acknowledg'd by his great∣est Enemies to appear so unjust and frivilous to uninterested Persons, that the Authors of those Councils cannot avoid the Name and Cha∣racter of Enemies and perfidious Men, which have been bestowed upon them by their own Brothers, nor hinder all Christian Princes, and especially such, who are oblig'd by Treaties or Reasons of State to Defend, and Protect the sacred Majesty of Kings from opposing with all their might the Election of another Person, to the prejudice of the publick Good of Chri∣stendom, and puting a stop to those impious De∣signs: They cannot be ignorant that his sacred Majesty as Elector of Saxony has still Forces e∣nough to repell those Hostilities, and main∣tain the good Cause and Right, he has once acquired; and rather the more, because the best Part of the most serene Republick, in conside∣ration of their Duty, and their Oath, have de∣clar'd
their Readiness to spill their Blood for their King, and Sacrifice their Lives and Re∣putation for his Defence, to the immortal Glory of them, and their Posterity; and what can be the End of all this, but to make their own Coun∣try a Theatre of War, and open a large Field for the Plunder and Devastation of their Neigh∣bouring Nations? As to the Authors of this De∣sign, and such who favour them, they will re∣ceive the punishment they justly deserve; they will bring a blot upon themselves and their Po∣sterity, which shall never be wipd of, and sinking at last under, the weight of Divine Justice, which never leaves those attempts unpunished, they will deplore their own Misfortunes, but too late.”

“As to those among you who have Cause to complain, for we know very well, that the whole most Serene Republick is not hurried a∣way by that impiety, but is for the major Part inclined for the King, we may say that 'tis cer∣tain that God himself, and the best and most prudent Princes cannot equally please all the World, and that the Chagrin and Disatisfaction of some proceed from particular Affections, which usually sway the Words and the Writings, and from Passion and private Interest of Parties; but although they had just Cause of Complaint, which does not hitherto appear, they ought for all that to consider, that those political Distem∣pers do not occasion so much Danger to the Re∣publick, as commonly do the means which, some are endeavouring to make use of as a remedy in the present Case, and to neglect the Friendly and Amicable ways prescrib'd by the fundamental Laws of Poland, even to the offended Party,
and have immediately recourse to Violence and Extremities, is a Practice contrary to the di∣vine and human Laws.”

“IF the Authors of these Novelties should by the permission of God, for some secret Rea∣sons of which there are some Instances obtain their Aim, what would they Gain thereby? ex∣cept to suffer somewhat sooner or later the Pu∣nishment due to their Wickedness, and their Posterity shall never wash off the Infamy they have brought upon themselves, and their Nati∣on; the Assistance of a Foreign Prince encourages them in this Design, but the Event will enable them to make a true Judgement of their Acti∣ons, and time will show their vanity in build∣ing such great things on a sandy Foundation, and that they have rely'd on a broken Reed; they have taken for the Defender of the Cause; and have espous'd a Prince, who for recom∣pensing himself for the trouble he must be at, and reimburse himself of the Expences and Charges, will seize upon after having ruined their whole Country; we think it needless to en∣large any further upon a Subject of so dangerous a Consequence, and flatter our selves that such who desire the Preservation of their Republick, amongst whom there is a great Number of Sena∣tors and good Patriots will exert their utmost Prudence to make their Brethren sensible of their Mistake, and bring back into the right way such who have been seduc'd; as to the rest, we declare to the most Serene Republick, that we are resolved to Interpose our good Offices, and in Order that such who remembring what they owe to God, their King and Country, have promis'd to lay down their Lives for his Ma∣jesty,
and likewise such who have the impu∣dence to oppose their Prince, and stir Heaven and Earth to obtain their Aim, may equally know our Intentions towards them; we do offer with a sincere Heart our good Offices to pacify the Divisions and Quarrels which have been excited between his Sacred Polish Ma∣jesty, and some Members of the most Serene Republick, out of our Affection for our Bro∣ther, Friend and good Neighbour; and are ful∣ly perswaded that God's blessing, and the Assi∣stance of our Friends, and Confederates con∣cerned therein, we shall restore Peace, Union and Prosperity to the satisfaction of both Parties, and the common Advantage of the Kingdom of Poland, and Great Dutchy of Lithuania; doubt∣ing not in the least, but that this offer of our good Offices proceeding from the sincerity of our Heart will appear free from all Suspicions to the respective Parties; for as his Sacred Ma∣jsty is fully assured of our constant Friendship, and Brotherly Affection, so the most Serene Republick may firmly rely upon our plain and sincere Intentions, whereby we are induced to Protect their Liberty in Consideration of the perpetual Peace herein alledged; therefore we friendly invite by this Letter to a speedy and Categorical answer, that we may know whether our Offers are accepted with the same Dispositions for the Peace and Tranquility of Poland and Luthania, as we do prosess before God we have at this time.”
