“HOWEVER we shall continue the neccssary Preparations, that in Case the disastected Party persist in their wicked Designs, we may be able to exert the power God has given us to Support
and Maintain his Sacred Majesty on a Throne he is lawfully possess'd of: As to those who shall side with the King, or shall in a due time re∣turn to their Duty, we shall grant them our special Favour, and show them as much Affecti∣on, as if they had done something for our selves, and promoted our own Advantage; promising to assist them with all our Power for pacifying these troubles; but for such who oppose the most Serene King of Poland their Soveraign, and will not desist from their pernicious Design, we de∣clare them our Enemies, with all their Ad∣herents, and shall punish them as such every where, and shall not forbear our Hostilities a∣gainst them, till those Disturbers of the publick Peace, and Enemies of their Country, as they have been justly called by their own Countrymen in the Acts, and publick Decrees, made during this Intestine War, have been severely punish∣ed, made an example to others, and are pluck∣ed out like a Weed of the Kingdom of Poland, and Great Dutchy of Lithuania, whereof the Peace and Tranquility is as dear to us, as that of our own Dominions; And in fine, till our Neighbourhood is cleared of those wicked Men, and that this Letter may be of greater force, and that not only the Serene Republick, but also all the World may know that this is our Design, and Resolution; we shall communicate this Declaration to all the Princes who favour our Cause, that the Justice of what we are going to undertake may appear every were; but for our Neighbours, who have the same good Rea∣sons as we, to look upon this Affair as concern∣ing them in a particular manner, we invite them to join, and enter into Alliance with us▪
and being resolv'd to neglect nothing for the Defence of the sacred Person of his Majesty, we shall take care of his Cause, Scepter and Crown, as of our own: We wish with all our Hearts the Graces and Blessing of the Almighty to such who sincerely desire the Advantage and Preservation of the most Serene Republick, and that they may succeed in the Design they shall go upon for the glory of God, the preservation of their King, and the Honour and Advantage of their Country, and we wish them a good Health. Done at Muscow, of your Eminency, your Excellencies and great Generosities, the good and affectionate Friend.”

IN Consequence of this Letter, and at the Request of the King of Poland, his Czarish Majesty order∣ed a Body of 45000 Men, Choice Troops and very well appointed to march to the Frontiers of Po∣land, on the Side of Sendomir, and there to re∣ceive Orders from the King of Poland; which they did very opportunely for the Service of that Prince, who was closely pursued by the Swedish General Rhenschild with an Army much Superi∣or to his own, and was oblig'd to pass the Vistule at Petrowinnear sendomir, and break down the Brige behind him to prevent his being fallen upon.

BUT now being Supported by a strong Confe∣derate ready at his call, and the apprensions of his being join'd by the Russian Army, having stop'd Ge∣neral Rhenschild in his pursuit, the King of Poland had time given him to Summon his Friends about him, and which was more the Palatinates on that Side, which were before in the Swedish Interest see∣ing
a powerful Army at hand to protect them, and that they might march securely, began now to draw together, and flocking in to the Support of their King; his Polish Majesty had presently a powerful Army of his own, and the Swedish General was glad to retreat in his turn to Cracow.

THUS his Czarish Majesty gave a Turn to the Affairs of Poland, and King Augustus from this time appear'd every Day more formidable than other: Here at sendomir he Summon'd a great Council from all the Palatinates which continu'd faithful to him, and they all under the Encourage∣ment of the Strength and Figure he appeared in, took now a new Oath to him in Opposition to the Confederate Rebels, who by the Politicks and Influence of the Swedes pretended to declare an Interregnum, and choose a new King.

IN this Assembly they declar'd their abhorence of that perfidious Conventicle, which call'd them∣selves a Diet met at Warsaw, and took a new Oath, obliging themselves to oppose it with all their Might: In the next Place they declared, That any Prince who shall take upon him the Title of King of Poland or shall stand Candidate in the pretended Election, shall be deem'd the Enemy and Tyrant of the Country; the Primate and the Bishop of Pozen being look'd upon as the chief Authors Pro∣moters of these troubles, not minding and the King's favours towards them, were declared Ene∣mies of their Country, Infamous and Rebels. And Application is ordred to be made to the Pope, That those Prelates be proceeded against by Excommu∣nication, and other Censures of the Church, as be∣ing the occasion of the Effusion of so much Chri∣stian Blood, and that in the mean time, their Revenues shall be seiz'd and confisticated; the
Marshal of the Crown, and others who have enter∣ed into the Confederacy at Warsaw, are declar'd Rebels, and condemn'd as such, unless within four Weeks they quit the Party of the Rebels, and return to the Obedience of their Soveraign, which favour was granted them upon the King's earnest desire, that such who shall return to their Duty, shall have their Pardon without any Re∣striction, and shall be paid off their Arrears, if they are in Service; that the Governours and Com∣manders of the Fortresses of the Kingdom shall no longer respect the Orders of the Marshal of the Crown; but shall receive Directions from the Marshal of the Royal Confederacy for King Augustus. Eightly and Lastly, That the Alliances made, or to be made with the Neighbouring Princes to invade by way of Diversion the Ter∣ritories of Sweden, shall e considered, provided there be not the least dismembering the Do∣minions of the Republick: These Articles, being subscrib'd and confirm'd by Oath, the Royal Confederacy repair'd to Church, where Te Deum was Sung, to return Thanks for the U∣nanmity of their Resolutions; The King has on the other hand swore again to keep the Pacta Con∣venta, that he shall not exact from the Republick the Sums of Money he has borrowed; That his Saxons Troops shall be under the Command and Direction of the General of the Army of the Crown; That the Subsidies that shall be granted, shall e applied to the Payment of the said Ar∣my. And Lastly, that any Conquests that shall be made on the Enemies of his Majesty, and the Nation shall be annexed to the Republick.

IN a few Days after this 12000 Russian Foot, and 4000 Cossacks join'd his Army, which was al∣so reinforc'd in and about 10 Days by 3000 Sax∣ons, Strengthen'd by these Assistances and the Pa∣latinates, as above, coming in with a great many of their Troops, he found himself of a sudden from 1500 Horse, which was all he had at his coming to Sendomir, encreased to 12000 Horse, and 18000 Foot.

FINDING himself in this Posture, the King an active vigilant Prince, having by good Intelli∣gence learnt that the Cardinal Primate, the great Domestick Enemy of his Crown; the pretended new King's Lady and Family, with abundance of his most Capital Enemies continu'd in the City of Warsaw, a Place of no great Strength, attend∣ed but with a very indifferent Number of Troops, he resolv'd to beat up their Quarters; in pursu∣ance of this Resolution he remov'd with all his Calvalry, with the utmost Silence in the Night, and without letting one Man in his whole Army know any thing of his Design; he march'd direct∣ly for Warsaw, he executed this Project with a Celerity scarce Practicable, ordering his Infantry to follow with all possible speed, and puting his Cannon into Boats on the Vistula: In this Posture before his Enemies had the least Notice of his being Decamp'd from Sendomir, he appear∣ed at the Gates of Warsaw, in the Morning, before it was quite break of Day, and invested the Place: The Confusion it occasion'd to those within, may a little be guess'd at, and the Success of it is a little describ'd in the following Account, which tho' not so very much relating to the Affairs of Russia, yet as the Russian Troops were concern'd in it, I could not omit the Relation.

THE unexpected approach of that Prince▪ ob∣lig'd the Cardinal Primate▪ the pretended new Queen, with the Palatines of Siridia, Lenite and Pod∣lochia, and several other Grandees to quit Warsaw, with the utmost precipitation; and they had the good Luck to escape: His Polish Majesty having not fully infested the City till the next Day; but Ge∣neral Horn, who took upon him the Command of the Life Guards of the new King, with some Swedes, Valachians and Cossacks seem'd resolv'd to defend the Place to the last Extremity: This ob∣lig'd King Augustus to raise some Batteries; but as soon as they were ready, General Horn quitted the Town, and retired into the Castle. The Forces of King Augustus took possession thereof the 3d in the Morning, but they were forbidden to Plunder, the Magistrates having promised to pay 50000 Rix Dollars; the same Day General Brandt, who had pass'd the Vistule with 6000 Cossacks and 1000 Saxon Horse, made preparations to attack the Castle, and a Battery of 4 Pieces of Cannon was erected the 4th in the Morning to Batter the same: This oblig'd General Horn to surrender with all the Officers Soldiers, and other Adherents of the Swedes, therein Prisoners of War, the King having refus'd to grant them any other Terms. The State Prisoners were the Bishop of Posnania, who proclaim'd the new King; the Sieurs Waslager, and Palemberg Plenipotentiaries of the King of Sweden; Lieutenant General Horn, the Castillan Kimpski, I tenant Colonel, 2 Majors, 10 Captains, 15 Lieu∣tenants, 14 Ensigns, 1 Adjutant, 72 Sergeants, 260 Soldiers, besides 25 Swedes taken some Days before by General Bradt at Latowitz; where he cut in pieces 20 Swedes▪ the fir Equipage of Prince Alexander, his Horses Mules, &c. wee
taken in the Castle; the Sieur Walschlager being born a Subject of the Republick, King Augustus has not showed the same regard towards him, as towards the Sieur Palemberg, and has sent him Pris∣oner into Saxony with the Bishop of Posnania, and the two Sons of the Castellan of Cracow: General Horn obtain'd leave to go to the Swedish Camp up∣on his Parole of Honour, to surrender himself Prisoner in Saxony, within two Months time, un∣less his Liberty was obtain'd before.

IN a very few Days after this Action, the King of Poland pass'd the Vistula again at Warsaw, and advancing towards Silesa, encamp'd at a Place call'd Whipsogrod, where he receiv'd a Body of 16000 Saxons, all fine Troops, and their Cavalry exceeding well Mounted, and to join whom it was, that he March'd that way, for he immediate∣ly returned.

ALL this while the King of Sweden, whose Fate it often was to be wining a great way off, and loseing nearer home, was advanc'd as far as the farthest part of Poland, and was attacking Lem∣berg, which he took, and his Men exercised such there unheard of Cruelties upon the Jews, and o∣ther Inhabitants to Extort from them the Discove∣ry of their Treasure, that made all the Christian World astonish'd, and made the Name of a Swede odious to the whole Polish Nation.

WHILE these things were doing his Czarish Ma∣jesty went on in a rapid Course of interrupted Victory in Livonia, and having taken the whole Province of Ingria, as above, taken Nyenschans, and Dorpat by Composition, raz'd Schansterney, built Petersburgh, Croonslot, and all the Forts on the Entry of that Royal Port, His Majesty now resolv'd on the attack of Narva, and the Fort on
the other Side of the River call'd Ivanagrod: He had held the Place block'd up for some time, but now he resolv'd to push the Siege with the utmost Vigour.

AND here the Governour found the difference be∣tween the Muscovite attacks now, and in the former Siege: The Trenches were open'd the 27th of Au∣gust, and the Place batter'd with 40 Pieces of hea∣vy Cannon, and 12 Mortars. The Batteries were so well serv'd, and the Defences of the Besieg'd so effectually beaten down, that after 13 Days open Trenches, the Russians gave a general Assault, and manag'd it so well, mounting the Breach with such Bravery, that tho' the Garrison which consisted of 1600 Men, besides Burghers, defend∣ed themselves with the utmost Bravery, the Rus∣sians entered the Place, Sword in hand, and put the Garrison, and arm'd Burghers to the Sword; the Swedes not calling for Quarter, but defending themselves, as it may be said to the last Man.

I NEED say no more to convince the Reader how the Russians were now improv'd in the Affairs of War, than to show how they behav'd on e∣very occasion, and particular in the attacking of this Town, which is now Storm'd in 13 Days, open Trenches, whereas General Horn formerly Defended it six Weeks against 100000 Men, till the King of Sweden came and reliev'd it.

THUS the Czar's Disgrace, as it was call'd be∣fore Narva was compleatly wip'd out: People began to enquire by what Magick his Majesty had infus'd Courage and Coduct into the Russians, who before were the Contempt of all the Soldiery of Europe.

THE Castle of Ivanagod, opposite to Narva, held out for some Days, but seeing the Russians
go seriously to Work with them, and fearing to share the same Fate with the City, the Gover∣nour beat a Parly, after sustaining a prodigious Battery for six Days: In short he Surrendered the Fortress upon honourable Conditions.

As to the City of Narva, being taken by Storm, it was given up to Plunder as a reward of the Labours of the Soldiery, only that they were forbid to kill any of the Inhabitants, except such as were arm'd, and made Resistance: In the Heat of this Execution the Czar gave such Orders, and took care to have them so well executed, that the Ware-Houses of the English and Dutch Merchants, and also their Dwelling-Houses and Families were not touch'd; no, tho' upon the Assurances gi∣ven them of Safety, they suffer'd their Houses to be a Retreat for many of the Citizens, and for an immense Treasure, which they brought to them for Preserving it from the Soldiers.

HAVING thus made an Entrance upon the Sea-Coast, his Czarish Majesty divided his Army into three Bodies, and sent one Part to block up Revel, and the other Riga, ordering the other Part to co∣ver their Camp, and Guard the Passes into the Country, being resolved to reduce those two im∣portant Places, before any Relief could come to them.

HOWEVER for some time his Majesty deserred his Resolution to Besiege them in Form being cal∣led off to yeild a yet more powerful Assistance to his distres'd Allie the King of Poland; in order to which, he order'd an Army of 60000 Men to draw together in Lithuania, with which his Czarish Majesty resolv'd to Advance in Person, and give the King of Sweden Battle; as the only way to make a short End of the Desola∣tions
of Poland, and drive his Enemies out of the County.

BUT as he was now for the first time entering Poland, at the Head of an Army to make War as I may call it in his own Name, tho' for the Inte∣rest of the King of Augustus; he published a Mani∣festo to the Polish Nation, and to the Lithuanians, signifying to them his Reasons for entering their Country with an Army, a Piece which will for ever record the Justice of the attempt, and con∣vince Posterity also of the Necessity of it at that time: The Manefesto therefore, is worth their peru∣ssing, who think it worth while to acquaint them∣selves with the History of those Times; the whole at large is as follows, (viz.)

“WE by the Grace of God, the most Illustri∣ous, and most Potent Czar, and great Duke, Peter Alexewitz, absolute Soveraign of the Great∣er, Lesser, and White Russia, and Hereditary Successor, Lord of several Principalities and Countries, in the East, and West, Northern Parts of the World.”

“SIGNIFY hereby to the Illustrious and Magni∣ficent Senators. Dignitaries, both Spiritual and Temporal, and the rest of the great Officers, and Nobility of the most Serene Republick of Poland, and the great Dutchy of Lithuania, that we pursuant to the perpetual Peace, concluded formerly between both Nations, and the subse∣quent Alliances made with his Majesty Augustus II, and the whole Republick of Poland, for a mutual Prosecution of the War against our com∣mon Enemy, have employ'd our utmost endea∣vours to oblige that Enemy, who has invaded the Republick of Poland to retire out of it; and
to prevent the Effects of such impious Factions, as either for Interest, or fear of the Enemies Power and Threats, have endeavoured these two Years past to Dethrone their lawful King; we have formerly declared our Abhorrence of such perfidious Proceedings, in a Letter sent to the whole Republick, wherein we acquainted them at the same time that we were bound by the strongest Ties of Brotherly Love and Alliances; and by our own Inclinations to defend the com∣mon Rights of Princes to prevent such a horri∣ble Design, which deserves the severest Expres∣sions of God's Vengeance and Wrath; and that we should be oblig'd to look upon such Rebels to their King and the Republick, as our Ene∣mies, and pursue them with Fire and Sword; these our Exhortations and Warnings had such good Effect at first, that the Fire which had be∣gun to spread itself, seem'd extinguish'd, but as appears soon after, it was only hid under de∣ceitful Ashes till the Swedes did blow it up a∣gain into a sudden Flame, and the Waywod of Posen, Lescinsky was unlawfully elected by a small Number of inconsiderable Persons to be King, contrary to the Sentiments of many of the Confederates that appear'd at the Electi∣on, and in opposition to the Liberties, and Rights, not only of Poland, but the whole uni∣verse; and this detestable Act was not only protested against by the Archbishop and Cardi∣nal Primate Radziowski, and other Senators of the first Rank, though they had at that time quarrel with their lawful Prince; but the Mar∣shal of the Confederated Nobility could never be perswaded to give his consent to this illegal Choice; but the Swedish notwithstanding, persist∣ing
ing obstinately in his Design, and exerci∣sing an absolute Power on the Republick, has compelled some of the Nobility to conclude a Treaty with the Swedes; Envoys, in the Name of the elected, who very submissively hearken to the Dictates of the Swedes: Part of the afore∣said Confederates were indeed taken Prisoners by their lawful King, and the rest were dis∣pers'd; but not only the distance of our main Army, and the Animosities between the Forces of the Republick, but also the small Number of Saxons, soon after oblig'd the foremention'd King Augusus to march to Saxony, with part of his Saxon Troops, in order to prevent the in∣tended Invasion of the Swedes in that Electorate; He design'd to return soon to Poland, but his return has hitherto been obstructed by the Swedes, who have shut up all the Passages, this emboldened the Enemy to publish in the Name of the Cardinal Primate, Circular Letters con∣firming the foremention'd unlawful Election, and having call'd together the petty Dyetts the 26 of June, a general one was Summon'd to meet the 11th of the next ensuing Month; we cannot believe that these Universalia were issued by the Cardinal Primate, who being not only the Head of the Clergy, but also the first Mem∣ber of the Republick, was chiefly concern'd to endeavour a Reconciliation between the Sub∣jects of Poland, and their lawful Prince; so that we have Reason to think that this unlaw∣ful Assembly of the Deputies of Poland, was purely contriv'd by the subtile Enemy, as may partly appear by the false Rumours spread by him, (viz.) that the King of Prussia disponding
of a Reconciliation between King Augustus, and the Swedes, had embrac'd the Party of the King of Sweden, and the elected Person; the falshood of this imputation is manifest by the Letter sent to the King of Prussia by the Cardinal upon this Account, and although the King of Prussia be∣ing a neutural Prince in this War, has not been adverse to the Party of the Swedes; yet we are assur'd that he will not Recognize the elected Person, in regard it would injure all crown'd Heads, who in this World have none above them, besides the Omnipotent Judge, who according to his holy Will and Pleasure deposes Kings, and places others in their room; so that we cannot imagine this detestable Practice, which is so abhorr'd in the sight of God can be approved by Men; even, if not only a small Number, but also all the Subjects should with∣out sufficient Cause presume to dethrone their Prince in compliance with his Enemies desires; for which Reason we are confident, that the faid Universalia were publish'd by the Enemy, who therein make mention of the desolations of the Country of Poland, and the depredations committed upon the holy Churches and Lands; but the Persons guilty thereof was not Named, yet it was propos'd therein, to call a general Diet to prevent such Grievances for the future, and that the best expedient for that End would be to confirm the illegal Choice of the Waywod of Posen, and to depend upon the Promises of the King of Sweden, as though he were come into Poland to preserve the violated Laws of the Re∣publick; we do verily believe that only such as are blinded by Bribes, will give any Credit to this cunning, dangerous and pernicious Deceit,
the plundering the Towns and Castles in Poland and Lithuania of their Wealth, Ornaments, Am∣munition and Artillery; the Churches and Mo∣nastries of the Relicts of Saints, their Orna∣ments and their very Bells; and the Oppressi∣ons of the Waywodships and other Lands by in∣tollerable Taxes exacted there, show what a Friend to Poland the Swede is, notwithstanding all his pretences that he is to come into Poland, not to seek his own Interest, but to Protect the Republick, and by the assuming the Soveraign∣ty of Courland, and giving his General Lewen∣haupt the Title of Vice Governour of that Country, it may be apprehended he will do the like by some forfeited Towns in Prussia: These things consider'd again, we do declare that we will defend our Brother and Allie King Augustus to the utmost of our Power, by vertue of our solemn Alliances with that Prince, and the Republick, and are for that End resolv'd up∣on the Petition deliver'd to us in the Name of the Republick to advance in Person with an Army into Poland, without any regard to our own Interest; and therefore we notify to all the States of the Republick to forbear coming to any Congress, or coming themselves to such as are Assembled at Warsaw, in favour of the Elected, on pain of being punish'd in their Per∣sons and Possessions, with Fire and Sword; and to prevent any Plea of Ignorance, we require all Sons of their Native Country, after they shall have detected the Artifices of the Enemy, to lay aside their private Animosities, and to joyn unanimously for their common good; and in or∣der thereunto to endeavour the expulsion of the enemy who has disturb'd your Peace; we Pro∣mise,
on our Parole, that we will asist you herein as a faithful Allie, having no Pretensions up∣on you. And we testify, before God, that we are advanc'd with our Forces into the Lands of the Republick, meerly upon pressing Invitations and Intreaties, and for the sake of your Interest only. And that we demand for the Subsistance of our Army, such Quantities of Bread as had stipulated in our Alliance with the Republick, and that we will enjoin our Forces, on Pain of Death, to commit no Disorders in your Coun∣try. We heartily wish that you will be unani∣mous, and open your Eyes to your Welfare, as the only Means to recover your Liberty. We remain a Faithful Allie, and Affectionate Friend.”

THE King of Sweden, at this Time, was in no Condition to meet such a Power, his Troops being dispersed, and the King of Poland was himself in Saxony, disposing Things as his Circumstances would permit, to prevent the King of Sweden's falling into that Country. But his Army having been defeated at the Battle of Frauenstadt, it was not possible for him to raise another time enough for the Work.

HOWEVER, the King hearing that his Czarish Majesty was arrived in Lithuania, went Incogni∣to from Saxony, and by his exceeding swift Riding, having prevented any Design to intercept him, arriv'd at Tycockzin, where the Russian Army lay, and there it was, that his Czarish Majesty let him, see what an Army he had brought to serve him. The Season of the Year not presenting any Op∣portunity of immediate Action, and some new Disorders having happen'd at Moscow, the Czar
took a Resolution to go away Post thither, which he did, leaving Prince Alexander Menzickoff to Command the Russian Army, with positive Di∣rections to obey the Orders of King Augustus in all Things, as effectually as if it had been his own.

HIS Czarish Majesty, by his sudden coming to Moscow, surpriz'd his Enemies, as he had done more than once before, and having made some Examples of Justice, and put to Death the prin∣cipal Authors of the Treason, he soon return'd to the Frontiers.

BUT I should have taken Notice that his Czarish Majesty, before he came into Lithuania with this Army, had been present at the taking the Town of Mittau, the Capital of Courland. The Swedes pretended that his Troops had receiv'd a Defeat at their first Enterance into Courland, a Body of 7000 Swedes under General Lewenhaupt ha∣ving attack'd them with great Vigour, and yet, even in this Action, the Russians behav'd so well, that in the Accounts which the Swedes themselves publish'd of the Action, they have this Expres∣sion; the Muscovite Foot were cut down in Rank and File, as they stood, for tho' they faw the Horse broken, yet not a Man of them would stir from their Post, tho' surrounded by the Enemy.

BUT this Victory, as the Swedes would call it, was far from an Overthrow, and far from reliev∣ing their Cause; for about three Days after the Battle, the Czar advanc'd with his whole Army, and surpriz'd, as I observed above, and took Mittau, with 900 Swedes in it Prisoners of War, with a great Magazine of Military Stores and Pro∣vision laid up there by the Swedes, which, as was
well observ'd by the Writers of those Times, was but a very indifferent Token of their having been beaten in a Set Battle, and 7000 of them killed upon the Spot.

Nor was this all, but immediately after this Bat∣tle, I might have said this Victory, for such, in∣deed it was to the Russians. General Lewenhaupt retired out of the Country, and the Muscovite General, Prince Czeremettoff, caused the City of Riga to be besieged in Form, which for want of Relief, was also taken about 2 Months after, the Garrison having been reduced to the last Extre∣mity.

IT is hard to come at the Journals of these Sieges, no particular Account of them having been pnblish'd in the World, but this may Sum up that Part; that while the King of Sweden went on pushing King Augustus with an implaca∣ble Rage out of his Kingdom, his Czarish Majesty over-run all the Swedish Dominions, on the South Side of the Gulph of Finland, and even the Dutchy Courland it self; this would have been called a Diversion in King Augustus's Favour, in any Place in the World, but here; perhaps to any Prince in the World, but to the King of Sweden it would have been so: For, who could have suppos'd, that any Prince like this, would have push'd on a remote Conquest, in which his own proper Dominions were so little concerned, and for the meer Satisfaction, or if you will, for the Glory of pulling down a King, who he had already sufficiently reduced; and at the same Time, suf∣fer his own Hereditary Dominions to be torn from him, his miserable Subjects ruined and ravaged without Succour; his strong and most Important Towns taken from him, without relieving them;
and his Brave Troops be beaten for want of Rein∣forcement.

HE that can do thus, may indeed say that no Expedition of his Enemies, by way of Diversion, can be a Relief to those he pushes with Revenge. 'Tis evident here, that the King of Sweden could not be said to fight for Peace, but for Revenge and Glory. For, it is evident, he might have glo∣ried in making Peace, both with Poland, and the Czar of Muscovy also, upon very Honourable Con∣ditions. But nothing would serve him but redu∣cing and dethroning the One; after which, he grew so opinionate, that he fancy'd he could do the like by the Czar of Muscovy; Nay, and his Ministers gave it openly out, that he had resol∣ved to do it: And had Heaven suffer'd him to have carry'd on his Victory that Length, 'tis not doubted but he would have deposed all the Kings of the Earth, if it had been in his Power.

BUT we must not anticipate our Relation of Things, we shall in the Course of this History, bring his Czarish Majesty and the King of Sweden nearer together in the War, than we have done yet, in order to this, we shall begin with what his Troops did in Poland, before the Czar came to act in Person.

THE Czar, as I have said, had left the War in Livonia to the Prince Czeremetoff, who managed it with such Success, that he beat the Swedes upon all Occasions, and at last compleated the Conquest of Livonia, by taking the Towns of Riga, Pernau, Rvel, and Neyen, with all the other Towns and Forts of any Strength; Posted a strong Body of Troops in Courland, to Cover Livonia from the Re∣turn of the Swedes, and then followed his Master, the Czar▪ into Lithuania.

HIS Czarish Majesty's Troops in Livonia had block'd up Riga, the Dunamund Schans was almost ruined by a Disaster of Fire, which taking hold of the Powder in the Magazein, blew it all up with a terrible Noise, 300 of the Swedish Garrison perishing in the Blast. This Accident caus'd the Russian General Baver, who Commanded at Mit∣tau, to advance towards Riga with 3000 Men, to see if he could make any Advantage of that Acci∣dent, but the Fate of that Place was not yet come.

WE are to understand now, that a great Coun∣cil of State had been assembled by King Augustus at Grodno, in Lithuania▪ where the King met sthem, and where they declar'd King Stanistaus a Traytor and Usurper, and agreed to assist King Augustus with the whole Army of the Crown, which was to be made up to 36000 Men, and to furnish Mo∣ney for their Payment.

THIS nettled Stanistaus, and he flies to the King of Sweden for Help, who drawing his Forces together, pretended to march to attack King Au∣gustus and his Army, at Tycockzin: But when he found that the Russian Forces had join'd with him, he thought better of it, and marched back, not thinking it fit to venture his Army. The Parti∣culars of this fruitless Attempt, was thus related from the very Place, by a Person who was an Eye Witness of it all.

DIV2.HEAD: GRODNO, Decemb. 31, 1705.
DIV2.P:
“THE King of Sweden having decamp'd from Bloni, passed the Vistula with all his Forces the 28th Instant, on the Bridge of Boats; and from thence continued his March with all Expedition to attack the Muscovites at Grodno and Tycockzin, the latter had secured the Bridges on the River
Bug. But the Swedes being favour'd by the great Frost, they pass'd that River with all their Ar∣tilery over the Ice. The Muscovites upon Ad∣vice of his Approach, left 3000 Men in that Place, under the Command of Lieutenant General Ronne, with Orders to defend it to the last Extremity, and march'd with the rest of their Forces, quartered in those Parts, to join the King of Poland at Grodno. That Prince receiv'd Advice the 30st, that the Swedes having not thought fit to attack Tycockzin, were in a full March towards Grodno, and were already ad∣vanc'd within 10 Leagues of his Camp; whereon he held the 22d. a Council of War, with all the Polish, Saxon, and Muscovite Generals; wherein it was resolv'd, that the Army should continue near Grodno, and expect the Swedes in Order of Battle; and that to render the Approaches to their Camp the more difficult, a considerable Body of Troops were posted in a Wood, to secure a Desile through which the Swedes would be oblig'd to pass: They settled likewise in that Council the Rank of the General Officers; the Right of the Army was given to Velt Mareschal Ogliby; and the Left to General Allard; and the Body of the Battle was commanded by the Muscovite Prince Menzickoff; all under the Orders and Direction of the King of Poland. This was the Posture of Affairs in Lithuania the 23d past, when the last Letters came away. But a Gen∣tleman of the King of Polands, who is just now arriv'd from thence, and who left the Court of that Prince the 31ft, reports, that the King of Sweden being advanc'd in Sight of the Mus∣covite Army, and finding the same advantagi∣cusly posted; he did not think fit to attack the
King of Poland: And continu'd his March to∣wards Wilna; his Polish Majesty held thereupon another Council of War, and according to the Resolutions taken therein. He march'd imme∣diately after, with a Detatchment of 3000 Horse directly towards Warsaw, and was arriv'd at Fokzen, in his way thither, when this Gentle∣man was dispatched away; he adds, that Prince Menzickoff is sent for Moscow, by express Or∣ders of his Master, and has left the Command of the Muscovite Army to Velt Marshal Ogliby; the King of Poland endeavoured to fall upon the Rear of the Swedish Army, and a 1000 Dra∣goons commanded by Major General Henke fell upon their Baggage, and took 40 Waggons; the Sieur Smigielski with his Poles, had also a Skirmish with them, and took 3 Lieutenants, with 50 Soldiers, besides the Secretary of Stanis∣laus.”

I have mention'd that his Czarish Majesty ha∣ving an Occasion to make a Tour to Moscow, left his Troops in Lithuania with positive Orders to obey the King of Poland, and the above Relation will show a little how they behaved: But this is not all, for I must new add that the King of Poland led them the Path to Glory; taking a strong Body of them with him, to the great Bat∣tle of Kalish in Posnania, which follow'd soon after the last recited Action.

IT must be observ'd here that the King of Sweden, finding he could not weary out, or dis∣courage his Indefatigable Enemy the King of Poland; but if he was beaten in one Place he re∣vived in another, and that the Confederated Pa∣latinates in the South of Poland, who form'd the Assembly of Sendomir, continu'd to Supply him
with Money, and Troops, and particularly the famous Smegielski, and above all the Czar of Mus∣covy in Person, whose Army having entered Li∣thuania, had appear'd too strong to be attack'd, as above, and had another Army ready to assist his Polish Majesty, lying on the Frontiers of Sendo∣mir, 12000 of which had actually joyn'd him, and that besides this, he receiv'd daily great Succours out of Saxony: I say, the King of Sweden finding this, resolv'd upon the only effectual way he had left to reduce the King of Poland; and this was to enter the Electorate of Saxony with his whole Army: The King of Poland had been aware of this some time, and had both written to the States of Saxony to put themselves into a posture of Defence, and had gone thither himself to see it effectually done, but the Swedish General Rhens∣child having routed the Saxon Army at Fruaenstat, and the Country, by that means being quite naked of Defence, the Swedes enter'd at once, without resistance.

THIS immediately brought the King of Po∣land to Terms; his Polish Majesty like a true Fa∣ther of his Country, could not stop his Ears to the Cries of his People, as the King of Sweden had done to those of his miserable Subjects in Livo∣nia, Ingria and Finland; if I may suppose he heard those Cries, for some People suggested that Court Piper, General Steenboch, and those Men who managed Affairs for the Prince, conceal'd from him the Miseries of his People: If it be true, that they did so, no doubt but the Ruin of his Country, and the Blood of its Inhabitants lye at their Door, seeing by a just and honourable Peace it might have been all prevented.

BUT to return to the History of Fact, the King of Sweden having enter'd the Electorate of Saxony contrary to the Representations made by the Mi∣nisters, of the Queen of Great Britain, the States Ge∣neral of the united Provinces, and several other Potentates, who all press'd him not to make such a Breach upon the Peace of the Empire, and would no doubt in time have join'd to have dri∣ven him out again, the King of Poland was at the Entreaty of his States of Saxony, brought to name Plenipotentiaries for a Treaty, and this Treaty was actually carrying on; but while these Agents were hammering at a Peace, the Armies in Poland having made no Cessation of Arms, act∣ed on every Side as usual, and the Swedes, that the King of Poland might not have an opportuni∣ty to follow them into Saxony, had post'd Major, General Mardevelt with an Army of about 25000 Men, Lithuanians, Poles and Swedes, at Kalish, in the Lesser Poland, as it were directly in the way to Saxony.

HIS Polish Majesty resolving to rescue his own Dominions whatever it cost him, found it abso∣lutely necessary to fight this Army in the first Place, and having now the Support of a power∣ful Army from his faithful Alie the Czar of Muscovy, he resolv'd upon the attempt, and there∣upon, call'd a great Council of War, at which were present the Russian General Prince Menzic∣koff, and several of the Polish Nobility that were in his Polish Majesty's Interest, who all agreed to what the King of Poland had resolv'd (viz.) to Fight; what followed upon this, will be best un∣derstood by the following Account, written up∣on the Spot where the Action was perform'd.

“IT having been resolved in a Council of War, held by his Majesty at Peterkan, that the Army Should continue their March in quest of the Enemy; the two Mareschals of the Crown, and General Brod were detach'd the 22d In∣stant, with 8000 Men; and the 23d his Maje∣sty and Prince Alexander Menzickoff followed with the main Body. The 26th, the two Bodies join'd near Szat, two Leagues from Kalish, with a Resolution to expect us; thereupon his Majesty went to take a narrow View of them, and caused immediately the Calmuck Tartars, and Cossacks, to advance under the Cannon of Kalish, to that several Skirmishes happen'd be∣tween them and the Enemy. The 28th, the whole Army advanced within a small League of that of the Enemy commanded by General Mardevelt; but having several Defiles, and a Bridge to pass before he could get at them, his Majesty employ'd the remaining part of that Day, in making the necessary Dispositions for attacking them the next, with the utmost Vi∣gour. The 29th, his Majesty march'd directly towards the Enemy in Order of Battle, and finding their Army drawn up likewise, behind an Eminence, about Three in the Afternoon gave the Signal for the Attack, by three Can∣non Shot; the Enemy answer'd by two Shots, and came down into the Plain with their whole Army, having intermix'd their Squadrons with their Batallions; their Right Wing being com∣pos'd of Polish Troops, was commanded by the Sieur Potocki, Palatine of Kiow; their Left con∣sisting of Lethuanians, had Prince Sapieha at their Head; their Center was commanded by the Swedish General Mardevelt; and the
whole Army was cover'd with two deep Mo∣rasses, the Town of Kalish, and a good Baracade of Waggons; insomuch, that the Design of at∣tacking them, seem'd to be attended with al∣most insuperable Difficulties; notwithstanding which, King Augustus persisted in his Resolution. In order to put the same in execution, his Ma∣jesty form'd the Center, and the two Wings of his Army, and divided his Saxon and Muscovite Troops; besides which, there were two Bodies of Reserve of the Polish Forces, commanded by the two Generals of the Crown; his Majesty took the Command of the Left Wing upon him∣self; gave that of the Right to Prince Alexander Menzickoff; and the Center to General Brand, or Brod. The Ingagement began between three and four a Clock, and his Majesty's Troops fought with so much Vigour, that the Enemy's Right Wing was soon overthrown, and driven within the Baracade of Waggons they had near the Town of Kalish, but the rest of their Army defended themselves with great obstinacy till fix at Night; his Majesty, during the whole Action, expos'd himself where the Fire was greatest, and charg'd the Enemy several Times in Perso, with his Horse Guards, and several other Squa∣drons; but his Majesty having no Foot, his Horse suffer'd much by the continual Fire of the Enemy's Infantry, and particularly of the French Troops, and others, who, in the Action at Frawenstadt, flung down their Arms, and went over to the Swedes. Nevertheless, the Enermy was push'd with the utmost Vigour, and, by the Blessing of God, we obtain'd a compleat and signal Victory over them. Their Forces, before the Battle, consisted of 10000 Swedes, and
15000 Poles and Lithuanians; and ours of 7000 Poles, 5000 Saxons, 9000 Muscovites, and some Thousands of Tarters, or Calmuck Cossacks; so that the two Armies were, almost of equal Strength; most of the Sweeds were kill'd in the Field of Battle; twenty Polish Companies of their Party, came over to us during the Action; and the next Morning, some Thousand Poles, who were retired within the Barricades of Waggons, were likewise oblig'd to yield them∣selves Prisoners of War; among the latter, were the Sieur Patocki, Palatine of Kiow, his Lady and all her Children; Sieur Tarlo, Master Cook of the Crown; and several other Persons of Note; who were all disarm'd, and their Horses taken, as were also 10000 Waggons that made up their Barricade: The Sweeds had left their Baggage at Kalish, under a Guard of 300 Men, and after the Action, 500 Horse escaped thither, but they were all afterwards obliged to sur∣render at Discretion. However, his Majesty was so generous, as to restore the Baggage to the Officers. All the Enemy's Artillery and Ammunition was taken. The Saxon Cavalry took 19 Standards and Colours from the Swedes, 44 from the Poles, and 4 Pair of Kettle Drums; the rest were taken by the Poles in our Army, and the Muscovites. This Victory is so com∣pleat, that 'tis believ'd, not above 2000 of the Enemy escap'd. All the Troops, as well Poles, and Saxons, as Muscovites, behaved themselves in this Action, with great Courage and Intripi∣dity; and all their respective Generals signa∣liz'd themselves in Emulation of each other. Our Loss is very inconsiderable, for we had only one Officer of Note kill'd, viz. Colonel
Guersdorf; this Victory is the more remarka∣ble, because his Polish Majesty's Troops had undergone great Fatiegues, by their continual Marches and Countermarches, during the Campaign; whereas the Enemy's had been a long time in Quarters of Refreshment.”

“HERE follows a List of the Prisoners taken from the Swedes, both in the Field of Battle, and in the Town of Kalish, besides the Poles that were taken the next Day, in the foremen∣tion'd Brigade of Waggons, viz. General Mar∣dervelt, who commanded in Chief; 4 Colo∣nels, viz. Marschal, Muller, Horn of the Foot, Horn of the Horse, 5 Lieutenant Colonels, viz. Guildenstern, Raad, Horn, Issendorff, and Mu∣mand; 4 Majors, to wit, Bornfold, Openbasch, Schelling, and Rurst; 27 Captains of Foot, and 4 of Horse, 39 Lieutenants, 21 Ensigns, 4 Adjutants, 294 Subaltern Officers, 1600 Sol∣diers, making in all 2007 Prisoners taken in the Battle, those taken in the Town of Kalish, are, 1 Major, 1 Captain of Horse, 16 Captains of Foot, 19 Lieutenants, 15 Cornets, 6 Ensigns, 4 Ministers, 18 Subaltern Officers, and 800 Soldiers, in all 894 Prisoners; which with those taken in the Battle, amount to 2901. We had 806 Germans and Saxons kill'd, and 800 wounded.”

THE great Share his Czarish Majesty's Troops had in this Victory, was acknowledg'd by King Augustus himself, till he found it necessary for Reasons of State to Cancel all the Obligations which he ow'd to his Supporters, and Consequent∣ly to lessen the Merit of the Support, which they had given him; but as he own'd to have in his
Army 9000 Muscovite Soldiers, I mean Regular Troops under Prince Menzickoff; so 'tis known▪ he had olso as many Cossacks and Circassians of his Czarish Majesty's Subjects, who in their way did him very good Service on that occasion.

BUT now we come to the Transactions of King Augustus's Life, which are the meanest part of his History, Namely, that of abandoning the Crown of Poland, quitting his Alliance with the Czar of Mus¦covy, who had never forsaken him in his greatest Distress, and yielding to the lowest Steps, which his insulting Enemies could put upon him.

IT must be confest that the Plenipotentiaries on either Side, had sign'd the Treaty at Alt Ran∣stadt, nay, the Peace was concluded and sign'd four Days before the Battle of Kalish was fought; otherwise, perhaps King Augustus would have ventur'd with his victorious Army to have march'd directly against the Swedes, who tho' they were indeed in possession of the open Country of the Electorate, yet had no fortify'd Place in their Hands, nor above 15 or 16000 Men in their Army, where∣as the King of Poland could in less than 12 Days have had 60000 Men in his Army, besides what Troops he had in Saxony.

BUT it was too late, and King Augustus made it a point of Honour to stand to the Agreement his Plenipotentiaries had made, however dishon∣ourable it might be; so he laid down his Arms at once, and gave up the Kingdom of Poland, and all his Friend, and Interest there to the Mercy of a Mer∣cenary, who the Poles dispis'd most heartily, tho' many of them were oblig'd to call him King, and this was the Condition of things when his Czarish Majesty return'd to his Army in Lithuania.

BUT this no way discourag'd the Czar, he re∣solv'd to Support the Party that had stood for the Liberty of their Country against the Swedes, and to this purpose he publish'd a Declaration, or Memorial to the Polish Nobility, and having re∣ceiv'd a formal Notification of the Treaty con∣cluded by King Augustus with the King of Swe∣den, he wrote Letters to the General of the Crown, the Primate of the Kingdom, and other Grandees, who were in the Party of King Au∣gustus, to represent to them, That he concluded an “Alliance with the Republick, and not in parti∣cular with Augustus, and that he was resolved to perform all the Articles thereof, of assist the Republick with all his Forces against the Swedes, who being not satisfy'd with having oblig'd King Augustus to adicate his Crown, would im∣pose a King of their own Election upon them. His Czarish Majesty promises therein to repair shortly to Lemberg to concert Measures with the Republick, and in the mean time to send such an Army as will be sufficient to enable the Poles to vindicate their indpendency; the Primate having held a great Council with the Officers of the Crown, has appointed a great Council to meet at Lembergh the 17th of the next Month, and has declared the Throne vacant, bidding all the Poles to acknowledge the Palatine of Po∣zen, under the Name of Stanislaus, the Primate also has written to the Emperor, the Queen of England, the Kings of Denmark, and Prussia, the States General, the Pope and other Potentates, to acquaint them with the vacancy of the Throne. The General of the Crown, has also published universalia, forbidding the Forces of the Re∣publick to receive any Orders from King Au∣gustus,
or King Stanislaus, and promising a re∣ward of 5000 Rixdollars to such who shall de∣liver up alive the Sieur Smigielski, or 2000 to such who shall deliver him dead; that Gentle∣man has lately embrac'd the Party of King Stanislaus, and set at Liberty the Weywood of Kalish, which has so provoked Prince Menzic∣koff, that he has caus'd him to be hang'd in Ef∣figie.”

IN pursuit of these Resolutions, his Majesty came in Person to Zolkiew in Poland, the 11th of January, 1707. And being inform'd by his Mi∣nisters “of what had pass'd during his Absence; he order'd them to write to all the Generals of the Army, and of the Crown, and to the Sena∣tors to invite them to repair to him, he also or∣der'd universaly in his own Name to be print∣ed for confirming those already publish'd by his Ministers; the 9th he went to Church attended by Prince Menzickoff, and other Officers and Generals, and afterwards Din'd in Publick; the 10th and 11th were spent in Conferences a∣bout the disposing of the Army, and in sending private Dispatches to divers foreign Courts.”

PURSUANT to this Summons of the Czar of Muscovy, the 7th of February the great Assembly of Senators, Generals and great Officers, that is to say, the Polish Nobility met together at Lemberg, there to consult with his Czarish Maje∣sty what was to be done in the present Con∣juncture: This Grand Council, for such they were call'd, open'd their first Session, by going in formal Procession to Church to implore the Bles∣sing of Heaven on their Proceedings, then they repair'd to the Hall of Council, where several Pathetic Speeches were made to explain to one
Author the Reason of their Assembly, and re∣present the present State of their Country, all of them concurring to declare the Throne vacant.

“AFTER these things they renew'd the Confe∣deracy of Sendomir, as the most effectual Means, to put themselves in a Condition to assert their Liberties; they seem'd very unanimous in their Resolutions; but had not yet taken any Mea∣sures for a new Election. And King Augustus having not notify'd unto them his Renuncia∣tion of the Crown; the Assembly seem'd to act rather, as if their King was Prisoner amongst his Enemies, or absent, than if the Throne were Vacant. Prince Dolhorucki, Chief Mini∣ster of State to the Czar, had then his first publick Audience of the Council, to which he was conducted by one of the Chief Officers of the Crown, with 7 Coaches, and a Detach∣ment of the Cavalry of the General of the Crown; he was placed in the Congress, be∣tween the two chief Ministers of the Repub∣lick; and delivered a Letter to the Assembly from the Czar, and then made a Speech in the Polish Language, importing, That notwith∣standing the Republick seem'd reduced to the last Extremities, by the Retreat of King Au∣gustus, yet, they were still in a Condition, to retrieve their Affairs and Glory, if they would concur in the Measures that should be proposed unto them on the Part of the Czar, a faithful Ally of Poland; whom no private Advantage whatsoever, that may be proposed unto him, shall be able to separate from the Interest of the Republick; Concluding with a pathetical Exhortation, to take vigorous Measures against their Common Enemy; and assuring them that
the Czar would restore to the Republick, the Places in the Ukraine, that formerly belonged to Poland, and furnish the Sums he had belonged fed for paying of the Army of the Crown.” The Primate of the Kingdom Answered, in the Name of the Republick; “And having return'd Thanks to the Czar for his Affection and Friend∣ship, he assured his Minister that the Council would not separate 'till they had taken such Re∣solutions, as the Glory of their Nation, and the distressed Conditon of their Country re∣quired from them. Then Prince Dolhorucki was conducted back to his House with the same Cere∣mony: The 19th his Czarish Majesty with his el∣dest Son Prince Alexander, Prince Menzickoff, and some other Persons of Note arrived there from Zolkiew; he was Complimented upon his arrival by the Primate, and other Grandees, and nob∣ly entertain'd by the General of the Crown; the 20th that Prince assisted at the Ceremony of the Consecration of the Bishop of Cujavia perform'd in the Cathedral, and presented that Prelate with a Crucifix, valued, at 15000 Rix-dollars; the 21st, there was a long Conference between the Ministers of that Prince, and the Council of Poland; but the Resolutions taken therein were kept very private: His Majesty with the Prince and Ministers, set out the next day to return to Zolkiew, and Prince Dolhoureki, continued there as his Plenipotentiary, the Count de Denhoff, Governour of Crawcow or∣dered the Fortification of that place to be aug∣mented with all possible speed, and has in con∣cert with the Czar, order'd the Neighbouring Districts to furnish without delay a quantity of
Forage, and Corn it being resolved to make a great Magazine in that City.”
The following Letter was also written by the Czar to the great General, and dated from Zolkiew the 7th of February.

THE King of Sweden, having by Force and Management, compass'd his Design against King Augustus, seeks with no lefs Cunning to gain his Ends of us and the Republick, and to render Fruitless our good Dispositions to maintain the common Interest. In this View, his Ministers in all foreign Courts insi∣nuate, that he is treating of a Peace separately with us. We do not deny, that (when) formerly, at Seoli∣za, several Ministers of foreign Potentates, sounded our Inclination to Peace; we intimated, that out of Christian Duty, and to spare the Effusion of Blood, we should always be ready to hearken to all Propostions of Peace which the King of Sweden should offer, but on Condition, that such Peace should be negotiated openly, and with the Consent and Participation of the Republick, and concluded by Commissioners appointed by all the Nations concern'd. We never did, or shall entertain any Thoughts of treating of Peace secretly, by the Intervention of any foreign Courts; prefering to all Interest and Advantage, the Reputa∣tion, Honour, and Inviolable good Faith of a Mo∣narch, in the strict Observation of all his Alliances. We therefore, assure your Lordship, that we have not yet enter'd into any Manner of Negotiation of Peace with Sweden, nor, for the future, will enter into any, otherwise than we have already declared, with the Participation and Consent of the Estates of the Re∣publick; being absolutely determin'd to keep inviolably
the Alliance and Guarantee we are ingaged in with the Republick.
IN Pursuit of the Czar's Resolutions to assist the Poles, we find that his Majesty's Troops were very numerous in Poland.

THE Body of Muscovits in Prussia consisted of 18000 Men, and were augmented considerably; the City of Dantzick were not a little alarm'd at it, especially since they receiv'd a threatning Let∣ter from the Czar on Account of their acknow∣ledging Stanislaus. The Body of Muscovites about Thorn were so strong, that they oblig'd Prince Lubomirsky to retire with his Troops into great Poland. The Muscovites also form'd another Bo∣dy near Calish, making near 30000 Men; and a Fourth about Guesna. During these things the Czar seeing the Poles unsteady in their Resolutions, and disputing Trifles with their best Friends, went himself in Person to the great Council of Senators, which were adjourn'd from Lemberg, and met at Lublin; where is Czarish Majesty arrived the 20th of May, 1707, with a Guard of 3000 Dragoons. The Senators had all agreed as above, that up∣on the King of Poland's having abdicated the Crown, they were in a State of Interregnum, and that the Throne was vacant; but could never be brought to fill up the Vacancy, and elect a new King, which his Czarish Majesty justly thought was the only way to engage them heartily, so that they might be depended on.

BUT they put it always off, alledging that King Augustus had not signified his Resolution of abandoning the Crown to them in Particular, and therefore they ought to send a Deputation to
him, to have his last Answer from his own Mouth.

THIS the Czar took for gross Triffling with him, and such indeed it was; for they had their Articles of Peace between the King of Sweden and the King of Poland, publish'd by the said two King's respectively, and the Letter which the King of Sweden oblig'd the King of Poland to write to King Stanislaus, owning him for King of Poland, all these were before them, and yet they made Excuses to put off a new Election of a King.

THEY were indeed, all of them willing to have his Czarish Majesty to advance with his Army, and proposed to concert Measures to act against the King of Sweden with joint Forces, and Endea∣vour to bring the King of Sweden to a decisive Battle; which his Czarish Majesty was willing enough to do, as soon as a new King should be nam'd, but did not think any other Step less than that, could sufficiently assure him of the Fidelity and Steadiness of the Poles, who in Case of a Battle, he knew well enough might have an Opportunity to make their Peace at his Majesty's Expence; and indeed, those Uncer∣tainties produced such a general Distaste, and gave such a plain Ground of Mistrust, that they, the Poles, only sought a Delay, and to see what Measures the King of Sweden would take, or whe∣ther he resolved to bring his Army again into Poland, or not, that they might have Time to take up with the Strongest; that his Czarish Ma∣jesty, from this Time, begun to see plainly, he had nothing but his own Power to depend upon; and that the Poles were not to be trusted; and this brought in the End, all the Consultations,
Confederacies and Pretences of Defending the Liberties of Poland to nothing, and ended as such generally do, in their falling all into the Hands of their Enemies; and being oblig'd to submit to King Stanislaus, as we shall presently shew.

BUT his Czarish Majesty who knew them too well, to be drawn into any Snare by them; acted an open, plain, and fair Part with them; and let them know, that since they would not do their Duty, and were not mov'd either by their present or future Interest, he would take Care to depend upon himself only, and take such Measures as he should think fit. But whereas their famous Champion Smegielski, who had done so many gallant Exploits against the Swedes in the Cause of King Augustus, had now made his Peace, and was gone over to Stanislaus, and had commit∣ted some Hostilities against the Russians: The Rus∣sian General caus'd him to be hang'd in Effigie, as a Traytor to his Country, and put a Reward upon his Head, to any who should bring him in alive or dead.

AT the same Time, his Czarish Majesty seeing himself thus used, by King Augustus, even just after his Troops had obtain'd a great Victory for him, the said King Augustus; and that notwith∣standing all this, he had not only abandon'd his Confederacy or Alliances with his Czarish Maje∣sty, but had joyn'd his Enemy the King of Swe∣den, and obliged himself to act Conrary to the Interest he had espoused; and also that King Au∣gustus had sent Letters and Memorials to England, to Holland, and other Places, to excuse and palli∣ate the Treachery of his Friendship. I say, see∣ing himself thus used by King Augustus; his Czar∣ish Majesty thought it needful to write to the
same Powers to expose the Ingratitude of King Augustus, and to let them see, what in the Course of the late War, his Czarish Majesty had done for him; the Copy of this Letter to the Queen of Great Britain, being as follows, that to the States General, being mutatis mutandis, much the same.

DIV2.HEAD: Most honoured and beloved SISTER.
DIV2.P:
ALTHOUGH 'tis not unknown to your Royal Majesty yet we have judged it necessary as Af∣fairs now stand in a Friendly and Brotherly manner, to acquaint you by this Letter, and as briefly as possi∣ble with the Services we have done King Augustus, from his first Election to the Kingdom of Poland, having by our powerful Endeavours for the common Benefit of that Crown, hindered the Prince of Con∣ti, who had been chosen before by part of the Repub∣lick from taking posession of it, and even sent a nu∣merous Army against the Prince of Conti's Party, for the use and Service of those Senators, that sided with King Augustus, before any League had been conclud∣ded with him, or his Enterance into Poland; the Army was immediately upon his arrival put under his command, that he might be able to punish his Enemies, besides which we threatned the contrary Party with Fire and Sword; upon Apprehension hereof, many were forced to acknowledge him, and so by our Assi∣stance he was firmly Settled upon the Throne; after∣wards by his particular Intreaties, and a Message by General Carlowitz in the Year 1700, we concluded with him an Alliance against the King of Sweden, in which there was no Subsidies of Money promised him, moreover many Affronts and Injuries having
been done us at the beginning of the War by the Crown of Sweden, we were prevail'd with by the earnest Sollicitations of his Minister General Langa in an unproper Season, it being the latter End of Autumn for his Relief, and to make the Enemy turn their Arms against us, to begin to attack Narva, and then his Forces, contrary to his Promise, leaving ours in Action, went into Quarters in Poland, and Cour∣land, on which occasion our Forces suffer'd no small Loss, notwithstanding which, a League being renewed with him at Birsa, in 1701, not a small Sum of Mo∣ney was Lent him, besides which, we assisted him with 20000 Foot, nevertheless this signified nothing, nor were our Arms made use of according to the Treaty, but by the Intrigues of the French Ambassador du Heiron, to whom contrary to our Agreement and Personal Protestations confirm'd by us, full power was at that time given to Treat about a separate Peace, those our Forces without necessity were greatly fatigued and the Enemy permitted to pass the Dwina, dismiss'd without being supplied with Provisions, du∣ring their March, for which the said King received Money from us, which caused great Numbers of them to perish, and others to Desert: Notwith∣standing all this, upon his repeated Assurance, and Messages, we renewed a League with him in the Year 1703, and promised 300000 Rubles for the use of his Forces, and 12000 Foot to be maintain'd at our own Charges, which we faithfully perform'd; and al∣though the Subsides, and Auxilliaries were not then specified in that Treaty, nor whether the same should be given Yearly, yet we sent him every Year no less then the abovementioned Sum, not reckoning other im∣mense Charges, we were at, for the preserving the Republick in his Interest; but instead of imploying the Forces against the Enemy, he made them March to
and fro in Poland, whereby they were very much fa∣tigued; and afterwards parting from them without any occasion, be permitted them to be driven into Sax∣ony, together with the Saxons, whereby without any necessity half of them were unaccountably lost, and the rest were forced to die with Hunger; and altho' free Winter Quarters were promis'd them in the Treaty, yet on the contrary, 'twas forbidden to sup∣ply them with Bread in their Quarters: Upon which our Minister extraordinary, Van Patkul, then re∣siding at his Court, and chief General of those Forces, in order to preserve them from utter and certain Ruin, agreed with the Emperor's Ministers to put them into his imperial Majesty's Service, for which by the Suggestions of the said King's wicked and trea∣cherous Saxon Ministers, he was put under Arrest contrary to the Law of Nations, and without our consent, was cast like a Traytor into a loathsome Pri∣son, altho' we were oblig'd for the Interest of the said King Augustus, as well as before the Affront of∣fered to our Minister, as after the going of the said King out of Poland, in order to preserve him upon his Throne, and defend the Republick of Poland a∣gainst the Swedish Forces, to leave all our Armies to Act for his Interest; and at the desire of the Re∣publick by their extraordinary Embassy to March with all our Forces into Poland, where they were ob∣lig'd to be maintain'd to this Day to our great Charge in own Pay; yet notwithstanding all this, his Generals at his going out of Saxony, with our and their Troops, suffered themselves, not without suspicion of Treache∣ry, to be beaten without any Resistance; and our Forces were so Deserted, that only 1600 of them re∣mained, and these with much a-do saved themselves, and return'd into Saxony, although King Augustus upon our repeated Instances and Sollicitations, pro∣mis'd
both before and after his infamous Peace, by his Messages and Protestations made to us by General Goltz, either to deliver up to us, or secretly to set at Liberty our said Minister, General Van Patkul; yet nothing was performed, notwithstanding which, without regarding the intolerable Falshoods of the said King Augustus, his Non-performances of the Treaty made with us, his imprisoning our Minister, and vio∣lating the Laws of the Nations, and tending to se∣parate Peace, as well by the Sieur Octima, as by Count Koningmark, and afterwards in Writing by their Secretary Nemitz and Figgstone from the beginning of the War, and after their enterance into Saxony, of which Transactions we had Notice given us by several of our faithful Friends, and notwith∣standing we had those Treaties in our Hands, yet we did not leave to assist him, both with our Forces and Money; and in the last Compaign, though the Seasou of the Year was so far advanced, it being the latter End of Autum, yet being desir'd to draw the Ene∣my back, and harrass his Army, we sent our Caval∣ry under the command of our General Prince Men∣zikoff to join him, and his Saxon and Polish Forces, who Marching towards Calish, met with the Swe∣dish General Mardefelt, and the Poles of the con∣trary Party under the command of the Waywode of Kiow, and by the Assistance of the most High, entirely defeated them, and took their chief General and ma∣ny other inferior Officers, and Soldiers, Prisoners of war, whereby all great Poland was brought under his Obedience; after this, being fully supplyed with all Necessaries, we desgn'd, by the Help of the most High, to act still in his Defence, which was begun with the Action at Wyburg in Finland, and did expect many good Consequences from that Defeat, and rely'd on a strict Observance of the Treaty, pursuant to the Assur
ances we had receiv'd from him in two Letters, written since the Battle, the first dated the 31st. of October, and the second the 20th of November; but saw at first, that he begun to take away from our said General, Prince Menzikoff, the General Officers, and other Prisoners we had taken, giving his Royal Word, and many Assurances, that he either would exchange them for our Generals and other Officers, detain'd in Sweden; for the Performance whereof, General Mardefelt, with the Rest of the Officers, gave also their Parole, and confirm'd the same to our General; or, if it were not possible to effect this Ex∣change, that he would restore the said Prisoners into our Hands; but contrary to all his Promises, he let them go without any Exchange. After this, we under∣stood to our great Astonishment, that he had already concluded a dishonourable Peace with the King of Swe∣den, and Lescheinsky; yielded up all his Rights to the Crown of Poland, and surrendering all to the Pleasures of his Enemies, without giving us any previ∣ous Notice, that we might have provided for our own Security, in Return of the innumerable Favours done him by us; but what shows his Ingratitude to the highest Degree, is, that the Peace was confirm' by him many Days before the Battle. After which, by his Letters, he gave his earnest Assurances of his firm Adherence to the Treaty; the Inconstancy of his Pro∣mises, Non-performance of the League, and Forgetful∣ness of our many Favours and Assistance, we leave to the righteous Judgement and Vengeance of Almigh∣ty God, and upon whose powerful Assistance in our just Cause, we firmly rely; protesting against the said King Augustus and his Subjects; and Leave also to all the World to Judge impartially of our faithful Performance of the League to the very last. More∣over, we are extreamly surpriz'd, at three Articles in
the aforesaid League, viz. the 11th, 12th, and 20th, in the first of which, be, the said, late King Augustus, promised to deliver up our publick Minister and Plenipotentiary residing at his Court, into the Hands of our Enemies, in an unheard of Manner, and to his utter Ruin, upon Pretence of his being a Swedish Deserter. Secondly, in the 12th Article be maliciously obliges himself to deliver up to the Enemy, as Prisoners of War, the Remains of 12 Regiments, viz. 1600 Auxiliary Troops, who for his Preservation have often expos'd their Lives; and were there sent by him as Auxiliaries into the Empire; which is not only contrary to divine and human Laws, but even to the Customs and Laws of Barbarians: Thirdly, In the 20th Article, he stipulates for him∣self, in Case of Peace between us and the Enemy, full Satisfaction. And afterwards, he the said Augustus, in that Treaty, obliges himself, to procure your Roy∣al Majesty Guarantee, therefore we in a brotherly and friendly Manner, desire your Royal Majesty, that through your innate and wonted Goodness, you would be pleased not to consent thereunto, nor countenance his dishonourable Actions. It would have been neces∣sary we should, before this Time, have exhibited this our Protestation, both to your Royal Majesty, and other Potentates in writing, which we absolutely would have performed by our Ministers, had we not been de∣luded▪ as we have made it appear, by the the fresh Assu∣rance he sent us by Major General Goltz, who among many other false Assurances of Friendship engaged for the Performance of the League, and solemnly assured us, that our Minister should never be deliver'd up, and that in Case, it should come to the last Extreme∣ly, King Augustus, should either set him privately at Liberty, or detain him in Koningstein 'till the De∣parture of the Swedes; and afterwards, deliver him
into our Hands. But we have since, with Wonder, and bitter Grief understood, that that Prince fore∣going his Honour, has deliver'd up our innocent pub∣lick Minister, contrary to the Law of Nations, and even Customs of Barbarians, and without the Fear of God, into the Hands of his Enemies. For which Reason, we have the rather thought fit to acquaint your Majesty with all the Premises; and in a friendly and brotherly Manner, to defire, that you would be pleased, by your good Offices, to procure the Liberty of our said Minister, Van Patkul, or at least, that he may be used by the King of Sweden, as our Mini∣ster, and not as his Subject, which we are confident, his Swedish Majesty will grant, at your Royal Ma∣jesty's Desire, whereby he will gain, with all the World, the Name of a magnanimous Monarch, in∣stead of giving an Example of so wicked and barbarous an Action. But, if on the Contrary, Van Patkul be hardly dealt with, and not used as our Minister, we shall be forced to seek Opportunities to return the like Usage. Trusting that in our just Cause, we shall receive all Asistance from the Most High. We hope likewise, by your Majesty's good Offices, and others, our Subjects detain'd at Stockholm, and now under Arrest, viz. the same Number and of the same Rank, as those that were permitted to go upon their Parole from our General, Prince Menzikoff, namely, his General Mardefeldt, and other Officers, and Soldiers, by Order of King Augustus; and on the Parole of the rest of the Swedish Officers. The said Augustus, having thus, Evidently before all the World, violated his Vows, and the Laws of Nations, by his unheard of dishonourable Proceedings, contra∣ry to the Dictates of Conscience; as appears by those Treaties, we shall be oblig'd to do our selves the Justice, and seek for entire Satisfaction from him, as
Elector of Saxony, and a Member of the Roman Empire, which our fair Proceedings and Stedfastness to the League entitiled us too. The rather, because by the 20th Article, contrary to his own Conscieoe, be proposes to seek for full Satisfaction from us; the remaining Part of our Auxiliary Troops now upon the Rhine, we put under your Royal Majesty's Protection; and desire that they may either enter your Majesty's Service, or that of your Allies; or at least we en∣treat your good Offices, that they may have Leave to return Home with Safety; hoping that you will fa∣vour us with your Concurrence and Assistance in these our just Desires; We the Imperial Czarish Majesty. Pray God to Grant, your Royal Majesty many Years Health, and a happy Reign, over your Majesty's Do∣minions.
DIV2.CLOSER: Given at Zolkew, April 27, and in the 25th, Year of our Reign, Your Majesty's Affectionate Loving Brother, PETER

DIV2.P: THIS Letter is too significant, and the Subsist∣tance of it of too much Weight, to be pass'd over, it being an Abridgement of the Conduct of his Czarish Majesty, in Aid of the King of Poland, and of his treacherous Return, and also a kind of Summary of the State of Things between them at that Time.

THERE are two Cases mention'd in this Le∣tter, which have not yet been spoken to; the one is, That of the 1600 Russians, who had been put into the Service of the Confederates in the Em∣pire, and were acting upon the Rhine, as Part of King Augustus's Quota to the grand Alliance a∣gainst France; and the other, is that of General Patkull, who the Czar here declares to be his Mini∣ster and Ambasstador to King Augustus; certain it is, that King Augustus yielded both these Points to the King of Sweden, that is to say, as far as lay in his Power; he gave up the Russian Troops up∣on the Rhine to the King of Sweden; but the Emperor, who had more Humanity and Honour, than to be a Party to so dishonourable an Action, stood out so long, 'till the said Regiments had Opportunity to retire from thence, and to dis∣band, and by small Parties to pass through the Imperial Countries into Poland, and so to their own Country. But as for General Patkull, he de∣liver'd him up to the King of Sweden, who, deaf to all Intercession, and not regarding him as a Publick Minister, but as a Traytor, caused him without Mercy, to be put to Death, by breaking him a-live, and that with some extraordinary Marks of Cruelty, such as particularly causing his own Nephew, an Officer then in the King of Sweden's Service, to be the Person to see the Execution
perform'd, to the Astonishment and Horror of all that heard it.

BUT to return to his Czarish Majesty, he now found that nothing was to be done with the Poles, and that he must resolve to stand upon his own Feet, against the King of Sweden, who having encreased his Army, in Saxony to 50000 Men, by raising Men almost over the whole Empire, was in Motion towards Poland. I say, finding this, his Majesty leaving 40000 Horse in Poland, to Coun∣tenance the Poles if they would be steady, and discharge themselves as was their Duty: Went himself into Lithuania, to draw his Forces toge∣ther there, in order to be in a Condition to Face the King of Sweden, or, withdraw the rest of his Troops, as he should find Occasion.

THE King of Sweden left Saxony, the Begin∣ing of September, to the great Joy of the Poor People there, who had been terribly impoverish'd by their long Stay in the Country. They ad∣vanced by long Marches through Silesia, and came the 10th of October, to Casimir in Poland, where the barbarous Execution of Count Patkull, above∣mention'd, was perform'd, being the first Town they halted at, on their entering Poland.

His Czarish Majesty being, as I have said, gone into Lithuania, had his head Quarters at Wilda; before the withdrawing his Army, he ordered the Lands of the alatines, in the Intercst of the U∣surper Stanislaus to be laid Waste, which his Ene∣mies represented as a mighty Injury; altho' he therein only follow'd the Example of the Swedes, who had so often done the like in an extraordina∣ry manner, to the Lands and Estates of the No∣bility who adheard to the Interest of their Coun∣try.

THIS was the Case wherein the King of Swe∣den's Party pretended the Czar had rifled the Seats of the Nobility in Poland, and carry'd away the Pictures, Statues, Orange Trees, &c. into Muscovy, as also several Extraordinary Libraries with many valuable Manufscripts, and other Curiosities, or Rarities in Nature and of Art, part of which, if it were so, was relative only to the Houses of his Enemies, which by the Laws of War he had Right to, they being now in Arms against him.

THE Diet or Assembly at Lublin, continued some time longer, and seem'd to adhere to their former Resolutions, and to support their Liber∣ties, against King Stanislaus and the Swedes, but as the Czar had no Confidence in them, so indeed, he had no Reason, as the Event shew'd after∣wards; for the King of Sweden advancing, they all separated and disappear'd, leaving his Czarish Majesty to stand by himself, as it may be said, in the War with the King of Sweden, which how well he was able to do, and how Ill they de∣serv'd it of him, will soon appear in the Conse∣quence of the Story.

NOT that they ever fell in heartily with the King of Sweden, or with Stanislaus, which made the Revolution which follow'd, the more easie to the King of Poland. But the King of Sweden coming with so formidable a Power, back into Poland, and bending the first of his March towards Thorn, and the Towns on the lower Vistula; it was no more Question'd for some Time, but that his Swedish Majesty, Would in the first Place, clear the Country of all King Sanislaus's Enemies, and use them with the uttmost Severity.

BUT the King of Sweden, whose dark Hours were just now begining, and who, as some have
observ'd, scarce ever took one right Step, after his coming from Saxony, but delay'd his Proceed∣ings either one Way or other, for near three Months, hovering on that Side of Poland next the Borders of Silesia, 'till he had brought the Empe∣ror to Execute fully a Treaty which had been made between them, in the behalf of the Pro∣testants of Silesia.

AND indeed, he was oblig'd to stay thus long about Posen, and Calish, and those Parts, to lay up Magazins, and Stores of Provisions for his Army; for the Russians had ruined the Country with a Designs to render it difficult to him to sub∣sist, and it had the desired Effect; for after he be∣gun to extend himself, there was no Forrage to be found, sufficient to supply his Army on any con∣siderable Occasion, and this made the King of Sweden lye still, till the Month of February at least.

DURING all this Time, things hung in suspense between the King of Sweden, and the Czar of Muscovy; several Powers, and Princes, sought to mediate a Peace between his Czarish Majesty and the King of Sweden; Nor was the Czar averse to a Peace, upon equitable and just Conditions; but the King of Sweden breathed nothing but War and declar'd or the World was so unjust as to publish it in his Name, that nothing should satis∣fy him now, but dethroning the Czar of Muscovy, as he had dethron'd the King of Poland; So that the Czar might be truly said to fight for his Crown, as he had fought before for his Friend the King of Poland, and for the Peace of the Republick.

IN Pesuance of this wicked Principle of Re∣venge, he turn'd his Arms froom Poland, not yet
subdued, and left his new pretended King, to strugle with a half reduced Nobility, and a di∣vided Nation, and profess'd to make War against neither small nor great, but against his Czarish Majesty in Person.

THIS chymerical Piece of Personality in War, drew is Swedish Majesty, otherwise a most gallant and experienc'd Prince, into so many wild and desperate Undertakings, as have never been heard of before; and into such Mistakes, to say no worse of them, as never any General of an Army run into, and which at last ended in his utter Ruin, and overthrow, as will presently appear.

His Czarish Majesty, dispising the Threatening or Gasconade of Deposing him; but not at all Dis∣pising, either the Person or Armies of the King of Sweden, had no more to do than to draw off his Armies from Poland, keep his new Conquests well guarded, and provided, and bring all his Forces into such posts, as that he might soonest draw to∣gether his Power, when he saw where the Cloud would break; wait to see which Way this new In∣vader would go about this great Work of entering the Russian Empire, in order to bring to pass the Revolution he had projected.
