IT was with some Reason that his Czarish Ma∣jesty thought the first Step that the King of Swe∣den would take, would be to march into Livonia, and there endeavour to recover what he had lost; retrieve the ruin'd Condition of that flourishing Country, and like a true Father thereof, restore Peace to his People. But far from this, he found that on a suddain, his Enemy turn'd his Face to the South, or rather to the South East, and bent his Marches really towards his Majesty's Dominions.

THEN it was, that the Czar, who early pene∣trated into the Design; foresaw, that some Trea∣chery must be form'd among the Cossacks of the Ukrain, and that the King of Sweden had held some private Correspondences with the Traytor Mazppa, General of that false and fickle People: And this was the more probable, because it was the only View that the King of Sweden could have on that Side: The Tartars of Cirassia, and all that Side of the Country, were too remote for any such Attempt, nor would it be possible for the King of Sweden to penetrate into Muscovy any o her Way, the Frontiers lying desolate for so long a Way before he could come to the inha∣bited fruitful Part of Muscovy, that it would be impossible for an Army to subsist, to find For∣riage for their Horses, and Food for their Men, and that the carrying it with them for so long a March, would be as Impracticable, as the other would be Impossible.

BUT the Ukrain, a fruitful and populous Coun∣try could it be brought into a Revolt, as the Swedes had flatter'd themselves, or as some had brought them to believe it would, might indeed, have given him an Inlet into the Heart of the Country, and have furnish'd them with Carriages and Hreses for carrying their Provisions, if the Czar should lay waste the Enterance into his Dominions, as they might conclude would be done.

WITH this View, the King of Sweden began the desperate undertaking, and marching thro' the whole Kingdom of Poland, past the Boristhe∣nes, and advanc'd directly towards the Ukra∣nia by long and Fateaguing Marches, having 42000 Men compleat in his Army, which a fine
Train of Artillery, and such an infinite Store of Ammunition and other millitary Things, as also of Provisions and Baggage as took up 11000 Waggons to carry after them, besides Mules and Baggage Horses innumerable, and besides an Army of 16000 Men, under the Command o Genral Lewenhaupt who his Swedish Majesty left to come af∣ter him, with another Train of Artillery, and 7000 Waggons of Amunition and Warlike Stores more.

NOW his Czarish Majesty knew his Business; the Field was mark'd out for him, and he knew where to expect his Enemy. Now he saw where this gathering Cloud would break, and where the Storm would fall; and he had no more to do but to follow and provide for his Defence.

HE did not however, abandon all Hopes from the confederate States of Poland, or their Assem∣bly at Warsaw, tho' he ceased to depend upon their Assistance; but as he knew the Disposition of the Poles perfectly well, he knew that tho' they would not go on in the Path that he proposed, that is to say, to bring Things to a Point, and set up another King; which, after they had de∣clar'd, and publish'd an Interregnum, one would have thought they should not have stuck at; yet, that they had gone too far, to go back again to King Stanislaus, and that at least they would create him a great deal of Trouble, and employ a great many of his Troops, to prevent him joyning with the King of Sweden, and this happen'd exactly as the Czar foresaw it would.

UPON this Foot, I say, he did not break with them, and leave them abruptly, and entirely to themselves, which had been to have them all torn in Pieces by the King of Sweden, or to have forc'd them to go in at once to King Stanislaus, and to joyn him against his Czarish Majesty's
Armies. But to prevent either of these Extreams, the Czar, tho' he retir'd with the Gross of his Army, to his own Frontiers; and as I have said, prepar'd to defend himself, yet he left a Body of Troops with them, to encourage, and assist them, and manag'd them so well, that they could ne∣ver be brought to joyn King Stanislaus, or fall in∣to his Measures, and Interest, to the last, no not when the King of Sweden had 60000 Men in the Bowels of their Country.

BUT to return to the King of Sweden, it has been observ'd by some Writers, and such too, as have made the best Judgement of those Things, that the King of Sweden never took one prospe∣rous Step, nor did any Thing thrive that he un∣dertook, after the cruel Execution of Count Pat∣kull, nor after his unjust and personal War against the Czar of Muscovy's Crown: I mean his declar'd Resolution, to depose and dethrone his Czarish Majesty; a Thing the World laugh'd at, and which was in itself, considering the numerous Armies the Czar had then on Foot, really ridicu∣lous. But this is by the Way.

THE King of Sweden having layn still, in the lesser Poland, as above, near 3 Months, and ha∣ving consulted with his Generals, and resolv'd what Course to steer, what Forces to take with him, and what Armies the Generals should Com∣mand in his Absence, set forward the 8th of March on his resolv'd Expedition into Muscovy.

THE Troops he took with him, were about forty two Thousand Men, all well disciplin'd cho∣sen Men, and he left General Rhenschild Field Mrscha, and Governor of Livonia as above, with 15000 Men more, and a second Train of Artillery, with 6000 Waggons Loaden with
Amunition, and Military Stores, and Provisions, to follow him.

THIS was indeed, a formidable Force, and might have been more suitable to the Under∣taking, had he been actually in the Field of Action, that is to say, had he been in the inha∣bited populous Part of Muscovy, and had not a vast unpeopled wasted Country to march through, and which the Czar had on purpose strip'd of all possibility of subsisting him, and that he must carry every Mouthful of Provisions with him, as well Forrage for his Horse, as Bread for his Men.

HOWEVER, about March, the King of Sweden, a Prince resolute and unalterable in his Underta∣kings, when once his Councils were concluded, began his March, as I have said, for Muscovy, and passing the Vistula, first advanced to wards Lithua∣nia: HIS Czarish Majesty had left a Body of 3000 Horse, and 22000 Foot, to guard the Passages of the Vistulla, against any Parties of the Swedes; but with Orders to Retreat in Case the whole Swedish Army should advance.

His Czarish Majesty, was at this Time, gone to Muscow, to settle the Minds of his People, and to raise Money for carrying on the War; as also, to appoint more Troops to advance towards the Frontiers, He likewise, settled his Affairs of Civil Government, and appointed a Body of an Army to continue about Moscow, to keep all quiet at the Capital.

HE had left the Army above, under the Com∣mand of the Princes Czermet and Repuin, both bold daring Officers, and accustom'd to the Ser∣vice, tho' natural Russians, and who had often look'd the Swedes in the Face. But, as above, it
was the Czar's express Order to them, to harrass the Swedes with continual Parties, and Excur∣sions, but never to come to a general Battle with them if it was possible to avoid it.

THIS they observ'd exactly, so that when the Swedes pass'd the Vistula these retreated before them; in the mean Time, the pretended King, Stanislaus, with a strong Body of Troops, as well Poles as Swedes advanc'd toward Sandomir, to try if possibly he could, either by fair Means, or foul, bring over the confederate Nobility to joyn with him; and he had the more Prospect of it at that Time, because he carry'd with him the In∣strument of King Augustus's relinquishing them, and in which, was somthing particularly reflect∣ing upon their Conduct; and which, if they resent∣ed, it might be very propable they would take Part with the new King. But it was not to be done, the Poles true to themselves, that is to say, ever factions, and steady to nothing but their Unstreadiness; tho' they had declin'd the Czar's Proposal for a new Election, tho' they had no new King, and their old One had disown'd them, as a People not worth any Prince's while to Go∣vern; yet they would not hear of Stanislaus, but assembling again at Opatow, they bound them∣selves by a new Oath, to oppose King Stanislaus, and the Swedes also, to the last Drop. So that King Stanislaus not being willing to use Force with them, least he should drive them again into the Arms of the Czar of Muscovy; and indeed, not be∣ing strong enough, to attack them, came away and left them, and jovn'd the King of Sweden at Minsk, in Lithuania. That which encouraged the Conse∣derate Nobility the more, was, that besides 22000 Russians, which the Czar had ordered to march to
Opatow, to defend them; they had by a particu∣lar Negotiation, brought over the Cossacks of the Ukraine, to favour their Interest; and General Mazeppa, the famous Chief of the Cossacks ad∣vanced to joyn them with 30000 Horse, and pro∣mised them, on Occasion, 20000 more.

THIS encourag'd them still the more, and made the other of the Nobility come in to them; so that they began to rise on every Side, against Stanislaus; his Friends had their Houses in∣sulted, and their Lands Wasted, and were every where fain to fly to the Swedes for Succour; even the Palatine of Kiow, was obliged to follow the Course of King Stanislaus, and with all his Depen∣dents, making about 6000 Men, came to the Swedes Camp at Minsk.

THE Swedes continu'd in Lithuania, from March to the Middle of June, not yet resolving, it seems, which Rout yet to take; And the King of Swe∣den not finding Poland in a Posture fit to be left to their own Defence; In all this Time, they could never come to any considerable Action with the Czar's Troops; The principal Skirmish we had with them, was near Mohilow, on the Boris∣thenes, where they surpriz'd a Body of about 8000 of our Men, most of them Dragoons; who, after a very Gallant Defence, in which the Swedes lost abundance of Men, were oblig'd to retire with the Loss of about 3000 Men kill'd, and taken Prisoners.

THIS Days Action might have let the Swedes have seen, that the Muscovite Troops were now quite another sort of People than they used to be, and fought with as much Order and regularity as other People; that they rallied as expertly after any Disorder; and retreated as orderly after a
Defeat. In a Word, That they would soon be equal to other Nations on all Occasions; but the Swedes were too blind in their own Praises, to foresee the Fate that was before them; so that this little Victory, did but animate them to their own Ruin, and prepare them still to do more rash Things than ever they had done before.

THE Swedes, as if irresolute still what Course to take, stay'd at Mohilow 'till the 20th of July. They were now at a Crisis of thier Affairs, if they had a Mind to march for Moscow, as they pre¦tended; the Way was before them from Mohilow North East to Smolenskow, and so keeping the Bo∣risthenes or Neiper on their Left, they had a plain Country, of about 360 Miles from Smolenskow to Moscow; it is true, the Czar had laid waste the Frontiers, and lay full in his Way with three Armies, which altogether made about 140000 Men, and these he was resolv'd they should fight at three Times, one after another, and all within two or three Days of one another, before they could go on.

BUT here it was plain the King of Sweden car∣ry'd on a secret Intelligence with that ruin'd Tray∣tor Mazeppa, having found Means by Bribe∣ry, and other Methods, to corrupt him, who had indeed, the Ukranian Cossaks much at his Call, be∣ing their hereditary General.

THIS Treaty was carry'd on, as we afterwards understood, by some of King Stanislaus's his Party, and particularly by the Palatine of Kiow, or, Kiovia, the King of Sweden's fast Friend; And in a “Word, was fully concluded, tho' in an ill Hour, as well for himself, as the King of Sweden, while their Armies lay at Mohilow.

As soon as the King of Sweden had a full Satis∣faction that this Treaty was concluded, he de∣camp'd from Mohilow, and to the Surprize, not of the Russians only, but of all the World, left the direct Road for Moscow, and turn'd away South, keeping the River on his Right, and march'd Di∣rectly to Czernikiow on the River Desna▪ on the Frontiers of the Cossacks Country, and where he had more immediate Correspondence with the Re∣bel Mazeppa, as we shall see presently.

HAD his Swedish Majesty continued at Mohilow, but 10 Days longer, he had been joyn by his famous General Lewenhaupt with 15000 Men, all gallant Troops indeed, and with a new Train of heavy Cannon, and a vast Quantity of military Stores, who was in full March to joyne him. But the King of Sweden, as I have observ'd, was un∣der the great Climacterick of his Fame, and all Things went against him, so he marched away, and General Lewenhaupt followed.

IT has been observ'd, by those who tell this Story in Favour of the King of Sweden, that Ge∣neral Lewenhaupt, having 15000 Men with him, all old Soldiers, and experienc'd well disiplin'd Regiments, he might be very well supposed not to want a Convoy; and the mean Opinion the Swedes had of the Muscovites, added to their Con∣fidence in that Affair; the King of Sweden having on that Occasion, said, as 'tis Reported, that an Army of 15000 Swedes was never beaten by the Muscovites, in a pitch'd Battle before, at least in the Memory of Man.

GENERAL Lewenhaupt had a long March, for he came from the Provinces of Courland, and Livania, where he had drawn this Army together, with great Care, and been four or five Months in
his Preparations; he made easy Marches through Lithuania, where he was joyn'd by some old Re∣giments of Swedes out of the Great Poland, and he was now come within three Leagues of Mohilow: His Czarish Majesty having Notice, of his March, resolv'd to try the Mettle of his Troops, upon this Body of Men, and to Cut them off from joyning the Swedes if possible; and, indeed, it was a Juncture that required some Coup d' Eclat; for that the King of Sweden was already possess'd of Czernikiow, on the Desua, where he had been joyn'd by the Traytor Mazxeppa, with 10000 Cos∣saks, and had the plentiful Country of the Ukrain open to him; so had General Lewenhaupt Joyn'd him, with these 15000 Men, his Army would soon have been 100000 Men; that is to say, 44000 of his own Army, 15000 of General Lew∣enhaupt, all Swedes, 8000 of the Palatine of Kiow, who lay ready to joyn him, and 36000 Cossaks who Mazeppa had promised to bring in.

IN this Case therefore, I say, the Czar resolv'd to begin and try his Fortune with General Lew∣enhaupt: For this Action he drew out a Select Body of Men out of all his Army, being about 8000 Horse, and 23000 Foot, which was the most, and gave the Command of them to that fortunate General Prince Menzikoff. But the Czar knowing the Importance of the Action, went himself in Person to see it executed, tho' not ta∣king any Command upon himself, but serv'd un∣der his General as a Voluntier.

THE Fight lasted two Days, and almost a Night, the Prince having marched with some Speed in the Morning, to come up with the Ene∣my, having shown himself in Order of Battle, abut Eleven a-Clock, he gave his Men some Time
to Rest, and Refresh themselves; so that he did not begin the Fight, 'till near Three in the After∣noon; when advancing in excellent Order, he came again in View of their Line, which was drawn up to great Advantage, being surrounded with a Morass on one Flank; and by their Carriages and a Rivulet running close by them on the other Flank: Had he entrench'd his Front, which it was easy for him to have done, and which he had Leisure enough for, it would not have been practicable for our Men to have attack'd him: But the Swedes scorn'd to Entrench against an Army of Muscovites. And this arrogant Tem∣per of theirs, was more than this once their Destruction. For now they gave us a fair Front to fall on, and we failed not to take the Offer.

“THE Onset was given by the Russian Dra∣goons, Prince Menzikoff commanded Colonel Campbell, a Scotch Man who had the Van∣guard, to cause his Regiment of Dragoons to Dismount and attack two Battalions, which the Swedish General Count Lewenhaupt had caused to advance about a Mile before the Front of his Line, and posted behind a little Morass, to dispute our Passage: Those two Battallions made so quick a Fire upon our Men, that they had hardly any time to Form them∣selves into Order of Battle; Colonel Campbell observing how active the Enemy were, caus'd the five Squadrons who had Dismounted to ad∣vance, to give Opportunity to the rest of his Troops to put themselves into a Posture to fol∣low them; and those Dismounted Dragoons ha∣ving stood the Enemies Fire for some time, his Czarish Majesty caused them to be supported by
four Battalions of his Guards, and two of Inger∣manland: Our Men pouring in their Shot, up∣on the two fore-mention'd Battalions, killed above half of them that guarded the Passage, and so facilitated our drawing up in Battalia before the Enemies front.”

“GENERAL Lewenhaupt, perceiving his Van∣guard was Beaten, resolved to prevent us; and caused his Army to march up and meet us in Battalia, then his Czarish Majesty observing that the Enemies Line extended wider than ours, ordered his Highness Prince Menzikoff, to cause four Regiments of Dragoons to alight, and they were immediately placed in our Left Wing, with two Regiments of Horse to cover their Flank, under the Command of General Pflug; and our Right was commanded by the Princes of Gallcizin and Darmstadt, whose Flank was cover'd by two Regiments of Dragoons of his Highness Prince Menzikoff's Guards; all these Dispositions being made, about Eleven a Clock the Signal for attacking the Enemy was given by a general Discharge of all our Artillery: About 12 a Clock the Enemy began to advance towards us with great Fierceness and Resolution; and the Fight being hot and obstinate on both Sides, for above an Hour and half, the Vict∣ory hung in Suspence.”

“DURING the terrible Fire, which was made every where, his Czarish Majesty appear'd in the Places of most Danger, to annimate by his Va∣lour, and Presence, all the Officers and Soldiers; and observing that the Left suffer'd much, he caused it to be reinforced by the Regiment of Guards of Prince Menzikoff.”
“THE Enemy observing, how well we acquit∣ted our selves under the Eye of our August Ma∣ster, begun to give Ground, yet drew off in Order of Battle.”

“THEN we redoubl'd our Efforts, to improve that Advantage: The Enemy being driven back to their Waggons and Baggage, the Action was for some time forborn on both Sides; about three a Clock our Cannon coming up, began to play again.”
“THINGS standing thus, His Czarish Majesty being inform'd, that General Bour was within half a League of him with 4000 Men, thought fit to wait a little for his Arrival.”
“ABOUT four a Clock General Bour came up with his Body, and was oblig'd to endure the Fire of the Enemies Artillery, before he could joyn our Right, where he was to post himself.”

“FROM this Junction, his Czarish Majesty be∣gan to entertain Hopes that all would end well; and order'd that neither Right nor Left, should renew the Fight one without the other; but the Left Wing, having stood a good while without attacking, the Impatience of all our Officers and Soldiers superceeded that Order, our Right Wing renew'd the Attack likewise with the utmost Vigour.”

“THE Enemy seeing themselves repuls'd, caus'd two Battallions and ten Squadrons of their Reserve to advance, and Charge our Right in Flank; but they were so well received, and afterwards so closly pursu'd, that, of the two Battallions, not above 50 Men escaped. Upon this Advantage, our left, and our Center, push'd forward among the Enemies Waggons, break∣ing
all their Left Wing. On their Right Lew∣enhaupt rallying his Troops, faced our Men who were among their Waggons, and caused such a Fire to be made on our Battallions and Squa∣drons, as oblig'd them to retire; but our Cen∣ter, and Left Wing advanced at the same Time against the Enemy, who were oblig'd to Face to the Right about, to make Head against us; then the Charge, was renewed with greater Fury than before, both by the Horse and Foot, and their Fire which the Enemy answer'd duly, did not cease 'till it was dark Night, when we could no longer distinugish our own Men, from our Enemis.”

“IN the Night, his Czarish Majesty consider∣ing the Difficulty of dislodging the Enemy from behind the Waggons, forbid the Officers, on pain of being Cashier'd, and the Soldiers of being hang'd, to quit their Ranks, to rifle the killed; so the Army kept all Night under Arms watching the Enemy, In the mean Time the Trophies of the Day, were presented to his Majesty, consisting of 47 Colours, and 10 Standards; and 16 Cannon, which he had gain'd, were added to our Train of Artillery.”

“THUS we pass'd the Night, which was very Cold, and towards the Morning, we saw the Enemy kindle Fires, about their Waggons. His Czarish Majesty order'd that Fires also should be made in the Front of our Line, and that we should hold our selves in a Readiness against Break of Day; which being come, we march'd towards the Enemies Waggons, expecting to meet no less Resistance than before; but we found that Lewenhaupt, had made use of that Stratagem to cover his Flight, abandoning to
our Discretion, all the Wounded, and 7000 Waggons design'd to Supply the Want under which the King his Master Labours.”

“GENERAL Pflug was immediately order'd with a 1000 Granadiers on Horse-back, and 2000 Dragoons, to pursue and harrass the fly∣ing Enemy; he had not March'd above half a League, when he found the Remains of the Enemy in a Wood, and falling upon them, he made a Slaughter among them for the Space of a League and a half, to Propoi∣sick' where the rest of the Run-aways, to the Number of 3000, retir'd into the Church-Yard.”

“OUR General advancing to Force them, they made a Signal that they were desirous to Capitulate; and then he sent a Lieutenant Colonel, with six Granadiers, to receive their Offers of Capitulation; but many of the Swe∣dish Soldiers being Drunk with Brandy, would not agree to their Officers Propositions, and many of them Firing, kill'd two of our Gra∣nadiers, the Lieutenant Colonel seeing their Headiness, retir'd. And General Pflug resolv'd not to spare them; our Granadiers and Dra∣goons enter'd the Church Yard Sword in Hand, kill'd all that resisted. During this Exe∣cution, part of them fled towards the River Soza; General Mikusch pursu'd that Party two Hours, and saw Count Leuwenhaupt Swimming through that River among his Men; whereup∣on he swam it with his Detachment, and com∣ing to the other Side, most of the Swedish Offi∣cers begg'd Mercy and he gave them Quarter, but caus'd the Soldiers to be put to the Sword: He rejoyn'd General Pflug, with all the Officers
and Booty; and those Prisoners reported, that General Leuwenhaupt was Dead of two Shots through his Body.”

“THE next Day, his Czarish Majesty caus'd Thanks to be solemnly return'd to the Almigh∣ty for this signal Victory, which cost the Ene∣my 20 Regiments, amounting to 16000 Men, among them, Major General Sculemburgh, who was kill'd on the Field of Battle, with all the Officers that were not taken Prisoners.”
“WE have 2673 Prisoners, 103 Officers, 47 Colours, 10 Standards, 16 Cannon, 7000 Wag∣gons, and all the Arms and Baggage; the Victory being compleat.”

“ON our Side, we lot 70 Officers kill'd or dangerously wounded, 1277 Soldiers kill'd, 2734 wounded, among them his Highness the Prince of Darmstadt, General Baur, Colonel Weiden, and two Muscovite Colonels.”

UPON this Dissaster, the Swedes were at a full Stop, they could neither go forward, or back∣ward, they had lost all their Ammunition, and all their Magazine, among which were 20000 small Arms, wherewith they propos'd to Arm, and Discipline the Cosacks which should Rebel; they lost 500 Ton of Musket Bullets, 6000 Barrels of Powder, and about 600000 Rixdolars in Money; their Communication with Poland was entirely cut off, and the Palatine of Kiow, the King of Sweden's faithful Allie, was utterly disabled by another Defeat given him, by the Crown Army of Poland; so that King Stanislaus, and General Crassau, who with another Army of 18000 were advanc'd almost to Lemberg, could get no intelligence of the King of Sweden, or
of his Army, nor by any Means break thorough to set him Free.

IT is true, the Province of Ukrania, a rich, fertil, and plentiful Country, supply'd the King of Sweden effectually with Provisions in Great Plenty; and his Swedish Majesty seeing what Condition he was reduced to, mark'd out a Camp, in a very advantagious Situation, on the River Desna between Czeruikhow and Mekoszi; where he caus'd strong Entrenchments to be made, and mounted his Cannon resolving not to be attack'd by Surprize. Here he resolv'd to stay till he had recruited his Magazines of Millitary Provisions as well as his Army with Troops; but during his whole Stay here, his Czarish Majesty so scour'd the Country with continual Parties, that no Mes∣senger he could ever send arriv'd, nor could he receive any Intelligence from the rest of Poland, or they from him.

DURING this long Encampment, his Czarish Majesty's General, by incessant Parties, cut off abundance of his Men, and continually harrass'd them with his Troops, and gave them two or three very considerable Defeats.

IN the mean Time, the Swedes on the other Hand, found Means to get some Supplies of Amu∣nition out of Podolia, and from Lemberg they got some small Arms, tho' all was with great Difficulty brought to them, the Confederates being strongest on that Side, and it being a most tedious Way to bring things all by Land Carriage to Kiovia in the Ukrainalso; and on the Side of Volinia, they Listed a great many Men, with which they fill'd up all the Regiments of General Leuwenbaupt's Army, which we had defeated, and made them as strong as when we first attack'd him; on∣ly,
with this Exception, namely, that they were not so good Soldiers by a great Deal.

THUS the two Armies pass'd the Winter, and the first part of the Spring. But the Season ad∣vancing, and the King of Sweden still fancying himself strong enough to put his Designs in Ex∣ecution, and hoping for great Matters from the Cossacks, he prepar'd for his Enterprize.

IT should have been obsery'd here, that the Rebel Mazeppa, finding the Czar Press'd hard up∣on the Cossacks, and terrify'd them from follow∣ing him; so that he could not bring that Number with him to his new Confederate the King of Swden, as he had Promis'd, endeavour'd by Par∣ties and Inroads on the side of Muscovy, to in∣tercept all the Provisions that should be convey'd that Way to the Czar's Army, and ravag'd the Country far and near, by the King of Sweden's Order; to punish them for which Treachery, Prince Manzickoff advanc'd with Treachery, Prince Menzickoff advanc'd with 24000 Foot, And 6000 Horse, to the East Side of the Ukrain, and having caus'd the greater Part of the Cos∣sacks on that Side to return to their Duty, he avan'd to Bury Mazeppa's chief Town and which he had sorisy'd, as well as the Place and Time would permit; Mazeppa soresecing the De∣sign, Pu 6000 Cossaeks, bold, hardv reolute Fel∣ls into the Place; which besles, was very well surisn'd with every Ting necessary for it's Dfence; the Prince, however, ame saly up Town, and formall attackd it, tho the S in a marner look n.

He had Time to lse in the Formalities peces fr a log ge, but having rised three Battcries in two Days Time, with the Help or a lti of Hans, he fired so furiously on
the Place, that in one Night and Day, he had made a tolerable Breach, which tho' it was not what they call practicable, in the Common Dia∣lect of the Enginiers, yet he caus'd it to be storm'd: The Garrison defended themselves with a great deal of Obstinacy, and kill'd the Mus∣covites by Heaps in their Ditches. But the Russi∣ans led on again, and annimated by the Presence of their Generals, fell on with such Fury, and withal, in such Numbers, that they enter'd the Town Sword in Hand, cut all the Traytor Cossacks, being 6000, as above, in Pieces; not giving Quar∣ter to one of them; which was a Piece of requisite Justice, not only upon them for their Treason and Rebellion, but in Terror to the rest, who had shew'd Inclination enough to Rebel; as for the Town it was plunder'd by the Soldiers.

NOR did their Execution fail of its disign'd End, for it effectually aw'd the rest of the Cossacks, from revolting to the King of Sweden, as was the design of the whole Nation of them, besides which, it lessen'd the King of Swedens Army 6000 Men, for those 6000 were Part of the 10000 who had join'd the Swedes with their General.

AFTER the taking of this Town, which was Sight of the whole Swedish Army, the River Desua only parting them; over which, however, the Swedes had no Bridge. I say, after this, the Russian General suppress'd entirely the Dissafecti∣on of the Cossacks, and having proclaim'd Mazep∣pa a Traytor, and caused him to be bang'd in Effigic, made the whole Body of Cossacks meet, and choose another Chief or General, which was done with the loud Acclamations of the People; so the Czar was in some Degree even with the King of Sweden, for if he deposed one King, the
Czar of Muscovy now deposed another, for tho Mazeppa was not a King in Title, he was equal to a King in Power, and every way Equal if not Superior to King Augustus in the divided Circum∣stances, in which his Power stood, even at the best of it.

AND now the King of Sweden having resolv'd to move forward, decamp'd, in an evil Hour for him, in the begining of June, and passing the Des∣na at Czeruibow advanced towards Pultowa. The Country all the Way in this March being low and level, is full of Rivers-which fall into the Neiper, and lying just cross the Way which the Swedes were to March, they had sometimes three or four of those Rivers to pass in a Day; the Reason of this is plain, for that the Course of the Boristhenes being here from North to South, and the great River receiving into it all the smaller Rivers of the Country of both Sides, the Course of those Rivers naturally must be from East to West, on the Side where the Swedish Army march'd.

THIS retarded the March of the Swedes very much, who were oblig'd to mate Bridges over most of those Rivers, and who drew a great Train of Carriages with them for their Baggage, and Ammunition, besides their Artillery.
SOME of these Rivers indeed, the Weather being dry, and the Season so far advanc'd, were low, and might be foarded by the Cavalry and Carriages, but others again could not.

HOWEVER, the King of Sweden whose Autho∣rity press'd on his Men, forc'd to March over all the Rivers, and whatever Difficulties offer'd to stand in his Way, push'd on till he came to Pul∣towa; a Town which the Czar had fortiy'd in a better manner than formerly; and as it was a
Frontier against the Budriack Tarter, who used to make their Incursions that way into Muscovy.

His Czarish Majesty finding the Swedes in Motion, broke up with all his Army from Smo∣lensko, where he had encamped in order to dispute the Ground Inch by Inch with them, if they had offer'd to move towards Moscow, and mov'd after them; he had never stirr'd from that Situation with the Gross of his Army while the King of Sweden lay on the Bank of the Desna, least find∣ing his Army remov'd, they should counter March and slip by him on the Way to Moscow; but now finding the Swedes, running farther into the Net, he pursu'd with his whole Army, which was about 70000 Men, besides about 42000 which were posted at distant Places, as at Mohi∣low, and at the River Bug, to prevent Succours passing to the Swedes.
WITH this Army his Czarish Majesty follow'd the Swedes so close, that he was always at Hand to take any Advantage that might offer.

THE King of Sweden, who was now near the End of his good Fortune, and found himself embarrass'd with the Difficulties of the Country, encamp'd under the Walls of a Town, tho' not considerable in it self, yet better fortified, and better furnish'd than he expected, wanting many Things necessary for a Seige of Importance; and which was worse, the Czar, who he had always flatter'd himself, would never venture a Battle, was, as I have said at his Back with an Army of 70000 Men, and not only seem'd resolv'd to venture a Battle with him, but posted himself in such a man∣ner, as that it was apparent he would Besiege him and his Camp, and perhaps attack his Intrench∣ments.

HAD not the King of Sweden's Courage exceed∣ed his Discretion at that Time, and his ill Fate hurry'd him on to his own Destruction, he would certainly have carry'd on his Attacks in the usual Form, and choosing a strong Situation, have en∣camped with the Gross of his Army to cover the Siege; expecting that if the Czar would raise the Seige, he should fight him with all the Disadvan∣tages usual on such Occasions; as namely, that of attacking a Powerful Army entrenche'd up to the Teeth, and posted with all possible Art and Ad∣vantage.

BUT on the other Hand, had their Resolution to Fight been attended with the usual Prudence of a good General, such as the King of Sweden cer∣tainly was, and such, as if he had not been so himself, all his other leading Men were esteem'd to be; particularly, Field Marischal Rhenschild, the Generals Lewenhaupt, Slippenback, Stakelberg, Stenbook and others; and it was very strange they should not rerain him, by Reasoning against the Measures taken; but to do him Justice, it is re∣ported that his Swedish Majesty was not so much for fighting as his Generals were, and that it was in a Council of War, before the King gave his Opinion: The case was dubious, and every Man to speak first against Fighting, least be should be supposed to want Courage, and least the King, whose Temper was 7s;o well known, should resert it; thus it was that all Men voted for even almost every one of them were against it in their Judgements.

THIS was too much the Effect of the exceed∣ing Fire in the Temper of their Monarch, who was so much by his Officers, that they it voted as they thought would be most agree∣able
to their Prince's Humour, than Safe and pru∣dent for his Interest and Honour.

THE Neighbourhood and Strength of the Muscovite Army made it difficult, and scarce practicable to carry on the Siege of the Place, the Garrison being numerous also, and well furnish'd, and the Swedes began to see a Necessity of removing the Enemy, or of raising the Siege, and upon this Occasion, the great Council of War was called, where it was, unfortunately for them, resolv'd to Fight.

BEING now come to mention the Battle it self, I refer the Reader to a full Account of it given by the Enemy themselves, because what they ac∣knowledge comes with ah Authority not to be deny'd; whereas, speaking of a Thing of such Consequence on the Side of that Monarch, whose Story we write, we may be the more suspected of Flattery and partiality; take it then from their own Accounts as follows,

“Our Army, say they, consisted of about 36000 Men if we had been all together, of whom our Cavalry made the better Half; our Infantry in the Battle, were not above 15000; neither had we any Artillery with us; the Design being to force an Enterance, and then break in with our Horse; of these Forces we left our whole Body of Reserve as before noted, in the Camp; which, with other Troops left there, were about 8000 Men; so that in the Battle we had not above 28000 Men.”

“THE King led on his Cavalry, and with him General Lewenhaupt, Steenboch, and Spar; Rhens∣child, Horn and Stakelberg commanded the Foot; as soon as we came out of the Defiles, and saw the Countenance of the Enemy, it was easie to
see we had a terrible Task on our Hands; but there was no looking back, the King with his usual intrepidity advanc'd to the Charge, and with his Horse fell upon a great Body of Musco∣vite Horse, who were advanc'd from The rest, and in a Moment drove them into the Line of Horse, which stood behind them, upon which the rest of the Swedish Horse advancing the whole Line acted at once, and push'd the Ene∣my several times into Confusion; but by the Vigilance of their Officers, and the help of new Troops, they restored their Line and fought with the utmost obstinacy: During this part of the Action, the Enemy with a great Body of Horse, and some Foot had wheel'd at some distance, and appear'd on our Flank in order to sur∣round our Cavalry, some Troops charg'd them, but being over power'd were repulsed, and this made us slacken the Charge in Front for fear of being cut of from our Infantry.”

“THAT in the mean time our Infantry ad∣vancing, and the Horse making a Halt till they came up, form'd themselves in order of Battle, the Horse on the Wings, and the Foot in Cen∣ter, and advanc'd again directly to the Enemy, Charging them with great Fury and good Suc∣cess; but the Cannon from the entrench'd Camp advancing, and the Troops opening in several Places for their playing upon us; it was impossible our Foot could keep their or∣der, or the Men stand in the Face of seventy Peices of Cannon, loaden with Cartouches of small Shot; so that our Generals saw it absolute∣ly necessary to draw of the Foot, the Horse all this while continu'd engaged, and drove the Cavalry of the Enemy every where before them,
but the Enemies Foot advancing to support their Cavalry with their Fire, our Horse also sounded a Retreat, and drew off in very good order out of the Field of Battle, recover∣ing the Defiles were our Foot was posted. The Enemy made a no pursuit at that time, the E∣nemy made shew of advancing indeed on our Left, and some Skirmishes happen'd, but they were beaten off with Loss; however, having thus left the Field of Battle to the Enemy, se∣veral Disasters follow'd; as first, being cut of from our Camp, our Body of Reserve, our Ar∣tillery, heavy Baggage, Carriages, &c. fell all into the Enemies Hands, and the Troops left there were oblig'd to yeild themselves Priso∣ners of War; in this Condition there was nothing left to consider of, but Retreating with all pos∣sible Speed before the Enemy should be in a posture to attack us, and the way for this was, if possible to reach the Baristhenes, and get means to pass over the Troops, and reach to Kiou.”

“GENERAL Lewenhaupt had the Conduct of the Retreat, and he march'd with such Expedition, that all the Troops came to the Bank of the River the next Day, about One at Night, tho' extreamly fatigu'd and harrass'd, especially the poor Infantry, of whom many died by the way, either of their Wounds, or by the extremity of the March; insomuch, that as appear'd after∣wards, there were not 4000 of them left, above 3000 of them chose rather to fall into the Enemies Hands, then suffer so severe a March, and so drop'd off some and some by the way, expecting every Hour to be knock'd on the Head by the Ene∣my, many of them wandered about the Coun∣try,
and got into Poland afterwards, and Listed in the Troops of King Stanislans, so escaping to the Swedish Army at better Leisure.”

“BUT we were in no better Condition now then before, for the River was a full stop to us; Boats there was none, we had no Materials for a Bridge, or time to ma ke it, we knew the Ene∣my was at our Heels; we had neither Strength left to Defend ourselves, nor Ammunition to Supply a Battle if we were disposed to it; nei∣ther had we Provisions to keep our Men from perishing: In this strait the main Concern of our Generals was for the safety of the King, to have him fall into the Hands of the Enemy was worse than Death to think of, there was but one way, which was to venture to Swim the great and rapid River that we lay on the Bank of, and then to make the best of his way into the Turks Dominions, his Majesty made light of the hazard; but it was easie to see that it was with extream reluctance that he parted with his be∣loved Troops, who he knew must immediately fall into the Hands of the Enemy; but there was no deliberating in the Choice; his Majesty could not by staying save his Men, and falling into the Enemies Hands with them, would but increase their Misfortune, so it was resolv'd; and the next morning the King, attended by about of the best Horse pass'd the River in a little Boat, most of the rest Swam the River, be∣ing by some Cossack Gentlemen, who it seems in that Country make light of it; they all safe on the other Side. His Ma∣jsty private Orders to the rest of his Men if could make any escape, they should fllow towards the Turks Dominions,
where they would soon hear of him, if he got safe thither. That same Evening the Muscovite Prince Menzickoff at the Head of about 10000 Horse, appear'd in sight of our Camp, and Ge∣neral Reinschild, who was then Prisoner among them, having signify'd to them, as they said, that it was probable in the Condition we was in, we would Capitulate; the Prince sent a Trum∣pet with a Swedish Captain, and a Muscovite Co∣lonel with a Letter to our General, to offer us, if we would Surrender, good Usage and hono∣rable Conditions; this was the more welcome to us, because it was wholly unexpected: The matter needed no Debate, our Circum∣stances admitted of nothing else, and if he had not sent to us; we must have sent to him, and have yeilded; wherefore our General after holding a short Council of War, return'd a respectful Answer to the Prince, signifying, that if he might have Soldier like usage, and be treated honourably, he would en∣ter into a Treaty, but that if not, they would die with their Swords in their Hands, and sell their Lives as dear as they could; in the mean time many of our Men enrag'd at the Thoughts of the Slavery of Muscovy, threw themselves madly into the River, some strip'd and Swam, but they found it worse, for many of them pe∣rish'd with Hunger, and with wandering naked over the Country, and some not able to reach over, for the River is there very Broad, were car∣ried down the Current and drown'd; to be short with this dismal Story; we obtain'd very hono∣rable Conditions, and Surrendered to the Mus∣covites; tho' we cannot say those Conditions have been so honourably prsrm'd as they
ought to have been. The Articles of our Sur∣render were as follows.”

DIV2.HEAD: THE under-written AGREEMENT shall be concluded in the Name of his Czarish Majesty, the Emperor of Russia, on the one Hand, and of the King of Sweden on the other Part; by the subscribing Generals.
DIV2.P: I. ALL the Swedish Troops, without Exception, who were commanded by Count Lewenhaupt, as well Generals and Officers, as Soldiers; shall with their Servants yield themselves Prisoners of War to his Czarish Majesty.

II. All private Soldiers, Troopers, Dragoons, and Musquetiers, shall lay down their Arms, and remain Prisoners of War, 'till their Exchange or Ransom; but they shall keep their Mounting, and all that they have, except their Arms and Ammunition; and all their Horses, exept those belonging to the Officers, shall be delivered to his Czarish Majesty.

III. All General Officers, and other Officers, shall keep their Baggage and Equipages, and their Persons shall be released without Ransom, or Exchange, as soon as Peace shall be made between his Czarish Majesty, and the King of Sweden, and in the mean Time they shall be honourably us'd, and be permit∣ted to go for a while to their own Country, on their Parole.
IV. The Swedish Artillery, all the Ammunition, Colours, Standards, and Instruments of Musick, shall be deliver'd to his Czarish Majesty, as likewise the Military Chest, or Camp Treasure.
V. The Zaperogian, and other Rebels, now a∣mongst the Troops of Sweden, shall be immediately deliver'd to his Czarish Majesty.

VI. For the Security and Confirmation of these Agreements, the afore-mentioned Articles, shall be sign'd by the Generals Commanding the Army of his Czarish Majesty, and that of the King of Sweden; and a Duplicate shall be made of this Capitula∣tion.

CLOSER.DATELINE: Done In the Camp Perewoloczea, June the 30th. O. S. 1709.
CLOSER.SIGNED: Sign'd ALEXANDER, Prince of Menzicoff. Count of Lewenhaupt.

DIV2.HEAD: ADDITION.
DIV2.P: All the Officers and Generals, shall not only retain their Baggage, but likewise their Servants, and the Commissioners, Auditors, Secretaries, Chaplains, and Surgeons, shall likewise be permitted to keep their Bag∣gage and Servants as the Officers.

UPON these Articles they being sent and ex∣chang'd, the next Day being the first of July, we laid down our Arms, and so ended our Mus∣covite Expedition: The Number and Particulars of this Surrender, as they were taken an Account of at the Surrendery; a Duplicate of which was given to the Swedish General, and which was
afterwards made publick by the Czar. Was as follows, Swedish Generals Prisoners.
Count Lewenhaupt, General of Foot, and Go∣vernor of Riga; M. Creutz and Crass, Major Ge∣nerals; the Counts Douglas and Bonde. Adjutants of the Field; Mareschal General Reinschild.

DIV2.HEAD: Regiments of Horse.
DIV2.P: Life Guards, Carelia, Standard of the Swedish Nobility, Standard of the Nobility of Livonia, Abosck and Bernebourgh, Smaland, Nieland, and North Scania. South Scania, Cruse, and Oster Gotten.

DIV2.HEAD: Regiments of Dragoons.
DIV2.P: Guards, Wennerstadt, Prince of Wirtemberg, Slippenbach, Schrotenfels, Meyerfeld, Helms, Tauben, Ducker, Alfendiel, Guildenstern; in these Regiments were seven Colonels, nam'd in the List, ten Lieutenant Colonels, and sixteen Majors nam'd, 182 Captains, 217 Captain Liuetenants, 215 Cornets, 10 Quartermasters of Regiments, 17 Adju∣tants, 522 inferior Officers, and 8637 Corporals and private Soldiers: Besides 26 Chaplains, 4 Commissa∣ris, 18 Clarks, 20 Surgeons, and 44 Surgeons Ser∣vants, 13 Kettle Drums, 67 Trumpeters and Haut∣loy, 7 Drummers, 528 Provosts, and necessary Attendants on the Troops.

DIV2.HEAD: Of the King's Foot Guards.
DIV2.P:
Colonel, aro Major, Count Oxenstrn, 8 Captains, 19 Lieutenants, 21 , 1 Adju∣tant,
121 inferior Officers, and 1196 Corporals and private Soldiers; besides a Commissary, a Provost of the Regiment, 6 Chaplains, 7 Clarks of Regiments, 6 Hautboys, 53 Drumers and Fifes, 13 common Provosts, in all 1465.

DIV2.HEAD: Regiments of Foot, or Remains of them.
DIV2.P: Upland, Dulkler, Westmandland, Westergotz, Sundermondland, Werk and Warmanland, Ofter Gotten, Jencoping, Wester Gotten, Cronenburgh, and Colmar, in these Regiments were 2 Colonels nam'd, 4 Lieutenant Colonels nam;d, 3 Majors nam'd, 60 Captains, 2 Voluntier Captains, 68 Captain Lieu∣tenants, 8 Quarter Masters, 6 Adjutants, 71 Ensigns, 296 inferior Officers, and 3056 Corporals and pri∣vate Soldiers; besides 5 Commissaries, 6 Chaplains, 4 Voluntiers, and 15 Surgeons and their Men; in all 3606.

DIV2.HEAD: Officers of Artillery, and Men employ'd in the Train.
DIV2.P:
Colonel Bierone, since dead of his Wounds, Lieute∣nant Colonel Appleman, 1 Post, 1 Major, 4 Captains, 1 Captain Lieutenant, 6 Sub-Lieutenants, 6 Ensigns, 1 Adjutant, with Gunners, Montrosses, Miners, Fireworkers, Bombardiers, and Artificers; to the Number in all, 535; the Total 1627 Persons, be∣sides, the following of the King's Houshold, Charles Guntzau, Chamberlain; Sickigell, Apothecary of the Houshold and Army; Sokimbers, Quarter Ma∣sters; Asil, Bier, and Brampt, Commissiaries; 5 Purveyors, and other Servants, Colonels, Standars, 142; Brass Cannon, four five Pounders, one of five Pound and a half Ball, 12 of three pound Ball;
Russian Pieces of 3 Pound Ball, taken by the Swedes at Wesprick, 2 Hanwitzers of 16 Chambers, 4 Mor∣tars of six, and four of three Pound Ball.

OUR Loss being thus of our whole Army, it is needless to enquire how many fell in each particu∣lar Action; but, this is certain, that what the Muscovites have publish'd of 10000 Men slain in the Battle, cannot be true; we reckon about 6000 kill'd in the Action, 2000 Prisoners, at that time also, 7000 in the Camp before Pultowa, about 2000 who swam over the River, with, and after the King, 3000 who wandred away and escap'd into the Country, and 16000 now with General Leuwenhaupt; thus far the Swedish Account.

I COME then to the Account, which was given from the Muscovite Army, which is more proper∣ly my Part, and which varies in nothing, but the Manner of Things: Which, however, is very significant to know, and is as follows.

“AFTER the Muscovites had pass'd the River Worksa with their whole Army on the 20th of June, O. S. they encamp'd within a League of the Swedes till the 24th, that Day they advanc'd within a Quarter of a League of them, and en∣camping, presently caus'd an Entrenchment to be thrown up before the Camp to prevent all Surprize; their Cavalr was posted in the Woods, cover'd by the Reoubts, furnish'd with Men; and tho' the Czar gave out Orders for preparing to attack the Enemy, they prevent∣ed him according to their usual Custom; for on the 27th early in the Morning, while it was yet dark, the Swedes came nut of the Defiles, where they had lain all Night on their Arms, and attack'd the Muscovite Cavalry both
with their Horse and Foot so vigorously, that notwithstanding they were repulsed several times, and beaten off with Loss from the Redoubts which they assaulted, the Muscovite Cavalry, who cou'd not be assisted in time by the Infan∣try, were oblig'd to retire towards their En∣trenchments; but soon return'd to the Charge, entirely defeating the Swedes Right Wing, and took Prisoner General Slippenback, who com∣manded it; while this was doing the Czar de∣tach'd Prince Menzickoff, General in chief of the Army, and Lieutenant General Rentzell, as well to cut of the Troops, who were advancing to the Assistance of the Enemy, as to attack those left in the Trenches under the Swedish Ge∣neral Rosen; the Prince marching accordingly, met in his way the Enemy's Body of Reserve of 3000 Men, whose Right Wing was Flank'd by a Wood; after some Ressistance he broke them, put some to the Sword, gave Quarters to the rest, and return'd to the main Army; leaving Lieutenant General Rentzell to proceed on to Pultowa, at whose approach the Swedish Ge∣neral Rosen retir'd with his Regiments into the Works they had made; however, the Muscovite General attack'd him, and forc'd him after some Ressistance to Surrender with all his Men at Discretion: On the other hand, the Swedish Army having in retiring joyned their Foot; all the Swedish Army drew up in order of Battle a∣gainst the Muscovite Front, at the distance of a∣bout a Quarter of a League; the Czar at the same time caus'd two Lines to move out of the Entrenchments, leaving the Third to guard the Camp, and drew up his Army in such a manner, that his Infantry made the main Body, and
the Cavalry the two Wings, of which the Right was commanded by Lieutenant Bauer in the room of Lieutenant General Rence, who was wounded in the first Engagement: The Left was commanded by Prince Menzickoff, his Presence being most necessary, and his main Body was commanded by the Czar in Person: The Field Marshal Czeremettoff; the Generals of the Foot, Prince Repin and M. Hallard, as also Lieutenant General Belling attend∣ing at his Post; Lieutenant General Brous had the Direction of the Artillery; the Muscovite Army being in this posture, no sooner began to move towards the Swedes, then contrary to expectation, these had the boldness after the re∣pulse they had receiv'd, to advance to meet them: About nine in the Morning the Fight began, and the fire grew thick on both Sides, which the Muscovites continu'd with such Brave∣ry that they defeated and broke the Swedes Army, after a Battle of half an Hour; a thing very strange, and put both their Horse and Foot to the Rout, the latter not daring to Halt, or make farther opposition, and were driven like a Herd of Cattle, with Sword, Bayonet and Pike quite to the Woods. Major-General Sta∣kelberg was the first Prisoner taken, then Gene∣ral Hamilton, Field Marshal Rhenschild, the Prince of Wirtenberg, Cousin to the King of Sweden; many Colonels and Subaltern Officers, and some thousands of Foot and Horse, a great Number of which yielded themselves volunta∣rily with their Horses, and Arms. The Musco∣vites Cavalry pursued the Swedes full speed a∣bove half a League, that the Plains and Woods for three Leagues round the Pultowa, were strew∣ed
with the Enemies Bodies; the Number of their kill'd being 8 or 10000; thus by the help of the Almighty they gain'd so compleat a Victo∣ry over the Swedes, that it is hardly to be paral∣lel'd, and that with little Loss by the Victori∣ous Arms of the Czar, and under his own Con∣duct, in which he most eminently fignaliz'd his Valour and Experience in the War, exposing himself to all Dangers, and had his Hat shot thro'; Prince Menzickoff had three Horses wounded under him; 'tis worthy to be remark∣ed, that 'twas only a Line of Foot, of 10000 Men, who defeated the Enemy, the other Line not being engaged. Here follows a List of the Prisoners, and of what was taken from the Swedes, as far as they could inform themselves in the first two Days.”

“HEREUPON the Swedes sent to his Highness Major General Cruitz, Colonel Duckers, Lieute∣nant Colonel Transetter, and Adjutant General Douglas to Capitulate, and an Agreement was presently made, sign'd afterwards by Prince Menzickoff, and General Lewenhaupt; pursuant to which, the Swedes who contrary to all expecta∣tion, were yet 16286 Men strong, well arm'd and mostly Horse, yielded themselves Prisoners of War, and laid down their Arms, surrender∣ing that Day to Lieutenant General Bauer, with the Camp Chest or Treasure, the Military Chancery; all the Colours, Standards, Kettle-Drums, and Drums; the Czar came up in Per∣son and joyn'd Prince Menzickoff, just at the time when the Swedes laid down their Arms.”

IMMEDIATELY after the Action, and before the taking of General Leuwenhaupt, and the Sur∣render of the Army Prisoners; the Czar, himself, sent an Account of the Fight in general, to seve∣ral Courts, Princes, and Persons, by Express; the Letters being written by his Majesty's own Hand, as particularly, to the Court of Eerlin, to Vienna, to the Hague, and King Augustus; the Czar's Let∣ter to his Minister, M. Goltz, at the Court of Ber∣lin, was as follows.

LETTER.OPENER: To the General, Velt Marischal, Lieutenant. MONSIEUR,
LETTER.P:
I Acquaint you, by these Presents, with the great Victory I have (unexpectedly) obtain'd, by the Blessing God, and the unspeakable Bravery of my Troops, with very little Loss on my Side; in the fol∣lowing Manner: The Enemy early this Morning, at∣tack'd with all their Forces, both Horse and Foot; our Cavalry, which behav'd themselves so well, that the Swedes were repulsed with great Loss; they drew up again in Order of Battle before our Army, where∣upon, we caused our Infantry to march out of our Intrenchments, and drew up our Forces in order of Battle; and posted our Horse, on the Wings of the Foot, which being perceiv'd by the Enemy, they did the like, and having attack'd us, they were so well receiv'd by our Troops, that they were oblig'd to quit the Field; and our Troops took many Standards, Colours, and Cannon; and among the Prisoners, there are the General Velt Mareschal Renschild, be∣sides four other Generals, viz. Slippenbach, Sta∣kellbrugh, Hamilton, and Rosen; the first Minister of State, Count Piper, the two Secretaries of State, Hermelin and Cederkielm; and some thou∣sands of Soldiers and Officers, of which we will cause the Particulars to be sent to you very speedily, because the Shortness of the Time does not permit to do it at present. To say all in a Word, the Enemy's whole Army has bad the Fate of Phaeton; we do not yet know what is become of the Person of the King of Sweden, whether he be Living, or with our Fathers. We have commanded our Lieutenants General, Galic∣zin and Baurs, to pursue the flying Enemy with our
Cavalry. We wish you, with this our Victory, all Prosperity.

DIV2.P: THUS ended all the vast Designs of the King of Sweden, of whom we shall say no more here, than that he escaped, as hath been said, into the Dominions of the Grand Seignior, and was well receiv'd by the Order of the Port at the City of Bender, a Frontier of the Turks, on the Side of Tartary, and on the Banks of the Neister, and where he meditated his Revenge, in a Manner so unbecoming a Christian Prince, as to animate the Manometans and Common Enemies of Christi∣ans, to make a War against the Czar; and was again the Occasion of much Blood, and much Cost to the Christian World, as shall appear in its Place.

HIS Czarish Majesty had now no more Work upon his Hands of this Kind, the Grand Enemy being thus gone, and that Army entirely defeat∣ed, which had been so long the Terror of Poland; what remain'd, was the Work of meer Negotiation and Alliance. The pretended King Stanislaus, and his Party, having now lost their main Sup∣porter, fell into their first Nothing, whence they came, and King Augustus dethron'd in an Arbitra∣ry and violent Manner, as has been said; was in∣vited to re-assume the Kingdom, even by many of those, who had been Instruments in turning him out.

THAT Part of the Affairs of Poland, relate so much to the Affairs of Muscovy, and the Czar had so much Glory in restoring that ruin'd Prince King Augustus, notwithstanding he had relinquish'd his Friendship, and broken his Treaties with him, that it cannot be omitted.

AS Moderation, and doing Good for Evil, is one of the Best of Christian Virtues, so forgetting Injuries, and relieving oppress'd Princes, is one of the brightest Parts in the Glory of the Conque∣ror; the Czar made it one of his first Dispatches, to give King Augustus a Part in the Joy of his Victory, and thereby let his Polish Majesty see, that he had Kindness enough left, to forget what was past, and place it all to the Account of the Violence he was under; and we were told a Mes∣sage was soon after sent to invite him to reas∣sume the Throne, with Assurances of Support, from the same conquering Hand, which had driven his only Enemy, that is to say, his only formi∣dable Enemy out of Christendom, and who was now in a State of Exile, among the Barbarians, without an Army, without his victorious Gene∣rals, without his Chief Minister Count Piper, without Friends, and without Money; and con∣sequently, that there was no Room to fear his Return into Poland, or meddling any more with the Affairs of that Country.

WHETHER this were so or not, this is certain, that King Augustus no sooner received this surprizing and unexpected News, but he began to cast about his Return and meditate his going back in∣to Poland, to recover the Crown, which was torn from his Head by Violence and War: Nor was it long before he receiv'd such Invitations from the Poles themselves, as without any Room to consider
farther, determin'd him in the Affirmative, as we shall see presently.

IF the Overthrow of the King of Sweden was a Surprize of Joy to the abdicated King Augustus, it was no less an Astonishment to King Stanislaus; indeed it was a Clap of Thunder to him, a Blat from Heaven, that at one Gust, overthrew him and all his Interest and Friends.

HE was at Lemberg when he met with the News, and had with him General Crassau, with a Body of 16000 Swedes, very good Troops, and had about 12000 Poles, who were most of them Gentlemen, and were very well mounted: So that he had near 30000 Men, besides the Palatine of Kiou, who was hearty in his Interest, and had about 8000 Men more, with him, at his capital City of Kiou, or Kiovia.

HAD the King of Sweden, after the Loss of the Battle at Pultowa, instead of Flying into the Turks Dominions he scarce knew whether, kept to the North, and gone to Kiou, and had directed all that could escape to have done the like, he had play'd a Game, that might still have renew'd the War, for his Cavalry which surrender'd to the Russians, would immediately have separated, and in small Bodies have escap'd, and perhaps five or six Thousand of them, have got together there; and having such a Body of Men at Hand, as King Stanislaus, and the Palatine Kiou had, as above, he would have been 50000 strong again immediately; but, Lui Jupiter vult perdere hos dementat, his Swedish Majesty was not to take one right Step, or do any thing but what was to pre∣cipitate himself, and all his Friends into farther Ruin.

AS soon as King Stanislaus, his People, receiv'd the News, they stood like Men Thunder-struck, looking at one another; the Poles that were with him, and adheard to his Interest, began to con∣sult their own Safety, and fled like Israelites eve∣ry Man to his Tent; so that of 12000 Horse, he had in a Weeks time, scarce 2000 left, General Crassan; with his Swedes, foreseeing the Storm that began immediately to gather behind him, I mean from Saxony, and of which I shall speak at large presently, began to consider in what Part of the World he was, namely in the remotest Part of Poland, that he had no Time to lose, and that if he did not immediately secure the Passages into Prussia and Pomerania, his Retreat might be cut off, or he might be obliged to cut his Way through with the Sword.

UPON this Consideration, he immediately put himself in a Posture to Retreat, and by long Marches, made towards great Poland; nay, he made such Expedition, that it look'd as if he had been pursu'd by the Muscovite Army; but the Truth of the Case was, that he feared more his Enemies that were before him, than those that were behind him; King Stanislaus went with him, and glad he was to have such a Convoy; for he, that a little before, had a great Body of Troops at his Command, was glad now to take Shelter in a Swedish Camp, and to quit Poland, as fast as he could, least he should fall into the Hands of his Rival.

AND this brings me to the Sum of the Affair on that Side; the Victory of his Czarish Majesty at Pultowa, had more Influence upon that remo∣ter Part of the World, by a great deal, than up∣on that Part where it was transacted; the Czar
had nothing to do, but to stand still and see with Pleasure, the Consequences of his Victory over the whole Kingdom of Poland, over the whole Electorate of Saxony, and indeed over all Eu∣rope.

I HAVE mention'd before how the Confede∣rated Nobility, call'd the assembly at Lublin, had rejected the, Invitations of King Stanislaus, and how they met afterwards at Sendomir, and how even after the King of Sweden's return into Poland, they yet kept together, and took an Oath to stand by one another; tho' at the same time they would not come into the Measures, which the Czar would have brought them to, viz, to Choose a third King of Poland.

NOTHING is more certain than that this Con∣federacy were the Life of King Augustus Cause at last, for they all a long kept a Correspondence with him, and waited only an Opportunity to re∣store him to the Crown; nor were they without very rational prospects of bringing it about, even from the first time, that they saw the King of Sweden pursue such wild Chimerick Projects as dethroning the Czar, marching into Muscovy, and afterwards into Urkania; but especially after they found that the Czar, at the Head, but of a Part of his Army had defeated General Lewen∣haupt, and such an Army of Soldiers as he had with him, who were thought to be invincible, and that all the Ammunition, and Millitary Provisions, which were carrying to the King of Sweden, were, fallen into the Hands of the Russians; these things not only put the Confederated Nobility in Heart; but they actually pursued the Design of bringing back King Augustus, let his Engagements submit∣ted
to, when under Violence, and Opposition of the King of Sweden be what they would.

“ON the other Hand it was easie to see for some time before the Battle of Pultowa, that King Augustus, had form'd new Designs, and was ta∣king Measures for another Attempt upon Po∣land, he found that notwithstanding the King of Sweden's advance into Poland, he made no great influence on the Poles; that the Nobility had an universal hatred to King Stanislaus; he found also, that altho' the Czar push'd at a new Electi∣on, yet he could not, bring the Poles to consent to it; but that they manifested an exceeding Af∣fection to his Person, and a great desire to see him once again at the Head of his Armies in Poland; the Czar also found he should never bring the Poles to fall into a Conjunction with him, but that the Interest of King Augustus reviv'd, and that he could not with all his Art, no not by threatening to abandon them to the Swedes, bring them to publish an Interegnum, much less to hear of a new Election; but that they owned to him, that they knew as King Augustus was driven by violence to give up the Crown, so he would not be backward to take the first op∣portunity to re-assume it. These Considerati∣ons brought the Czar and King Augustus also to a secret Correspondence, and even before the Battle of Lesno, where Count Lewenhaupt was beaten; King Augustus, who all the World ex∣pected would have retrench'd his Expences, and lessen'd his Troops to recover his Losies, on a sud∣den listed Men throughout all his Dominions, and among all the Princes of his House, till he had such an Army as all well knew the Revenues of his own Country could not maintain, tho'
it had been in the time of his greatest Prosperi∣ty; for he had rais'd above 30000 Men, where∣of at leaft 16000 were Horse; a Force which it was apparent, was with some extraordinary Enterprise in View: Certain it was, he could not foresee the Defeat of the King of Sweden, neither could he expect with all the Forces, which it was in his power to raise, to be able to fight the Swedish Forces; so that if he had not had some secret Assurances, he could never have been so weak to have ventured a second. At∣tempt, after the first had been so fatal to him; It is true, when by the frequent going, and re∣turning of Courriers to and from the Czar of Muscovy, and King Augustus, and from publick Conferences held with the Minister of the Czar at Dresden, some umbrage was taken, that he was forming new Designs in Concert with the Czar against the Swedish Interest, he endeavour'd to take off those Apprehensions by publickly declaring there was no Designs of that kind on Foot; ordering his Minister at the Court of Ber∣lin to signifie to his Prusian Majesty, that the Reason of those Conferences, and Dispatches, were only to ettle some mutual Pretensions between him, and the Czar; particularly, as to Patkull's Papers, and Writings belonging to his Czarish Majesty, which were in the Hands of a Muscovite Commissary, who died at Dresden; These were the Answers given upon those Occa∣sions; but we found not long afterwards that this first was only to amuze the Courts of Eu∣rope, till his Designs were ripe for Execution; for no sooner was Count Lewenhaupt defeated at Lesno, as has been said, and the Swedish. Communication with Poland cut off, the Czar
sending Word to King Augustus, that he had the King of Sweden at an Advantage, and that he would answer for giving a good Account of him. I say, no sooner were these Appearances of Suc∣cess in his View, but King Augunstus began to discover himself; the great and open Concourse of the Polish Nobility to his Court, the fre∣quent Expresses sent to Cracow, where the No∣bility in his Interest were Assembled; the visi∣ble Concert of Measures with the Crown Ge∣neral, and the Polish Army, and several other Circumstances made it no longer doubted but that he had resolv'd to return into Poland; but as soon as he had receiv'd by Express from the Czar, on Account of the Battle of Pultowa, and of the entire defeat of the Swedish Army, as you have heard, with the Flight of his Swedish Majesty to the Turkish Dominions; he then threw off the Mask, and made his Designs no longer a Secret.”

BUT this went farther immediately, for now the Polish Nobility throng'd to Dresden, to make their Court to the King, and to tender their Ser∣vice to him, and a little after this came a solemn Deputation from the Crown Army, and from the Confederate Nobility at Sendomir, to invite him to return to his People, and to take upon him a∣gain the Governvent; promising all the Obedi∣ence and Fidelity of Loyal Subjects, and to set him upon the Throne again, and maintain him thereon against all his Enemies whatsoever.

UPON all these Encouragements he could do no less than consent, so he receiv'd the Polish Deputati∣on, acquainted them with his Resolution to return into Poland, and at the same time sent an Ambassador the Czar of Muscovy, to Congratulate him upon
the News of his Victory, and to acquaint him with his new Measures, desiring his Concur∣rence, and Assistance, which was only matter of Form, all that Part having been concerted, and concluded between them long before his Prepa∣rations.

IT is time now to look back to his Czarish Ma∣jesty's Proceedings after the great Battle at Pul∣towa; the first thing was to send a strong Body of Troops over the Boristhenes, to push the flying Enemy; this Party pick'd up some straglers, but the chief Service was to hurry the King of Swed∣land forward, who hearing of those Troops in his Rear, would be sure not to return towards Poland, which was the only thing that the Czar was unwilling should happen.

SOME of the stragling Swedes, who escaped from the Battle, fell into the Hands of a Musco∣vite Officer, who was posted on the Frontier of Polodia, who attack'd them, and after a short, but bloody Engagement, the Swedes, of whom about 120 were kill'd, surrendered, and were made Prisoners, being about 250 Men; but as for about 800 Cossacks, the Russian General looking on them as Rebels, and Traytors, would give them no Quarter, but they were all cut in Pieces.

THE Palatine of Kiou was the only Man that stood firm for King Stanislaus, even after he had receiv'd News of the Loss at Pultowa, and after the Retreat of the said King Stanislaus, and of General Crassau, as above; but as his Forces were small, he was fallen upon by a Deteachment from the Russian Army and entirely defeated, and fled afterward to the King of Sweden at Bender.

THIS was that Palatine of Kiou, who brought the Cham of the Tartars and the King of Sweden
together, and so wrought with the Cham, and thro' his means with that Turkish Emperor, that he brought the Czar into the fatal War with the Turks, in which he had that Misfortune to pur∣chase Peace with the Loss of that important For∣trese of Asoph, and there-with of all that pro∣spect the Czar had of Commerce, and Conquet on the Side of the Black-Sea, of which so much has been said in the beginning of this History, and of which we shall have more to say very quickly.

IT might take up some time here to look into Muscovy, and take some Notice of the rejoycings there, upon the News of this Victory and the Triumph of the Czar at his return to Muscow, his Capital City; but I shall Couch it all in this short Abridgement at present, (viz.) that it was such as it is impossible to describe.

THE Muscovites were not a little in pain at first, on the approach of such a Prince, and such an Army, as Fame had represented the King of Swe∣den and his Army to be; and at the Apprehensi∣ons of that very Prince approaching them, who had so terribly defeated them at the Battle of Narva; and to have an Account that this Prince was beaten, and that in such a manner, as scarce ever Army was beaten before, viz. so that none at all of so great a Power should escape, except such a trifling Number as is mentioned to have gone away with that King; this must be surpri∣sing (to be sure) to them, since it was so to all the World.

BUT the Triumph of their Prince exceeded all the rest, and indeed his Czarish Majesty had as much Reason to Triumph as ever any Roman Consul, or Roman Emperor had for the greatest Victory they ever won; for the Romans exceeded
in Military Knowledge, and the Experience of Wars of all the Nations of the World; but here was a Prince, and even a Nation, who were, as it might be said, but as of Yesterday in War, yet victorious over the bravest and most experienc'd Soldiers then thought to be in the World: In a Word, it was a Victory that the World thought impossible; the Scholars beating their Masters the Russians beating the Swedes, was like the Gauls beating the Romans; which was the Wonder of the World.

AS the Glory of the Victory was great, so, the Czar being willing his Subjects should see what their Monarch had fought so boldly for, and to show familliarly to them the Affair of War, he let them see the Trophies which he brought, and what had been purchased at the Expence of their Blood. This glorious Triumph was made the 21st of December, 1701, and is here set down at large, from the most Authentick Account.

On the 11th, his Czarish Majesty attended by Admiral Aparxin, and several of the Nobility, arriv'd at a Country Seat, call'd Kolemski, which is about five English Miles distant from Moscow, Prince Menzikoff went thither on the 14th, and on the 16th, the whole Court took up their Lodg∣ings in one of the Suburbs which is separated from the Town by the River Moscow; his Czarish Majesty had appointed to receive the Compli∣ments of all the Foreign Ministers on the 17th, but a great Fire happening to break out in the Neighbourhood, the British Envoy was oblig'd to defer his Visit till the Day following; at which Time the Czar receiv'd him with great Distinction, at Prince Menzikoff's Appartment,
and was pleas'd to confer with him several Hours. Monsieur uel, Envoy from the King of Denmark to that Court, together with Monsieur Grand, his Predecessor, had Audience of his Majesty, in a private manner. But it being inconvenient the Court should stay in a Place where there were so litle Accommodation, his Majesty gave Orders that the Publick Entry should be made on the 21st, altho' the Preparations which were making for that Solemnity were not compleated, and the Triumphal Arches, of which they had erected seven, were not perfectly finish'd; the necessa∣ry Instructions being accordingly given, the Pro∣cession was perform'd on the 21st, in the following Manner.

The Seminiowski Regiment led the Way, who were followed by the Cannon, Colours, and Officers that were taken in the Battle against General Lewen∣haupt; these were closed by a Company of Preobra∣fenski Guards, the Swedish Remains, of the Battles of Pultowa, and Perewolosch marched in the next Place, the Non-commission'd Officers of this Body led the Way, next to them the Ensigns and second Lieute∣nants, in the third Place came the Lieutenants, and next to them the Captain Lieutenants, after whom the Captains of both Foot and Horse; these were followed by the Officers and other Attendants of the Train of Artillery, who preceeded the Ordinance; after which were carry'd the Kettle-Drums, and Co∣lours; then march'd the Majors, Lieutenant Colonels, Colonels, and General, Adjutans and were succeeded by the King of Sweden's Houshold, and Equipage, to∣gether with the Litter and Bed that he used in the Day of Battle; after which came the chief Officers, each marching single, in this Order; Monsieur Posse Colonel
General of the Guards, Major General Hamilton, Major General Stakelbergh, Major General Rose, Major General Crass, Major General Caxcits, Major General Schelippenback, General Lewen∣haupt, Field Mareschal Rheinschild; the whole, be∣ing closed by Count Piper, the King of Sweden's first Minister of State, then his Czarish Majesty on a stately Horse, which had been presented to him by King Au∣gustus, with his Sword drawn, which was formerly a pre∣sent from King Augustus to the King of Sweden: He followed the Prisoners, at the Head of the Preobrasens∣ki Guards, having Prince Menzikoff on his Right, and Prince Dolgoruki on his Left; in this Order they made their Procession through the City, and his Majesty was received at the first Triumphal-Arch, by the Magistrates, at the second, by Prince Gavari Governour of the Town; at the third, by the Nobi∣lity; at the fourth, by the principal Merchants; at the fifth, by the Clergy; at the sixth, by the Empresses Dowager, and the Princes of the Blood; and at the last, by the Burghers: The foreign Mini∣sters had separate Houses allotted them for their Cere∣mony, and his Majesty made a short stand at the re∣spective Places where they stood: The Cannon was fired several times round the Town during the Solem∣nity, and all possible Demonstrations of Joy, were ex∣press'd on that Occasion: About Eight or nine Thou∣sand Soldiers that were taken Prisoners, were brought into the Town on the Day preceeding; but the Officers belonging to the King of Sweden's Foot Guards, ha∣ving not arriv'd from Kiow, soon enough to appear in the Czar's Triumphant Entry, they were publickly conducted into that City, on the 27th, with the same Solemnity, as the other Prisoners, had before march∣ed, on the first Instant.

HIS Czarish Majesty treated all the chief Per∣sons of Quality, and the foreign Ministers at a publick Dinner; in the Evening sumptuous Fire Wors, on which were several Inscriptions, and Representations, was prepar'd and went off with great Exactness: The chief Machines were, a Phaiton struck with a Thunder-Bolt; and another Figure, in allusion to a late Medal Struck in Swe∣den, two Pillars were first lighted, which sup∣ported imperial Crowns, and were adorn'd with great Variety of blue, green and pale Flames; when they had burnt some Time, a Lion mov'd forward, on whose Approach, the first Pillar broke short at the Pedesal, but as he advanc'd near the second, a Spread Eagle representing his Majesty's Arms, launch'd a Rocket, which blew the Lions Head and Neck off, and the Pillar re∣mained firm to the last.

HIS Czarish Majesty, however, made but a short Stay at Moscow, he knew as well how to im∣prove, as how to gain a Victory, having there∣fore driven his two capital Enemies, the King of Sweden, and the Palatine of Kiow into the Turkish Dominions, secur'd the Frontiers as well of Poland, as of Moscovy, from their returning, by posting a strong Body of Horse, on the Frontiers of the former, about Lemberg and Kiovia; and another on that Side of the Unkrain, on the Bank of the Boristhenes, with Orders to them both, to Scour the Countries so effectually, that no Foreign Troops might enter. I say, His Czarish Majesty having thus secur'd the King of Sweden, from re∣turning into Poland or Muscovy; he order'd his Troops to File off to the North, and by easy
Marches to come to Smolensko, under the Leading of Prince Czeremetoff, and General Baur,

FROM thence, one Body of them marched in∣to Lithuania, and about 28000 of them, were di∣rected to wait the Orders of King, Augustus, who was now, in Concert with the Czar returning in to Poland as above; as soon as they heard his solish Majesty had pass'd the Oder, they were to ad∣vance to the Banks of the Vistula, on the other Side of Warsaw, to be ready to go wherever the King of Poland should lead them.

HIS Czarish Majesty had now a clear Country before him, and having before reduc'd all the Inland Part of the Province of Livonia, taken Narva, reduc'd Ingermanland, razed Scansterny on the Neva, built the Fortress of Croonslot, and be∣gan to build the Royal City of Petersburg; he resolv'd now, to attack the Coast Towns of Livo∣nia, which were very Strong, and had in them numerous Garrisons of Swedish Soldiers, who were sure to make a long and vigorous Defence; at the same time, his Czarish Majesty resolv'd, to extend his Conquest on the North of Ingermanland, into Finland, and the Hereditary Dominions of Sweden.
