IN Consequence of these Resolutions, his Cza∣rish Majesty ordered a Body of an Army to march from the Side of Pleskow and Novogrod into Fin∣land, and attack the strong City of Wybourgh, the best Port in all that Part of the Country, while another Army at the same time march'd thro' Lithuania into Livonia, and besieg'd the strong City of Riga.

THIS last was an Undertaking of great Impor∣tance, for the City of Riga was a terrible Place, strong by situation, and that situation improv'd
with the otmost Art; it had a numerous Artille∣ry, a strong Fort, or rather Fortress command∣ing the Entrance to it by Sea, call'd the Duna∣muder scans, being indeed a Royal Citadel, exquir∣sitely Fortified, and almost inaccessible; it was reported that there was in the City and the Shcans a Garrison of 10000 Men, including the Burghers, who did Duty as Soldiers, commanded by General Stromfield, an experienced Officer, and a Man from whom the World expected all that became a Man of Honour, and of the utmost Bravery.

BUT all this was far from Discouraging the Czar from the attempt; he knew the importance of the Enterprise, and that now was the critical Juncture, in which it was to be Undertaken, with a prospect of Success; the Affairs of Swe∣den being in such Confusion, that he was very sure to meet with no Interruption from without, his Majesty therefore resolv'd on the Seige.

THIS Siege was begun by Field Marshal Cere∣mettoff, but was after some time stop'd, and af∣terwards carried on only by a Bombardment and Blockade, in order to save the effusion of Blood; it was certain that there was time enough before them to reduce the Garrison to Extremity, no Relief being likely to come to the Place by Sea, and none possible to be brought by Land; at the beginning of this Blockade a most lamentable Dif∣saster befel the Besieg'd, in which the Besiegers had no hand at all; for the 22d of January the Labratory where the Engineers made their Fire∣works, and fill'd their Bombs, which was built in the Rear of the Bastions, adjoyning to one of the Magazines belonging to the Garrison took fire by accident, and the fire reaching one of the shells it burst, and in an instant the whole House, with
the Magazine, adjoyning, blew up into the Air with a Blast that shoke the whole City, and made even the Earth as far as the Russian Camp trem∣ble: There was, 800 Barrels of Gunpowder in the Magazine, besides what was in the Labratory; and besides the Shells which were fill'd; the Con∣sternation in the City was inexpressible, not a a House but suffer'd, and the whole Place look'd like a City in Ruins; of the Garrison the Bar∣racks being near the Place, 600 Men were entire∣ly lost, including the Guard of the Bastion; the Bastion it self was entirely ruined, and the great Hospital, in which was 1200 sick or wounded Sol∣diers, besides the Officers of the House attending them was blown up, and not a Soul of them all left a live; so that in the whole, near 2000 Peo∣ple were destroyed, besides such as were wounded an other Parts of the Town.

THE Governor under the greatest surprise of Mind, as well as influenced by the Blast being on the Parade of the Place, giving orders for a Sa∣lly fell down as one dead; and when by proper Applications he recovered himself, he could not hear, no not the Noise of a Drum; he had no Notion for a great while, but that a Mine had been Sprung by the Enemy under the Bastion, and that they would immediately Storm the Breach.

THE force of the Powder had not only blown up the Bastion, but it had made a Breach in the Bo∣dy of the Place nine or ten Yards wide, so that e∣ven the Horse might have come in; the rest of the Officers, while things were in this Extre∣mity, being under no such great Concern, and Consequently less surpris'd, than the Governour, resolv'd sooner what was to be done, and beat∣ing to Arms, rais'd the whole Garrison to defend
the Place if they should be attack'd; then they caus'd all the Horse Dung and Litter, which could be had to be brought to the Place, and made up the Breach in the Bastion as well as time could permit, setting three Rows of Pallissadoes before the Breach, and making a large Coupre or Re∣trenchment behind it; so that tho' the Russians, had they been aware of the Blow, might have made an Advantage of it; yet such was the Diligence of The Garrison, that they made it up, as above, the same Night that the Dissaster happen'd; nor could Muscovite Generals make any advantage of it.

THE Blockade of this Place held till the latter End of July, 1710, when General Stromfield, the Governor was oblig'd to Capitulate, the Garrison being reduc'd by Hunger, and hard Service, and by the fire of the Bombs, together with the Dis∣saster above-mention'd, to less than 2000 sound Men; the Russian Velt Marshal gave them honour∣able Conditions, as well for the Garrison, as to the Burghers and Inhabitants, Courts of Justice, and Nobility, to whom all their Priviledges, Judica∣tories, and civil Rights were continu'd and pre∣served; as to the Garrison, they were allowed all Soldierly Honours, and to be conducted to Revel, upon Condition nevertheless, that they should Em∣bark there, and return to Stockholm.

GENERAL Baur, who as I have noted before, serv'd under the Velt Marshal Czeremet at this Seige was immediately after the surrender of Ri∣ga, Detach'd with a good Body of Troops, to at∣tack Peruan, which he reduc'd in about 6 Weeks, being taken the 19th of September.

DURING the Blockade of Riga, General, or Admiral Apraxin, who for the time commanded the Land Army, besieged Wybourgh in Finland, as
above. The Governor had Conditions granted him also upon the Capitulation; but the Admiral thought fit after the Surrender to detain the Gar∣rison, by way of Reprisal, till satisfaction was obtain'd for several Breaches of the Rules of War, which the King of Sweden in the time of his Pros∣perity had practis'd upon his Czarish Majesty's Subjects: As first, detaining a Ship sent by his Gzarish Majesty's order into Sweden with a Flag of Truce, to propose some Regulations of Passes and Rules for visiting the Ships of Neutral Nations, which Ship contrary to the Law of Nations was never restor'd. (2.) Detaining the Russian Resident at Stockholm, at the breaking out of the War, tho' the Swedish Resident at Muscow was suffer'd to go Home, without any manner of Restraint. (3.) Because the Subjects of Saxony, who went into Sweden, and liv'd there in the time of Peace, on the meer Affairs of Commerce, and behaving quietly and peaceably, had notwithstanding their Effects seiz'd and confiscated.
GENERAL Apraxin found in Wybourg, part of the Magazine for the whole Province of Finland, The particulars are as follows,

DIV2.HEAD: An Inventory of the Artillery, Arms, and Ammu∣nition found in Wybourg.
DIV2.P:
“EIGHT Mortars, Four-Bombs, from 40 to 80 Pound weight; 2 Hauwitezers of 16 Poun∣ders, 3 Brass Cannon of 9 Pound Ball, and 95 of Iron, from 3 Pound to 24 Pound Ball, 8644 Granadoes, from 5 Pound to 30, 17540 Bullets, from 3 to 40 Pound, 1816 Cartridges, for from 3 to 24 Pounders, 638 Quintals of Powder, 16 of Brimstone and Salt Petre, 3 of Match, and 2
of Copper, 1660 new Musquets, and 1950 used, 1700 new Carbines, 189 damaged, &c. There were likewise found in the Town 58 Colours, and one Standard.”

THE City and Port of Revel, the Isle of Osel, the Town of Arensburg, and Kexholm in Finland, were all taken this Campaign; a Year almost, as glorious to the Czar as the last: In these Places the Muscovites found great Quantities of Cannon, and Ammunition, as also small Arms, and Hand Granadoes in abundance.

THE whole Province of Livonia was now re∣duced, except the Dunamunder schans, which Hea∣ven gave into his Czarish Majesty's hands soon af∣ter, his own way, that is, by another Blast of Powder. The Czar of Muscovy, having by this time compleated the Conquest of Livonia, and conse∣quently Triumph'd over the Swedes in those Parts of the World; his Majesty, to gain the Affection of the People promis'd them, not only the con∣tinuation of their Priviledges, but likewise to discharge them from several heavy Burthens they complain'd of under the Regency of the Swedes. He also publish'd a Proclamation to encourage Trade, and Navigation, and permitted the Ex∣portation of all the Goods of the Country, ex∣cept Timber fit for building of Ships, which he had occasion for himself, being resolv'd to have in a short time a considerable Navy in the Baltick. Foreign Shirps which were come into the Harbours of Livonia since the Conquest thereof, have been receiv'd with all possible Civility; and in short, the Muscovites neglected nothing to render their Government acceptable to Foreigners as well as to the Natives.

WE must now look a little back to the King of Poland, and to the Powers with whom the Czar of Muscovy had necessarily to do in this War; I have taken notice that his Polish Majesty having been invited by the Confederated Nobility, and encourag'd by his Czarish Majesty, and especially upon the Victory at Pultowa, to re-assume the Crown of Poland, had declar'd his Resolution to do so, and was march'd for Warsaw, with 800 Horse, having pass'd the Order the 24th of Augusst, 1709.

IT remains to take notice that his Polish Ma∣jesty, at his Entrance into Poland publish'd a full Circular Letter of the Reasons, both of his having Abdicated, and of his Return, which has so much in it of his former Concert of Measures with his Czarish Majesty, and so much just Acknowledge∣ment of his Obligation to the Czar, that when we shall find him forgetting those Obligations a second time, we shall have occasion to look back upon this Circular Letter, as a great Satisfaction, in order to make a Judgement of the Justice of his Proceedings. The Circular Letter, is as follows;

DIV2.HEAD: We Augustus II, by the Grace of God, King of Poland, Great Duke of Lithuania, &c.
DIV2.P:
TO All, and every One, this may concern, and in particular, to the most Venerable, the Venerable in Jesus Christ; the most Illustrious, Magnificent, and Generous Senators, and Officers of the Nobility, and to all the Inhabitants of the Kingdom of Poland, and the great Dutchy of Lithuania, of what soever Condition they be: We make known what follows, you may have easily understood from our Proceedings, tho'
we did not declare it; that altho' through a hard but unavoidable Necessity, we were obliged to absent our selves from you with the Body, yet you always re∣main'd in our Hearts: However, seeing that God who has been mov'd with Compassion on one Part, for our Sufferings and Misfortunes; and provok'd on the other, by the excessive Pride of our Enemies; be∣gins to promise more favourable Days to the King∣dom of Poland; and seeing on the other Hand, that in maintaining the Confederation of Sendomir, in all its Parts, you have used your utmost Endeavours, for preserving the Republick in the same Condition in which we left it, according to the Example of true and faithful Polanders; who have on all Occasions, express'd their Loyalty to their Kings. And 1astly, Seeing that after an Heroical Patience, and so long a Tryal, you are continually exhorting us, to re∣turn and Resume the Government of the Kingdom of Poland. We on our Parts being no less desirous than you, or any Member of the Republick, to express our Paternal Affection and Fidelity, being so indispenci∣bly obliged thereunto, by the Pacta Conventa; that according to the express Terms thereof, it ii not left in our Power, altho' we should have a Mind to it, to renounce a Crown which was so lawfully put upon our Head: Insomuch, that whatsoever has been done con∣trary thereunto, is to be look'd upon as null and void, as you have declar'd, in the Diets of Leopold and Lublin: Therefore we are return'd into Poland, to assert and defend the Honour of the Crown; and we declare, by these Presents, that as we have therein no other Aim, than chiefly to maintain the holy ortho∣dox Faith, defend the ancient Rights and Privileges of the Nation, and preserve the Bounds of the King∣dom; of all which, we are ready to give full Assu∣rances, in the next Assembly or Council, by confirm∣ing
the Pacta Conventa, as to the Points aforesaid, according to the desire of the States: Therefore, We earnestly invite all such, as are faithful to us, and adhere to our Majesty, either Burghers or Military Men, to assist us; and in this, we think to give them Proofs of our paternal Gratitude; at the same time we offer our Clemency, and paternal Affection, to all those, who before we left the Kingdom, or since, have quitted our Party upon any Pretence whatsoever; re∣presenting unto them, that unless they are willing, through a desperate Attempt, to expose the Publick to a general Subversion, they have no Reason to de∣cline this Act of Indemnity; being willing to forget their Offences, and promising to receive them into our Favour and Protection. Furthermore, We assure the States of the Republick, that in the Passage and Quartering of our Troops, we will keep them under an exact Discipline, and will have all possible Regard to the Estates of the Clergy and others, as long as the War will continue; and after the Conclusion thereof, which we pray God to hasten, we promise, upon our Royal Word, to send them, without delay, out of the Kingdom; being willing, wholly to conform ourselves therein, to the Intentions of the Republick. We Command all Officers, Civil and Military, and others, to cause these Presents to be read and published, in all Places.

THIS Circular letter was publish'd by King Au∣gustus, at the Head of his Army as soon as he enter'd Poland, and it was annex'd to a long Mani∣festo, and to a like Circular Letter to the Nobility and Clergy of Lithuania inviting them to come and joyn him at Warsaw, offering to receive them, and promising his Amnisty, or Pardon, even to those who had joyn'd King Stanislaus, and acted against him.

THE Poles embraced this latter part, with al∣most an universal Consent, and the King of Poland was received with all the Caresses, and all the Tokens of Zeal and Affection imaginable; as to the particulars, such as the vast Concourse of the Nobility to him at Warsaw, and the Harangues, Speeches, Compliments, and Promises, &c. made to him, by those that attended his Court at War∣saw, they relate more particularly to the History of King Augustus, and I therefore refer the Rea∣der to other Writers of them; only observing that in the Course even of his History, we may per∣haps see of how little importance, Vows and Pro∣testations of Sincerity, Loyalty, and Fidelity are in this Age, in those Parts of the World.

BUT leaving these things, it follows of Course now to carry our History farther from his Czarish Majesty's share of acting than before, and go as far as Denmark to find another Allie in this War, in whose Territories, we shall quickly find his Majesty obliged to act, as well in Person as by his Armies and Navies, and to make a yet more considerable Figure in the War, than ever he did be∣fore.

IT has been mention'd in the beginning of this Work, how far the King of Denmark was an Allie with the King of Poland, and with his Czarish Ma∣jesty,
in the beginning of the War with Sweden; how the English and Dutch assisting the Swedes by Sea, and the Troops of the House of Lunenburg assisting the Duke of Holstein by Land, the King of Den∣mark was forced to make a Disadvantageous Peace with both Sweden and Holstein, and have the Mor∣tification to see his Conquest in Holstein snatch'd out of his Hands, to raise his Siege of Toningen, and to see the King of Sweden under the Protecti∣on of the British and Dutch Squadrons Land just at his Palace Gate, and Bombard his capital City of Copenhagen.

BUT now the Tables were turn'd, the King of Sweden was, as it were, out of the World, and the Czar the King of Denmark's Allie, and fast Friend, was Victorious, and very Formidable; now his Majesty of Denmark thought it was a Juncture happily offer'd by Heaven, for him to push the Swedes in his Turn, and to retrieve the Dishonour which he had suffer'd, and that he had as just Rea∣son, to Break with the King of Sweden, as the King of Poland had, whose Case was many Ways the same.

WITH these Thoughts, and concerting Mat∣ters with his Czarsh Majesty for assistance, as well by Sea as by Land, he resolv'd to break with Sweden immediately, and according to the King of Poland's Method, his Danish Majesty publish'd also a Manifesto, of the Reasons for his Resolution; this, as being not to our present Purpose, I omit, and only mention it to Intro∣duce the Story of his Czarish Majesty's Part in this War, which follow'd after.

THE King of Denmark having declar'd “War, and brought a considerable Army together, re∣solv'd to pass over with them to Shonen, a Pro∣vince
of Sweden, once belonging to Denmark, but Conquer'd formerly by the King of Sweden, and conceded to Sweden, by the Treaty of Ros∣child.

TO bring this Abridgment of the History of this War into a narrow Compass, it is to be ob∣serv'd, that the Swedes being at first surpriz'd, to be thus attack'd, were at first under great Apprehen∣sions, but General, Count Steinhock, one of the Swedish Officers at the Battle of Pultowa, and who made his Escape out of that Battle, being ap∣pointed to Command the Swedish Army, gave Battle to the Danes, under the Walls of Helsing∣burgh in Schonen, and entirely defeated their whole Army, taking all their Cannon, Baggage, and Ammunition, and forcing the Remainder of their Army, to embark as well as the could, on board some Dutch Ships in the Sound, and get over into Jutland, and to Elesnore, to save their Lives; the Swedes kill'd in this Battle, about 3000 Men, and took near 4000 Prisoners.

THIS Victory deliver'd Sweden effectually, for a time; but the King of Denmark, who burn'd with an impatient Desire of Revenge, not being equal to his Enemies, enter'd into a Treaty with his Czarish Majesty, to be supply'd with 8000 Men, who were to be Convey'd to Copenhagen by Sea.

IT now comes in the Event of Things, to take Notice that the Czar of Muscovy, having, as has been fail, built a Royal City on the Neva, and a Fortress defending the Port, by which it was effectulaly secur'd, so as to be able to receive and protect any Number of the bigest Ships. His Majesty whose Genius for the Sea Service, has been sufficiently mentioned, resolv'd to build
himself a Royal Navy; and to that Purpose, having now made himself Master of Narva, and Riga, Wyborg, and Revel, and other Places on that Coast, he thereby got great Supplies of Seamen, besides what he hir'd at other places.

IN a Word, such Expedition his Majesty made in building Ships of his own, and employing also several Persons to buy Ships of great Burthen, in England and Holland, which he fitted up as Ships of War; that by this Means his Czarish Majesty began to haVe a Fleet at Sea, as well as the Swedes and Danes, tho' not at first of so great Ships; tho' now he has built so many noble, large, beautiful Men of War, that he dispises those bought Ships, which being built generally for Merchants Busi∣ness, and not for the War, were not so useful as those which he built.

FOR the effectual Furnishing these Ships with experienced Seamen, for managing them, his Czarish Majesty was not dismaid with the Impos∣sibility; he got Men for Money, in almost all Parts of Europe: And thus his Men of War appear'd in the Baltick in this Danish War, of which we shall say more in its Place, sooner than could have been imagin'd: From these Beginnings, his Czar∣ish Majesty has raised himself to that formidable Posture in his Marine Affairs, which we see him in at Present.

BY the Conversing with, and by Direction of the foreign Seamen, which his Majesty has entertain'd in his Pay, his own Subjects are gradually bred up to thte Sea, and are found to be as expert in guid∣ing the Ships, and as bold and daring in Fight, as can be desir'd of them; and even the Men, fol∣lowing in that, the Genius of their Sovereign, appear pleas'd and delighted with the Service,
and with Maritime Affairs; so that now his Czarish Majesty has many Thousand able Seamen of his own Subjects, and will in a few Years have as many Thousand more as he pleases.

TO furnish himself with Ships he had nothing to do but to furnish himself with Builders, and Carpenterps, having all the Materials for building with in himself, and able to furnish all the Nati∣ons of the World, besides: Naval Stores of all kinds are the natural Produce of his Country, and our East Country Merchants know very well, that even the Royal Navies of great Britain, Hol∣land, Frarce and Sweden are furnish'd with Hemp, Flax, Timber Plak Pitch and Tar, from his Czarish Majesty's Dominions, and as for his Iron, which is the only thing wanting, he has enough in his own Country, if they please but to dig for it, and of Copper also.

HIS Czarish Majesty's known Diligence in these things is such, and his Application has been follow'd with so much Succcss, that the List of his Fleet, as I have seen it in the latter End of the Year 1720, was thus,
36 Ships of the Line, from 50 to 104 Guns each.
28 Frrgates, from 12 to 40 Guns each.
20 Brigantines and Sloops, from 4 to 10 Guns each.
360 Gallies for Transporting Soldiers.
120 Transport-Ships, and Ships employ'd in fetching Timber, and Naval Materials from Riga to Petersburg.

IF this List he a true One, I refer the Reader to any, or all the Histories in the World, to find
out one Example of any Prince in the World, who from having not one Ship, or one Sea-Port in those Seas, did in so short time furnish out such a Navy, and bring a Nation, who before knew little or nothing of the Sea, and had neither Genius for it, or Notion of it, to be Masters of the Business, ex∣pert and able Seamen, and equal, if not Superi∣or to all his Neighbours of the Baltick.

IT was but three Years between his Czarish Ma∣jesty having not one Ship, and a strong Navy, not one Port in those Seas, and be Master of six of the strongest Port Towns in the North, (viz.) Riga, Pernau, Revel, Narva, Petersburg and Wy∣bourg.

THE King of Denmark, as I have noted had declared against Sweden, and had Landed an Ar∣my in Schonen, but was driven out again by plain Force, and his Army entirely routed, and cut in Peices at the great Battle of Helsingburg: This throws him into the Arms of his Czarish Majesty, who was now become the general Refuge of op∣press'd Monarrhs, his Czarish Majesty embracing all occasions to Support the Enemies of Sweden, went in Person to his Assistance, where a second Descent upon Schonen, was resolved, and his Ma∣jesty carried such a Fleet, and such an Army to assist in that Work, that had been more than suf∣ficient to have reduc'd the whole Kingdom of Sweden, rather than a Province, which attempt, how it was laid aside, and why, and what the Consequences of it were, we may see farther that the relating the Story, of which in its turn.

BUT we must now turn our Eyes to the East and the South, from whence new Enemies were rais'd up by the indefatigable bustle of the King of Sweden, and the Palatine of Kiou, of whom I took
Notice, that being defeated he fled to Bender, after the King of Sweden.

THE King of Sweden was now come to Bender, where the Bassa receiv'd him Civily, but would not go any Length in protecting and succouring him, without Orders, and therefore sent a Chioux Express to Constantinople, for farther Instructions, in the Affair of the King of Sweden; the Answer to which, was, an express Order to shew the King of Sweden all possible Respect, to assure him of the Protection of the Grand Senior, and to assign him a Place to reside in, near the Town; and to defray his Expence, and the Expence of all his Retinue, out of the Publick Treasure; sending at the same time, a Messenger to the King of Sweden, to condole the Necessity of his Flight, and to assure him of a powerful Protection from the Grand Signior; with his Assistance, as far as he was able to restore his Affairs: This was brought at the first Enterance of the King of Sweden into the Turk's Dominions, but the King of Sweden found Means afterwards, to put the whole Turk∣ish Government into a Ferment, by the Means of the Cham of Tartary, and the Platine of Kiow above-nam'd.

IT seems, the Palatine was an Intimate of the Tartar Prince, and receiv'd signal Favours from him, upon the first News of his Misfor∣tunes, and some time after, the Palatine took a Journey to the Camp of the Cham, to return his Acknowledgement, but principally to set on Foot the Conferences, which afterwards produc'd such remarkable Events.

AT this Interview, the Palatine firmly in∣gaged the Tartar Prince, in the King of Sweden's Interest; and from that Time forward, they
meditated together, the proper Measures for bring∣ing in the Port to the same Sentiments, and to break, if possible, the Peace between the Grand Seignior and the Czar, and bring a War upon the Muscovites.

THEY had Room to Insinuate the exorbitant growing Greatness of the Czar, upon this Defeat of the King of Sweden, the Danger which hung over the Head of the whole Ottoman Empire from the encrease of Naval Power in the Black Sea; the Czar building a Royal Navy at Veronitz, his Fortifying of Azoph, and threatening, even the imperial City of Constantinople it self.

THIS with some other, and more powerful Motives, inflam'd the Cham of Tartary, who fail'd not to have them represented with Advantage to the Grand Vizier, Embarking the Bassa of Bender also in their Interest.

THIS Issued in the Palatine of Kiow's going to Constantinople; some told us he was sent for by the Grand Vizier; others, That he was sent as an Envoy from the King of Sweden; others, That he was sent by the Cham, or Han of Tartary. Be that as it will, `tis certain that they manag'd their Affairs so artfully, that a grand Divan was call'd at Constantinpole; the Grand Seignior, the Grand Vizier, the Muffty, and the Captain Bassa, or Admiral, were all brought into it being perswad∣ed that assisting the Swede, and declaring against the Muscovite, was absolutely necessary, and this was the only Crisis, when it might be effectual∣ly brought to pass, and when the Czar would necessarily be reduc'd, and all the Danger ap∣prehended from him, be avoided, and return'd upon himself.

IT was about the middle of November, 1710, when the Turks came to a Resolution, in their great Givan at Constantinople, that it was necessary to Break with the Czar; immediately the Horse-Tail, was set up at the Gate of the Vizier's Pal∣lace, and the Russian Ambassador was clapt into Prison in the seven Towers, according to the Cu∣stom of the Turks in such Cases.

THE Cham of Tartary was, it seems, at this Divan, and appearing to concur with the Propo∣sal of a War, making a long Speech to the Coun∣cil to move them to it, by setting forth the great Growth of the Czar's Empire, the Improvement of his Soldiery, and the Naval Preparations which he was making, to attack the Imperial Ci∣ty of Constantinople, and to Force a Passage and Communication with the Levant, and with the Emperor, and the Venetians, the ancient Enemies of the Turkish Empire.

THIS Discourse, together with his setting forth the great Opportunity put into their Hands, upon this Junction of the King of Sweden, to reduce the Power of the Czar, and even, if needful to de∣throne him, annimated the Turks to that Degree at the War was resolv'd on with the greatest Allacrity imaginable, and the Preparations began Immediately; for the Cham was sent Back to be∣gin Hostilitics and order'd to make Excursions; the Palatine of Kiou had a great Sum of Money given him, for the King of Sweden; and that Prince was encourag'd to entertain a Body of Troops, to be able to enter Poland, under the Protecton of the Grand Army of the Turks, when they should advance to the Frontiers; and Munsieur de Kiou had 10000 Dollars given
him for his own Share, and to support himself and Friends.

HIS Czarish Majesty was not much alarm'd at this, his Affairs being at that Time in so good a posture, that he was able to appear Equal in the Field to any of his Enemies, or to all of them if they were put together. However, his Majesty was not backward to make the needful Prepara∣tions; and when it appear'd that nothing was to be done by Negotiation, he prepar'd to repel Force by Force, and in the mean Time, caused his Troops to march for the Frontiers, to prevent the Ravages and Incursions of the Tartars.

WHILE these Things were doing, and that both Sides prepar'd for War, we must bring our own Country of England into a little Demellez, or Broil, with his Czarish Majesty, in which there is, however, this to be said, that her Majesty Queen, Anne being sensible, that the Injury was done on the Side of England, and that the Czar had Justice on his Side, nothing was omitted that could reasonably be done, to give his Czarish Ma∣jesty Satisfaction; the Case was about an Affront put on the Czar's Ambassadour, by some Tradesmen here, who very rashly, and without considering as they ought to have done, the publick Character he carryed, Arrested Monsieur Matteuoff, the Russian Ambassador, and insulted him very rudely, also detaining him in Custody for some Time.

THIS we must not over-look; the Story is thus, Monsieur Andrew Matteuoff, was Embassador Resident to her Majesty the Queen of Great Britain, from the Czar of Muscovy: Upon some Occasion or other, he was Arrested, as above, by some private Persons; who finding his Excellency had had Audience of Leave of the Queen, and was going
away; and imagining, or pretending to imagine, he would leave the Kingdom, as it were in Cog∣nito, without paying a few Debts which he ow'd; imploy'd some Bayliffs to Arrest him; the Am∣bassador justly surpris'd at this Treatment, in Relation to the Laws of Nations; and perhaps not so readily submitting to the stop, was very roughly handled by those sort Canibals: Upon which, he made Application for Redress to her Majesty, and her Council, who immediately took Care to confine those Fellows, who had thus, in Contempt of Authority, put this Affront upon him. There were various Stories which flew about, in Reference to the Particulars of Reparation insisted on, by his Excellency, which I shall not trouble my self to repeat. But in short, his Excellency, at last, seem'd to be a lit∣tle satisfy'd; and her Majesty, even after his De∣parture, order'd her Attorney-General, a little before the Beginning of that Micaelmas Term, to prosecute those who had been guilty in that Par∣ticular, in the Queen's-Bench Court. That this was all that could be done, was certain; but how little the Russian Ambassador was satisfy'd with it, will appear by the following Letters, which pass'd between Mr. Henry Boyle, now Lord Charleton, then Secretary of State, and the said Monsieur Mattueoff, who was retir'd to Holland; and by which the whole of the first Part of that tedious Story may be fully understood; the first Letter was from, the Ambassadour to the Secreta∣ry, as follows.

LETTER.P: “HAVING observ'd (ever since I had the ho∣nour of being Ambassador extraordinary of his (Czarish Majesty the Emperor of Great Russia, at the Court of Great Britain) the sincere and particular Affection which her Majesty as showed to my Master, and her earnest Desire of Maintaining a good Correspondence between the two Crowns of Great Russia, and Great Bri∣tain; also the Queen's Zeal for Justice, so well known throughout the Universe: And, Lastly, the singular Favour and Benevolence her Ma∣jesty has been pleas'd to Confer on me, I have all the Reason in the World to hope that she will vouchsafe to give me a Satisfaction proportio∣nable to the unparalell'd Affront which was put upon me Yesterday in the Evening, in the Street call'd, Charles-Street.”

“THE matter of Fact speaks of it self, and I shall only say in short, that the Bailiff of that City had the Rashness to Arrest me in my Coach, and to carry me a Prisoner to the Black Raven, a scandalous House, without notifying to me the Reason, and to abuse me, by thrusting himself into my Coach, and seizing on my Person, af∣ter taking away my Sword, Hat and Cane, as it were from a Malefactor; not only contrary to the Law of Nations, but even the Right of all private Persons, the immunity of Ambassa∣dors, and their sacred Priviledges are sufficient∣ly
known; and as for the Pretence of Debts alledg'd, it is impudently done; for I have appointed this very Day for the time of Pay∣ment, and I am so far from going away with∣out Discharging them, that I have not as yet receiv'd any Letter of Recredence, nor Passport, nor other things Necessary for my Departure; so that this share has been laid for me, purely with a Design to insult the Honour of his Czarish Majesty, in the Person of his Representative; therefore I solemnly Protest against this Vio∣lence offer'd to the Law of Nations, and Demand that all those who are guilty of it be hereby pu∣nished.”

“THE Queen, who is so zealous of the Respect to the Ambassadors of Crown'd Heads, and has so gloriously vindicated the Honour of the Earl of Manchester her Ambassador at Venice, and caus'd a rigorous Punishment to be inflicted on the Officers of the Custom-House; some of whom were set in the Pillory, and others con∣demned to Imprisonment, only for insulting the Gentlemen of his Retinue, cannot but most just∣ly Revenge the Affront lately put upon me by a Corporal Punishment.”

“COUNT Zobor, who was delivered up to the Dis∣cretion of the King of Sweden, for picking a Quar∣rel with his Envoy; likewise affords an Instance of the satisfaction I require, as being desirous of nothing with greater Earnestness, than to avoid all the ill Consequences of this Affair: For in Case the Criminals are conniv'd at under any Colour whatsoever, I shall be oblig'd to take o∣ther Measures, and retire without Recreden∣tials, leaving the whole matter to the Manage∣ment of his Czarish Majesty my Master, as the
Protector of his injur'd Honour, and his abus'd Minister,”
LETTER.CLOSER: Sir, I am, &c. To Mons. Boyle, Minister and Secretary of State to Her Majesty of Great Britain. Sign'd A. De MATUEOFF. Mons. Mattueoff, receiving no Answer to this Letter so soon as he expected, be followed it with ano∣ther in four Days time, as follows, (viz.)

LETTER.P: “FOR as much as I have not Receiv'd any Testimony of Concern or Regret, neither on the Part of the Queen's Majesty, nor from any of her Ministers since Thursday last, the 22d In∣stant, when I sent to you in writing any Com∣plaints about the wicked Attempts made upon my Character; and in Regard that no Resentment has been in any wife shewed upon the occasion of that Indignity, in which the Honour of his Czarish Majesty my Master has suffered, after an unheard of manner, you cannot take it ill that: I intreat you to get a Pass-port for me as soon as possible, and without Delay, to the End that I may forth with go out of this Kingdom,”
LETTER.CLOSER: I am, Sir, &c. Sign'd, A. De MATUEOFF.

DIV2.HEAD: A Copy of the Answer to the Former from White-hall, the 27th of July, 1708.
DIV2.P:
ACCORDINGLY, as I had the Honour to tell your Excellency the first time I was with you, after the great Affront that was put upon you, I have us'd my utmost Endeavours with all the Zeal I Profess for your Excellency's Person, and Character, to find out the most effectual Means for causing a due Repara∣tion to be made you; as soon as I arriv'd at Wind∣sor, I inform'd the Queen of the Outrage committed against your Excellency, and her Majesty order'd me to assure you, that she is extreamly Concern'd upon account of that enormous Procedure, and highly displeas'd with Her Subjects who were the Authors of it; and for as much as the Queen has all the Respect imaginable for his Czarish Majesty, whose Friendship and good Cor∣respondence have been at all Times, and ever will be most Dear and Precious to Her; and in Regard that she has a very peculiar Esteem for your Excellency's Person and Merit, she will omit nothing that lyes in Her Power, to give an ample Satisfaction for the extraordi∣nary affront which has been put upon your Excellency; and to shew her own Resentments on Sunday last, an extraordinary Assembly of her Majesty's Privy-Coun∣cil was call'd at Windsor, and seven of the Princi∣pal Accomplices in that desperate Attempt were ta∣ken up, and committed to Prison; and the Council is to meet again about that Affair, as soon as possible, which will be on Thursday next, to Treat in the same manner the rest who shall be found guilty of that in∣solent Presumption: And further, the Queen has or∣dered her Attorney General to draw up an Indictment
against all those Persons, to the End that they may be Punished after the most severe and rigorous Manner, that can be according to the Law of this Realm; and I am very sorry that your Excellency expresses so much earnestness to Depart, since one would be glad that you would stay to see with what strictness Endeavours would be us'd to give you Satisfaction.

AS for my Part, I am extreamly troubled the Oc∣casion is so Bad, and the Subject so Disagreeable, up∣on which I profess my self Devoted to your Service, but as I always took great Delight, when I was other∣wise employ'd; so your Excellency will permit me even on this unfortunate Account to declare how much I am Concern'd for your Interest, and with what Af∣fection and Esteem,
DIV2.CLOSER: I am your, &c. Sign'd, H. BOYLE. To his Excellency M. DE MAT∣TUEOFF, Ambassador Ex∣traordinary of his Czarish Majesty.

DIV2.P: THE Ambassador was so far from being satis∣fied with the Letter above, that he immediately demanded his Pass-port for himself, and Family, in a short Letter as follows,

LETTER.P:
“PURSUANT to your Word, which I obtain'd this Day, I waited from Noon, till about Half an Hour after Three a-Clock for the Resolution in Writing about the solemn Com∣plaints
I to you the 22d wrote Instant; but for as much as the Business very much Resembles so many former Promises, which prov'd Inef∣fectual in other Affairs, I shall leave it to your Discretion, and only intreat you to send me a Pass-port for my self and Family: Sir, I expect at least this Favour from your kind Disposi∣tion,”
LETTER.CLOSER: Who am, &c. To Monsieur Boyle, Minister and Se∣cretary of State to her Majesty the Queen of Great Britain. Sign'd A. DE MATUEOFF.

DIV2.HEAD: Mr. Secretary Boyle, tho' very unwilling the Am∣bassador should have gone away without having first receiv'd full Satisfaction for the Ill-usage he had met with, sent him the following Letter, with the Pass-port enclos'd.
DIV2.P: “I HAVE sent to your Excellency this Morn∣ing the Pass-port you desir'd, and as for the Orders concerning your Moveables, having writ about them some time ago, I have since got further Information in the Treasury, where they assure me that the Orders are issued out; and that the Officers of the Custom-House are to wait on your Excellency this Morning, to cause the Equipages to be Transported without any Molestation, and I hope they have already done it to your Excellency's Satisfaction.”

“I ALSO give my self the Honour to notifie to your Excellency, That an extraordinary▪ Meet∣ing of the Lords of the Queen's Privy Coun∣cil is to be held this Day at Noon, to enquire farther into the Circumstances of that dismal Affair; they have made a strict Search after those who were in any Wise Concern'd therein, and have caus'd Ten others to be apprehended; so that there are at present Seventeen Persons confin'd in Prison, for being concern'd in that enormous Action against your Excellency, and further Orders have been given again to the At∣torney General to Prosecute them with the ut∣most Rigour, and to omit nothing that may Contribute toward the making to your Excellen∣cy the most signal Reparation that can be accord∣ing to our Laws.”

“I have already had the Honour to assure your Excellency of the Queen's Sentiments touching this Outrage: But I am to Repeat again, that Her Majesty will not forbear by all possible Means, to shew the extraordinary Indignation She has conceiv'd, against those who have put so notorious an Affront upon the Ambassador of Her good Friend, and Allie, his Czarish Majesty your Master.”

“I cannot conclude without returning Thanks to your Excellency for your last Letter of Ye∣sterday, assuring you that my Duty, as well as Inclination engages me to use my utmost Efforts, in order to procure the most ample Satisfaction for your Excellency; and that nothing affords me greater Delight, than being perswaded
that you'l do me the Justice to believe, that I am with a great Deal of Respect, and Af∣fection,
DIV2.CLOSER: SIR, To his Excellency, Monsieur De MATEUOFF, Am∣bassador Extraordinary of his Czarish Majesty. Sign'd H. BOYLE.

DIV2.P: AFTER these Letters were written on both Sides, the Muscovite Ambassador retir'd to Hol∣land; but a new Memorial was soon after pre∣sented, on his Part, at the British Court, with a Letter sent by his Czarish Majesty himself, a Copy of which is here subjoin'd.

DIV2.HEAD: A Translation of a Letter, written in Latin, by His Sacred Czarish Majesty, to the Most Serene Queen of Great Britain.
DIV2.P:
WE, cannot forbear notifying to your Majesty, with how great Trouble of Mind and horror, by the humble Remonstrances of Andrew de Matteuoff, our Ambassador at your Court, Charg'd with several im∣portant Commissions; me have receiv'd an unexpected Peice of News, viz. That the said Ambassador, after having obtain'd an Audience of Leave of your Majesty, at London, the Place of your Residence; out of premeditated Malice, and of set Purpose, (as
it appears) was set upon in the open Street, by several Bailiffs, who receiv'd their Commission from a certain Viscount or Sheriff, and acted like Robbers against the Publick Laws of Nations, with an unheard of, and unparallell'd Barbarity: For by Dispersing his Servants, violently breaking his Coach, taking away his Sword, Cane and Hat, and tearing his Cloaths; put, upon him such a notorious Affront as no civil∣liz'd Person would presume to offer to a foreign Mini∣ster of his Character; nor even to a Commoner, unless he would run the Risque of being Most severely pu∣nish'd: And what most of all inhances the Heinous∣ness of the Fact, while our said Ambassador, crying out for Help, against the Outrage and Robbery, had got together some Persons, who intended to rescue him out of the Hands of the Pillagers; and when they, for that Purpose, bad stopp'd the Coach, and being desirous to know the Cause, brought him into the next Victualling House, the audacious Miscreants, produc'd a Warrant to detain the said Ambassador, for the Sum of 50 l. Sterling, due from him, to cer∣tain Merchants: And when the People, who ran together, began to separate again, upon the Discovery of the Matter; they forthwith hurry'd him into a Hackney Coach, taken by Force, and delivered him up to be confin'd in a certain Infamous House, call'd the Black Raven and altho', our said Ambassa∣dor, had notify'd this unheard of, and flagitious Out∣rage, to the Secretary of State, nevertheless, he could not be found; and Secretary Walpole, only came to the House, not to set him at Liberty, (as most evidently appears) but to be an Eye Witness of this Usage; the like of which, was never seen under the Sun; neither did he offer any Assistance to our Am∣bassadour, as a Person skill'd in the publick Law of Nations, which Protects the Character of an Ainbassa∣dor
from all manner of Insults, but went away: So that our said Ambassador being destitute of all Help, and forsaken, was forced to Redeem himself, from the House of Bondage; and after a long Space of Time, to procure his Liberty.

Forasmuch, then, as our Majesty is apparently assaulted, by thi wicked Attempt and Indignity, put upon the Person of our Ambassadour, such as was never practised nor even heard of in the whole World; much less among civiliz'd People; not only profain∣ing, but quite subverting the Law of Nations. Therefore hoping that your Royal Majesty will have due Regard, to the grievous Affront offer'd to us, in the Person of our Ambassador, together with the In∣fringement of the Law of Nations, occasion'd primal∣ly by the Sheriff, as the Author of the whole Mis∣chief, inasmuch, as the said Sheriff countenanc'd so andacious an attempt, and look'd upon the detaining ur Ambassadour, as a Trile. And, secondly, by the Bailiff who presum'd to abuse our said Ambassador in the open Street, after the above-mention'd Manner. And lastly, by the Merchants, who occasion'd his Confinement, (as is evident from their malevolent stigation, in order to overthrow the ancient Friend∣ship establish'd with us and our Empire) wherefore, we being persaded, that your Majesty will esteem Persons no otherwise, than as the most proli∣gae of Pillagers and Violater of the Law of Nations, proprtioaile to their Guilt, we intreat your Maje∣sty to Consent, for an Example to others, a diligent Search may be made after the rest of the Accompli∣ces of the Crime, and that a capital Punishment ac∣cording to the rigour of the Law, be inicted on them all, or at least such a one, as is adequate to the Na∣ture of the Affront, which every Particular Person put upon the Ambassador.

The same Ambassador, by Vertue of the In∣structions given him, on this Subject, will more largely explain our Request to your Majesty, which has been already declar'd, by our Ministers, to your Majesty's Resident in our Court; on those Conside∣rations we have Reason to hope, from your Majesty's justice, such a Satisfaction for this Intolerable Out∣rage; and the rather in regard that your Majesty's Honour, and Reputation of all your Subjects of Great Britain, will by this Means become famous throughout the whole World; and we shall be certain∣ly assur'd of the Continuance of your Royal Friend∣ship, and all Effects of a contrary Opinion, will be entirely remov'd: And least, upon Failure of a Satis∣faction worthy of, and equivolant to our injur'd Honour, we be compell'd to obtain it by way of Repri∣sal; which, indeed, would be very irksome to us, upon Account of that particular Esteem, we have for your Majesty's Friendship. Finally, We wish your Majesty Health, and a prosperous Reign.
DIV2.CLOSER: Given at our Camp, near the Village of Sowo∣lewo, the 17th Day of September, O. S. in the Year of our Lord, 1708, and the 27th of our Reign, by your affectionate Brother. Sign'd by his Sacred Czarish Majesty, PETER. Under-neath, Count Goloskin, Peter Scapiraff, Secretary of the Privy. Council.

DIV2.HEAD: To the Ambassadors Letter, Mr. Secretary Boyle return'd the following Answer.
DIV2.P:
“I Did not think Fit to return a Speedy An∣wer, to the two Letters of the 27th of November, and 4th of December last, N. S. with which your Excellency was pleas'd to Honour me; because I could not inform you, what Sa∣tisfacton our Laws would afford, against those who put that grievous Affront upon your Excel∣lency's Person: But forasmuch, as-I am appre∣hensive that too long a Silence, may be taken for want of due Respect for your Excellency; or, that I have net been sufficiently solicitous to put in Execution, every thing that is incumbent upon the Queen's Majesty, in order to procure the promis'd Reparation: I could no longer for∣bear making Answer to your Excellency, to assure you, that the Resentment you express of the outragious Affront, particularly in your Letter, of the 27th of November ult. Cannot be greater, than the Indignation which her Majesty has conceiv'd upon that Account; and I doubt not, but Mr. de Ayrolle, according to the Inructions he receiv'd, has already notify'd to your Excellency, that the indispensable Forms of the Laws of this Kingdom, cannot admit of a final Determination of that Affair, till the next Sessions of our Court of Judicature, which is so well known, and so firmly regulated here, that in order to punish any Malefactor, for the most enormous Crimes, even Treason against
her Majesty's Sacred Person, he must be brought to his Tryal, according to usual Forms establish'd in this Country: I am perswaded that your Excellency's Sagasity and Equitableness, will distinguish between the Insolence and Bru∣tishness of some particular sensless Men, and the Marks of a very particular Esteem and Respect, which you have receiv'd upon all Occasions, as well from the Queen, as from Persons em∣ploy'd in the highest Offices of the Govern∣ment: And that your Excellency will be so Just, as to believe, that they would not have failed to give you the most ample Satisfaction, long ago, if the Means of doing it were as rea∣dy at Hand, and Practicable, as the Queen's inclination is forward to satisfy his Czarish Ma∣jesty thereupon: Therefore I hope your Excel∣lency, will represent the State of this Affair, to his Czarish Majesty, after the most favoura∣ble Manner, assuring him, that nothing has been neglected by, and that nothing for the Future, shall be omitted, which tends to procure all the Reparation the utmost rigour of the funda∣mental Laws of this Kingdom can afford. And farther, if this be not found sufficient, and any thing can be suggested, that is in the Queen's Power, whereby the may express her high Dis∣pleasure against those who committed so notorious an insult, which may contribute to the maintaining of Amity and good Correspondence between her and his Czarish Majesty, she will not fail on her Part, to be always ready to do it; upon that Account, I lately proposed, by the Queen's special Order to the Parliament of Great Britain, that a Bill might be brought in,
for establishing, and securing the Privileges of Ambassadors and other foreign Ministers, as well to prevent the like Outrages for the future, as to notify, at the same Time, to the whole World, how far her Majesty, and the whole British Na∣tion detest the Violence that was offer'd to your Excellency's Person and Character, but for as much, as her Majesty, is desirous of nothing more, than to be in a Capacity of giving Satisfaction in that Affair and she is abso∣lutely disposed to do all that lies in her Power for that Purpose, we are perswaded, that his Czarish Majesty will not forbear ha∣ving so just a Regard to the Queen's Friendship, and the ancient Alliancies, between the two Crowns, that he will not insist upon her attempting Impossibilities; and that he will not undertake any thing, which may in any wife be prejudicial to the good Correspondence that has been hitherto maintain'd between both their Majesty's, and which, as I hope will continue for ever. I have the Satisfaction to inform your Excellency, that the Queen had no sooner Notice, that two young Mus∣covite princes, the Relations of his Czarish Ma∣jesty, were arrived in this Kingdom, but she forthwith gave Orders for their Reception and Entertainment, with that particular Di∣stinction, and Respect, which is due to their high Birth. As for what Concerns my self have, in executing the Queen's Orders on this Emergency, I shall discharge my Duty with a great deal of Delight: And I can assure your Excellency, at that time, that no Person in the World can be more for∣ward
in expressing to you upon, all Oppor∣tunities which shall offer themselves, with how great Esteem and Respect,”
DIV2.CLOSER: I am, SIR, Your Excellency's, &c. H. BOYLE.

DIV2.HEAD: To this Letter the Ambassador of Muscovy made Answer to this Effect.
DIV2.P:
I HAD the honour to receive your Letter, dated from White-hall, the 11th Instant, O. S. and I find therein many Declartions and Promises for the future, as to what relates to the Reparation to the un∣paralell'd Assault made upon me by the Rabble, which Promises are directed to his Czarish Majesty my Ma∣ster, on the part of the Queen of Great Britain; but for the rest, all that I can observe most considerable, is the Proposal you have tendered to the Parliament of Great Britain, by the Queen's Instructions, in order to get a Law enacted for the Security, and Mainte∣nance of the Sacred Privileges of Ambassadors, and other foreign Ministers, residing in her Majesty's Courts; indeed this is a very proper Means to dissipate the Fears which they were seized with, since the Insult that was made, on a Minister of the first Rank, however, give me
leave to tell you farther, that nothing carries less Ap∣pearance of the Satisfaction which his Czarish Maje∣sty requires, since the definitive Resolution is still want∣ing and is referr'd to the particular Laws of the Country, so that the Business is protracted by putting it off from Time to Time, and from one Delay to a∣nother: If it were in the Queen's Power to consult the Parliament about enacting of a new Law, touching the immunity of foreign Ministers, and to prevent the Out∣rages which might be hereafter offer'd to them, could not due Measures have been taken at the same time, for the Reparation of the pass'd Affront, which ac∣cording to your Letter is detested by the, Queen, and the whole British Nation: Certainly, it is a very ea∣sy Matter to do it, in Case her Majesty has the least Inclination to bold an amicable Correspendence with his Czarish Majesty, as his Czarish Majesty is dis∣posed to do with her, and to maintain the Law of Nations in its Vigour, as the whole Universe does; which ought to be the rather to be expected from the Queen, since she has formerly Contributed very much to the Preservation of the same, by firmly demand∣ing of the Republick of Venice, for an affront offer'd to the Earl of Manchester her Ambassador, altho' the Insult was only made upon his Barks and domestick Servants; so that the Snate, not∣withstanding the most ancient Laws of the Re∣publick, was prevailed upon to follow the Law of Nations, by satisfying the Ambassador, after the manner he desir'd and demanded. Sir, You desire by the same Letter, that I should acquaint his Czarish Majesty with the delay of your Courts of Judicature, which binders this Affair; from being brought to an Issue, altho' it might have been very conveniently ad∣justed in the Space of six Months, since which Time the Accident happen'd. But forasmuch as your Let∣ter
contains nothing definitive, with Respect to the Sa∣tisfaction. I am extreamly concern'd, that it is not in my Power to comply with your Desires in that Particu∣lar, and I am so much the more uncapable of doing it, in regard that I have receiv'd his Czarish Majesty's positive Resolution upon the Busines; as also, later Orders, earnestly to press for the Qneen's Answer to my Master's Letter, and a Categorical Determi∣nation, whether the Law of Nation, with Respect to foreign Powers, will be observ'd or not? There∣fore, pursuant to the said Orders, which I have newly receiv'd, I would entreat you, Sir to honour me with an Answer to the above-mention'd Articles, after you have shewn the Contents to the Queen; to the End that this Affair may be no longer deserr'd, for the Delay occasion'd by your Laws, cannot give any manner of satisfaction to his Czarish Majesty, As to the Honours that have been lately done, by the Queen's special Command, to the two yomng Noble Men, who are taken for Muscovite Princes, related to his Czarish Majesty, and are now at London; I can assure you, that his Majesty reckons none but the Imperial Hereditary Prince within the Virge of his august House: They are two young Lords of illustru∣ous Birth, who have the Honour of being a Kin to him, and are Travelling, incognito, to see the World. But his Czarish Majesty does not desire that they should be defray'd by any Power, they have where withal to bear their own Charges, and if with∣out their Master's Orders, they think fit to accept of Lodgings, or any thing else of that Nature, they are to be accountable for t be same. It only remains, that I return Thanks for the Kindness and Good Will you profess to have for me, of the future Continuance of which you are also pleas'd to assure me; offering you, my reciprocal Readiness, to express to you,
the particular Esteem, and unlimited Affection, where∣with,

IN the February next, after this, the Persons were brought to Tryal on an Information in the Queen's Name against Tho. Morton, Isaac Spiltmb, Andrew Slan, Ed. oung, and Ten more, for Meet∣ing Consulting and Conspiring to Arrest the said Russian Minister, for which they were all, except oug found Guilty; the special Matter of the Privilege of Ambassadors being refferr'd by the Jury to the Opinion of the Judges.

BESIDES this prosecution, a Bill was brought into the next Parliament for preserving the Pri∣vilege of Ambassadors, and other publick Mini∣sters, which was done to prevent the like for the future; but this would not be taken as Satis∣faction to the Czarish Minister, for what had pass'd before; bat to give him as much Satisfaction as the Case would bear, and to give as much weight to the said Prosecution and Act of Parliament as possible.
Monsier D' Ayrole's, the Queen's Secretary at the Hague, wrote to Monsieur Mattueoff, as fol∣lows.
The Ambassador was then at Amsterdam.

LETTER.CLOSER: My Lord, Your Excellencies, &c. Sign'd, J. D' AYROLLE.

DIV2.P: TO this the Ambassador made a short Reply, intimating, that the other Letter was not satis∣factory; on which Mr. Secretary Boyle, being willing, if possible, to give him full Satisfaction, wrote as Follows.

LETTER.P:
“FOR as much as Mr. D' Ayrole, has had Or∣ders from time to time, to notifie to your Excellency, what has happen'd with Respect to the Trial of those Persons, who put the Out∣ragious Affront upon your Excellency; I look'd upon it as needless to trouble your Excellency with any Letters about that Affair; but since I perceive by the Honour of your last, that you press for an Answer to his Czarish Majesty's Let∣ter, with a great deal of earnestness, I can no long∣er exempt my self from acquainting-your Excel∣lency, that the Queen on her Side is very desirous of being in a capacity to Answer the said Let∣ter, after such a manner as is Requisite; but for as much as the Tryal cannot be brought to a Conclusion, by Reason of the indispenable Formalities of our Laws; it is evident that an Answer must needs be imperfect before a final Determination of this Case; this is the only Reason, for which it has been judged expedi∣ent to defer the Answer, and I doubt not but your Excellency will do so much Justice to the Queen, as to make convenient Excuses there∣upon, to the End that his Czarish Majesty may be certified, that this stop put to the Business, does not proceed from any affected procrastination, but from an insuperable Necessity, and I ought to assure your Excellency, that when the said Cause comes to be determined, her Majesty will not ail to Answer his Czarish Majesty's Letters, in such Terms as that he will clearly perceive the Queen is Solicitous of nothing more, then to give the most ample Satisfaction which can
be made for the said Indignity; I likewise do myself the Honour to inform your Excellency, that the Bill for maintaining the Privileges of Ambassadors is ready to pass into the House of Lords; so that in a short time the Queen will give the Royal Assent thereto, and thus your Excellency will see how much the British Nation is concern'd at what has so unfortunately befal∣len you, since it is therein express'd at large, that the said Outrage was the only Motive which in∣duc'd them to make such an Act; and further, I cannot forbear acquainting your Excellency, that for as much as the 2 Muscovite Princes have lately signified that this Business obliges them to pass over into Holland; the Queen who has conferred extraordinary Favours upon them, by Reason of the Honour they had in being nearly related to the August House of his Czarish Majesty, has given them to understand, that they are at full Liberty to set out on their Voyage, when, and in what manner they shall Judge most expedi∣ent; and that her Majesty will endeavour to make their Departure as agreeable, as she has hitherto made their Residence in these Parts easy, and delightful: I have often assur'd your Excellency of my particular Inclination to your Service, that it were needless to add any thing more, but a Repetition of the Esteem and Re∣spect with which I have the Honour to be.”

DIV2.P: BUT all this would not pacify the Russian Mini∣ster, as may appear by the following Reply of Monsieur Matteuoff.

LETTER.P:
I Have defer'd 'till now, the returning an Answer to the Letter with which you honoured me, dated 29th of March, O. S. because, my Lord, Duke of Marlborough, and the Secretary of the Queen of Great Britain, Mr. d' Ayroll, had several Times as∣sur'd me, they were ready to bring to pass the just Reparation, that his Czarish Majesty, my Master, requires of the unheard of Insult made upon me, and the Satisfaction due to my Honour, and the great Damages I have sustain'd; waited for the Issue thereof, with so much the greater Complacency, in regard, that by your Letter, you confirm'd to me the same Assurance, of the sincere Intention, and particular Care taken for that Purpose. But, for as much, as the Letters from England, of the 17th. Instant, O. S. do not express, that from the 11th, which was the Beginning of the Term, to the said 13th Day any Progress has been made in the Courts of Judicature, in order to obtain the Sen∣tence which ought to be pronounced against those Wretbes, who assaulted me; nor even that the Af∣fair has been debated; it appears to me, that the application of the Court, does not concur so much as the sincere friendship betwixt his Czarish Majesty and the Queen of Great Britain requires, in order to put an End to those Delays, and Means of demur∣ing which have caused the Business to be protracted, for the Space of almost a whole Year: And there∣fore,
not seeing at this very Instant, any apparent Effects of the fair Promises which havebeen made to me, and finding my self oblig'd to obey the Orders I receiv'd from his Czarish Majesty; again, once more to demand, whether it be the Queens Pleasure, to give Satisfaction proportionable to the Outragiousness of the Affront, such as his Majesty, my Master, re∣quires, and to answer his Letter; I would also in∣treat you to send me an answer in Writing, which I impatiently expect, to the End that I may send it to the Court, conformable to my Orders. As to the no∣tifying the Act newly made, upon the Occasion of the late Assault, upon my Person, for maintaining the Privileges of Ambassadors, of which Act Mr. d Ay∣roll afterwards deliver'd a Copy to me, by your Or∣der, I do my self the Honour to tell you, that it con∣tributes not, in any wise, to the Satisfaction now in Debate; because, the sacred Characters of Ambassa∣dors have been in all Ages, accounted inviolable among the Christan Powers, before that Declaration; which being but a particular Law, can only serve to justify the Honour of the Nation, and prevent for the Fu∣ture, all Inconveniencies which may happen to foreign Ministers in Great Britain, as well as to those of your Crown, in other Courts: 'Tis very much against my will, that my Name is Celebrated in such a Man∣ner in your Constitution, and that the Example is transmitted to Psterity; whereas, there being no∣thing Blame worthy in my Conduct, during my Re∣i|dence in London; I had Reason to hope, I should not be thus exposed to the deadly Affront, put upon the Character of an Ambassador, with which I am invested. For the rest, being perswaded of your par∣ticular Friendship, and that you are desirous to give me farther Marks thereof, upon this Occasion, I would have you to believe, that I am, as I formerly
bad the Honour to be, with a most profound Esteem, and Affection,

DIV2.P: AFTER this Mr. Matueoff sent over a Letter from the Czar himself, to her Britanick Majesty, wherein he express'd in very Warm, but respect∣ful Terms, his Resentment of the Treatment of his Ambassador, and that he expected such Repa∣ration, as was suitable to the Indignity he had received.

ALL these Writings to, and again, having brought this Affair to no Conclusion, it was re∣solved on both Sides, at last, that the Queen should send a solemn Embassy to the Czar to his Court at Moscow, to make an Acknowledgment for the Affront, and to desire his Czarish Majesty to be pacify'd, and to take this, for a Testimony of her Majesty's great Desire to give him ample Satisfaction upon that Occasion, and indeed, it was a great Testimony of it.

ACCORDINGLY, Mr. Whitworth was sent by her Majesty to Moscow, what he did, and how this Matter was ended, in a manner very honou∣rably to his Czarish Majesty, may be seen at large, by the following Account of his Reception at Moscow, &c.

DIV2.HEAD: A RELATION of what past at Moscow, on the 16th of February, N. S. 1710. the Day his Majesty, Peter, Emperor of Great Russia, admitted to publick Audience, his Excellency Mr. Charles Whitworth, formerly Envoy Extraordi∣nary of her Majesty, Anne Queen of Great Bri∣tain; and since, vested with the Character of her Ambassador Extraordinary, Commissioner and Ple∣nepotentionary, expresly and purposely to make so∣lemn Excuses in her Name, for the insult done at London, the first of August, N. S. 1708. to his Excellency, Mr. Andrew Artemonides de Ma∣tueoff, Minister of State, Governor of the Dutchy of Jaroslaw, and at that Time, Ambassador Ex∣traordinary of his Czarish Majesty, at the Court of her Britannick Majesty. To which are added, the Articles stipulated in the Conference between the Minister of the Czar, and the same Ambassa∣dor of the Queen.
DIV2.P:
THE 8th of February, being appoint∣ed for the Solemnity, Monsieur Basilis de Salticof, Chief Carver to his Czar∣ish Majesty, accompany'd by Mon∣sieur Athanasius de Dmitreemomonof, Cup-Bearer, who officiated as Master of the Cere∣monies, went from the Court in one of his Czar∣ish Majesty's Coaches, to the House of her Brita∣nick Majesty's Ambassador, being follow'd by twenty other Coaches, of the Grandees, and Principal Lords of the Court, some, only to make up a Train for Show; and others, for
the Ambassador's Secretary and Gentlemen, who were all richly Cloath'd, answerable to the Coaches in which they Rode.

BEING come to the Ambassadors House, the Carver, and Cup-Bearer, went up to his Appart∣ment, where they declared to his Excellency, the Business they were come about, and after some Moments Conversation, they went into the Coach with the Ambassador, who took the Place of Honour; the Chief Carver sat by his Side, and the Cup Bearer against him; the Secretary, and Centlemen of the Embassy, went in the Coaches appointed for them, each according to his Rank, and the Train being encreased by the Ambassador's Coaches, proceeded to the Court.

ARIVING there, the two Regiments of Guards Preobrazenski and Semionasski, who were drawn up within the Court, made the Salutes of Honour to the Ambassador according to Custom, and re∣main'd standing in Parade During the whole Audience; making a very fine Shew, the Rich∣ness of their Cloaths, and the neatness of their Arms and Accoutrements setting off the comely Men, of which those Regiments are compos'd; the Officers at their Head made the most Splendid Appearance that can be imagin'd; and the whole Extent of the Court, as large as 'tis, could hard∣ly afford them Room enough.

Monsieur de Narichkin, Gentleman of the Bed-Chamber, to his Czarish Majesty, received the Ambassador at the Foot of the Stair-Case, where his Excellency came out of the Coach, and com∣plimented him; Prince George de Scherhaty, Coun∣sellor of State perform'd the same Honours to him at the Top of the Stair-Case; and Monsieur de Mussinpuchkin, Privy-Counsellor, complimented
him in the Anti-Chamber, and the Ambassador was conducted according to the Cerimonial, to the Hall of Audience, where his Czarish Majesty was standing, uncover'd, under a Canopy, leaning against a Table, having an arm'd Chair behind him, the Grandees, and Ministers of the Court, with the Generals of his Armies standing on each Hand of him.

AS soon as the Ambassador came in Sight of him, he made his first Obeisance, in the Middle of the Hall, his second, and the third when he had ascended the Estrade on which his Czarish Majesty stood; where standing, and with his Hat off, his Excellency made a Speech in English, of which the Secretary read aloud, a Translation in the German Tongue, sign'd with the Ambassador's Hand, to the End, the foreign Ministers, who had been formally Invited to assist at this Solem∣nity, might understand the Contents of it; and then one of his Czarish Majesty's Secretaries read it out in the Russian Language, for the Information of the Lords and Gentlemen of the Empire; the Speech was as follows,

LETTER.OPENER: Most High, and most Powerful Emperor.
LETTER.P:
“'TIS not without a very sensible Grief, that I am oblig'd to mention to your Majesty, the Affront which was offer'd to your Ambassador, in Great Britain; and I should be much more concern'd at it, were I not furnish'd with express Orders, and full Power, to de∣clare, with how great Diligence, her Maje∣sty, the Queen of Great Britain, my most gracious Mistress, has endeavour'd to give sufficient Satisfaction for it, proportion'd, as well to her
Equity, as to her Greatness of Soul; and such, as may serve, as an evident Mark of her con∣stant Friendship, which she has always had for your Imperial Majesty, and which her Ma∣jesty, is desirous inviolably to continue to you.”

“THE first Advice of that unfortunate Acci∣dent, was no sooner brought to Court, but the Guilty were made sensible of her Royal Indig∣nation; they were immediately arrested; they were examin'd before the Queen, in her Coun∣cil; they were imprison'd, and prosecuted with the utmost Severity of our Laws: And tho' these were found not to be extensive enough, yet, they were declared infamous, by the Con∣sent of the whole Nation, assembled in Parlia∣ment, who declar'd to the whole World, by a publick Act, how much they abhor'd the Indig∣nity of the Fact, and took necessary Precau∣tions to prevent the like Insolencies for the Future. Neither did they stop there, for those Criminals, were afterwards declared unworthy any Favour or Protection, and excluded from the General Pardon, which her Majesty, the Queen, caused to be publish'd, for all her Subjects; even, for those, who had in a most inormous manner, attempted against her sacred Person; and tho' other Criminals do actually Enjoy that Benefit, those are still under her Majesty's high Displeasure.”

“AND to the End, that her Royal Equity and Amity may reach farther, and become the more shining in the World, her Majesty, has graciously been pleas'd to honour me with the Charracter of her Ambassador Extraordina∣ry, Commissary, and Plenipotentiary, and to
give me the Power, to represent her Royal Per∣son, as if her self were here present, in the first Place to testify the Sorrow, and the just and high Abhorrence she has for that rash Deed per∣petrated against a Publick Minister, especially, against such a one as her Majesty the Queen, has a most particular Esteem for; and afterwards, to beg Excuse for the Defect, and Insufficiency of our ancient Constitution, in the Case of so extraordinary a Violation of the Law of Nati∣ons; for which, the Criminals should with Justice have been punished with the utmost Ri∣gour, according to your Imperial Majesty's De∣sire: And in the last place, to assure your Ma∣jesty, in the most sincere manner, how much her Majesty, the Queen, is inclin'd to maintain the ancient Friendship, and good Corespondence, which for so long a Time, have been between the two Crowns: Of which your Imperial Ma∣jesty, may please to take further Notice, in this her Letter, which is a Testimony of the great Affection, and high Esteem, her Majesty the Queen, has for your Imperial Majesty.”

“WHEREFORE, I most instantly desire, in the Name of her Majesty, the Queen, that your Imperial Majesty, may vouchsafe to accept the aforesaid Excuse, with the usual fraternal Af∣fection, and not to impute either to her Maje∣sty, the Queen, or the British Nation, and Action of which, some disorderly Persons are the Au∣thors: But that entirely putting the same in Oblivion, your Imperial Majesty may again generously continue you high Affection to the Queen, my Mistress, and her Subjects.”
“FOR my own part, I shall esteem my self most happy, if I may any way contribute to so great a Work, so advantagious to both the Crowns, and so necessary to the Present State of Europe.”

“SEVERAL great Benefits and Marks of Fa∣vour, which I have already receiv'd, during the Discharge of my former Employment, of which, I shall ever retain a thankful Remembrance, makes me hope for the same favourable Recep∣tion, during the Remainder of my Stay here, in the Exercise of my new Commission, as often as I shall have the Honour to make any new Proposal to your Imperial Majesty's Court, by Order of my most gracious Queen.”

“IN the Conclusion, I beg Leave to recommend the British Subjects, who live in this Country, to your Imperial Majesty's high Protection, with Respect to the Free Trade, which their Ancestors began first, by the way of Archangel, with great Expence, and Loss of abundance of Men.”

DIV2.P: AFTER the Speech was made, and two Tran∣slations of it Read, his Excellency the Ambassa∣dor, deliver'd to his Czarish Majesty, her Ma∣jesty's, the Queen of Great Britain's Letter, to the Effect following.

DIV2.HEAD: (After the usual Titles on both Sides.)
DIV2.P: WE have already written to your Imperial Majesty, to declare to you, the Grief we conceiv'd, for the unhappy Affront which was offer'd to your Am∣bassadour before he left our Court: We have since re∣ceiv'd the Letter which your Imperial Majesty wrote to us, and we can assure your Imperial Majesty, that we were touch'd with true Sorrow, when we saw how highly you resented the Violence which had been offer'd to your Imperial Majesty's own Person, in the Cha∣racter of your Ambassador, and we were the more griev'd on this Occasion, when we reflected on the insuf∣ficiency of our Laws, to give as ample a Satisfaction as we desire to make, as well for the just Sense, We our Self had, of the Indignity which had been offer'd, as to Convince your Imperial Majesty, how much we were Inclin'd to make a suitable Reparation, for the Inju∣ry done so good a Friend and Ally; but we must con∣fess, that at the same Time, we had a singular Pleasure, in observing your Imperial Majesty's desire, to pre∣vent the Misunderstanding that might arise there∣from; and the great Esteem you shew'd for our Friendship; as well as the Care you Express'd, to pre∣serve and cultivate it by Reciprocal marks of Friend∣ship and Affection.

Wherefore, we promise our self, from your Good∣ness, that upon the Representations, which, from Time to Time have been made to you, in our Name, by our Envoy Extraordinary, at your Imperial Court, your Imperial Majesty will be pleased, to examine in∣to the Nature of this Affair; where your Imperial Majesty, will not see the least Inclination, to favour the Criminals, nor to screen them from Justice. But that there are insuperable Difficulties, with Re∣spect
to the ancient and fundamental Laws of the Government of our People; which we fear, do not permit so severe and rigorous a Sentence to be given, as your Imperial Majesty, at first, seem'd to expect▪ in this Case; and we perswade our self, that your Imperial Majesty, who are a Prince Equally famous for Clemency, aud exact Justice, will not require us, who are the Gaurdian and Protectress of the Laws, to inflict a Punishment upon our Subjects, which the Laws do not impower us to do.

Nevertheless, we have not been wanting, at the same Time, to use all the Means, which we judg'd most effectual, to perswade your Majesty, and the whole World, of the Sincerity of our Intentions, and of our Endeavours in this Affair; and to the End the guilty might be Punish'd, so far, as the Laws and Constitutions of our Kingdoms, which were then in Force, would permit; we gave express, and re∣peated Orders to our Officers of Justice, and to our Ministers, to prosecute them with the uttermost severity.

That Prosecution has been long continu'd with ve∣ry great Diligence, and nothing has been omitted, to bring it to as speedy a Conclusion as possible: But after all▪ the Matter is such, that we find our self oblig'd, to inform your Imperial Majesty, that as well, because of the different Pleadings, in Favour of the Criminals, the slow, but indispersable Manner of proceeding in a Law Suit of so great Importance; as of the Case it self, which is of an extraordinary Nature, against which, no sufficient Provision is made; in the ancient Statutes of these Kingdoms: It has not been in the Power of our Council Learned in the Law yet to obtain a Sentence, nor a final Decission in this Affair.

Wherefore, considering all these Inconveniencies, and foreseeing the Delays which might probably hap∣pen, in the ordinary Course of Law, and desiring, at the same Time, to give you signal Marks of our Sorrow; as also to shew you the Indignation of all our Subjects on this Occasion, we have pass'd an Act of Parliament made in the most solemn manner, by the Council, and Assembly of our Kingdom of Great Britain, wherein is made a Declaration as Authen∣tick as possible, of the just Horror which our Sub∣jects in general have against this violent Insult, and all the Acts and Proceedings which relate to the Ar∣rest of the Person of your imperial Majesty's Ambas∣sadour, are annul'd, and raz'd out of the Registers of our Courts of Justice; and those who had a Share therein, are branded as infamous Criminals, and ob∣noctious to the Laws, which were then in Force; and if any Person hereafter, durst commit the like Offence, or any ways violate the Privileges of Ambassadors and other foreign Ministers, they will be lyable to the most severe Penalties and Punishments, which the arbitrary Power of the Judges, shall think fit to inflict upon them, and to which no bounds are given, in this new Act; so that all Insults of this Nature, will be prevented for the Future, and the Security, which all Prince's Ministers ought to enjoy, will be firmly establish'd and preserv'd by this famous Law; And this will remain as a Monument to all Posterity; as a Defference, which has been shewn to your Imperial Majesty: And all the Ministers, which shall come for the Future, will be indebted for this extraordinary Act for their Protection, to the particular Considera∣tion which we, and our People have had for your Im∣perial Majesty's Honour: Therefore, your Imperial Majesty cannot but see, that we have used our utmost Endeavours in prosecuting the Criminals, and in
causing them to be punished, tho' not with the Suc∣cess we could have wished; and since we have pro∣cur'd an Act to be made by the Representative of all our Subjects of Great Britain, as well for Repara∣tion of what has been done, as to prevent the like Insolence sor the Future, we instantly pray your Impe∣rial Majesty, to accept of all that we have done on our Side, as the most we could do here, for your Sa∣tisfaction; whereby your Imperial Majesty will give us the strongest Proof that can be of your Affection towards us, and you may be assured that we shall not fail on our Side to do all that lies in our Power, on all Occasions, to shew you our Gratitude, by our firm Friendship and Esteem.
