And to the End, that nothing may be omitted, which is in our Power, to do farther, by way of suitable Reparation, we thought fit to make Choice of some worthy and able Person to declare to your Im∣perial Majesty, in the most publick and solemn Man∣ner the Indignation we conceiv'd at the Affront offer'd, and our Concern that it is not in our Power to cause the Criminals to be punish'd according to their Deserts: And as our trusty and well beloved, Mr. Charles Whitworth, has merited our Royal Approbation, by his Ability and Experience in all the Affairs which have been entrusted with him, as also, by his good Conduct at your Imperial Maje∣sty's Court, for several Tears past; we have therefore given him a special Power and Commission, to repre∣sent our Person, as our Ambassadour Extraordinary for this End, and desire you to give entire Credit to all that he shall say to you in our Royal Name, as if we were Present, to do it in Person. We will only add, as a Mark of our Esteem, for your Ambassadour himself, who suffer'd this Insult, that as we were sensible of his Personal Virtues, and
great Qualities, during his Residence at our Court; so we were more particularly concern'd, that such an Injury should be offer'd to a Gentleman of so great Merit and Consideration; being, besides, the Ambassadour of so great a Prince, and so good an Allie. And so praying, that the Dispencer of all good Things, will vouchsafe to Power forth his heavenly Benedictions, upon the Person and King∣doms of your Imperial Majesty, we recommend you to his holy Protection.
DIV2.CLOSER: Your Imperial Majesty's, Most Affectionate Sister, Given at our Palace, at Windsor, the —Day of Au∣gust, 1709. ANNE R.

DIV2.P: HIS Czarish Majesty, having receiv'd this Let∣ter from the Hands of the Ambassador, deliver'd it to the Count de Galoffkin, great Chamberlain of his Empire, and was pleas'd to make the fol∣lowing Answer in his own Tongue.

“IT was but requisite, that her Majesty, the Queen, should have given us Satisfaction, by punishing the Criminals, conformably to our Demands, in the most rigorous Manner, as is the Custom in such Cases through out the Uni∣verse: But seeing her Majesty has ordered you
to make Excuses, in the Quality of her Am∣bassador Extraordinary conferr'd upon you, ex∣presly for this Purpose, and to remonstrate that her Majesty could not inflict such a Punish∣ment upon them, because of the Defect in that Particular, of the former establish'd Constitu∣tions of her Kingdom, and that with the una∣nimous Consent of the Parliament, her Maje∣sty has caused a New Act to be passed, to serve as a Law therein for the Future, we accept all this, for a Proof of the Affection, her Ma∣jesty has for us, and for sufficient Satisfaction; and we will give Orders to our Ministers, to settle entirely this Affair with you in a Con∣ference.”

HIS Czarish Majesty having conluded his An∣swer, his Excellency, the Ambassador, retired backwards out of the Hall, making three Obei∣sances, in the same Manner as when he came in, and was conducted back to his House, with the same Ceremony, and with the same Train, ac∣company'd by the Carver and the Cup-Bearer, the First of which, treated him three Days suc∣cessively, by express Orders of his Czarish Maje∣sty, with the greatest Plenty, Delicacy, and Mag∣nificence, the Officers of his Czarish Majesty's Houshold serving at the Table.

ON the 9th. O. S. The Ambassador came to the House of his Excellency, the Count de Goloff∣kin, Great Chamberlain of the Empire, and there had a Conference with him, and other Mi∣nisters of his Czarish Majesty, in which this trou∣blesome Affair was terminated, to the mutual Sa∣tisfaction of the two Powers, the Differences which had been occasion'd by so ill an Accident,
were Compos'd, and the ancient Friendship, and good Correspondence between the two Crowns renew'd, on the Condition, that the following Articles, which were stipulated, should be per∣form'd; the Ambassador of her Britanick Majesty, Engaging to procure the Execution of the last but one.

THAT his Czarish Majesty Emperor of Great Russia, will send Orders to Monsieur de Ma∣tueoff his Ambassador, and Plenipotentiary, at the Hague; to notify, provisionally, by a Letter to her Majesty, the Queen of Great Britain, that Mr. Charles Whitworth, being vested with the Cha∣racter, of her Ambassador Extraordinary, and Pleni∣potentiary, expresly, and purposely to make Excuses, on occasion of the Affront, in Question has perform'd that Commission; and that his Majesty, having re∣gard to the Instances of her Majesty, the Queen, has been pleased to accept the said Excuses, made in her Name, for Satisfaction of the outrage done at London, to the Ambassador of his Czarish Maje∣sty; with an Intention, thereby to shew, the high Value he puts upon the Friendship of her Britanick Majesty, and on the Continuance of that Friendship, and in Hope of the like Return on her Part, in Occasions wherein his Czarish Majesty may be con∣cern'd: And that in Consequence hereof, his Czar∣ish Majesty is willing to forgive the criminal Pro∣ceedings of the Authors and Accomplicies of the said Affront; and desires her Majesty, the Queen, to be pleased to order them to be discharg'd from the Pro∣cess issued against them, and from the Sentence pro∣nounced, and the Penalties to which they were con∣demned for to the said Insult.

His Czarish Majesty having a just regard, to the faithful and signal Services which his said Ambas∣sador, who was insulted, has perform'd; and in a gracious Remembrance of the laudable Zeal of his deceased Father, his Excellency, Monsieur Artemon Sergiewicz de Matueoff, first Minister and Boyar in the Reign of his Czarish Majesty's Father, and Grand-father of glorious Memory, who in exhorting Rebels to their Obedience, Crowned his faithful and important Services with his Blood, shed by Mutiniers: He cannot but (in token of his good Will towards him) after his own Satisfaction, regard the particu∣lar Satisfaction of his Minister, namely, the Repa∣ration of his Honour, and that of his Family by the Expedient of a Letter from her Majesty, the Queen, and the Reimbursement of all the Costs and Dama∣ges which he has been obliged to be at, and to suf∣fer on Account of the said Affront.

His Czarish Majesty, will give Orders to his said Ambassador, to demand his Letter of Re-cre∣dence, which he refused to accept when he left Lon∣don, as well as the usual Present, and the Yatch which her Majesty caused to be offer'd to him; and this, because of the aforesaid Affront.

All that is above specify'd, being Executed, his Czarish Majesty will acquaint her Majesty, the Queen, that he is content with the aforesaid Satis∣faction, by a Letter, which shall be deliver'd to the Ambassador, Mr. Whitworth.

THUS ended this Affair, in which, some Peo∣ple thought the Queen stoop'd to low to the Czar; as if the Czar had not been a Prince of such Fame and Power, as merited so much Consi∣deration; but the Queen and her Council knew better what Figure the Czar made in the World,
and of what Use the Commerce of Great Britain to the Russian Dominions was of; and besides this, her Majesty very well knew, also, that Justice requir'd it, as she would expect her Ministers abroad should be well used, by the Princes and Powers, her Neighbours; and as she expected o∣ther Princes and Nations should act by her, if her Ministers receiv'd any Affront from the Rables and Clamours of the People.

WE are now to return to the Affair of the Turks, the Czar was really, very loath to fall out with the Turks. But, as he found his Enemy, the King of Sweden, and the Palatine of Kiow, had the Ascendant there, and would kindle a Flame whether he would or no, he made the ne∣cessary Preparations for his own Defence.

HOWEVER, heat the same time wrote Letters, and sent Ambassadors to the Grand Seignior, if possible, to prevent a Rupture, and publish'd several Declarations, offering to refer any Differ∣ences that might happen between the Grand Seignior and himself, to the Arbitration of other Princes; and the Turks at the same Time, send∣ing an Aga, as a Minister to Vienna, to prevent the Emperor taking Umbrage at his Breach with the Czar, His Czarish Majesty transmitted one of his Declarations to Vienna, that it might be commu∣nicated to the said Turkish Minister, upon his Ar∣rival there; this Declaration shewing a Readi∣ness in the Czar, to preserve the Publick Peace; is of very great Consequence in this Case, to clear the Character of the Czar, from the Scan∣dal of Breach of Treaty, which was pretended to be charg'd upon him, the Turks being manifest∣ly the Aggressors.

WHEREAS, we have receiv'd certain Informa∣tion, from divers Places, that the Ottoman Port endeavours to justify the Violation of Peace, by a War; already declared against us, and actually begun, by the Irruption of the Tartars into our Territories: And for that Purpose, charge us with several ground∣less Matters, by which, they pretend they were forc'd to come to a Rupure; and amongst others, as if we were not inclin'd to continue in Peace with them, but had actually resolved to begin a War: As also, that contrary to the Peace concluded with the Otto∣man's we had erecteds several new Fortifications, on our Frontiers; suffer'd our Troops to Enter the Turkish Dominions; and that we would not give them Leave to Convoy the King of Sweden in Safety, back to his own Territories. We have thought it necessary to declare here openly, that we never had the leaft Intention, to break in any Manner whatsoever, the Peace concluded between us and the Ottoman Port, and to enter into a War with the Turks; but the same has been hitherto, religiously, and inviolably observed by us; the For∣tifications erected by us, are likewise, in no Respect, against the Treaty, but upon our own Territories; which partly belong'd to us of Old, and partly was yielded to us by the Treaty, and the Limits marked out by the Commissaries on both Sides, which have been fixed many Years ago: And it is therefore to be wonder'd, that the Port would take Occasion to com∣plain thereof, at this Juncture; our Troops never enter'd on the Turkish Dominions, but remain'd only upon the Frontiers; and altho', they did some Time ago▪ according to the Laws of War, pursue their Enemy into the Turkish Territories, and seized them there∣in; which, however, was done in such Places, where
there were, no Inhabitants; yet all this as well as other Matters, were fully setled and adjusted, in the Confirmation of Peace, renew'd last Year; whereby the Port did likewise stipulate with our Ambassa∣dor, that they should Convoy the King of Sweden, with 500 Turks, thro' Poland, and that we should Guard him by our Officers from the Frontiers; to which, we not only consented, but also, promised to procure the like Consent, from the King and Repub∣lick of Poland: But this being not accepted by the Port, on the Account of several Pretences, we did at last, in two of our Letters to the Sultan, and by our Ambassador, and Privy-Councellor Tolshoy, at Constantinople, declare that we would suffer the King of Sweden to pass through Poland free, and unmolested, into his own Dominions; and to that End, permit him a Guard of 5000 Turks, to send him safe thro' Poland; whereby our peace∣able Temper sufficiently appears, and that on our Part, we have contributed all, what might pre∣vent all manner of Disturbance, and maintain a good Correspondence, and Neighbourly Friend∣ship with the Ottoman Port, and that all the World may be sensible thereof, we confirm here, with our former Declaration an Offer, before a tedious War be commenc'd, to accommodate Matters with the Port, and to live in a neighbourly Amity with her, as formerly: And notwithstanding, in order to provide for our Precaution and Security; (after we have been informed from all Parts, of a Rupture, and that the War is actually declared against us at Constantinople, and our Ambassa∣dor carried Prisoner to the Seven Towers), we have caused our Troops to march to the Turkish Frontiers: They shall, however, not undertake any Hostilities, provided the Turks live on their Part,
peaceably; put a Stop to all Preparations of War, and set our Ambassador with all his Retinue, at Liberty; and we will, as soon as we are sufficient∣ly assured of these Things, by the Ottoman Port; Order our Forces to with draw from the Frontiers, and facilitate as much as in us lies, a friendly Ac∣commodation: So we willingly accept, and herewith desire the Mediation of his Imperial Majesty, her Majesty the Queen of Great Britain, and their High Mightinesses the States General. But in Case the Port, without any Occasion given her by us, should persist in her Resolution to break the Peace with us, and begin the War against us; we declare before God, and all the World, that we are excusable, and not guilty of all the Blood that may be spilt on this Oc∣casion; and we have an entire Confidence in God, that he will assist our just Cause, and prosper our Arms with Victory, against an Enemy who breaks Treaties; and who but a Year ago, by so many Oaths and Promises, confirm'd, and renew'd the Peace with us.

AFTER this, the War being actually begun by the Turks, his Czarish Majesty published another Declaration, which was sent to all the Ministers of Christian Powers at Constantinople, in order to have them insist as Occasion offer'd, with the Turkish Ministers, upon the Terms offer'd, there∣in, as follows.

“TIMES have produced Revolutions, Peace and War have alternately succeeded in the World; and Mankind in every Age, has been toss'd with strange Vicissitudes: But the present Profidiousness of the Ottomans, is such, as Antiquity can scarse Paralel, and the modern Ages deservedly abhor.”

“NO doubt, but the Common Report of this, has reached most Peoples Ears; Be it therefore, manifestly Known to all, how Achmet, the now Reigning Sultan of the Turks, has impi∣ously, frivolously, and without the least, just Occasion, violated, and broken the 30 Years Peace, concluded between his sacred Czarish Ma∣jesty, and his Predecessor, Sultan Mustapha, tho' renew'd by himself, this very last Year, 1710, and ratify'd by a solemn Oath, in the Presence of the most high God of Heaven; which he afterwards confirm'd, as well in his Letters which he writ to his said Czarish Maje∣sty, as in the Deed of publick Renovation; and yet, in the Month of November, the very same Year, e're the Sun had compleated its annual Course, he declared War publickly, at Constantinople; and contrary to the Law of Nations, cast his Czarish Majesty's Ambassador, and Privy-Councellor, Monsieur Tolsoy, and his whole Family, into the Prison called the Edicul, after having first affronted him in a most ignominious Manner, and seized upon his Goods.”

“IT is true, he has not herein degenerated from his Fore-fathers; for being born an Enemy to the Name of CHRIST, he never Ar∣ticles with an Intention to observe the sacred
Laws of Peace; but as a Man void of all Honour, does it only, that he may after∣wards, with greater Security, attack, and ut∣terly overwhelm those that rely upon the religious Sanctions of publick Treaties.”

“The Historians of former Ages, and especi∣ally that most excellent Patriarch of Jerusalem, St. Nectaris testifies, that the Ottomans, from their very Beginnings, made it their chief Study, to watch Quarrels and Disagreements, that at any Time happen'd between any Chri∣stian Princes, and States; and that as often as they found Occasion, they never stuck at any Stipulations of Peace, or solemn Oaths; and that thus, the Offspring of Thieves and Rob∣bers, did in a few Years, subdue to their own Dominions, so many ancient and renowned Christian Kingdoms and Provinces, together with a great many holy and venerable Places; and at last became the most powerful, and formidable People.”

“THE poor oppress'd Grecians, Valachians, Bulgarians, and Servians, groan still under Yoke, and their Misery shews by woful Experience, how little a Value do those Bar∣barians set upon publick Treaties. Nor has the Kingdom of Hungary experienced less to its great Detriment.”

“THE Russian Monarchy, still bears in Mind, the Destruction with which it was threaten'd, in the Year, 1677, when in the Reign of the Czar, Theodore Alexowits, Emperor of all Russia, of pious and glorious Memory; the per∣fidious Turk, being in Hopes that the lesser Russia, should become a Prey to his Ambition, thro' the Treachery of Poroszen, General of the
Cossacks, beyond the Bristhenes, broke the Peace, and with a vast and dreadful Army, invaded the Ukrain, and tho' he had been already inform'd that the said Traytor, had submitted to his Czarish Majesty's Mercy, and the Higirin, the Place of his chief Residence, was actually Garrison'd, by his said Majesty's Forces: Yet finding that the noble Firmness of the Russian Troops, did hinder him from penetrating far∣ther into the Ukrain, he bent all the Fury, which he design'd to make the whole Province feel, against the City, which he in Vain be∣sieg'd, tho' but slightly fortify'd, insomuch, that the Russians themselves, would have aban∣doned and demolish'd it, but that the Exegency of the War requir'd their keeping it for that Time: So, that after a prodigious Loss of Men, he was forc'd to retire to his own Teritories, loaded with Shame and Ignominy, and to beg Peace of his Czarish Majesty, which was con∣cluded in 1681.”

“THE memorable Slaughter, made of these Peace Breakers at Vienna in Austria, in 1683, and the wonderful Progress of the Christian Arms afterwards, are still fresh in every Bo∣dy's Memory; nor is it needful to mention, the Insolence, with which they then broke in, to besiege that Metropolis.”

“IT is recorded in the Archieves of Christan Princes, the having seriously fore-seen the cun∣ning Designs, which the Barbarians form'd, of swallowing up their several Dominions, one by one; they enter'd into a holy and mutual League: To wit, his Czarish Majesty, the Em∣peror of the Romans, the Roman Empire, his Polish Majesty, the Republick of Poland,
and Venice, and the Pope of Rome; and their Czarean Majesties, John Alexowitz, of pious Memory, and Peter Alexowitz, who now happily Reigns, being likewise invited, for the common Safety of Christianity; and induced both by the continual Irruptions of the Turks and Tartars into their Territories, and their Hostilities and Incursions into the Dominions of other Christian Princes; join'd first in a perpetual Peace, and a perpetual League, offensive and defensive, with his Royal Majesty the King of Poland, in 1696; and the Following Year 1697, in a triennial Alliance, with his Czarish Maje∣sty, the Emperor of the Romans, and the Re∣publick of Venice, mutually Engaging them∣selves, to deliver the Kingdoms of Hungary, Sclavonia, Dalmatia, and the Morea; together with the Cities of Tanna, (commonly called A∣zoph) and Casifurmen, from the Tyranny of the Infidels: Nor could this Design well fail of the wish'd Success, if by continuing the War, a few Years longer, as his Czarish Majesty would have had it. The Enemy, who was already reduc'd to great Straits; had been brought so low, as not to have it in their Power, but at the Peril of their unavoidable Downfal, ever to annoy the Christian World any where again.”

“BUT to our great Sorrow, these irreconcilea∣ble Barbarians, did at the Congress of Carlowitz, partly by Perswasions, and partly by Artifice, induce the High Confederates to enter into a Treaty with them; made Room for Intrigues, sow'd the Darnel of Discord, and withdrew all the above-mention'd Potentates from his Czarish Majesty's Alliance, and at last conclud∣ed a 25 Years Peace, exclusive of him; no
other Remedy being left, Monsieur Worniori, his said Majesty's Ambassador, but to adjust a Truce for two Years, on the 3d of July, 1700; which was soon followed, by 30 Years Peace, concluded at Constantinople, between his Czarish Majesty, and the late Sultan Mustapha, by his said Majesty's Envoys, Monsieurs Ucranstow, and Heredajow: But enough of Things done so long ago, let us come to Matters near Hand, which require a more diligent Exami∣nation.”

“HIS Czarish Majesty did so religiously ob∣serve the Articles of this Treaty; and tho' be∣fore it was ratify'd, the Sultan of the Budziack Tartars, did offer to subject himself, and his People, to his most powerful Scepter; the Proposal was rejected, because nothing should be done, that might have the least Appearance of Contravention; nor did the Turkish Subject, Kubjick Murza succeed better afterwards, when he came to Azoph, with a considerable Body of Cubak Tartars, to offer also Homage.”

“AND his said Majesty being also▪ resolv'd, to observe the Peace, still with more Exactness, after it was ratify'd by his Ambassador Extra∣ordinary, and Plenipotentiary, Prince Deme∣trius Galickzin; he enjoyn'd all his Governors in the Frontier Towns, the General of the Zaporavi∣an Tartars, who was one of his Subjects, and all other Commanders of his Troops, as well Na∣tives as Foreigners, under most severe Penalties, that they should not presume to disturb the Peace, and good neighbourly Friendship, by any Incursions, into the Teritories, either of the Turks, or Tartars.”

“AND his Czarish Majesty carry'd the punctu∣al Observation of the Articles of this Treaty, to that Height; that whereas, some of the Zaporavion Tartars, did in the Tear 1701, Rob some Grecians, who were coming to the Ukrain with Merchandize, and that the Sultan of the Turks demanded the Damage to be made good; his Czarish Majesty knowing, it was to no Purpose, to expect any Reparation from the Robers, order'd that the said Grecians should be indemnify'd out of his own Treasury, and that 100000 Dollars of an Ounce Weight, should be paid to them.”

“ON the other Hand, notwithstanding this, Peace was confirm'd by both the Sultans own Letters, and his solemn Oath, the Turks and Tartars did continually, and by all manner of Ways, injure his Czarish Majesty's Subjects, kil∣ling line some, carrying others into Captivity; and taking away their Horses, and other Cattle; as the following Instanoes, faithfully extracted out of the Registers, do clearly mark out, as well the Crime, as the Time when it was Committed.”

“HIS Czarish Majesty's Ambassador at Constan∣tinople, made his Complaint of these Outrages; but to no purpose: For neither were the Da∣mages made good, nor any Stop put to those Depredations; tho' on his Majesty's Side, the Turks receiv'd Satisfaction, even to their most frivolous pretentions.”

“WHO would have doubted, but that after the above-mention'd Instances of his Czarish Maje∣sty's true Friendship, in rejecting so many Ho∣mages offer'd him, he should at least have met with a suitable Return on the like Occasion; but it was quite otherwise.”

“THE Turks in the Year 1708, did not only give Shelter and Assistance to the fugitive Re∣bel Cossacks, Nearassaw, and his Adherents; but permitted the Tartars to join with them, and make Inroads into his Czarish Majesty Ter∣ritories.”

“NOR did they act with more Candor, in the Year 1709, in Reference, to the Remains of the Swedish Forces, after the glorious and me∣morable Battle of Pultoua: For the King him∣self, with as many of the Officers, and Soldiers of his routed Army, as did escape the Conque∣ror's Sword, and his Czarish Majesty's Be∣trayor the base Mazeppa, with his Adherents, retiring into the Turkish Dominions, where pro∣tected there: And tho' by the Law of Nations, and War, his Czarish Majesty's Troops might have pursued them, yet they receiv'd Orders by no Means to approach Oczacow, where the Enemy and the aforesaid Rebels were, but on the Contrary, to come back again to their own Territories. And whereas his Czarish Ma∣jesty did first by his Ambassador, and after∣wards,
by three different Letters, which he writ to the Sultan, demanded that he would not protect his Enemy; but that without far∣ther Delay, he would make him depart his Dominions, and deliver up the Rebels: Neither was he comply'd with, nor any Answer return'd to his Letters in a great while: But rather Leave granted to the Enemy, and the Rebels to invade his Majesty's Dominions; which they did in conjunction with the Valachians and Tar∣tars, surprizing in the Night-time, the Town of Jaharhick, and carrying away the Com∣mander, with whatever belong'd to him.”

“AFTERWARDS, in the Year 1710, they car∣ry'd off all the Inhabitants of Jargowitz and Nemback, with all their Substance; kill'd a Captain and several Soldiers, of Uman Cossacks; carry'd away another, with 150 private Centi∣nals; they plundered a great Company of Car∣riers, that were coming with Salt from Mo∣lonaw, carrying away most of the Men, and all the Horses; they also robb'd the Waggons design'd for carrying the Baggage of the Army, at a Place call'd Cammen Laton, carrying off most of the Waggons, and all the Beasts of Carriage, and plunder'd the Town of Comensea, in the District of Czigirin.”
“NO Redress was ever made for any of these Damages, nor any satisfactory Answer given, to the many Complaints made of such hostile Invasions, but the Matter still put off, with frivolous Excuses.”

“THE Ottomans at last, being resolv'd to carry their wicked Designs, under the Masque of Peace, their chief Minister, the Visier Ali Basha, proposed to his Czarish Majesty's Ambassador,
that if his Majesty would consent, to confirm the thirty Years Peace concluded between him and the present Sultan's Brother, and give his positive Word, that he was firmly resolv'd, to observe it; he promised, that the Sultan then would not only ratify it, but that also, the King of Sweden's departure out of his Domini∣ons should be agreed upon.”

“HEREUPON, his Czarish Majesty was pleased to send full Powers to his Ambassador for that Purpose, and writ to the Sultan himself about it; upon which the Sultan of the Turks, did so∣lemnly confirm the Peace with his Majesty, in December 1709, and bound himself by Oath, calling the great God of Heaven, to witness, (as shall appear by the Copy hereto annexed) that he would Religiously observe the Laws of it, and the Ratifications were afterwards mutu∣ally exchang'd.”

“AS to what concerns the King of Sweden, it was agreed with the chief Minister Ali Basha, 1. 500 Turks should be permitted to accompa∣ny him thro' Poland into his own Country; and that for his greater Security, from being insult∣ed by any of his Czarish Majesty's Troops, one of his Majesty's Officers, and some of the Rus∣sian Garrisons would receive him upon the Fron∣tiers, and conduct him safe thither, but that in Reference to the Rebel Cossacks, they should be all expell'd the Turkish Dominions.”

“HIS Czarish Majesty gave Consent to this Agreement, and order'd Letters to be writ thereupon to his Ambassador; But the Turk, far from putting the Articles thereof in Execu∣tion, did neither dismiss the King of Sweden, nor expel the Rebels; But rather gave way to
several ill Designs, which were carrying on against his Carish Majesty.”

“UPON Notice of these Artifices, his Czarish Majesty resolv'd to write a Letter to the Sul∣tan, (the Copy of which is hereunto annex'd, and mark'd with an A); wherein he was pleased to declare to him, that he consented that the Number of the Turks design'd to accompany the King of Sweden, should be augmented to 3000; sending Orders at the same Time, to his Ambassador, that they should be made up 5000.”
“BUT it was to no Purpose to expect any Answer to this point: On the contrary, the Report began ro encrease, that the Turks began to incline their Thoughts to War.”

“WHEREUPON his Czarish Majesty order'd a second Letter to be written to the Sultan, on the 18th—29th of October 1710, (as appears by the Copy hereunto annex'd, and mark'd B) and dispatch'd an Envoy Extraordinary on pur∣pose with it. But in stead of an Answer, Word was brought to him, that-his Envoy, contrary to the Law of Nations, was seiz'd and put into a Dungeon, where he Lies to this very Day.”

“Couriers at length began to arrive from all Parts, with Advice, that the Sultan at the In∣stigation of the Han of Tartary, had actuallay declar'd War at Constantinople against his Czarish Majesty, without any Conscience, and only with a bear Pretence, that his Czarish Majesty had given some Motives thereunto, as forced him to break the Peace; which is but a ridicu∣lous saying; for those very Motives pretended, were all decided by the last Peace. They
further brought Word that his Majesty's Ambas∣sador, after several base Affronts put upon him, was imprison'd; the warlike Preparations were making throughout the whole Turkish Empire; the Troops were drawing together about Bender, and the Expedition was notify'd to all the Yurkish Generals (commonly call'd Bashas) with Orders to raise Soldiers.”

“THESE Proceedings were more than enough, to expose the perfidiousness of the Sultan; how∣ever, his Czarish Majesty, to convince the whole World, that the Breach of the Peace, and the Effusion of Humain Blood, which of Necessity must follow, ought not to be laid to his Charge, but to the Sultans; did after all, tho' to little Purpose, order another Letter to be writ to him in his Name, dated at Petersburg, the 6th, 17th, of January last, of the same Tenure with the Copy (here unto also annex'd, and mark'd with C. (viz.) that if the said Sultan did not acquaint him put of Hand with his positive Resolutions, of renewing, and strictly observing the Treaty of Peace; he would look upon it as a real Breach of it; nor would he suffer himself to be amus'd, or circumvented by any Craft; but would (with God's assistance) begin Warlike Prepara∣tions with all Expedition, in order to oppose him early both by Sea and Land.”

“NOW let the honest and impartial Part of the World examine the several Heads of the Turkish Declaration of War, so falsely and so awkardly patch'd together, and publish'd every where, as also, the Crimes they charge us with.”

“THE Ottomans give out, that they began this War purely to assist the Rebel Lezeinsky, whom they look upon to be the right King of Poland, and to deliver the Republick from his Czarish Majesty's Troops, and that they do this at the Request of the said Republick, prescribed there∣to (viz.) the depriv'd Palatine of Kiow Polocky, and Poniatowsky, but who in every Fact, are Be∣trayers of their native Country; and likewise, because his said Czarish Majesty had refused at the Turks Request, to withdraw his Troops out of the Kingdom, and to relinquish his Royal Confederate Augustus the Second, King of Poland.”

“WHO is the Man will say, that this was a Thing fit to be done; or that such a Demand was just; whereas the whole Republick of Po∣land, and the grand Dutchy of Lithuania, do own his Royal Majesty Augustus the Second, for their lawful King, and the said King and Kingdom, continue in Alliance with his Czarish Majesty, by Vertue of which, the said Troops are obli∣ged to continue in Poland, as Auxiliaries; and that the King and Senate, are under a Necessi∣ty of keeping them there: For it is as clear as the Sun at Noon, that their Common Enemy, the King of Sweden, and the Polish Rebels are protected by the Sultan, for no other End but that through their Means, a bloody War might be again kindled in the Russian and Polish Domi∣nions: Besides if his Czarish Majesty had with∣drawn his said Troops, the Consequence would be; that the Turks introducing the King of Sweden into Poland on one Side, and Lezeinsky entring on the other, after they had ravaged the whole Kingdom at their Pleasure, would
unite their Forces, and fall upon his Czarish Majesty, and so create worse Disorders than the former: This is the Reason why his Czarish Majesty refused to comply with the Turkish Arrogance, or by relinquishing his Confedera∣cy, to expose Poland as a Pray to the Barba∣rians.”

“WHY was not the King of Sweden all this while dismiss'd out of Turkey, by some of the ways proposed by his Czarish Majesty, either by Sea or Land, or even with a select Guard, or by some other better Way; laying aside all tnose far fetch'd, and Frivilous Pretences, which are made use of; and then his Czarish Majesty would immediately have withdrawn all his Troops out of Poland, and out of the fortify'd Towns of the Republick, which for their Com∣mon Security he is at Present oblig'd to Gar∣rison, until the Danger be over.”

“THE Turks complain besides in their Declara∣tion of War, that his Czarish Majesty had built some Forts, within the Boundaries of the Otto∣man Dominions; but this Pretence is manifestly false: For his Czarish Majesty caused no Forts to be Built any where, but in those Places that were incorporated with his Empire, and expres∣ly adjudg'd to belong to it, as well by the Treaty of Peace, as by the Agreement ad∣justed on assertaining the Boundaries on the Side of Tana, vulgarly call'd Azoph, between Monsieur Tolstoy Governor of the said City; and Hasan Basha, in 1704: And in the Ukrain, between Monsieur Ukrainstow, and Kasi Mee∣met Basha, in the Year 1705.”

“AND as for what the Turks object, in the same Declaration about his Czarish Majesty's Troops breaking into their Territories, in pur∣suit of the fugative Swedes, where they killed some and enslav'd others; the Muscovites did this according to the Manner and Custom of War; with which the Turks did not find Fault, when the Thing was afterwards rightly ex∣plain'd to them; besides, that this Affair, was entirely adjudg'd, and for ever to be hush'd by the last renewing of the Peace.”

“BUT as far as we dive into the true Design of the Turks, it appears to be, first, To force by previous Aggressions, his Czarish Majesty's Troops, who by Virtue of the Alliance with his Royal Majesty King Augustus, and the Re∣publick of Poland as is already mention'd, re∣main the Kingdom as Auxiliaries, to return out of it. Next, to introduce the King of Sweden thither; afterwards, to raise a Sedition; then drive the aforesaid Lawful King again from his Throne; and last of all to obtrude with Fire and Sword, the Rebel Stanislaus Lezeinsky, whom the King of Sweden did by Violence set up, and so, not only Subject the Kingdom to the barbarous Yoke of the Ottomans, by a Free Tribute of three Millions of Gold Ducats Yearly, to be paid by the Republick, but also, the several Provinces being for ever dismem∣bred from it, should together with the strong Fortress of Caminick, be yielded up to the In∣fidels, according to the Promises made by the King of Sweden, and the late Palatine of Kiow Postoki, and Poniatows in Lezenisky's Name; besides, what by the Artifice of their Confede∣rates, what by means of the Swedish Forces, and
those of Lezeinsky, now lurking in Pomerania, they would raise a Storm in the Roman Empire, and kindle a War there; which done, to carry on the War against his Czarish Majesty, in conjunction with their Confederates, and by the perfidious Means of the Mazeppian Rebels, and Blavian Cossacks, to foment Sedition within his Majesty's Empire; and thus to put in Ex∣ecution those most pernicious and abominable Designs which they have premeditated as well against his Czarish Majesty, and the King of Poland, as against the whole Christian World.”

“THAT therefore, the Justice of his Czarish Majesty's Cause, may clearly appear to all the honest Part of the World, that he never since this first Minute of the Truce of Carlo∣witz, and the Conclusion of the 30 Years Peace, which the Sultan of the Turks has now basely broke to this very Hour, gave him any Occati∣on for such a Breach, but did holily and reli∣giously observe the same, notwithstanding the great and many Attempts made to the Con∣trary, on the Part of the Turks, what by ho∣stile Irruptions in his Dominions; and what by protecting his rebel Subjects, and giving Shelter to his Enemy, he has the Contrary been graci∣ously Pleas'd to command this most wicked Breach of the Turks to be exposed to all Mens View.”

“LET every Body now consider the Inclinati∣on which his Czarish Majesty has shew'd all along for Peace: Then discuss the just and Moderate Steps he made in the whole Series of this Af∣fair, and judge whether there was the least Oc∣cation given on his Majesty's Side, for break∣ing
of the Peace, and whether after the previ∣ous Marks which he gave of his good Intentions, he could abstain from declaring War in his Turn, against the profidious and perpetual Enemy of Christanity: And finally, let him conclude, that this particular War was forced upon his Czarish Majesty contrary to the Faith of Treaties, and the Sacred Tye of publick Oaths; who thereupon with God Almighty's Assistance, has resolv'd in his own Defence, to order his Army, to March to his Frontiers against his perfidious Enemy, the Sultan of the Turks, and all his Confederates and Abettors: And to follow it himself in Person, very soon, and committing upon his bended Knee, the Justice of his Cause, to the same great God's Judgment, thus betakes himself to Arms.”

“AT the same time the Czar wrote a Letter to the Grand Seignior himself, to remove the Ob∣jection about the conveying the King of Sweden into his own Territories, offering to give him free Passage through the Muscovite and Polish Domini∣ons, with a sufficient Guard for the Safety of his Person, or to allow the Turks to convoy him with a certain Number of Troops. The Letter is as follows.”

WE wrote twice to your Highness, namely, first the 28th of July, and secondly, the 29th of October, of the last Year, that according to inter∣cepted Letters, and by the long Abode of the King of Sweden in your Territories, it was to be fear'd that that Prince and his Adherents, with the Cos∣sacks,
Rebels to us, and to the King of Poland, our Ally; would by Means of the tryaterous Palatine of Kiow, and others, who finding Refuge in your Ter∣ritories, endeavours to engage your Highness in a War; for which Reason we desir'd that your Highness would Cause his Swedish Majesty forthwith to depart your Territories, and return into his own; offering him a free Passage through our Armies, under a a Guard of 4000 Tartars, and 5000 Turks, in case your Highness should think it proper, for his greater Security: This is what our Ambassador was charged to propose to you; and his Polish Majesty having likewise consented to it, we were bound to answer for the said free Passage.

Moreover, We declared, that in case your High∣ness would grant a more numerous Guard to the King of Sweden, and conduct him into Poland by force of Arms, This would be look'd upon by us, and by his Polish Majesty, that your Highness had a mind to break the Peace of Carlowitz and that we should be oblig'd to oppose the same to the utmost of our Power, by Virtue of the Alliance, whereby we are mutually bound to assist each other.

We are not the violators of that Peace, but would religiously observe it on our Part, to prevent the Effu∣sion of Human Blood; God will surely revenge it upon the Fomentor of the War, and Violator of the most Solemn Treaties: and should the King of Swe∣den offer to return into his Dominions by any other Way than has been proposed to him under Colour of greater Security, we shall look upon that Proceeding as an open Violation of the Peace.

We have not yet received any Answer from your Highness, to our former Letters, nor from our Am∣bassdor, to let us know whether he deliver'd them to your Highness, and whether he had any Answer
or not: But on the Contrary, we have received cer∣tain Advice, from several Places, that our Ambas∣sador has been arrested, that the War against us has been resolv'd upon at Constantinople, and Orders are given for forming an Army at Bender; and that the Tartars who are ready to conduct the King of Sweden, are order'd to enter Poland by Force of Arms; wherefore we thought fit to write this Letter to your Highness, to exhort you once more to answer our former Letters, and to let us know whether you intend to observe the Treaty prolong'd with us last Year, for 30 Years, confirm'd with several Oaths, made before the Judge of all our Actions, or to vio∣late if, without the least Occasion on our Part given.

We also declare, that in case we receive no Answer touching your Intention to preserve the Peace, and that your Highness continues your Military Prepa∣rations, to conduct the King of Sweden through Po∣land, with a powerful Army, we shall look, upon this as an open Violation of the Truce; and calling God to our Assistance, shall provide for our own Safety, and endeavour to repulse our Enemies with the Ar∣my we have sent upon the Frontier.

In the mean while, if the Rupture of the Peace be attended with the Effusion of Human Blood, we declare, before God and Man, that it will not be our Fault, but that we shall be forc'd to it. We like∣wise take God to Witness that it was never our In∣tention to break the Truce, but to observe it religi∣ously as we promised, wherefore, without Trusting in any vain Immagination, but only in the supreme Judge, we hope, he will defend us against all Di∣sturberso the Peace and Violators of Cats.

We expect therefore, an Answer to these Pre∣sents and in case none comes, we shall look. up∣on it, as a Breach of the Peace: But if we see by your Highnesses Answer, that your Inten∣tion is to let us alone, and inviolably to main∣tain the Peace with us, (the King of Sweden be∣ing sent back, without its being in any wise in∣fringed) all our Umbrage will Cease.

And as our Army is advancing towards the Frontiers, without committing any Act of Hosti∣lity, the Rupture cannot be attributed to us; the less because, if the Satisfaction that is re∣quir'd be given us, our Troops shall forthwith with∣draw from your Neighbourhood, and we will in∣violably maintain the Truce, with your Highness; We wish your Highness perfect Health.

CLOSER.DATELINE: Given at Petersburgh, the 16th of Janu∣ary, 1711.

DIV2.P:
ALL these Things put together, will convince any indifferent Person, that the Czar was no ways accessary to this War; but that on the Con∣trary, his Majesty used all just Means consistent with his Honour, to keep the Peace, so newly entred into, and so solemnly sworn between him∣self and the Turks. But it could not be, the Turks prepair'd for War, with all imaginable Diligence; the King of Sweden began to grow formidable again at Bender, having gotten near 20000 Men together, very good Troops, most of them Swedes and Poles, and now the Grand Army
of the Turks which had encamped at Adrinople some Time, began to advance.

THE Czar had a good Army of excellent Troops, and he had order'd the Horse for some Time to rendezvous about Lemberg, where his Czarish Majesty came soon after in Person, and advanc'd with them to the Frontiers; they con∣sisted in about 40000 Horse, and a great Body of the Horse remain'd about Jassy, to secure the Communication.

WITH this Army, when joyn'd by the Infant∣ry, the Czar advanced; and having an intimate Correspondence with the Hospodar of Moldavia, he made Conditions with him, to furnish his, Army with Bread, and other Provisions, and to give him Passage and Re-passage thro' the Country.

SOME have said the Hospodar kept a secret Correspondence with the Grand Vizier, all the while; and did this on purpose to betray the Czar, but this was grounded on a Mistake; the Hospodar perform'd his Agreement as long as he was able to do it without ruining himself, and all his Affairs; but drew off, when he saw the urkish Army was so much superior to the Czar, that he apprehended a Blow, and that he should fall into the Hands of the Turks; then indeed, it was to be expected he would act with more Caution.

ON the other Hand, 'tis said, the Hospoder did perform his Part effectually, as to furnishing what Provisions the Czar requir'd, and that no∣thing was deficient, but that the Hospodar never condition'd to furnish Troops, or to draw his Sword in the Quarrel.

BUT to let that pass, his Czarish Majesty set out from Jaroslaw, the 10th of June, 1710, where Matters were concerted between the King of Poland and himself, for mutual Assistance in this War, after which the King of Poland went away into Saxony, to settle his Affairs in Germany; and the Czar went from thence to Lemberg, as above, then the Army; that is to say, the Cavalry, were order'd to advance to the Dneister; His Majesty joyn'd them near Kami∣nieck and march'd, keeping the River on his Right, till he came to Raskow, on the Dneister, where he was joyn'd by the four Regiments of his Guards, or Houshold Troops; the rest of the Infantry coming up in a few Days more, by the Way of Bracklaw and Czarkassy; some passing by Kiovia, and some by Pultowa, a Place made famous by the late Overthrow of the King of Sweden.

WHEN the whole Army was brought toge∣her, they reckon'd them to be 35000 Foot, and 40000 Horse, all choice Troops, especially the Infantry; 3000 Turks posted overagainst Raskow, in order to dispute their Passage Over the Neither, abandon'd their post upon the coming up of 2000 Muscovite Grenadiers, who had pass'd in the Night in some small Boats, at about a League di∣stance, and out of their Sight.

AS soon as the Turks were fled, two Bridges being laid upon the River, and a small En∣trenchment at the End of each Bridge, to se∣cure the Passage, the whole Army passed over with their Artillery and Baggage.

FROM the Neister, the Army advanced to the Pruth, and the Czar went in Person with 5000 Dragoons to Jassy, the Capital of Moldavia;
to Converse with the Hospodar, and to secure sufficient Magaziens of Provisions which that Coun∣try and Wallachia, being very fruitful, were very well able to Furnish: Here the Czar staying too long, gave the Turks, who where then as far off as the Danube, Time to come up, for the Vizier hearing that the Czar was past the Neister, made long Marches, fearing the Russians should reach to the Banks of the Danube before him, and con∣sequently should prevent or dispute his Passage, and perhaps have given him a Blow, if he had attempted it.

The Vizier was decamp'd from Adrianople ac∣cording to the best Advices, when the Czar came to the Banks of the Neister; but had sent a great Body of his Infantry that they might pass the Straights of the Mountain Hemus, which runs in a Chain, from the Shore of the Venetian Gulph, thro' Macedonia and Thrace, to the Euxine Sea; but as soon as the Vizier had an Account, that the Czar had advanc'd, he put himself in full March with the Horse, and came to the Danube, the 24th of June.

HAD not his Czarish Majesty been delay'd at Jassy too long, but had pass'd the Pruth at that City, and march'd on directly to the Danube, he had certainly carry'd the Point, and the Vizier had been kept at Bay, at the passing that River; for he would not have ventur'd to have pass'd the Danube, which is a prodigious great River at Silisiria, a little above which he went over, and the Stream fierce and Rapid: I say, he would not have ventur'd to pass that River, in the Teeth of the Russian Army; or if he had, he would have run a great Risque of being defeated.

IT was without doubt, either a Mistake, or a Misfortune, that his Czarish Majesty's Army should Halt upon the Pruth, and let the Turks pass the Danube; and his Czarish Majesty saw it, when it was too late; for had the Banks of the Danube been secured, the King of Sweden must have shifted his Quarters, and have quitted Bender, with as much Precipitation, almost, as he did Pultowa, and perhaps would have found it more difficult to have made his Escape.

NOR would the Forces of the Tartars have been so troublesome, if the Grand Army of the Turks had been kept off; for tho' they call'd the Tartars 50000 yet the Russians would have fac'd about, and have made them shift off, as fast as they came: But when the Turks lay at the Danube before, and the Russians had their Hands full of them in their Front, it was easy for a Body of Tartars to do Mischief in the Rear.

'TIS to no Purpose to enlarge upon what might have been done, it is our Part to give the History of what was really done; and the Czar having lost 12 Days Time at Jassy, the Banks of the Pruth, the Grand Army of the Turks Pass'd the Danube undisturb'd, and advanc'd. a-pace.

WHILE the Turks and the Russians were then facing one another, the Tartars by their Inroads Harrass'd the Russian Army, took many Horses, and killed a great many People, and at last, effectually cut off their Provissions, sunk or burnt all the Boats they had on the Purth, and in a Word, being very numerous, they did the Russians a World of Mischief.

THIS brought them to a Battle, for the Turks advancing to the Pruth, and the Russians seeing themselves almost reduced to an Extremity, re∣solv'd to wait their coming and Fight, them; the Mystery of this Engagement, and of the sudden Peace which was the Conseuence of it is not fully known in the World, and perhaps never may.

THE Sum of the Story, is this; the Turks ad∣vancing, and appearing very numerous, the Czar caused his Men to entrench, believing the Ene∣my would attack them; as, indeed, they did the next Day; the Entrenchment which they attack'd, was Guarded by 12 Battallions of Mus∣covite Infantry, and about 3000 Granediers; who all together ply'd their Time so well, and lay'd so many of the Enemy dead upon the Spot; that the Janizaries after a furious Attack, which lated four Hours, the Basha's bringing on fresh Men, as the others were beaten off, were finally repulsed with great Slaughter; a Body of Dragoons, who were posted to Support the Defendants, falling out also upon them in their Retreat.

THAT Night the Intrenchments were en∣larg'd, and 10000 Foot, supported by Dragoons, were posted to defend them; the Enemy came on again to the Assault, with 20000 Janizaries, supported by a great Body of Horse; the Russian Army stood in Order of Battle in two Lines, in their Camp, which was also entrench'd; the Fight was obstinate, and very bloody; the Fury of the Turks not being to be resisted, without great Loss on the Russian's Part also; However, the Turks were again Beaten off; and in these two Days, it was said, that the Turks lost 12000 of their best Men.

HOWEVER, as the Turks still prepar'd to re∣new their Efforts, as if resolv'd to carry the Entrenchments, whatever it Cost; and his Czarish Majesty finding the Tartars which harraz'd him, continually in the Rear, had 10000 Foot sent them from the Viziers Army, and that he should be in Danger of being quite Surrounded by two vast Armies of near 100000 Men each; and which was worse, that his Convoys were cut off by the Tartars; he resolv'd to Retreat; which, however, was done in such Order, and with such daring Boldness of Courage, in Sight of the Enemy, that when the Turkish Cavalry, pretended to pur∣sue them, the Foot fairly faced about, threw down their Chevauz de Frieze, and pour'd in their Volleys upon the Turks, and then Re∣treated.

HOWEVER, this retreating fareagu'd the Army to the last Degree, and the Tartars surprizing a great many of the Czar's Horses, added to the Misfortune, several Regiments of Horse be∣ing entirely dismounted: So the Czar finding a convenient Situation to Encamp and Entrench, halted again.

HERE the Vizier came up with the whole Turkish Army, but durst not attack the Russian Camp, the Front being defended by a Morass; the Right Wing, by a winding Branch of the Ri∣ver Pruth; and the Left, by a Hill, which the Muscovite Infantry, had entrenched: The Vizier seeing this, brings up his Cannon, and Can∣nonaded them in their Camp, with 50 Pieces of heavy Artillery; and their Camp lying exposed to this Battery, there was no hindring it; at the same Time, they seem'd entirely to be shut in, by the winding of the River Pruth, and the E∣nemy;
so that in short, the Generals began to look one upon another, as Men desperate, and at a Loss what to do.

THE Colonels, and inferiour Officers, were for drawing out the Array, and giving the Turks Battle, and the Common Soldiers cry'd out to be led against the Enemy, that they might dye with their Swords in their Hands, and sell their Lives as dear as they could, rather than be torn in Pieces with the Cannon, and perish in the Camp for Want of Provisions: But his Czarish Majesty, who alone was not dismaid at the Cir∣cumstances he was in, quikly resolv'd what to do, and order'd a Trumpet with three Officers, to the Vizier, writing a Letter to the Vizier himself.

THE Effect of this Message, what ever the Pro∣posal was, answer'd so well what his Czarish Ma∣jesty desir'd, that it produc'd a Treaty; and tho' it must be confess'd, that the Circumstances of the Russian Army then were such that a De∣feat was inevitable, except by a desperate Brave∣ry they could have broke thro' the whole Turkish Army, which being so destitute of Horses, was next to impossible; yet, as they were all re∣solv'd to dye with their Emperor, and to sell their Lives like Men of Honour; the Vizier, who knew it, must have caused a most bloody Action, and perhaps might have been ruinous to him also, thought fit to consider what Proposals were made and whether the Demands he might make, might not only save the present Effusion of Blood, but a future Expence both of Blood and Treasure to the whole Ottoman Empire.

UPON this Foot, he Demanded the City of Asoph, which was indeed, a Purchase, which a whole Campaign, and a good Array could not have procur'd them; (some say, his Czarish Ma∣jesty offer'd the City of Asoph) he demanded also 1200000 Dollars in Money; the first, he called, the Agreement of Peace; and the second, he called, the Ransom of the Army; who, he supposed, to be all as good as his Prisoners, and consequently Slaves, ready to be sold at Market; which indeed, as Things stood, was almost the Case.

THE bringing such a Treaty to Conclusion, in such an Exigency, was a Master-Piece of the Czar's own conducting; for on the other Hand, the King of Sweden did his utmost to pre∣vent it, nay, even he reproach'd the Vizier in the Head of has Army, complaining that he should give up the Grand Seignior Enemy, when he was in his Hand, and that in one Day the Czar must be his Prisoner, and all his Army; and even threatening to represent it to the Grand Seignior, as to be sure he afterwards did.

I say, it was a Master Piece indeed, for the Vizier, by what Means is yet unknown, and per∣haps will ever be so, continued firm, and repre∣sented the Advantages of Peace on the Terms proposed, particularly the restoring of Asoph, a Place, the Loss of which, had been a hear Breaking to the Turkish Court: I say, he repre∣sented this so effectually to the Port, that the Sultan confirmed the Treaty, and ratify'd it with great Satisfaction, notwithstanding all the Representations of some of his Courtiers, who were against it.

AS for the King of Sweden, and the Han of Tartary, they fail'd not, to give a quite diff∣erent Account of the Thing, representing the Vizier as Confederate with the Czar, to betray his Master, the Grand Seignior's Interest; and that he had taken a great Sum of Money to let the Czar escape out of his Hands, when he might with Ease have carry'd him away in Triumph, and have deliver'd him up, at the Gate of the Seven Towers in Constantinople.

THIS they aggravated to that Degree after∣wards, and told their Tale so speciously, that the Grand Seignior was quite turn'd about in his Judgment of the Thing, and resented it to the Ruin of the Grand Vizier, who was strangled soon after, by Order of his Master, for making the Treaty, which he himself had approv'd.

BY this Treaty, (the Peace being made) the Czar of Muscovy, and his whole Army, march'd safe and quietly, to the Bank of the Dneister, and so by easy Marches, into the Ukraine, with all their Cannon and Baggage; and thus ended this short War, wherein tho' the Czar indeed lost the Honour of the Field, yet he gain'd this great Point; namely, that the Turks abandon'd the Interest of the King of Sweden; which was all i. deed, that the War was made for; and which if they would have done before, the Czar would never have took the Field at all: The Loss the Czar sustain'd in this Battle, was not much less than 10000 Men, and a prodigious Number of Horses, some said 30000, but no Artillery, or Trophies.

HIS Czarish Majesty having thus gotten over the main Article, the War with the Turks; little of Moment pass'd for some time, the King of
Poland was wholly taken up in settling himself in his newly restored Kingdom; and the Czar giving his Troops a whole Winters Rest, had lei∣sure to recrute and refresh them, and in particular to fill them up with Forreigners, Germans, Scots, Livonians, Poles, nay, even with the Swedes, them∣selves, for whole Companies of the Swedes, who surrendered at Pultowa, and were taken in Bat∣tle there, and other Places, finding no other End of their Misfortunes, Listed in the Czar's Service, and were generally employ'd on the Side of Cyrkassia, and Ukrania, and such remote Parts of his Dominions.

THE Articles of Peace, thus agreed upon, by the Turks, and the Czar of Muscovy, however they may be thought hard, and worded disho∣nourably for his Czarish Majesty, the Justice due to an impartial History, requires they should be recorded, as follows.

DIV2.HEAD: The grand Reason of this authentick WRITING is, That by the Grace of God, the victorious Musselman's Army, having by sur∣rounding and shutting up the Czar of Muscovy, with his whole Army, in the Neighbourhood of the River of Pruth, brought him into Sraights; he himself desir'd Peace, and on the Instance of the said Czar, the Treaty and Ar∣ticles were settled and concluded, in the fol∣lowing Manner.
DIV2.P: I. THAT be shall restore the Fortress of Azoph, in the Condition wherein he formerly took it, with its Territories and Districts.

II. That Taiganrog, Kamenki, and the new Fort on the further Side of the River Kaman, shall be totally demolish'd, the Cannon and Ammunition of War in the Fortress Kamenki (or Kaminick) to be left therein, to the Illustrious Port, and no new Fort to be ever built in the same Place.

III. That the Czar shall not concern himself with the Polacks, nor with the Cossacks, their Depen∣dants, named, Barabasci and Porcali; nor with the Dependants of the most successful Han Daubet Gherai; but shall leave them in their former Con∣dition, and withdraw all his Forces out of those Coutries.
IV. That Mrchats may come y Land into the wll guarded Dominios, with their Merchandize; but no Person shall be admitted to reside at the Illustrious Port, in the Quality of Ambassador.
V. That all Musselmen, who formerly, or in this War have been taken, and are Slaves in the Hana of the Muscovies, shall be Restored to Liberty.

VI. That the King of Sweden, having taken Sanctuary under the Wings of the powerful Protection of the illustrious Port, shall have free and safe Pas∣sage without being in any manner hindred or stopp'd by the Muscovites; and in case they can come to a good Understanding together, and have a Mind to make Peace, it may in Consequence be treated between them.
VII. And for the future, no Damage or Injury shall be done by the Port to the Muscovites; in like Manner, these last shall do no Wrong to the former, or their Subjects or Dependants
“WHEREFORE, the immence Goodness of my most powerful and gracious Emperor, and Lord, is besought, to be pleas'd, to ratify the foregoing Articles, and to overlook the past ill Behaviour of the Czar.”

“THUS, and in the foremention'd Manner, by Vertue of the full Power to me given, is this pre∣sent Treaty made and deliver'd; we shall there∣fore confer about the Hostages given by the said Czar, for Performance of the Articles contain'd in the said Instrument; likewise, the Treaty of Peace nam'd Temeruki shall be mutually Ex∣changed; after which his Army shall march off free, and the direct way to their own Country, without any Hindrance, either by the Victorious Army, or by the Tartars, and others; the fore∣going Articles, shall of Course be executed, and the Capitulation mutually Exchang'd; after which we will immediately give Liberty to the Two Hostages that are in the victorious Army, namely, the Chiefest among the Nobility of the Nation of the Messiah, his Privy Chancel∣lor, Baron Peter Schaphirof, and the Grandson of Czeremext Michael Boriz (Whose Ends be
Happy) after every Point shall have been per∣form'd; in Testimony of what is agreed, this present Writing, Sign'd in the aforesaid Camp, the 6th of the Month Gemaiel Acir, of the Hegira,” 1123, (or, the 21st of July, 1711.)

WE shall now bring our History into a more compact Method of Relation; for as hitherto, the several ally'd Powers of Muscovy, Denmark, and Poland, have acted single, and in seperate Parts of the World, So that we have been ob∣lig'd to trace their Proceedings from one Part of the World to another, and give the Story a-part; we shall now find them joyn all three together in pushing the Swedes as their Common Enemy, in order to thrust them quite out of Germany, and dispossess them of all their Domini∣ons, on this Side of the Baltick Sea.

IT has been already noted, how King Augustus, after the Defeat of the Swedes at the great Battle of Pultowa, had reassum'd the Crown of Poland; 'tis no part of my Business to relate his Proceed∣ings there; or the Manner in which he went on to Establish himself on that Throne, other than as the Czar of Muscovy, whose Story we are up∣on, was Concern'd in it, that part belongs more particularly to the History of King Augustus, and his Affairs in Poland.

BUT now we shall find the Czar, King Au∣gustus, and the King of Denmark, all in a Body acting together in concert, and all in one Place, viz. in Pomerania, in order to push the Swedes out of that Country; which, in short, was the Center of all their Force, and by which Country all their Reinforcements from Sweden arriv'd; And here General Craan, with a Body of Troops,
had hover'd over the Frontiers for some time, threatening Saxony with another Invasion, and perhaps had made good their Menaces they gave out, had not the Power and Princes of the Grand Alliance's form'd, what they call'd, a neutral Army to prevent it.

THIS the Swedes resented in the highest Man∣ner possible, and fail'd not to testify their Re∣sentment, in Seizing the Ships belonging to the said Confederates in the Baltick, and refusing to allow them the Liberty of Trade to the Towns of Livonia, taken from them by the Czar, as par∣ticularly Riga, Pernau, Revel, and Narva, as also Wyburgh, and even to Dantzick.

THINGS standing thus, the Allies above-nam'd, resolv'd to reduce the Provinces of Pomerania, and the Isle of Rugen, as the only Footing the Swedes had on this Side the Baltick, except the City and Port of Wismar, which they afterward found Means to reduce also.

THE King of Poland began this Part of the War, as the Person who was more nearly con∣cern'd, and having publish'd a large Manifesto of his Reasons for it; the Czar came in rather as an Auxiliary than otherwise tho' his Czarish Maje∣sty's Quarrel at the Swedes, was equally concern'd with any of them; this Manifesto stating the Case of the whole War, I amoblig'd to mention, because the Czar is nearly concern'd in the Consequences, tho' not in the Reason of that part of the Quarrel.

HOW great a Regard the most Serene King of Poland has ever had since the Beginning of this War, to the Friendship of the most Serene Allies in the War against France; and what he has done up∣on that Consideration, must be sufficiently known to all the World; how also, and often postponing his own Advantage; he has neglected no Occasion to express his Inclination and Readiness to promote their In∣trest, of which, certainly, his Majesty gave an unde∣niable Instance, in the Year 1709, when the Swed∣ish Troops under General Crassau retir'd from Po∣land into Pomerania; it was doubtless his Polish Majesty's Interest, to fall upon his Enemies at that Time, and give them no time to re-establish their Forces, in order to disturb again the Kingdom of Poland, or invade the Hereditary Dominions of his sacred Majesty, or at least to keep them in continual Apprehensions of an Irruption: These were suffici∣ent Reasons to induce his Majesty to the Enterprize, and he had Forces enough to execute it; For, besides the Army of Poland and Lithuania, the Auxiliary Troops of Muscovy, under General Goltz, were at Had▪ his Majesty might very well have followed the Example given him by the King of Sweden himself, in the Year 1706, and have pursu'd and attack'd the Swedes in Pomerania; but notwithstanding this appear'd highly necessary for his own Security, he forore it of his own accord, at the desire of the High Allies, making War against France, he so wisely, and prudently directed that Affair, that upon Condition of a certain and sufficient Guaranty, which was to be given by the said Allies; for the Security of the cofederated Princes in the North, they alter'd their Resolution to pursue the Troops under General Crassau, in the Province aforesaid. The Czar of Muscovy, and the Republick of Poland, caus'd im∣mediately
after, their Minister at Ratisbon and the Hague, to signify, as they did likewise themselves, by Letters, their good Intentions, for the Confede∣rates against France; adding, however, a Clause, or Condition, that not only the Saxon Territories, but also the Kingdom of Poland, and the Danish Pro∣vinces, afterwards mention'd in the publick Acts of the Nutrality, should be absolutely secur'd against all Invasion on the part of the Swedes, by the Guarant∣y of the High Allies, against France; for it would have been highly unjust in any, to have procured a free and safe Flight and Retreat for the Enemies above∣said, and to have refus'd, at the same time to pre∣vent the Danger that might be apprehended from them.

This being approv'd, Treaties were set on Foot, and concerted for that Neutrallity at the Hague and Ratisbon in the usual manner, and the most Se∣rene Allies, look'd upon that Affair, at that time, almost as the Safety and Preservation of the Empire, and as if the Fate of the whole Common Cause de∣pended thereupon; the Confederates in the North, having the same Notions, accepted the Neutrality, and by means thereof, bound themselves in some man∣ner with the Allies against France; and it was re∣solved, that if any should act contrary to this Agree∣ment, that the other, should unite their Forces against the Infringer of the said Neutrality. The most Se∣rene King of Poland observed religiously what had been concerted and agreed to, by the Allies on both sides; expecting and confiding, that the King of Swe∣den would agree, and conform himself to that Con∣vention, according to the obligatory Declaration of the Royal Senate of Stockholm, delivered in a solemn manner in Writing at the Hague; but con∣trary to the Opinion and Expectation of all, the King
Sweden was of a different Opinion, and manifested the same by Word and Deed, as it is sufficiently known to the World; be endeavour'd at first, amusse the most Serene Allies in several ways, and set on Foot a Treaty with them for putting into their Ser∣vice 8000 Men, to be detach'd from the Troops un∣der general Crassau in Pomerania;, but when Great Britain, and the States, had conented to every Thing that had been desired of them, and the Treaty was look'd upon as concluded, e forbid the Senate of Stockholm to part with any Forces for the Ser∣vice of the Allies.
I. Not contented therewith, he augmented his Army in Pomerania, above one half of the Number the same was at first, by new Levies.
II. He caused a considerable Number of Men, to be brought over, at several Times, from Swe∣den, into Pomerania, sometimes 500 Men, and at other times 800.
III. He caused several Danish Ships belonging to the Provinces included in the Neutrality, to be chased by his Men of War, and used in a manner, breaking thereby the Neutrallity afore∣said.

IV. After having concluded an Alliance with the Ottoman Port, the Hereditary Enemy of the Christian Name, which cannot be excused; he did not scruple do declare a the Hague, and at the Diet of Ratisbon, by a solemn Writing dated from Bender, the 30th of November, 1710; that he rejected the Neutrallity aforesaid, and would not be oblig'd to the same; and the Baron de Stralenheim, his Envoy at the Impa∣rial Court, had already protested against it, the 11th of August the said Year; e used there∣in
a harsh Stile, attended with Mennaces, hard∣ly to be endur'd, as that the Convention for the said Neutrality was partial (tho' it was for his Advantage, if he would consider the Thing Right:) that e reserv'd to himself an unlimit∣ed Liberty, to employ his Forces against whomsoever, and in such Times, and Places, as e should think fit, according to the Laws and Customs of War; if any one offer'd to hinder him from pursuing his declared Enemy with his Arms, he could not but consider him as an Ag∣gresser, and declare him for such: Which a∣mounts in Effect, not only to a Declaration of War against the Confederated Princes in the North in general, and against the most Serene King of Poland, in particular, and a Signification that he will attack him in the Polish Dominions, and in his Electorate, or, wheresoever he should think fit; but may be look'd upon also, as a De∣claration of War against the Allies, now in War against France; and an intimation that he will carry on the same on all Sides, by the help of his Confederates the Turks and Tartars: This the King of Sweden has express'd in plain Terms, in his Manifesto dated from Bender, 28th of January, of this present Year 1711. which the Palatine of Kiow dispersed in Po∣land, attended with an Army of Barbarians and Infidels, and which was directly intended against the King of Poland, wherein he declar'd be has made an Alliance with the Turks and Tartars, for that Purpose; But these Threats will not binder the most Serene Allies; against France, from adbearing to the Measures con∣certed, for maintaining the Neutrality, afore∣said.

V. To what has been already said, it must, be ad∣ded, that the Rebel Smigielski, was lately sent from the Swedish Pomerania with a Manifesto of Count Lezinski (who not only continues in the Country, but is maintain'd therein) and with some Troops has made an Irruption into the Country to exhort the Poles to Rebellion, and has actually committed Hostilities against the Troops of the King of Poland, and when they were Pursuing him, he retired again into the Swedish Province aforesaid, where he is en∣tertain'd, and supply'd with Necessaries, by which Action, this Neutrality has been again infringed by the Swedes: Therefore the most Serene King of Poland, is not only grounded in Justice, But besides, lies under a pressing Necessity, to make use of all lawful Means, for eradica∣ting this Evil, and preventing those Dangers in their very Source.

There is no Reason to believe, that when the most Serene Allies against France, induced the most Serene King of Poland, and his Allies, to accept, out of Regard to them, a Neutrality so advantagious to the King of Sweden, tho' he had rejected it with Scorn, ever pretend that this Compliance and Readiness of his Polish Majesty, should turn to the Ruin of the Kingdom of Poland, and other Provinces belonging to him; tho' this has, in a great Measure, already hap∣pen'd; seeing that out of Fear of an Invasion on the Part of the said Swedish Forces in Pomerania Many Subjects of his Majesty have abandon'd their Country, whereby the Credit of the Merchants amongst Forreigners, and trade in general, has receiv'd great Prejudice: besides this Damage; the Expences for raising new Forces, and equiping them, their
Marches, and Maintenance, with the raising of the Militia throughout the whole Electorate of Saxony, have not only put the most Serene King of Poland to great Charges, and involv'd him in great Difficulties, but have also lessen'd very much his Revenues, and occasion'd many other Losses.

Furthermore, it would be altogether unreasonable, that the King of Sweden, who has already receiv'd this Benefit of the Convention of the Neutrality tho' irreverently rejected by him, in that no Body has pursu'd the Forces of Crassau into Pomerania, should conti∣nue to enjoy the said Neutrality, to the Prejudice of the King of Poland, and his Allies, in the North; for no Body can be insensible that the Turkish War is founded on the Augmentation of the Swedish Army in Pomerania, and the future Invasion by the same, of Poland or Saxony.

The State of Affairs being such, and the World being perswaded that the King of Sweden has so ex∣plain'd his Mind by Words and Deeds, that nothing further is to be expected from him; and that on the other Hand, it appears, after other violent Means of that King, which were scarce ever heard of before, from a Christian Prince; That the Security of the most Serene King of Poland, and his Dominions depends on the Dispersion of the Swedish Army in Pomera∣nia; it follows that the most Serene Allies against France, are oblig'd to assist him with their Forces, according to the Tenor of the Convention, and as the Preservation and Tranquility of the Holy Roman Empire, and the happy Success of the Common Cause depend, in a great Measure on this Point; the most Serene King of Poland expected that the most Serene Allies against France, would have sent their Forces, design'd for maintaining the said Neutrality, to be employ'd under his Command, as being the Party of∣offended,
and in Danger; but as they have not able hitherto, to execute their good Intentions, as the Delays of the March of their Troops they had pro∣ised, and other Difficulties sufficiently shew; the most Serene King aforesaid, thinks himself Necessitated to take without delay, such Measures as are necessary for his Affairs, and for preventing the Inconvenien∣cies, and Damages afore-mention'd, and their Conse∣quences; on the other Hand, the faithful States of the Kingdom of Poland, will be no longer uncer∣tain, as wishing to see the Tranquility of their Coun∣try settled upon a firm Bottom.

But the Reasons alledg'd here, for the Preserva∣tion of Poland and Saxony, are not the only Motives that induce his Polish Majesty to make use of the lawful Means aforesaid; but the Tranquility of the holy Roman Empire, whereof the Preservation is chiefly committed to his Care, at this present time as Vicar thereof, besides the Dignity of Director of the Circle of Upper Saxony, does chiefly require this from him; especially, seeing it is known that the King of Sweden has lately made an Alliance with the King of France, the Tenor of which, could not be kept a Secret, but that the Allies had notice of it: Be∣sides, it is likewise known, that the Swedes in Pome∣rania wait only that the Elector of Bavaria may ex∣ecute his Projects on the Upper Rhine, against the Holy Roman Empire, there being no doubt but they would lay hold of that Opportunity to invade Saxony, and the Provinces of Germany, rather than those of Poland: From whence it appears, how necessary it is to use proper Means in Time, that thro' the Disper∣sion of the Swedish Army in Pomerania, that Tran∣quility of the Holy Roman Empire, may be settled, and preservd, that the dangerous Machinations, afore said, may be prevented, and that the Fire hid
under those treacherous Ashes, may be Extinguish'd therefore no Body can blame the Design of the most Serene King of Poland, to provide for his Security, and discharge his Office with the Forces God has given him, and the Assistance of his Allies; Its further more declared, on the Part of the most Serene King of Poland, that he has no other Intention and De∣sign, but to procure the Security of the Holy Roman Empire, and his own; and that he is induced to it that the most Serene Allies against France, will see that the most Serene Allies in the North, have made such Dispositions, and taken such Measures, that they will more readily concur therein, and perform what they are oblig'd to, by their Agreement; and this happy Band of UNION among themselves, which is hitherto continued may remain in-disoluble to their Common Advantage.

THO' the King of Poland began this Part of the War, in declaring the Intentions of the Allies, yet the King of Denmark first enter'd the Country, that Prince perhaps glad to leave his own Domi∣nions, and his Capital City where the Plague rag'd, at that Time, most violently, enter'd the Swedish Pomerania with his Army, the 8th of August, 1711. And without any Resistance, that was considerable, advanced to the Neigbourhood of Stralsound.

BUT this was too great an undertaking for the King of Denmark's Army who were not full 20000 Men, without the King of Poland; however in September, the Saxons arriv'd, to the Number of 12000 Men, and the two Armys being thus joyn'd, they invested Stralsund: But Stralsund strong by Situation, and well fortify'd, was too knotty a Piece of Work, even for both the Kings
united; for they found, that there was no In∣vesting it effectually, unless the Isle of Rugen, which lies over-against it, should be first reduc'd; to prevent this, the Swedes had in that Island, and in the City, an Army of old Soldiers, Stronger in Foot, than both the King's Armies put toge∣ther, tho' not equal to them in Horse; they like∣wise found, that the Swedes Daily relieved the Town, by Sea, as they thought convenient; having a Squadron of Men of War, and Frigats, always in the Harbour; these Difficulties oblig'd them at last to raise the Siege, without so much as carrying on any effectual Attack, or, so much as offering to Storm any of the Out-works. But it must be enquir'd a little how they spent their Time.
IT was the End of October before the Saxon Artillery arriv'd in the Camp, as for the Danes, they brought no heavy Cannon along with them, but had some afterwards, when it was too late.

HOWEVER, for a great while they amused the World with their Resolutions to attack the Isle of Rugen, and the Danes who understand Sea Affairs better than the Saxons, contriv'd to make great Rafts of Timber, on which to transport their Horse; but the Arrival of some Swedish Fregats who lay at a Distance, and batter'd those Rafts, and threw Bombs upon them, shew'd the King of Poland that the transporting their Cavalry in that manner, would be impracticable.

IN the mean time, 12 Swedes Men of War arriv'd on the Back of the Island, and Landed some Troops, and sent 3 Ships about to Stralsund, laden with Ammunition for the Garrison, and two more large Ships laden with Corn, which
were Danish Ships, that were bringing of Corn to the Danish Army, which was in great want of it, but they fell into the Hands of the Swedes, and the besieged had the Satisfaction of eating the Bread which was furnish'd for the Besiegers.

THE Swedish Captain gave out, that a large Embarkation of Troops and other Necessaries, was práeparing at Carelscroon, and would sail in a few Days; this News discourag'd the Besiegers, and in a Word, Provisions also growing very scarce, in an exhausted Country, and the Season ad∣vancing, the Troops separated, and gave over the Enterprize for that Year. But I should have mention'd, that before this, a strong Detatch∣ment of 15000 Muscovites, in 1 Regiments, all Infantry, arrived in the Camp; and a strong Squa∣dron of Danish Men of War, came to the Back of the Island of Rugen, pretending to support the Allies in attacking of the Town but it was too late.
HIS Czarish Majesty was all this while Carry∣ing on his Interests of one kind or another, on the Frontiers of Tartary, by Negotiations with the Turks, on the Subject of Peace, of which, in its Place.
HE arriv'd the 24th of October at Torgau on the Elb, where the Marriage of his eldest and only Son was solemniz'd with the Princess of Wolfem∣buttel; an happy Match, of an unhappy Son!
