THIS Marriage had been concerted for some Time, but was not consummated till the latter End of the Year; the View that the Czar had in this Match, was very well lay'd, for as his Cza∣rish Majesty always aim'd at the getting a Footing, by some Means or other, in the Empire of Germany, he did not question but by this Alliance, some Pretentions might in Time arise, to give him
Room to intermedle on that Side, as afterwards he try'd again in the Dutchy of Mecklemberg, but both without Success, as shall appear in its Place.

BUT ro return to the Siege of Straelsund, the Muscovite Infantry having joyn'd the Confede∣rate Army, and the Danish and Saxon Artillery being all arriv'd, and a Danish Squadron of Men of War superiour to the Swedish, the World ex∣pected they would go on with Success; but we shall see this Part reserv'd for a further Exercise of their Patience.

THE Danes indeed, out did themselves on this Occasion, at Sea; for their Fleet consisted, if we may believe the List they publish'd, of 36 Men of War of the Line of Battle, from 50 Guns the least, to 110 Guns the highest, and eight Fregats; but we shall never see them fit out such a Fleet again, neither were these all at Sea together; nor were those that were out fully mann'd for an Engagement: However, the Swedes had no Fleet able to look these in the Face, so that their Affairs, had they managed them rightly, were in a fair way, and the Swedes must have yielded up the Town. Their Troops were as follows.

LIST.ITEM: Danes—57 Squadrons of Horse, making 5000 22 Battallions—13200

4 large Bat. Militia 3600
Foot 16800
Saxons—46 Squadrons—Horse 4600
15 Battalions—Foot 7500
Muscovites 12 Regiments of Infantry making 30 Battallions—Foot 15000
Some Accounts say the Muscovite Troops Consisted of—Foot 10000
and Dragoons 5000

DIV2.P: THIS was a great Army, had they been well apply'd, and well supply'd, but the Season of the Year was too far gone; they had used the Coun∣try ill at their first coming, especially the Danes, so that if the poor People who would have supp∣ly'd them, had neither Corn nor Forrage left them to bring to the Camp; in a Word, the Country was Exhausted, and the Swedes at the Beginning scour'd the Seas so, that nothing could come that Way; for the Danes Fleet came too late, and when 'twas to no Purpose to open Trenches, the whether being Cold, and begining to freez; this made their Soldiers dye and defert for meer Want, and the Severity of the Weather and service; so that the Danes Foot were reduc'd to a Handful, the Cavalry was ruin'd and the Horse starv'd; and in a Word, the Danes did not march off above 9000 effective Men, as we were told, out of 21800 they brought with them as above.
AS for the Russian Troops they came late, but they brought some Stores with them, which assist∣ed them, and yet they suffer'd very much too, and were extremly fateigu'd with long Mar∣ches.

BUT to return to the Siege, as the Difficul∣ties and Hardships the Troops indured were great, so their Councils were divided; the ablest Generals were of Opinion, to raise the Siege, hold the Place block'd up during the Winter, and At∣tack it early in the Spring with 60000 Men; others were for carrying it on, whatever it cost;
and to that Purpose to send for more Troops, and both the Kings were really loath to break up the Siege, especially, while the Danish Fleet was so strong, and the Swedish Fleet durst not appear.

BUT a new Piece of Advice alter'd their Measures, the King of Denmark, had Advice that the Swedes prepard a great Fleet of Transports at Carelscroon, with a Convoy of 28 Capital Men of War, and that they Shipp'd 18000 Men, on Board this Fleet, under the Command of Count Stienboch, a Name terrible to the Danes; this brought the King immediately to consider, how naked he had left his Capital City, the Army and Fleet being all here; and that if the Swedes should go directly to Copenbagen, they would ruin him at once, while he was pushing a foreign Project.

WITH this Apprehension, which was very just in it self; the Danish Fleet was sent back to the Coast of Denmark, except some Fregates left to Cruise before the Isle of Rugen, and the Strait at Straelsund, to prevent Succours being brought to the Garrison.

BUT the Swedes, who shew'd themselves, on this Occasion, appear'd in the Beginning of December upon the Back of Rugen, where the Transports immediately Landed about 8000 Men with a great Quantity of Ammunition, a Train of Artillery, and Store of Provisions for the Besieged, and immediately stood back again for the Coast of Sweden, to fetch more Troops, which, however they did not bring at that Time.

IN this Posture, Things stood till the End of December, when the two Kings finding they should but ruin their Armies, and perhaps fail in their Enterprize at last, resolv'd to break up the Siege; and accordingly the Troops de∣camp'd the 17th of January; and we shall find this difficult Work reserv'd for the power∣ful Assistance, and Councils of the Czar in Person.

ABOUT the Beginning of November this Year, the Hereditary Prince of Mouscovy, with his new Bride, the Princess of Wolfembuttle, set out from her Father the Dukes Court, on their return to Petersburgh; the Czar at the same time came to meet them at Koningsberg in the Royal Prussia, the 19th, where he was magnificently treated by the Duke of Holstien Sonderburgh Governor of Purssia, who went to receive him at Fredericksburg, on the Frontiers of that Dutchy; they all return'd to Petersburgh in December, where the Princess (afterwards unhappy!) was treated by the Czar himself, with great Affection aud Tenderness: But we shall say more of this Affair hereafter, perhaps in a Treatise by it self.

WHILE these things were in agitation, the Turks began to discover some uneasiness at the Russians not having perform'd the Articles of the late Peace, particularly that, about the Surren∣der of Asopb, and the withdrawing the Russian Troops out of Poland; the Czar had, indeed, de∣sired to have the King of Sweden's Passage settled first, for his Return to his own Dominions; but the Turks were positive, and insisted that the manner of his Return was not any Part of the Condition, upon which the evacuating of Asopb was stipulated.

AFTER many Debates on either Side, the Czar not having the least Apprehensions of the manner of his Return, one Way or other, re∣solv'd to perform his Part of the Treaty; and accordingly order'd all the additional Works at Asoph to be demolish'd, and the royal Fort over∣against it with the magnificent Bridge, the most beautiful Building in that Part of the World, to be all blown up in the Air, and the Town to be put in the same Posture at was before, and then gave it up to three Bassa's, who were sent with some Troops from Constantinople to receive it; at the same time, his Czarish Majesty declared to the Court of the Grand Seignior, that he would oppose the Turks by Force, if they offer'd to send back the King of Sweden, either through his Dominions, or through the King of Poland's Country with an Army, or with more than 5000 Horse, the Number proposed; and thus ended that knotty Business, the only Action of his Life, which the Czar had brought to Account of Loss, where he led his Armies in Person having never been personally defeated before.

I must now look back again to Pomerania, to lay a Foundation of some great Actions, which will bring his Czarish Majesty into the Field on this Side of the World, where he was, perhaps, least expected: The Siege of Straelsund was raised, as has been observ'd, and the two Kings of Den∣mark and Poland gone Home, and their Troops put into Winter Quarters. In this Interval, the Swedes brought over more Troops; and together with those already there, formd a considerable Army and that, such a one, as they threaten'd to invade their Enemies with, on every Side,
and particularly, they were greatly alarm'd with the Apprehensions of them in Saxony.

THIS made his Czarish Majesty, at the pres∣sing Instances of the King of Denmark and Poland, prepared for an early Campaign, and his Czarish Majesty resolv'd to be there also in Person; accordingly 25000 Russians, of the choicest of his Czarish Majesty's Army, began their March so early, that they were upon the Frontiers of Pomerania by the End of April; the Danes were longer, because their Naval Pre∣parations seem'd to take them up, almost entir∣ely; being resolved to support the next Years Enter∣prize, with such a Fleet, as that the Swedes should not dare to show themselves at Sea to interrupt them; but we shall soon see the Effect.

THE Swedes in the Mean time had Ship'd off so many Troops, and such a Prodigious Quanti∣ty of Arms and Amunition, that they began to threaten to take the Field with an Army; and yet to leave the Cities of Stetin and Straelsund with sufficient Garrisons to defend themselves in Case of an Attack; they had also put a sufficient Number of Troops into Wismar, which the Danes had in vain block'd up, the Year before: The King of Prussia was pleased so far to favour this War against Sweden, that he gave Passage to Prince Menzikoff, who commanded the Russian Army, and to his Troops in their March for Po∣merania, and the said Prince Menzikoff, pass'd by Koningsburgh, the 15th of April, 1712.

Europe had now been allarm'd for several Months with the News that the King of Sweden at Bender, by his own Interest, and by the Solicitation of the Cham of Tartray, had prevailed with the Grand Seignior to break again with the Czar of Muscovy,
and to renew the War; and so much there was of truth in it, that the Turks made several ex∣travagant Demands, and that with some Mena∣ces added to them, which were, (however, insisted on) yet very unjust, but as his Czarish Majesty had in the first Place, perform'd the last Treaty in every Part of it; and more-over, that Ways and Means were found oat to bring over the Cham of Tartary, from the Interest of the King of Sweden: A new Treaty was set on Foot, at Corstantinople, which was at length finish'd, and sign'd, the principal Articles are as follows.

I. THAT the Czar shall be oblig'd within 30 Days to withdraw all his Forces out of Po∣land, which shall not return thither upon any Pretence whatsoever, unless it should happen that the King of Sweden being return'd into his Dominions, should joyn with the Poles and attack Muscovy on that Side, in which Case his Czarish Majesty shall be at Liberty to march again into Poland with his Troops.

II. That the Port shall be allow'd to procure the Return of the King of Sweden into his Dominions, by such Ways as the Grand Seignior shall think fit, without allowing the Muscovites to fix the Time of his Departure, or his Way; but in case that Prince marches through the Territories of Mus∣covy, the Turkish Troops that shall attend him, shall commit no manner of Hostilities or Ravages.

III. That the Czar shall remain in Possession of Kiou and Ukrania, with their ancient Limits, but shall renounce all his Pretentions to the Country of
the Cossacks on this side of the Borifthenes, that are not in the Dependance of Kiof, and on a certain Island in that River, and that good Orders shall be given on both sides, to prevent the Excursions of the Cossacks and Tartars.

IV. That for the Future, no Fortress shall be erected between the two Frontier Places of Asoph and Ciraski by either of the Parties, and that the Forts erected by the Muscovites in the Teritories of Asoph shall be demolish'd in four Months, but that the Grand Signior shall be at Liberty to rebuild the Fort of Cinoli, over-against Asoph.

V. That whereas by the Articles of the Treaty concluded at Moldavia, it was stipulated that Asoph should be restor'd in the same Condition that it was in when the Muscovites took it, and that it appears that there were then in that Place 60 Pieces of Brass Cannon, which have not been found therein when it was restor'd; his Czarish Majesty shall be obliged to restore the said Artillery, or pay the Value thereof, and the Turks shall deliver to the Muscovites the Iron Cannon that they have left in that Place.
VI. That none of the Parties shall be allow'd to erect any Forts at Comenski and Savar, which by Virtue of the Treaty of Moldavia have been de∣molish'd.

VII. That the Peace shall be continu'd 25 Years, to reckon from the signing of the Treaty, but may be prolonged before that time is elapsed; and lastly, that after the Ratification of the present Treaty, the Czar shall be allow'd to send an Ambassador to Constantinople to receive the same, &c.

BY the beginning of May, the Russian Troops arriv'd in Pomerania, commanded by Prince Men∣zikoff, and encamped at Schweds, having there
a Bridge over the Oder, being the same Place where Gustavs Adolphus, the Great King of Swe∣den encamp'd, when he reduced that Country; but notwithstanding all this, the Danes did not appear, and in a Word, the Czar was fain to re∣mit them 90000 Crowns before they could stir out of their Quarters: With this Relief, the King of Denmark came to his Army at Itzhoe the 10th of July, and when all the World expected him to march Into Pomerania to joyn the Russian and Saxon Armies, his Danish Majesty turn'd his Arms another Way, and passing the El, enter'd the Dutchy of Bremen, then-under the Govern∣ment of Count Welling for the King of Sweden; and not to enter into that Part of the Story too far, he reduced it entirely, and with it the Coun∣try of Verden, and afterwards Morgag'd them to the King of Great Britain; which will give Occasion of farther History to relate the Affair which attended that Mortgage.

THIS Attempt was a Diversion, however, to the Arms of Sweden; as was also the Attack of Wismar, which the King of Denmark and the Hanover Troops, for the King of Great Bri∣tain, as Elector of Hanover, had declared against Sweden also, held block'd up a great while.
BUT to return to the Affair of Pomerania, his Czarish Majesty arrived in that Country the 26th of July, and it was time to enter upon Action.

I cannot omit, in this Place, (tho' it be a Transition at once, from the Baltick Shore, to the Black Sea) to mention that the good Under∣standing at this time settled between the Turks and the Czar of Mascovy, was so firm and pro∣mising,
notwithstanding all the Mannagement of the King of Sweden, and his Friends, that no∣thing could be better establish'd; and the World wat surpriz'd to hear that the Muscovite Resident at Constantinople, had made a formal Rejoycing, or Festival in that City, on the Birth-Day of his Master, the Czar; this being what was not usually allow'd by the Turks to any Princes Am∣bassadors, was done the more publickly now, that the Princes of Europe might see that the great Boast that the Swedes had made of the powerful Interest that the King of Sweden had at Constan∣tinople, was really nothing in Substance, and that the Turks shew'd all posible Honours to the Russian Ambassador: The Particulars of this Rejoycing are very remarkable, as follows.

“The 10th of this Month being the Festival of St. Peter and St. Paul, the first being the Name of the Czar, the Baron de Schapfir of, Vice-Chancellor of his Czarish Majesty, his Privy-Councellor, and his Ambassador Extraordina∣ry and Plenipotentiary at the Port, gave a great Entertainment upon that Account, and also for celebrating the Anniversary of the famous Bat∣tle of Pultowa, tho' he had already observ'd the same two Days before with Illuminations in his House. All the Ambassadors residing here were invited to the same, as were also the Resident of the Emperor, the Vicar of the Pope, the Secretaries of Ambassadors, and the chief Merchants of all Nations, so that there was an Appearance of above 100 Per∣sons, for whom there were seven Tables, and they were treated with an extraordinary Magnificence. During the Entertainment
there was a fine Consort of Vocal and Instru∣mental Musick, and after the same, the Com∣pany was entertained with a Comedy in the Muscovite and Italian Tongues. The Secretary Interpreter of the Ambassy, pronounced after∣wards the Panegyrick of his Czarish Majesty in Latin, and another Gentleman recited some Epigrams on the subject of the Feast, to the Satisfaction of the Company, &c. The Col∣lonels of the Jannizaries of the Guard, had caused the Doors of the House of the Ambassa∣dors of that Prince to be adorn'd with Festoons of Palm, Lawrel, &c. which Civility the Vice Chancellor afore-said, acknowledg'd with a Present. The Windows of the Honse were illuminated at Night with Emblems of the He∣roick Actions of the Czar; and there was a Fire-work representing the Arms of that Prince, his Name in Cyphers, and the Town of Pultowa with proper Descriptions. On the side of that Fire there were two Decorations, each representing two Hearts united, and upon one there were this Inscription, Long live the Emperor Perer I. and the Empress Catherina; and on the other, Long live the Prince Imperial Alexis, and the Princess Imperial Charlote. These two Decorations continued illuminated all Night, and the two Nights following, and the Feast concluded with a Bll, which lasted till the next Morning, and during the same there was a magnificent Collation, &c. This Fire-work and the Illuminations were expresly noted in the Consent given by the Port to that Enter∣tainment, which has been seldom allow'd to any Foreigm Ministers, and especially in Constanti∣nople, which sheweth the Value the Turks put
upon the Friendship of his Czarish Majesty, and their Esteem for his Ministers.”

BUT to return to Pomerania, where the Czar and King Augustus, now commanded in Person, as above, the King of Denmark being employ'd in the Reduction of Bremen, as before; yet the Danish Fleet put to Sea in aid of the Pomeranian War, and the Swedes having been at Sea, to bring over Troops of Reinforcement to the Isle of Ru∣gen, the Danes attack'd them in their Return, and had a sharp Fight, but the Swedes having done their Business, made a rnnning Fight over to their own Coast, and the Danes could do no more but fall in among the Transports, of which they destroy'd near 20: However, the Danes, to keep their Reputation a-float; which, as to their War with the Swedes shrunk very low, the Swedes always beating them, cry'd this up for a great Victory: But this has not been his Czarish Maje∣sty's Method to boast of Victory, when he had won nothing from his Enemy; the Truth is, if any had the Victory, it was the Swedes, for they did their Business, viz. landed their Troops; and their Business then, was not to Fight, but to go back to fetch more, which they also did, notwithstanding all the Danes could do.

HAD the Danes met them at Sea, with their Army on Board, and fought them then, had they either sunk or taken any of the Men of War, or hinder'd their going to land the Troops, and made them go back again with them to their own Coast, there had been a Victory indeed; but as it was, the boasting of a Victory, because the Swedes declin'd a close Engagement, and
the taking a few empty Transports was rather a Gasconade than any thing else.

THE Troops which the Swedes landed amount∣ed to 2000 Horse, and 7000 Foot, Which added to the Forces they had before, made the At∣tempt upon that Island appear impracticable, and so the Czar and the King of Poland lay'd the Thought of it aside, for that Year also, while the Isle of Rugen is not reduc'd.

HIS Czarish Majesty therefore, finding no∣thing considerable could be done more, and his Affairs calling his Majesty to Petersburgh, he left the Army the 7th of October, under the Com∣mand of Prince Galiczin; but with Direction to obey in all things, the Orders of King Au∣gustus.

THE Army was then so posted, as to hold both Stralsond and Wismar block'd up all the Winter; which contributed greatly to the further Ditressing the Enemy, who, notwithstanding their Reinforcement, could do nothing considera∣ble, till they had yet another Embarkation of Troops from Sweden, as we shall see pre∣sently.

BUT now we must come in its Turn to do Justice to our Enemies, and to shew what Mea∣sures they took, in the Prosecution of this War: The Czar who was the Life of the War, being gone, and the Armies being left, as I have said, to the Order of King Augustus, the Swedes, who were now grown strong by the arriving of the Succours above named, transported their Troops over from the Isle of Rugen to Stralsond, and Count Steenbock who commanded them, form'd an Army of 18000 Men in the Plain, under the Cannon of Stralsond, and began to threaten to
act offensively; nor were the Russian and Saxon Army in the best Condition to receive them, ha∣ving been much diminish'd and fateigu'd by the Service, and much want of Provisions besides. If Count Steinbock had resolv'd to attack them, so near Hand, he could have drawn eight or nine thousand Men more out of the Garrisons of Stralsond, Gripswald, and other Places, which he could not do when he should march farther from their own Territories.

THINGS standing thus, King Augustus and the Russian General Count Galiczen, order'd their Posts to be intrenched, and the several Passes by which the Swedes might march out, to be forti∣fy'd with very good Lines and Redoubts, and posted their Troops in them to oppose their Enemies.

As the Swedes are allow'd to be a daring and Enterprizing People, so their Generals are uni∣versally Men that understand their Business, and want no military Experience: Count Steinbock being now once more at the Head of an Army, and Pomerania being no Place to subsist them in at this Time, When it was so exhausted by other Troops, that it starv'd its own Inhabitants, he resolv'd to push out, and try the Fortune of the Field; accordingly he began his March the 3d of November, and having forc'd the Pass of Dam∣garten, which the frighted Saxons quited, and let him pass by, much too cheap; he entered the County of Mecklemburgh with his whole Ar∣my, the 6th, and marched directly towards Wismar.

IMMEDIATELY upon this News, away run the Danes, who had roosted all the Summer at Rostock, and other Danish Regiments likewise; who car∣ry'd
on the Blockade of Wismar marched off with the greatest Precipitation, nor to hazard their Rear, which the Garrison press'd upon, but were disappointed.

THE Dominions of Denmark upon the Conti∣nent were allarm'd at this March, and the King of Denmark, whose Troops lay about Hamburgh, from which City they had, drawn about 260000 Rix Dollars, began to gather togther, and to ad∣vance for fear of being cut off from joyning their Allies the Russians, without whom, they were not able, as will appear presently, to look their Enemies in the Face.

THE King of Denmark hasten'd likewise to his Army, he left Gottorp the 19th, and having joyn'd General Schoult and all his Troops, ad∣vanc'd to meet the Swedes, who were as forward as his Majesty to come to Action: This Excur∣sion of the Swedes, as it relates to the War, in which his Czarish Majesty was so much concern'd, cannot be omitted here, or the Acton which fol∣low'd it, because it would render the History of his Czarish Majesty uncompleat, the Czar having acted in it presently afterwards in Person, with all his Army; the Story of the Excursion of the Swedes is absolutely Necessary, that it may appear how ill the Danes and Saxons did their Part; for certainly, if they had done their Duty at the Pass of Damgarten, which they pretended to Guard, and which, as will appear by the Ac∣count following, a few Troops well disposed, might have defended, the Swedes could never have broke through, and then all the Loss and Dis∣grace, and all the Miseries that the King of Den∣mark's Dominions suffer'd aferwards had been Prevented; whereas it was manifest, by what
follow'd, and if the Czar had not afterwards come to his Assistance, his Daish Majesty had been utterly ruin'd at that Time.
The Account of this Action, as publish'd by the Swedes, is as follows, viz.

DIV2.HEAD: From the Head Quarters of Count Steinbock at Ribitz, November 5. 1712.
DIV2.P:
“ALL the Troops that were in the Island of Rugen, having been brought over to Straelsund the 30th past, in the Evening, with their Baggage, Count Steinboch, Commander in Chief of the Swedish Army, took his Leave the next Day of the Garrison and Burghers of Straelsund, who were drawn up in Arms, to whom he made a pathetick Speech, wherein he exorted them to continue Faithful to their So∣vereign and Country, and be Vigilant in their several Stations for the Preservation of that Place. The same Night he gave Orders to the Generals of the Army, and the next Day the Troops began to move, it being given out, that they were to attack the Lines of the Enemy before Straelsund. The general Disposition of their March was as follows; Lieutenant Gene∣ral Ducker, who commanded the Van-Guard, consisting of the Cavalry of the Dutchy of Bremen, and the Dragoons of Marderfeldt and Stromfeldt, with nine Pieces of Cannon, was to march with all Speed towards Damgarten, to take Post there, and lay Bridges over that Ri∣ver, before the Enemy could draw their Troops
together, and hinder the Swedes from passing the same; and as the Success of the whole Enterprize depended in a great Measure on the Secrecy and Expedition of the March of this Body; Care had been taken for three Days together, that none should go out of Strael∣sund or the Camp, to inform the Enemy there∣with. General Ducker with his Detatch∣ments, continu'd all that Night at Ribbartz, from whence the Adjutant General Leppenon was detatch'd with 200 Men toward Frautz∣bergh to observe the Motions of the Enemy behind their Lines, and give timely Notice thereof. Lieutenant General Taube with the Cavalry of the Province of Westergothland, a Pomeranian Regiment of Horse, and one of Foot of Colonel Ekeblad encamped that Night at Karnin, having under him Major General Ashenberg. This was the Body of Battle, and the Rear commanded by Count Steinboch him∣self, and under him by Major General Patkul, consisted of the rest of the Horse, Foot and Artillery. These were followed by 1500 Boors, carrying Deal Boards and other Matte∣rials to lay Bridges. The Roads being very bad by Reason of Rainy Weather, the Rear of the Army could not march from Noon till the Evening, above one League, and encamped at Pyts. King Stanislas came after the Rear with his Retinue, The 2d, Lieutenant Gene∣ral Ducker advanced to Damgarten, where he took Post, and marched immediately through a Defile to a small Fort, or Redoubt, the Enemy had erected on the other Side near Ribnitz, which he took Sword in Hand, whereby the Enemy had many Men kill'd and Wounded.
Lieutenant General Taube continu'd at Kar∣nin till Count Steinboch came up with the Rear, and then they march'd together to Lan∣gen-Hansagen. The following Day, being the 3d Instant, they march'd by Break of Day to Damgarten, where all the Troops joyn'd about Noon, the General taking his Quarters at Blom∣monsdorf on the River Ribnits, within a Quar∣ter of a League of that Place. That River has on both sides a long and deep Morass, which especially on the side of Mecklemburgh was said to be unpassable even for Cattle tho' in the hot∣test Summer; but however, Count Steinboch re∣solved to try whether his Troops could go over it or no. In order thereunto, he commanded Boards and Planks to be joyn'd together, to serve instead of Bridges over such Places as should appear too deep to be pass'd otherwise, and posted 400 Foot with 8 Field Pieces, on the Banks of the River to cover the Men who were sent before to take a View of the Morass, and to see which way it might be more con∣veniently pass'd over. The Enemy who ob∣serv'd these Motions, posted about 1000 Horse, on the other side of the Morass, but were ob∣lig'd to quit that Post by the extraordinary Fire, that was made from the Field Pieces afbresaid, and retire into the Wood. The Swedes posted at Damgarten fir'd also upon them, and they had above 90 Men kill'd and wounded. The General order'd the Pontons to be brought down the River, with other Materials for Brid∣ges over the said Morass, and at Damgarten, which were finish'd that Night. The Generals being call'd together, Count Steinboch gave them the following Directions for the next
Day. Lieutenant General Ducker was order'd to pass over the Bridge laid at Damgarten, with six Pieces of Cannon and the Vanguard of the Army, consisting of the Regiments of Dragoons of Marderfeldt and Stromfeldt, the Cavalry of Westergothland and Bremen, and the Regiments of Foot of Ekebladt, Schultz, and Elforg; while Count Steinboch himself and Lieutenant General Taube with the rest of the Foot and eight Field Pieces should pass the River and Morass by Blommendorf. The rest of the Cavalry was order'd, if pos∣sible, to march after them; but in case they found it too long and difficult, they were order'd to pass over the Bridge of Damgarten, under the Command of the Majors General Ashenberg; and Mereschal. The 400 Foot posted on the Bank of the River aforesaid, under the Com∣mand of Lieutenant Colonel Slippenback and Major Lewenhaupt, were order'd to march first of all over the Morass, and take Post on the other side. These were to be follow'd by the Detatchment who carry'd the Planks and Bridges designed to be laid over the deep or un∣passable Places of the said Morass. Major Ge∣neral Patkul was to march next with the Regi∣ments of Sudermania, Dalecarlia, and Wester∣gotbland. These were to be follow'd by the Prince de la Gardic, who brought up the Rear with the Regiments of Ostergothland, Westman∣land, Helfinge, and the two Regiments of the Provinces of Narike and Wermerland. Lieu∣tenant General Cronstedt was order'd to follow the Infantry with the Artillery, but if he did not find it practicable, he was commanded to march after the Cavalry by Damgarten. Col∣lonel
Rozen with 600 Horse and 500 Foot was order'd to guard the Avenues to Damgarten, that the Enemy might not attack the Baggage which was sent thither. Adjutant General Lop∣penon with his 200 Horse came the same Night from Frautsbergh, and reported that the Enemy were quiet in their Lines, and he had met only with a Party of Hussars of whom he had kill'd ix. According to the Dispositions aforesaid, the March begun the following Day, the Sol∣diers carrying along with them Plaks and all the Doors they could get from the Houses, and besides every other Man carry'd a Fascine to fill such Holes as they should meet in their way, whereby not only the Infantry but even the Artillery pass'd in good Order over the Morass, Which as it has been said before, was thought impassable even for the Cattle in the Summer Time. The General seeing there was no Ene∣my to oppose him on the other side of the Mo∣rass, order'd the Cavalry to pass over the Bridge at Damgarten, and the whole Army be∣ing on the other side in the Country of Mack∣lenburgh, was drawn up in Order of Battle, and made a general Salvo of their 8 Field Pieces and small Arms for this happy Success in their Passage, without the Loss of one Man, and which has rendred useless the strong Lines on which the Enemy have been employ'd about a Year. The Prince of Weyssenfeldt, who com∣manded 3000 Men on that side, retired to∣wards Rostock, but not thinking himself Safe in that Place retired farther, and Colonel Bas∣seitz was sent to take Possession thereof.”

UPON the News of this Success of the Swedish General, the Czar who was then at Dresden, took Post immediately to put himself at the Head of his Army in Pomeren, where he arrived the 25th, having before order'd a strong Reinforcement of Troops to joyn them.

KING Augustus was there with his Army alrea∣dy, so that Count Steinboch had no less than 3 Mo∣narchs at the Head of three Armies to encounter with, and was so surrounded by them, that they made no Question to give a very good Account of him; and for this Reason it was, that the Czar resented very much a Cessation of Arms for 15 Days, which was agreed between Count Stein∣boch and the Allies, and spoke with some Tokens of Displeasure against Prince Menzikoff on that Account; but when his Majesty came to the Army, that General convinc'd him, that King Augustus had agreed to it without his Participati∣on, that he had opposed it, and that he would have had the Saxons to have joyn'd in following the Swedes, till they should be forced to Fight all the three Armies together.

IT is true, the Saxons were not ready, nor the King of Denmark, so that King Augustus acted upon a just Necessity; and when he lay'd the Reasons before the Czar, and convinc'd him that he had no private Treaty in Hand, either with the King of Sweden, or with Stanislaus, who was then in the Swedish Army, his Czarish Majesty was better satisfied, and the two Armies ad∣vanc'd to Gustraw, where his Czarish Majesty had his Quarters; the Danes who likewise had not agreed to the Cessation, but who alone had the Benefit of it, having gain'd the Time to bring their Army together, had they made a right Use
of the Advantage, were now advanced to Gads∣husch; so that Count Steinboch was, as it were, block'd up in the narrow District of Wismar, having his Infantry quartered in the very City, and his Cavalry canton'd in the Villages round; where had the three Armies joyn'd, they must have fallen all into the Hands of the Allies, without Fighting, at least all the Horses, the Country not affording Forrage Sufficient to sub∣sist them.

BUT Count Steinboch knew the Enemy he had to deal with, and gathering his Troops together in one Days time, the Truce being to end the very next Day, he put himself in full March to∣wards Gadsbusk, even before the Danes had No∣tice of his being stirr'd from Wismar; as the Saxons and Russian Armies were near, the King of Poland detached 4000 Saxon Horse to reinforce the King of Denmark as soon as ever he heard that Count Steinboch went that Way, and the Danes hasten'd them in their way by many Messengers on the Heels of one another, and at last by a Signal of three Pieces of Cannon, which inti∣mating the Extremity, caused the Saxon Cavalry to make such Haste, that when they arriv'd, be∣ing immediately to go on Action, their Horse were so fateigu'd, that they were neither able to fight, or to run away, and were easily defeated, helping rather, to discourage, than reinforce the Danish Army, who they came to serve.

IT was the 20th of December when the two Armies came to engage; a full Account of the Battle can never be drawn from the Perticulars which were made Publick at that time, each side setting forth their own Case with the Boasts and Rhodomontadoes, usual with those Nations: But
in few Words, 'tis evident the King of Denmark was soundly Beaten; his Army being driven out of the Field; his Majesty, very little to his Ho∣nour, retiring even before the Battle was entire∣ly lost; the Swedes took all their Cannon and Baggage, several Colours and Standards, and near 4000 Prisoners, and the scatter'd Remains of their Army retir'd to Oldesloe, and afterwards Count Steinboch enter'd into Holstein, and had not the Czar of Muscovy reliev'd the King of Denmark by joyning his Forces with the Danes and Saxons, and persuing the Swedes, the King of Denmark had, in all human Probability, been Ruin'd.

THUS his Czarish Majesty has been first, or last, the Deliverer of all his Allies, and the only Prince that has appear'd able to reduce the haughty Courage of the Swedish Nation; as soon as his Czarish Majesty had an Account of the Battle, he joyn'd the King of Polands Army, and all together march'd after Count Steinboch, who had already passed the Trave, and was advanc'd into Holstein; the Remains of the Danish Horse which had escaped the Battle of Gadsbusch, joyn'd them in their March, being 2700 Men, and the whole Army was now, by the Consent of the two Kings, put under the Command of his Czarish Majesty, as Generalissimo.

IN the mean time, the Swedes went on, they passed the Trave near Lubeck, and Advancing towards the Elb, came to Hamburgh; here they sent out Parties to demand heavy Contribu∣tions of all the Country, and particularly, of the City of Hamburgh it self; and having enter'd the King of Denmark's Territories, they burn'd Alte∣na, a rich trading Town, within two Miles of Hmburgh: This they pretended was done in
Reprisal for Towns the Russian Army and other Confederates had destroy'd in Pomerania.

THIS barbarous Action, Count Steinboch lay'd to the Charge of General Welling, late Governor of Bremen; and in Justification, publish'd the fol∣lowing Letters about it, one whereof pretends to reproach his Czarish Majesty's Troops, in their Treatment of their Masters Enemies, perhaps he intends Livonia tho' he names it not; the o∣ther, lays the same Violent Method to the Charge of the Danes, and their Usage of the In∣habitants Ossenden in the Dutchy of Bremen; which perhaps was the Occasion of this Works being order'd by Count Welling, as above. The Letters with the proper Introductions to them, are as follows.

“THE Swedes having continued for some Days about Odesloe and Segebergh, made a Motion to∣wards Pinenberg, and Colonel Bassewitz with 200 Horse came to Altena, and requir'd the In∣habitants to pay a great Sum for Contributions. On Sunday in the Afternoon Count Steinboch came to Hamburgh with several Generals and having had a long Conference with Count Wel∣ling, went to joyn his Troops posted before Altena, which had been reinforced by several Detatchments. 'Tis said the Swedes demanded of that Place 200000 Rixdollars, whereupon, they offer'd 50000, declaring, that it was im∣possible for them to pay a greater Sum, upon which the Agreement was broke, and the fol∣lowing Night several Detatchments march'd into Altena, and set it on Fire, whereby 'tis computed that about 3000 Houses were reduc'd to Ashes, together with the Popish Church; but
those of the Lutheran and Reform'd were pre∣serv'd, with about 70 or 80 Houses. The Swedes burn'd also several large Magazines along the Elbe, whereby there are a World of People ruin'd. The Dutch Factors who foresaw that Misfortune, withdrew most of their Effects from that Place, and removed them to Ham∣burgh. The Generals Fleming and Scholten, who were there, sent a Trumpeter to Count Steinboch, to complain of this Proceeding, who, as we heard, answer'd, that he would acquaint the World by a Manifesto, with the Reasons that have oblig'd him to carry Things to these Extremities; and in the mean time, they Hand about here a Copy of a Letter written by that General to Monsieur Wibe, on of the Privy-Counsellors to the King of Denmark, which is as follows,”

LETTER.P:
IT is with great Regret that I have found my self constrain'd to destroy the Town of Altena; Reasons of War, and an indespensable Necessi∣ty, have prevailed over my own Inclination, which is not to imitate the Enemies confederated against the King my Master: I can at least assure your Excellen∣cy, that the Devastation of several of his Majesty's Provinces, and the Inhumanities committed therein, will not move me but in the last Extremities, to re∣taliate the same on the Subjects of his Danish Ma∣jesty; and 'tis with this sincere Intention that I have thought fit, Sir, to recommend to you a Pre∣caution
absolutely necessary to be used with the Forces of his Czarish Majesty, which is to hinder that they do not leave behind them in Pomerania, upon their marching out of that Country; burning Tokens and frightful Ashes, to mark the Stay they have made there, as they have done elsewhere; of which the poor Inhabitants will never lose the dreadful Remem∣brances.

It will be easy for the King, your Master, for the good of his own Subjects, to agree about this with his Czarish Majesty, or else it will not be in my Power to forbear using, tho' against my Will, Reprisals in the Dominions of his Danish Majesty, and to destroy therein as many Towns and Villages as the Russians shall have laid in Ashes in Pomerania at their De∣parture. I am,

DIV2.P: “This is the Account Count Steinboch has given himself of this Affair, and a Letter written from his Camp, dated the 8th In∣stant, from Pinenberg, gives some Explanation of those Reasons of War mention'd by that General. That Letter is as follows,

COunt Stienboch having, receiv'd certain Intelli∣gence in his Camp at Segeberg, that they were ma∣king great Magazines at Altena to bake Bread and to brew Drink for the Muscovites and Saxons, which were expected there, his excellency thought fit to al∣ter his March, and move that Way with his Army, to destroy, as the Reasons of War requir'd, those pre∣judicial Stores of Provisions, which by more particu∣lar
Accounts, me knew the whole Town was with; but Time, (with Respect to the Approach of the said Troops, and the want of Carriages) not permitting to carry off the said Provisions, nor to destroy them otherwise than by setting them on Fire, his Excellency was oblig'd to give Order for the do∣ing it, thereby coming even with the Danes in some Measure, for the dismal and cruel Burning exercised on the good and ancient Town of Staden. His Excel∣lency commanded however, that the Inhabitants should be allow'd some Time to save their Effects, and a∣bove all, the Churches should be respected and spr'd, tho' that just Moderation was not observ'd by the Danes in the Burning and Destruction of Staden.
AFTER this Count Steinboch publish'd a brief▪ but bold Manifesto on the same Occasion: As follows,

COunt Magnus Steinboch, Counsellor of State and War, and Commander in Chief of the Ar∣my of his Majesty the King of Sweden, notifies and makes it known, that the Enemies of his Majesty ha∣ving presum'd to destroy by Fire the Town of Staden, and the Dutchy of Bremen, belonging to the King of Sweden, his Majesty has commanded him to use Reprisals, and burn down the Town of Altena; de∣claring further, that if the Enemies make any new Execution by Fire in the Dominions of the King his Master, he will make use of all the Severities of War in the Dutchy of Holstein, and other Coun∣tries belonging to his Danish Majesty, by Right of Reprisals, as he has done at Altena.

BUT the Ravages of the Swedes grew near an End; the Czar mov'd a pace with his Ar∣my, joyn'd by the Saxons, towards the Swedes; the Danes joyn'd his Army in their March, with what Troops they had, and all together amount∣ed to 36000 Men, which was too many for the Swedes to pretend to grapple with; his Czarish Majesty arrived at Hamburgh, the 14th of Janua∣ry, attended by Prince Menzikoff, and several Generals, as well of his own Troops, as of the Dane's and Saxon's Army, which Coming on by slow Marches, the Weather, and the Ways being extreamly bad, the Soldiers suffer'd very much in their March.

WHILE his Czarish Majesty continued in the Neighbourhood of Hamburgh, he caused a Day of Fasting and Publick Prayers to be proclaim'd in the united Army, to ask of Heaven Success up∣on, their Undertaking, and to add Alms Deeds to their Devotion, his Czarish Majesty caused 1000 Rubles in Gold to be distributed to the poor Sufferers at Altena, and caused Proposals, and Encouragement to be offer'd them, if any of them thought fit to go Abroad, and would settle in any part of his Dominions.

WHILE this was doing, Count Fleming, the Saxon General, and General Scholten the Danish Vlt Marischal, wrot an expostulatory Letter to Count Welling, upon the Subject of the Burning of Altena, and the Reasons alledg'd, which Let∣ters are as Follows.

DIV2.HEAD: A LETTER from Count Welling, Governor General of the Dutchies of Bremen and Werden, to Count Flemming, and Mon∣sieur Scholten.
DIV2.P: SINCE you have done me the Honour to com∣municate to me the letter you have written to Count Steinboch, concerning the Burning of Altena, tho' without mentioning the Magazines that were therein; so I suppose you design'd thereby to engage me to explain my self upon this Matter.

I don't know, Messieurs, whether the Sight of the Destruction of Staden has been more dreadful to you, than that of the Burning of Altena; but it is cer∣tain, that the former might have been avoided, where∣as the latter was absolutely necessary. The Reasons that obliged Count Steinboch, tho' entirely against his Will, to come to such Extremities, have already been made Publick. If the red hot Bullets you threw into Stralund and Wisinar, had had their Effect, and burnt those Towns as well as our Magazines therein, the Reason of War would have justifyd you, as well as it now does Count Steinboch.

But the many Flames that have been kindled, and the dreadful Devastations of several of the King my Master's Dominions, cannot find the same Justifica∣tion, being committed without any manner of Necessi∣ty, by those of your Allies, that you even call Chri∣stians.

The Danish Zealand, and Saxony, will always be an Evidence, that the Swedes never had recourse to Flambeaux, unless they were forced to the same, by Reasons of War; but that our Nation, always used
to revenge themselves upon their Enemies, by way of Arms, and of▪ Humanity, never with Burning, and exercising of Cruelties.

The dreadful Ruins several of his Swedish Maje∣sty's Provinces and Towns belonging thereunto, have suffer'd, and the Chains of Slavery under which a∣bove a hundred Thousand of the King of Sweden's Subjects, of both Sexes, who have been sold to the In∣fidels, groan at this very Time, will, for the good of your Master's Countries, prevail upon you, to concur with Count Steinboch in making a more humain War.

I have deliver'd to Colonel Meyer the Precau∣tion Count Steinboch has recommended to Mon∣sieur Wibe, to be taken in this Matter; and I do not at all doubt, but you will contribute thereto. Count Steinboch has assur'd me, that for his Part, he will proceed not to any Extremity against the Dutchy of Holstein, unless he be necessitated to it.
Your own Wisdom, and the Reason of War, will justify his Conduct in such a Case.

DIV2.HEAD: A LETTER from the Generals Flamming and Scholten, to General Welling.
DIV2.P: BY the Letter which you have done us the Ho∣nour to write to us, we have seen the Reasons which you alledge for the Burning of Altena.

We being Parties, will not take upon us to be Judges, There are enough to decide it. Mean while, you will allow us to tell you, there is no Comparison between what has been done at Altena, and what happen'd at Staden. Staden is a fortify'd Town, which resisted the Arms of his Danish Majesty, and against which, it was allowable to use all the Means that are ordi∣narily taken to reduce a Town: But Altena is an open defenceless Place; and we believe, Sir, that a Parallel can never be made, between a Bombardment and the setting a Town on Fire with Torches. 'Tis as if the inevitable Slaughter in a Battle or an Assault, should be compared with a Massacre of People who do not defend themselves, nor are in a State of De∣fence.

The other Reasons for the Burning of Altena, that have been made Publick, amount to this, that Magazines were providing, and Bread baking there; but 'tis certain, there was no Magazines in Altena, or if there were, they were so inconsiderable, that there could be no Pretence on that Account, for burning above 2000 Houses, and reducing several Thousands of People to Beggary; and this, without gaining any Advantage by it. According to this Allegation that there were Magazines, was not thught of in the Answer which Count Steinboch made to the Deputies of Altena; nothing was then urg'd, but the Affair of Staden, to which we think we have given a sufficient Reply.
As to the Burning Bullets fired into Stralsund and Wismar, we refer to what we have said about the Bombarding of Staden. This is lawful, but voluntary Burnings are abhorred.

As to the Conduct of our Allies, we suppose you will allow a Distinction between cutrages committed without Order, and those committed by express
Order. Count Steinboch himself made that Di∣stinction very justly some Months ago, when speaking of some Disorders done by the Muscovite Soldiers, he ask'd, whether they had been order'd to commit them; and being assured, that not only such Orders had never been given, but that the Authors of those Excesses had been punish'd; he said, he was glad to hear it, adding, that he could not treat those who should commit such Outrages by Order, and who should fall into his Hands, as Prisoners of War, but as In∣cendaries. What you can alledge farther of the Con∣duct of our Allies, may be easily justify'd by the Right of Reprizals. Remember only, Sir, what was practised on our Side, after the Battle of Nerva. Before that Time, had any such Cruelties been acted?

Those who were Authors of the First, are answer∣able for all that have been committed since. You know, Sir, that there is no other Foundation of the Law of Nations than Agreement and Example. After the Precedent yo have newly set us, it will be lawful for our Masters to retaliate others upon you, of what kind soever, and this by the Law of Nations.

In our Opinion the Swedish Moderation in Zealand ought not to be alledged on this Occasion, for the King your Master not having landed there as an Enemy, but as a Guarantee of Peace, could not exercise Acts of Hostility there.

As for Saxony, your Interest had a greater Share in your Humanity, than Humanity it self. With the 23 Millions which you drew from Saxony, it might have been restored to its former State, had it been all laid in Ashes. And how otherwise could you have cloathed, recruited and remounted your Army.
Be this as it will, those two Examples prove however, that Burnings and Acts of Inhuma∣nity, are more authoriz'd by the Ministers and Ge∣nerals of the King of Sweden, than by that Prince himself.

We have reply'd to the Example which you al∣ledged of the Ruin of several of your Provinces; but we cannot apprehend what you mean by advising us to concur with Count Steinboch in carrying on the War humanly, after the Example of Inhumanity and Cruelty, which he has newly given us: A Cruelty, that has cost the Lives of so many poor Innocents, of Women in Childbed and in Labour, of Sick who were not in a Condition to get out of Bed. How many Children and Aged snatch'd from the Violence of the Flames, were unable to endure the Extremi∣ty of the Cold, and perished miserably in the Snow?

How many unhappy Wretches of both Sexes and all Ages, exposed to the Rigour of the Season, perish daily of Cold and Hunger? Are these the Instances of Humanity which Count Steinboch would have us Imitate? Can we make such a Proposition to our Masters?

We have seen the Letter which Count Steinboch wrote to Monsieur Wibe, we will suspend our Judg∣ment on it; bnt know that Threats work nothing upon the Persons who are just, and of generous Minds, such as are in the Court of the King of Denmark. We conclude, by saying, that you can never justify the Burning of Altena; but it will Justify all that we may attempt for taking true Vengeance, if our August Masters, agreeably to their usual Humanity and , do not think fit to defer the imitating so cruel an Example, unless they are forced to it by new Cruelties of the like Nature: We are assured in
the mean while, that the Almighty mill not let pasts without Punishment, the unheard of Cruelties that have been practised at Alten.
DIV2.CLOSER:
Hamburgh, Jan. 13, 1713. We are, &c.
FLEMMING.
SCHOLTEN.

DIV2.P: AFTER all that has been said, of the Civility of the Turks to the Czar, and to his Ministers, such was the uncertainty of Things, on that Side the World, that in the midst of the Proceedings of the Czar, in so remote a Part of the World, his Czarish Majesty was again allarm'd with the Ru∣mour that his Ambassador at Coustantinople was a∣gain imprisoned in the Seven Towers, and that the Turks had declared War again against him; and he was earnestly press'd by his Generals to leave this Petty Retail War, (as they called it) and ad∣vance to the Frontiers of Tartary, to prepare to oppose the Turks.

HOWEVER as his Majesty had better Intelli∣gence than his Enemies in the Ottoman Port, he was always appriz'd of things as they really were reported to be, and knew very well how far they were True, and how far not. The Turks were for awhile much influenc'd by the Han of Tartary, and the Creatures of the King of Sweden; 'twas a little hard that the King of Sweden should be able to bribe the Turks with their own Money, and distribute the same Sums, which the Port gave him for his Support, to the great Officers of the same Port, to engage them to break Faith with the Czar of Muscovy, after he had perform'd all that was required by their last Treaty; had re∣stor'd
Asoph, had dismantled Kassirkameen, and the other Places, and fully withdrawn his Troops out of Poland.

BUT the Czar was too many for them here too, for his Ministers at the Port having Power given them to enter upon a new Treaty, and the Czar causing about 70000 Men to advance to the Frontiers of Moldavia, to let the Turks see he was not unprovided; the Russian Ministers found it much easier to reconcile Matters with the Port, than was imagin'd, and the old League was not only renew'd for 30 Years, but other Terms were gain'd, which made as much for his Czarish Maje∣sty's Interest as could be desir'd.

ALL this while his Czarish Majesty was at the Head of the Confederate Army in Holstein, push∣ing the Swedish Army under Count Steinboch; his Majesty had, indeed, determin'd to leave the Army, and return to his own Dominions, and the rather, because of the Mischief which he knew was breeding at Constantinople, by the Intreagues of the King of Sweden; but knowing the Misun∣understandings in the Confederate Army would be such, about the Command, that there would be no Agreement; and it being hard, that the Army, two Thirds of which were at the same Time his Czarish Majesty's own Forces, should be Commanded by any but his own Generals; up∣on this Consideration, he resolv'd to manage the other Part by Negotiation, and to Command the Army in Holstein himself.

THE Confederates were, as things then stood, much too strong for Count Steinboch; their Force was above 36000 Men, the Swedes nor above 14000 at best, but led by an old Fox that knew his Advantages, and how to lay hold of them, to
a Tittle; that knew how to fight when he had a feir Field, and how to avoid it, when he was out Number'd and not in Condition.

THIS, Count Steinboch seeing the Confederates advance, and that they were too powerful for him, march'd from Altena, North into Upper Hol∣stein, and advancing along the Eyderstorm, kept the Confederates at Bay a great while, about Fred∣rickstand, near which Place they pass'd the said River Eyder, and advanc'd to Oerfield, and to Husum: Here they laid the Country under Con∣tribution, and raised a very great Sum in Mo∣ney, and Provisions: Here Count Steinboch post∣ed himself to so much Advantage among the Ri∣vers and Dikes, that it was not easy to attack him.

BUT his Czarish Majesty resolv'd to make short Work with him, and in a Word, to attack him, where-ever he could find him, cost what it would; for as I noted above, the Czar at this Time, was press'd by his own Affairs, not know∣ing whether his Affairs with the Turks would End in Peace or War; Orders were therefore gi∣ven to make Dispositions for the Attack, while the Swedes on the other Hand, fortify'd their Camp, and made an Appearance of Resistance, threatening to give the Russians a very warm Re∣ception. But Count Steinboch, after repulsing our Men at the Attack of one of his Posts, where the Russians and Danes had some Loss, thought fit not to stand the Shock of a general Attack by the whole Army; and accordingly, quitted the advantagious Camp, and retired to another, and thus retiring from one Post to another, and the Confederates still following him Close, and push∣ing
him from Place to Place, he begun to be brought to Extremity.

THE best Account of these several Motions leave them very uncertain, and are scarce worth our collecting; the short of the Matter is, that the Confederates attack'd the Swedes at Holling∣stede, but were repulsed with the Loss of 300 Men; and the next Night the Swedes retired, and posted their whole Army in a very strong Situa∣tion, between Fredrickstadt, and the Fortress of Toningen. This last was a very strong Place, be∣longing to the Duke of Holstein, and Garrison'd by his Troops, who being in Sweden, a Youth, and under Age, the Administration of his Estates, was left to the Care of his Uncle, the Prince and Bishop of Etin.

THE Governor of this Fortress made Show of keeping an exact Neutrality; and once, when Count Steinboch sent a Letter to him, sent it un∣open'd, refusing to receive any Letter or Messa∣ges on either Side; and while Matters stood thus, Count Steinboch stood but in very ill Terms, being streighten'd for Room, and also for Provi∣sions, and almost surrounded by the Confedorate Armies, who were so much superior.

IN this Posture the Confederates press'd him very hard; and tho' he avoided Fighting, and retir'd from one Post to another, yet it was apparent he must at last Fight to his inevi∣table Destruction, or suender to his Ene∣mes.

HE defended himself, however, in this Man∣ner a long time, viz. from the Beginning of January, till the 14th of February, 1712 13. In vain pring the Governor of Tonnighen to give him a Retreat into the Fortress, and being
push'd to Extremity by the Confederates, he came with the whole Swedish Army and encamp∣ed at Gardenghen, a Village, within half a League of Toningen.

THE Confederates follow'd him Close, and here the Governor of Toningmen, whether by Order of the Prince Administrator of Holstein, or by Stratagem of Count Steinboch, is very little known to this Day: But the Governor, I say, let the Swedish General, and with him, his whole Army, into the Place, to the great Relief and Encouragement of the Swedes, who were, indeed, brought to the Point of being ruin'd.

THIS was a Blow to the Confederates who had been extreamly fateigu'd with the Service they had been upon, having kept in the Field all the Winter: The Matter was now come to a Point, there was now no way left now to force them, and nothing but a very close Blockade, could Effect their Reduction, and this the Army a∣greed on.

THE Czar finding now that the Thing would be drawn out in Length, left the Army and went to Hamburgh; and from thence, to Hanover. His Czarish Majesty left the Army the 15th of Fe∣bruary, having first had a long Conference with the Kings of Denmark, where the Command of the Army was settled, and the Rank of the Troops, and every thing needful to carry on the Design; for having Count Steinboch and the Swedes in so close a Place, it was certain, they ought not to let them go off, cost what it would.

THE Czar having now left the Army, had se∣veral private Affairs in Hand, as particularly, at Wolfembotle, where he made some Stay, in order to reconcile things between the Princess of Russia,
his Daughter-in-Law, and her Husband, the Czarowitz, or Hereditary Prince, who, it seems had had some Difference with the Princess, his Spouse, of which we shall hear farther.

FROM Wolfenbuttel, the Czar went to Magde∣burg, and thence to Schoonhosen near Berlin, where he had an Interview with the King of Prussia, and where his Prussian Majesty entertain'd him with the utmost Magnificence. This was the 10th of March, the next Day, the two illustrious Monarchs dined together; and the Czar having abudance of Reason to be very well satisfy'd with his Reception, parted the same Afternoon for Dantzick in his way to Livonia.
WHAT was made Publick at this Time of his Czarish Majesty's Journey, seems to have Truth in it, being writen from Dantzick, after the Czar's Arrival there as follows, viz

THE Court of Wolfenbuttel is highly satisfy'd with the Czar of Muscovy, and the Princess, Wife to the Hereditary Prince, set out the 16th of March under the Discharge of the Cannon for Petersburg by the way of Berlin and Dantzick. The Czar presented her with a great Sum of Mo∣ney for the Charges of her Journey; and at the same time assur'd her, that she should be used with so much Respect in Muscovy, that he did not question but she would easily forget Germany. That Prince made considerable Presents to the Mother of that Princess, and amongst other Things, presented her with his Picture set with Diamonds, of a considerable Value. The Court of Muscovy is to continue at Petersburg for some Time, and some Grandees of the Retinue of the Czar, report, that that Prince intends to make that Place the Seat of his Empire, and 20000
Persons are remov'd thither from Moscow. His Czarish Majesty designs to have at Sea this Sum∣mer a Squadron of his own Ships, and besides those that have been built in his own Harbours, he has bought several Frigats at Dunkirk, and in Holland, which are to be man'd and fitted out at Copen∣hagen, to act in Conjunction with the Danish Fleet under the Command of Vice Admiral Cruitz. Thus far this Account.

WHILE these things were doing, the Czar's Troops kept their Footing in Pomerania, and a great Part of the Town of Wolgast refusing to pay their Contributions, was burnt by the Russian General's Order. But the Attack of Stralsund or Stetin, was not thought proper to be undertaken 'till the Swedes in Holstein were en∣tirely reduc'd, which were yet a Work of Diffi∣culty.

THIS Year his Czarish Majesty's Queen, or rather Empress, tho' they call'd her in Muscovy by neither of those Stiles, but that of Czarina, was deliver'd of a Daughter, or Princess; this happen'd very much to his Czarish Majesty's Sa∣tisfaction, just after his Arrival at Petersburg. This Princess was baptized a few Days after, ac∣cording to the Rites of the Greek Church, and named, Maria Petra Witza.

ALL this while the Preparations against the Turks went on as before, the Russian Court not yet knowing what the unsettled Dispositions of the Ottoman Court might issue in; and his Czarish Majesty, that his Enemies might not flatter themselves with Hopes of taking him at the same Advantage they did before, viz. to be surround∣ed with their Tartars, to cut off his Provisions, or to be betray'd by the Moldavians, who had under∣taken
to supply the Army, I say, of take from his Enemies all Expectations of that kind; his Maje∣sty caused three large Forts to be erected upon the Banks of the Dniester, and two Bridges of Com∣munication to be laid over the River; and here he laid up, and resolv'd to lay up Stores of Corn, and Forrage, with Meal, and an infinite Quanti∣ty of other Provisions, sufficient for his whole Army; resolving also, if he advanc'd into Mol∣davia, to build two strong Forts; one at an impor∣tant Pass, in the Way to the Pruth; and another, on the Bank of the Pruth; to secure his Convoys and Provisions from the Tartars: In this Posture the Turks found Things when they held their great Divan, or Council, to conclude, whether they should break with the Russians, or, no: Their seeing the Czar, in such a formidable Po∣sture, contributed not a little to cool their Warmth for a War, and to adhere to the wiser Councils of Peace, as we shall hear presently.

BUT to come back to Holstein, where the War was now near a Close, the Swedish Army being at length forc'd by the Confederates to quit their Intrenchments and Fastnesses they had made, and retire into Tonningben, where they were reduced to Extremity for want of Provisions, and the Danes and Russians resolving to attack them in Form, and force them out of that Fortress Sword in Hand, General Count Steinbock was forced to Capitulate; several Treaties and Offers had been made on one Side and other, which came to no∣thing: But on the 16th of May, the whole Mat∣ter was agreed on, and an End put to that War. The Terms of this Capitulation, as it was call'd, was as follows, viz.

LIST.ITEM: I. THAT the whole Swedish Army under Count Steinboch, in the Territory of Eyderstadt, and in Tonningen, shall surrender with their Commanders in Chief, Generals, Officers, Volun∣teers, and private Soldiers, to the King of Den∣mark: That all the General and chief Officers, to∣gether with the Volunteers, shall keep all their Arms, Baggage, Writings, Field Chest; and every thing thereto belonging, without being plunder'd. The Subaltern Officers and Soldiers shall keep only their Swords and Cloaths; the Cannon, Fire Arms, as also the Horses of the Troopers, Dragoons and Ar∣tillery, and what more belongs to the Military Ser∣vice, none of which shall be spoil'd or made away with, shall be left behind, and after the March out of Tonningen be given up at Heyersworth, with all the Colours, Standards, and Drums. The March from Tonningen shall be within three Days after the signing of the Capitulation, and shall be com∣pleated in eight: The Rout for marching, and the Quarters, shall be settled by the Danish Commissa∣ries of War.

II. The Transporting the Swedish Troops, when they shall be exchang'd or ransom'd, shall be to no other Parts than to Sweden, at their own Charge: They themselves shall proide the Vessels for that Purpose, the King of Denmark shall furnish Pas∣ports to those Vessels; and they may make Use of Danish and Holstein Vessels if they can be had voluntarily for Hire.
III. The Swedish National Troops shall no the sepa∣rated from the Germans, but be transported to Sweden together.
IV. The Transportation shall be immediately after the exchanging or ransoming.
V. The Swedes shall on their resting Day in their March have free Lodging, but buy their Provisions themselves.

VI. The Danes or their Allies, who have been made Prisoners, and have since taken Service among the Swedes, as also the Deserters, shall be stopt; but if the voluntarily return to their former Regiments, they shall be pardon'd.
VII. Of the Swedish Troops, none shall be forc'd into and detain'd in Service, except Diserters.
VIII. The Baggage of the Generals, chief Officers and Volunteers, mention'd in the first Article, shall be transported to Sweden, or elsewhere, unsearch'd and free.
IX. The March out shall be by Brigades, which shall be conducted by Commissaries, and be furnish'd with Provisions, the Swedes paying for it.
X. The Troops shall march three Days, and rest the forth; and Waggons shall be provided for those who shall fall sick on the Way.
XI. The Sick now in Tonningen, shall be removed in∣to the Eyderstad, till they are recover'd, at their own Expence.
XII. The Mounting and Cloaths, which lie at Lubeck and Hamburgh for the Swedes, and are paid for, shall be carry'd free to Sweden with Pasports.
XIII. All Swedish Officers who are Prisoners in Den∣mark, Holstein, Hamburgh, or elsewhere, shall after the Cartel is satisfy'd, be permitted to repair to their respective Regiments.
XIV. The Swedish Officers, who on Account of Sick∣ness or Wounds have been left at Lubeck, Ham∣burgh, or Wismar, shall be transported free with Passports where ever they please.
XV. So shall their Baggage, and other Things.

XVI. For the Convoy of the Swedish Troops to Swe∣den, two or three Frigots shall be granted; the Tran∣sportation shall be to Carelscroon, Carelshaven, Cimbershaven, or Ystedt; and if in the Passage any Ships be by stress of Weather driven to the Da∣nish Coast, they shall not be seized again and detaind.
XVII. On the Part of the Danes a Physician and Surgeon shall go into Tonningen▪ to take Infor∣mation of the Sick; as also some Commissaries, to take a List of the Horses and other Things.

XVIII. The Swedes oblige themselves to set at Liberty, pursuant to the Cartel, the Prisoners taken frem the Northern Allies, and kept in the Swedish Provinces in Germany; and Count Steinboch promises to use his best Endeavours that the Prisoners kept in Sweden may be discharg'd likewise.

XIX. The King of Denmark promises, that he will not Bombard Tonningen this Year, and the Tren∣ches and Batteries which the Danes have made be∣fore the Place, shall be levelled by the Swedes on their marching out.
XX. The Swedes shall be allow'd to desire the Guarn∣ty of other Potentates of the present Capitulation Granted them; but their March out shall not on that account be delay'd.
XXI. The King of Denmark engages to perform all that is above stipulated, and to procure the Concur∣ence of the Commanders of the Armies of the Allies.
XXII. Two Copies of this Agreement shall be made, to be exchang'd against each other. Done and con∣cluded at Oldensworth, the 16th of May, 1713.

CLOSER.SIGNED:
Sign'd,
G. Roynbolt Patkull,
Carl. Mellin,
G. C. Stramfeldt.
Schwaudlodh

DIV2.P: THIS Affair being thus concluded Prince Men∣zikoff, and the other Russian Generals prepared to bring away the Army, and put them into Quar∣ters of Refreshment, after so severe a Campaign, which had lasted now from the beginning of De∣cember, to the middle of May.

ON the 4th of June, the Muscovite Forces march'd from their Camp with their Quota of the Swedish Prisoners Colours and Cannon: This Pro∣portion, or Quota was thus stated, and agreed a∣mong the Generals of all Sides; the whole was divided into five equal Parts, of which the Russians had two Fifths, the Danes two, and the Saxons one, and upon this Division, Prince Menzikoff sent to his Camp 47 Swedish Colours, 27 Standards, 3 pair of Kettle Drums, and 6 Pieces of Cannon; with these the Troops decamp'd, and march'd to∣wards the Trave; but the Prince Menzikoff then went to Hamburgh, where he resolv'd to humble the City for some Insolences they had suffer'd to be put up on the Russians, and their Affairs; where∣upon he demanded 500000 Rixdollars of them, and to give the more vigour to his demand, he mark'd out a Camp for 15000 Men in their Ter∣ritories, he order'd the Troops to approach, as if he intended really to attack them.
THE just Pretentions the Prince had to be of∣fended at the Conduct of the Hamburghers were sent them in a Letter, and are to the Purpose following.

LIST.ITEM:
I. “THAT some Years since they have print∣ed in this City false Reports reflect∣ing on the Honour of his Czarish Majesty, and that upon Complaint thereof, the Magistrates
have refused to deliver up the Authors of the same.”

II. THAT the Sieur Vosbein, Director of Com∣merce “for Muscovy, was arrested and kept Prisoner, till he was released by giving Bail, whereby he sustain'd a Damage, amounting to above 100000 Florins, tho' he was known to be under the Protection of the Czar.”
III. “THAT in the Year 1700, 20000 Fire Arms belonging to that Prince, were betrayed by the Hamburghers to the Swedes.”
IV. “THAT an Officer of the Czar coming through Hamburgh, was suffer'd to be plunder'd at one of the Gates by the Officers of the Custom House, in sight of the Guards.”

V. “THAT the Baron de Lewenwodle, Adjutant General of the Muscovite Army was lately af∣fronted in a most scandalous manner at the Gate of Altena, which the said Prince Menzi∣koff declares, that his Master expects a suita∣ble Satisfaction.”

DIV2.P: HIS Czarish Majesty, who never Sleeps upon the Enterprizes he has in View was at this time, at Petersburgh, as is observ'd above, and had the satisfaction in one Day to receive an Account from Constantinople, the hopes his Ministers there had of renewing the Peace with the Turks, and from Hamburgh, of the Surrender of Count Steinboch, and the whole Swedish Army at Ton∣ningen.

THO' this did not hasten his Preparations for his other Designs, which he was resolved to have push'd, tho' his Enemies had not made Peace in Turky, or had not been reduc'd in Hol∣stein, yet it added this to it, that he was now at
Leisure to appear at the Head of his Army, and on Board his Fleet for an Expedition against the Swedes in Finland.

THIS was the Enterprize, and it was not an Undertaking of small Consequence for could he but reduce this Province, the Swedes would be entirely driven not only out of the Gulph of Nar∣va, and the great Gulph of Finland, but even out of theGulph of Bothnia; for if Finland was once taken, the Eastern Bothina would fall of Course.

IT was for this Reason, that his Majesty pre∣par'd so considerable a Force for this Conquest. The Czar sail'd the 19th from Petersburgh, with with a Fleet of 20 Men of War 100 Gallies, and 200 Transport Ships, having on Board 18000 Foot, with a Train of Artillery, as well of heavy Can∣non and Mortars, as of Field peices with a great Magazine of all sorts of Stores of War directing, his Course strait for Abo in Finland; the Cavalry, consisting of 9000 Horse, and Dragoons were or∣der'd to march by Land to meet the Army at their coming on Shoar: The Hereditary Prince of Russia also attended his Father the Czar in this Expedition.

HIS Czarish Majesty went on this attempt, as to a certain Conquest, for the Affairs of the Swedes were at this time at so low an Ebb, and the Nation of Swedland under such discouragements, that they were in no Condition to repulse him, or defend themselves; he therefore carried with him a Mani∣festo to be published at his Landing, to assure the Inhabitants, prevent their flying from their Ha∣bitations, and promising them all possible good Usage, and that the Army should not Plunder, but observe good Discipline, and pay punctally
for all the Provisions they took of them over and above the ordinary Contributions, &c.

IT is not to be wondered at, if this Expedition put the whole Kingdom of Swedeland into a ter∣rible Consternation, for seeing the great Prepa∣ration making for a Descent, and so great an Army embark'd, the Senate and Governors of Swedeland made no Question, but that it was designed against the Capital of the Kingdom, and Consequently was a blow at the Root in order to subvert the whole Government, and make an entire Conquest of Sweden it self, which as things then stood, had been no difficult thing for his Czarish Majesty to have done: This alarm however, they had really no Cause, for yet the Fright, had this good Effect, that the Governor of Sweden drawing all the strength of the Kingdom together for the Defence of the Coast about Stockholm, and the Coast of west Gothia, between Stockholm and Um, and between Stockholm and Carelscroon; so they left the Province, and Coast of Finland, whether the true design of the Czar was pointed quite unguarded, and in a manner neglected, not that they forgot the need∣ful Care of it, but that being anxious to preserve the Heart, or Main of the Kingdom of Sweden, they had not Troops to spare for the succour of the re∣moter Provinces, where the Danger indeed only lay.

THIS gave his Czarish Majesty an easie Con∣quest of Finland, where he Landed his Army without any considerable opposition: He Landed at Hesingsford, a small Port Town, which the Swe∣dish Garrison not being in Condition to defend, set on fire, and retired towards Abbo, where the Swedish General Arenfield, who had the com∣mand of the Troops left for the Defence of that
Province, drew all his Forces together to make Head against the Russians, and had advanc'd to Borgo, a strong Pass, which he pretended to de∣fend; but we shall afterwards see how well they maintain'd themselves there.

IN the mean time we must cast back our Eyes to Prince Menzikoff, and the Russian Army in their Victorious return from the Country of Holstein, their demand upon the City of Hamburgh has been mention'd; the Conclusion of which was, that the Hamburghers Paid the Prince 200000 Rixdol∣lars, and so the Russian Army quitted their Di∣strict; the like Pretensions the Prince made upon the Citizens of Lubeck, and got 100000 Marks of them, and then without any stop they ad∣vanc'd towards Pomerania; it was propos'd to at∣tack Wismar, and the Danes provided a great Train of Artillery for that Purpose; but the Ge∣nerals differing afterwards upon particular Diffi∣culties in the Enterprize it was laid aside, and the Russian Army march'd and joyn'd the rest of their Troops in Pomerania, where being together, they made up an Army of 36000 Men, with which Prince Menzikoff resolv'd to attack the City of Stetin, the Capital of the Royal Pomerania.

THIS is a City of great strength, and the Works were in very good Condition, and considering the gallant Defence this City made when besieged by the King of Prussia's Father, then Elector of Brandenburgh, against whom it defended it self to the last Extremity; I say, considering this, it was esteem'd a desperate Undertaking of the Russian General, and the World expected it would be the ruin of their Army, and the disgrace of the Gene∣ral; but this did not Discourage Prince Menzikoff, who about eight Days after he had Invested the
Place, rais'd a Battery against the Oder Fort, a strong Work, which guarded the Bridge, and af∣ter having Batter'd it two Nights, caus'd it to be storm'd, which his Men did with such Fury, that the Swedes, which defended it, being not able to maintain their Ground, the Russians entered Sword in Hand, the Defendants being all cut in pieces, except a very few, who had Quarter grant∣ed them: This gave the Courage of the Citizens a shock, and it was easie to see they had not the Gallantry and Resolution of their Ancestors.

WHILE this was doing, the Saxons who lay at Damin and at Gripswald, found means with the help of some Danish Fregates, and some other Vessels to Land upon the Isle of Rugen, the Swe∣dish General Ducker, who commanded in the Island, having but very few Troops retired to a strong Pass in the way to Stralsund, and made a stand there, but kept his Retreat open to Stralsund, if need were, and the Saxons receiving some Re∣inforcements from Gryswaldt advanced towards him, on which being in no Condition to maintain the Post, he retir'd to Stralsund, and left the Saxons Masters of the whole Island; and now the King of Denmark repented heartily that he had not caus'd his Army to advance into Pomeren, for now had been the Time to have attack'd the City of Straelsund, in which there was not a sufficient Garrison, or Provisions to have held out a Siege, nor any Relief at Hand, the Affairs of Sweden, being as I have said in great Confusion; the King's Sister, since Queen of Sweden, being about that time about taking upon her the Regency of the Kingdom in the Absence of the King.

THE Saxons were sensible of the Advantage they had, but they wanted every thing needful for such a Seige as that of Straelsund; however they sat down before the Place, invested it, and surpriz'd 400 Horses, and 50 dismounted Troopers, in the Enclosures near the City, and dispatch'd Expresses to Denmark for Cannon and Ammunition, which came not in time, as you shall hear, which occa∣sion'd the Seige to be deferr'd till new Laurels were prepar'd by these things for his Czarish Ma∣jesty.

THERE happen'd at this very time a Discovery of the villainous Design against the Life of the King of Poland, which made a very great Noise, and oblig'd Count Flemning to go away imme∣diately, and the Saxon Troops were order'd to draw off from the intended attack of Straelsund, and follow with all speed the King of Poland, ex∣pecting a General Revolt, especially on the Side of Lithuania; but his Polish Majesty manag'd his Affairs with such Dexterity that nothing of that kind happen'd.

THE attack of Stetin was also deferr'd for the present, but the City was closely block'd up, and the Blockade so well concerted, that the Navigati∣on of the Oder was cut off from the Stetiners, which was indeed the only Means to reduce them.

THE Enemies of the Russian Glory had now the Mortification also to see the renew'd Peace between his Czarish Majesty and the Turks confirm'd, by in∣telligence from all Parts, and particularly from the King of Sweden's exil'd Court near Adrianople, and the Articles were publish'd by themselves, which being allow'd to be right and in Substance, are as follows.

LIST.ITEM: I. The Muscovite Troops shall march out of all the Territories of Poland within two Months, and shall not return thither upon any Pretence whatsoever.
