II. The Port shall be allow'd to procure a Passage to the King of Sweden thro' Poland or Musco∣vy to his own Dominions, under a Guard, at the Charge of the Grand Senior, and the said Guard shall return without any Hindrance or Opposition.

III. The Cossacks shall be restor'd to their ancient Privileges, and Kiow with all the Country on the other side of the Dnieper or Boristthenes, shall belong to the Czar, and the Country on the other side of that River to the Port.
IV. Asoph shall remain to the Turks, who are al∣low'd to repair the Fortifications thereof, but Ta∣ganorock shall be demolish'd.

V. The 60 Pieces of Cannon which the Muscovites have carried away from thence, shall be restor'd, or an Equivalent given for it, after which they shall be at Liberty to take away the Iron Guns which they have left in Asoph.
VI. According to the Peace concluded near the River Pruth, the Turks shall be at Liberty to rebuild some Places in the neighbourhood of Caminieck, that have been demolish'd.

VII. The River Zamara shall be the Limits of Tur∣key, and that of Exceez shall be the Frontier of Muscovy, and both Parties are allow'd to build each a Fortress on their respective Frontiers; but Asoph, and the Limits on that Side, shall re∣main in the same Condition.
VIII. All acts of Hostility shall cease on both Sides, the Cossacks, and other Countries belonging to the Czar are included in this Peace.
IX. The Calmucks shall remain to the Czar, and the Crim Tartars to the Port, and those two Na∣tions shall be hindered from committing any Ho∣stilities.
X. The Pretentions of the Tartars of a yearly Tri∣bute shall be referr'd to another Time.
XI. This Peace shall continue for 25 Years, and may be prolong'd for a longer Time.

DIV2.P: THE publishing of these Articles, stopp'd the Mouths of those People who insulted the Czar, with having submitted for fear of a War with the Turks, to be Tributary to the Tartars, as for∣merly the Czars had been, but as his Czarish Majesty had always rejected the Articles with Scorn, so it was now apparent that the Turks had dropp'd it.

THE Russian Army lay all this while before Ste∣tin, sometimes resolving to besiege it in Form, and then, at other times to blockade it; but now Prince Menzikoff being returned from Berlin, where a Treaty for Sequestring the Town into the Hands of the King of Prussia had been set on Foot, but came to nothing. I sy, the Prince being Return'd, resolv'd upon a Bombardment, which he knew would either bring the City to surrender, or the King of Prussia to yield to the Sequestration upon the Terms propos'd, which was to pay to the Czar of Muscovy 600000 Rix Dollars for the Charges of the Siege.

ACCORDING to these Resolutions, our Trenches were open'd, and advanc'd to proper places; and the Batteries raised with the utmost Expedition,
the Artillery consisted of 58 Pieces of heavy Cannon, and 32 Mortars: On the 20th of Sep∣tmber, all our Batteries of Cannon and Mor∣tars being in a Readiness, it was resolv'd to Fire upon the Place the 28th in the Morn∣ing. All the Drums and Houtboys of the Ar∣my were order'd to meet in the Trenches about 9 of the Clock, where they play'd about an Hour, to the great Surprize of the Besieged, who appear'd on their Walls to see what the meaning of it could be; but about Ten, we began to fire from all our Batteries at once, and continu'd till the Evening; which had such an Effect, that the Inhabitants seeing about 160 of their best Houses burnt, and their Churches batter'd down, they oblig'd General Meyrfelt to desire a Cessation of Arms. The Sieurs Bassewitz and Brukenthal were sent into the Place, and told the Governor that the Hostilities should be discontinu'd for seven Hours only, and that he might take his Measures there∣upon. Those Gentlemen reported, that the Burghers refused to take up Arms, and the Regi∣ment of Pomerania expressing an Inclination to lay them down. General Meyrfelt offer'd to march out with his Garrison in 5 Days, provided they would give him leave to send an Express to Count Welling, to acquaint him there with; which was granted him, upon Condition that a Muscovite Officer should go along with the Person he would send to the Count aforesaid, and that his Letter to him should not be seal'd. This being agreed to, the Swedish Officer and the Muscovite set out the same Morning very early or Hamburgh, and we hop'd in a few Days to be Masters of this important Fortress.

BUT while the Garrison of Stetin were thus, at the Extremity, another Medium was found out, which made all Sides easy, and this was the Treaty of Sequestration, mention'd above. This was absolutely, necessary for Prince Menzkioff to yield to; or, to break with the Danes, and the King of Prussia also; for the former, protested absolutely against Stetin being put into the Hands of his Czarish Majesty singly, and insisted that there should be a Quota of Danish and Saxon Troops put into Garrison there, as well as Muscovite, which Prince Menzicoff rejected; those Powers having not contributed one Farthing towards the Siege.

IN a Word the King of Prussia sending a very obliging Answer to the last Offers of the Prince, was in Return invited to the Russian Camp, where his Prussian Majesty arriv'd the 5th of October, at ended with 3000 Dragoons and 9000 Prussian Foot, being on the other Side the Oder, where they encamp'd. His Prussian Majesty was very Magni∣ficently entertain'd by Prince Menzicoff, and a Royal Tent set up, in which his Majesty lodg'd; the 6th at Night, having been shewn all the Ap∣proaches of the Russian Army, their Batteries, and the Preparations which the Ingineers had made for storming the Place, and that we were sure of our Game.

THE next Day the Sequestration was settled and agreed upon, and the Garrison and Burghers of Stetin, agreeing also that the King of Prussia should march into the City the 7th at the Head of 1600 Dragoons, his Infantry entering the Town by the Oder Bridge the next Day.

BY this Treaty, the Possession of Stetin was to remain a-like to the King of Prussia, and the Duke of Holstein till the Peace, and 1600 Men of the
Troops of Holstein were allow'd to remain in Gar∣rison with 1600 Puissians; and the King of Prussia paid Prince Menzikoff 500000 Rix Dollars, and so this troublesome Affair ended.

BUT I must observe here, that both the Saxons and Danes took great offence at this Treaty; for the Sequestration of Stetin was not Communicated to them, the Saxons alledg'd, seeing the Cannon furnished for the Siege belong'd to their King, his Polish Majesty ought to share the Money, and de∣manded one half of the 500000 Dollars; but Prince Menzikoff gave them good Words, and kept all the Money.

THE King of Denmark took the Allarm, there being a Report spread that another Treaty was also on Foot for the Sequestration of Wismar and Stralsund, upon which the Danish Minister presented a Memorial in his Master's Name, to the Ministers of Prussia and Muscovy, intimating that his Master had been very much surprized to hear▪ that an Affair of so much Importance as the Sequestration of Stetin had been concluded, and that Place deliver'd to the Troops of the Duke of Holstein, whose Interest is inseparable from that of Sweden; That his Majesty hopes nothing shall be concluded without his Participation in relation to Wismar, because of his particular Concerns in that Affair, and that the whole Matter, which has been hitherto kept Secret from him, shall be fairly communicated to his Majesty, and in the mean time the said Minister has thought fit to protest against whatever has been done in this Sequestra∣tion without his Consent and Knowledge.

As to the Treaty for the Sequestration of Wis∣mar and Stralsund, it came to nothing; and all things being now over, the Muscovite Army, which was
by this Time reduced by hard Service without any considerable Action to 22000 Men from 36000; they began their March out of the Coun∣try, the 25th of September, according to the Capi∣tulation of which, that was one of the most par∣ticular Conditions.

WHILE this was done, the Armies of his Czarish Majesty were Victorious in Finland; General Le∣becker had been recall'd from that Government, and General Arenfield sent in his Room, as is no∣ted above; but he had no better luck than the other, for being encamped at a very advantagious Post, with 7000 Swedes, regular and old Troops, and 18000 Men, new raised, but well arm'd, and un∣der very good Officers, yet the Russians attack'd them; the new raised Troops being undisciplin'd, yet made very great Resistance at first, but were charg'd with such Fury, that they were at length defeated; which occasion'd that the 7000 Swedes were surrounded, and after a very good Defence, were almost all cut in Pieces, or taken Prisoners, with all their Artillery, and Baggage.

AFTER this Action, the Czar's Troops enter'd Abo without Resistance, and his Czarish Majesty resolv'd to batter down the Defences of the other two Forts, which lye adjoyning to the Sea, and which interrupted his Progress; and thus he became Master of the whole Province, with the Loss of very few Men, and the Tranquility of the Country ws restor'd entirely: As the Czar had gain'd this whole Province so eaily, he was resolv'd it should not be so easily taken from him; he therefore went to Work immediately, to forti∣fy the Towns of most Importance, as Abo and Helsingvos, and others, both which, he has since made very strong.

THIS Action with the Swedish Troops under General Ahrenfield, having been diversly reported, and the Russians being charged with Partiallity, in relating their own Affairs; I shall therefore give here a Copy of General Ahrenfields own Ac∣count, which tho' he makes the best of his Loss to save his own Character; yet an impartial Rea∣der will easily perceive, a Total defeat was given him, and that he has lost not only his Army, but the whole Province; so that our Account will be effectually ackowledg'd by the Enemy, which is the best kind of Confirmation; his Letter is as follows:

THIS will inform, that we sustained Yesterday a fierce Attack from the Enemy, who, at last, oblig'd us to give Ground. Our Intrenchments near Palka∣na were very strong, and we reckon'd to be able to deend 'em a great while against considerable Forces: But, contrary to our Expectation, the Enemy found Means to land 7000 Men within a quarter of a League behind us. I had made several Detachments, and sent our Parties to get Intelligence, by which I learnt, that several of the Enemy's Boats were in sight; whereupon I made all the necessary Dispositions to hinder a Descent; I also view'd the Place where the Enemy design'd to land, and caus'd same Horse to be posted there. I had besides this, drawn two thirds of the Infantry, that were within the Lines, in order likewise to oppose the Descent; but the Wind, which had been contrary to the Enemy's design all Night, turn'd favourable to them at Break of Day; besides which, there was a thick Fog, that we could not per∣ceive till they advanc'd upon us. Our Cavalry was
at first oblig'd to retire, because the Infantry I had drawn from our Line could not came up time enough to sustain them; the Enemy before their approach, having landed the best part of their Troops. Never∣theless, we advanc'd and charg'd them with a great deal of Bravery, and by our superior Fire, push'd them into the Water; but they being supported by such as hourly landed on all sides, we were obliged to give way in our Turn. We had disposed things in such a manner, that the Horse was to attack the Enemy in Flank, and if they had perform'd their Duty, 'tis probable we should have had Success: But tho' the Foot did all that could be expected from the best Troops, yet we could never prevail with the Cavalry to do the like, each Plattoon giving way one after another. Things being at this Pass, it was not difficult for the Emnemy to attack our Lines; however, they lost abun∣dance of Men, till upon certain Considerations, I order'd the Troops to abandon the Intrenchments. The Loss we have sustain'd in those Attacks is not small. We were oblig'd to march through the most con∣venient Places to favour our Retreat, and the Infantry being obliged to take several Routs, it is not yet possible for me to know what Number of Men are missing. In mean time, I have again posted my self in this Passage, in order to make all possible Resistance. The great Number of Roads and Passages had oblig'd me to divide my Troops in such manner, that I had only with me 700 Horse and 1100 Foot to oppose the landing. This Day the Enemy advanc'd near this Place, and I am now in Expectation of their further Undertakings, &c.

THE Truth of this Matter was thus, that Gene∣ral Ahrenfield was entirely defeated, his Horse which indeed did not do their Duty were never
heard of, till they were effectually secured at a∣bout 60 Miles retreat North, and the General with that small Remnant of his Infantry, which, out of 25000 Men, did not amount to above 8000, 5133 being kill'd in the Action, and 512 taken Prisoners, quitted the whole Province, and made long Marches, tho' none pursued them into Lap∣land, whence we heard of them no more; but suppose they got Boats to carry them over the Gulph of Bothnia into Swedeland, where they were at that time in Confusion enough.

THE Conquest of this Province has been of great advantage to his Czarish Majesty's Affairs, for he was now sufficiently separated from Sweden, and under no Obligation to maintain a great Number of Troops upon his Frontier, as before the keep∣ing of good Garrisons in Abo and Helsingford, Places which he has made very strong, and keeping a Number of Gallies always ready up∣on that Coast, is sufficient to keep all quiet on that Side.

FROM hence also his Majesty had drawn a vast Number of good Soldiers, the Finlanders being al∣ways esteem'd the best Men in the Swedish Ar∣mies, and especially for Horse, it being a Coun∣try for breeding of Horses, the Men are naturally good Horse-men, and yet I understand that his Majesty has not Levy'd any Men there, but such as voluntarily Listed into his Service.

THE Czar had now finish'd the Conquest of the Swedish Territories, as far as they lay con∣tiguous to his own; nothing could more be at∣tempted against the Swedes, but by Naval Pre∣parations for a Descent on the Kingdom of Swe∣den it self. His Czarish Majesty had, as I have mentioned already, very much improv'd his
Marine Affairs, as well as his Millitary Affairs by Land, but not to such Perfection, for his Land Forces were brought to a Perfection not to be question'd; his Troops were able to grapple with any of the Forces of his Neighbours Man for Man, nay, he has often beaten the Swedes when they have been superior in Number, and in the last Action at the Siege of Stetin, where there were no Troops but Russians, it appear'd how well they did their Business; how regularly they carry'd on their Approaches; how boldly they storm'd; how firmly they sustain'd the Sallies of the Swedes; and how artfully they mannag'd the De∣fence of their Trenches. We shall now see some Proceedings in which their naval Force was al∣ways concern'd.

HIS Czarish Majesty who knew the Disposition of the King of Sweden, as well as any Man; knew there was no sitting still while he was in being; and the only way to reduce him to Rea∣son, was, to push his Kingdom of Sweden to the utmost Extremity, while he was Absent; if possi∣ble, to bring the Regency, newly establish'd there, in the Princess Ulrica Eleonora, and the Senate, to the Necessity of making a Peace, before the King of Sweden return'd from Turkey.

To this Purpose, the Czar caused a Project to be laid before the King of Denmark, for a se∣cond and more effectual Invading of Schomen, an Undertaking, which he knew very well, would be very ageeable to the King of Denmark, who having receiv'd a terrible Disgrace in his former Attempt there, at the Battle of Elsenburg, would be very willing to retrieve that Blow, and also push the Swedes; he having likewise push'd the War on this side the Sound, to the utmost, and
compleated the the Conquest of Holstein, Bre∣men, and Verden; nothing remaining to the Swedes on this side the whole Baltick Sea, but Pomeren, and the City of Wismar; which were at that time under a kind of Offer to be Seque∣strated to the King of Prussia, tho' afterwards the King of Sweden forbid it.

HOWEVER the King of Denmark did not re∣ceive this Proposal at first, in such a manner as the Czar of Muscovy expected; and much Time was spent in debating upon the particu∣lar Branches of the Undertaking, and the Quo∣tas, and Expences necessary to be furnished. But at length his Czarish Majesty who knew this was the only way by which the King of Sweden could be effectualy humbled, conquered all his Danish Majesty's Objections, and offer'd such As∣sistance, as well of Land Forces, as of Shiping, that the King of Denmark saw an evident Oppor∣tunity put into his Hands, for recovering that Part of the old Kingdom of Denmark, which his Ancestors had lost to the Swedes, and which was given up by the Treaty of Roschild, viz. Scho∣nen, Bleaking, and Halland, Provinces extended on the Coast of the Sound and the North Sea, from Malmo to Gottenbro', and which lye in the very Sight of his Pallace in Copenhagen.

AS the King of Denmark began at last to li∣sten to his Czarish Majesty's offer; so Troops were prepar'd, order'd to march into Pomeren, and Meck∣lemburgh, to be transported from thence to Copen∣hagen, and in a Word, his Czarish Majesty made such Preparations both by Land, and Sea, as con∣vinc'd the King of Denmark, that he should be put into a Posture to humble Sweden effectually, and this brought him to come heartily into the thing, tho'
as it appear'd the Circumstances of Denmark, were not at that time equal to the Undertaking.

HOWEVER, as his Czarish Majesty stuck at no∣thing in Reason to animate the King of Denmark, to persecute the War with asuitable vigour, 300000 Rixdollars were remitted to Copenhagen, and 200000 more afterwards to encourage the King of Denmark to hasten out his Fleet to Sea, and in the mean time the Czar fitted out his own Fleet, con∣sisting of 30 Men of War, most of them being brought and fitted up in England, and Holland, and having embark'd 24000 Men on Board, they sail'd for the Isle of Aland, where his Majesty attack'd Ad∣miral Ehrenschild, and took his Ship, and six Gal∣lies, killed 327 Men, and took about 936 Priso∣ners, and landed 16000 Men in that Island; which put the whole Kingdom of Sweden into the most terrible Surprize, and Consternation imaginable, the Isle of Aland, being as it were at the Mouth of the River of Stockholm.

BUT all this while the Danes did nothing, not∣withstanding the Assistance his Czarish Majesty had sent them, they pretended indeed to fit out their Ships and joyn the Czar's Fleet, but they were so long in doing it, that the Swedes was at Sea, and rendezvous'd at the Isle of Bournholm before the Danes were in Condition to act; so that the expected Conjunction was prevented, which indeed was the Disappointment of all farther Opperations for that Summer.

THE Czar seeing how little such Allies were to be depended upon, put off his intended Descent upon Sweden, for the Swedish Fleet was so strong, being 20 Men of War, and some of their Men of War so large, for they had four or five three Deck Ships from 84 to 106 Guns, and his Majesty's
Fleet, tho' well appointed, yet consisted chiefly of Ships, bought in England, and Holland, most of them being from 44 to 60 Guns, three Ships or four of his Majesty's own building might be there of 70 and 80 Guns, But was not adviseable to come to a general Engagement with the Swedes, without the Conjunction of the Danes.

IT is to be remembered here, that his Czarish Majesty having for some Years, when he first ap∣plyed his Thoughts to encrease his Naval strength, had his Eyes and all his Measures employ'd up∣on building a Royal Navy for the Service of the Black-Sea, so he had now brought that Work to such perfection, that he had a Fleet at Veronowitz, on the Tanais, consisting of 44 Ships, from 50 to 90 Guns, whereof 16 of them carried from 80 to 90 Guns; all which Preparations were intirely lost, and rendered useless, by the surrender of Asoph, given back in Consequence of the unhappy Cam∣paign in Moldavia a, s a above.

BUT the opening a Navigation into the Bal∣tick, by the taking the once impregnable Castle of Notteburgh; the making a Harbour and Port at Croonslot, and building the Imperial City of Pe∣tersburgh, which we find at the writing this Histo∣ry to be rais'd in about 22 Years from a vacant piece of Ground, to a City of 50000 Houses be∣sides publick Edifices, all these were at the time of this taking of the Island of Aland, but new things, and therefore, tho' the Progress the Czar had made, was for the time surprising to the World, yet his Naval strength was young, his Subjects not yet enur'd to Sea-Service; and he was too wary a Prince to put the Success of all his great De∣signs upon, the hazard of a general Engagement
so early, and as it were in the beginning of things; and for this Reason he withdrew from the Island of Aland, upon the Disappointment of the Danes, and gave over his Enterprize for that Year.

SINCE this, we have found his Czarish Majesty has improv'd his Marine strength to snch a degree, and furnish'd himself with such Capital Ships of his own building, that now he is a Match for the Swedes, and the Danes put together, and when∣ever those Powers apprehend his coming to attack them, thy are oblig'd to get the aid of a Squa∣dron of Men of War from Great-Britain to their Assstance, or rather as it may justly be call'd for their Protection.

BUT to return to the Danes; the King of Denmark, began now to besensible of his Mistake, and of his having lost the Opportunity for the humbling his Enemy the Swede; and now to re∣trieve it we find, that the Czar press'd him to en∣gag in a new Scheme for the said second Invasion of Schonen, and offer'd him his Assistance, as well by Sea as Land; also seeing how successfully the Czar went on, and how it might be probable that at one time or other, the Czar, by his Supe∣rior strength would break in upon the Swedes without him, and then he might lose the Oppor∣tunity, and have no share at all of the Advan∣tage: This turned the Scale at the Court of Denmark; and as the Czar press'd him before, as I have said to engage in such an Attempt, and promis'd o Assst and Support him; so now he, his Danish Majesty press'd the Czar as much to come into that Scheme, as if it had been contriv'd at Copenhagen and not at Petersburgh.

IN the mean time, the Czar, as I have said, withdrew from Aland; and having order'd his Gallies and light Fregates to carry the Land Forces to Abo in Finland, he sail'd with the Gross of his Fleet, and the Ships, he had taken from the Swedes to Petersburgh, where he made his publick Entry, with almost as much Triumph as he did for¦merly at Muscow, after the Victory at Pultowa.

AND his Majesty did this the rather, because it was the first Snow of that kind, which had ever been made in his new City; and because it was a heartening, and Encouragement to his Seamen, to merit by their Bravery, and to other of his Sub∣jects to enter into the Sea-Service, which they might see had such Honours, and Triumphs attending it. The Sum of which is as follows: As to a particular Description of his Triumphal-Arches, and other Works for the Decoration of it, it is too long for this Work: I shall only say they were such as shewed, that the Contrivers of them very well understood their Business, and if they had been in France or Holland, they would not have been out done by any: This Triumphal-Entry was made at Petersburgh, the 20th of September, 1714, in the following Order:

LIST.ITEM: I. CAME up some Russian Vessels called Scam∣pavia.
II. Three Swedish Sherboats.
III. Six Swedish Gallies.
IV. A Swedish Frigate, (these taken in the Fight with Admiral Ehrenschild) all with the Swedish Colours hanging down.

V. The Scampavia of the Czar, as Rear Admiral; fix other Russian Scampavia, which Vessels being come up over against the Triumphal Arch that was erected on the Bridge near the Fotress, they saluted the same with all their Cannon, and were answered with the like Discharge from the Cannon of the Fort and the Admiralty.

DIV2.HEAD: All the Men that were on Board land∣ed there, and the Procession began in the following Order.

LIST.ITEM: I. A Company of Brebrezinski.
II. The Cannon on their Carriages which were taken last Winter near Vasa by Lieutenant General Prince Galizin in his Victory over the Swedish Major General Arenfeldt.
III. Sixty three Colours or Standards taken in the Action aforesaid, and the last Engagement.
IV. The Swedish Subaltern Sea Officers, Soldiers and Seamen.
V. Two Companies of Brebrezinski.
VI. The Swedish Sea Officers, Prisoners.
VII. The Flag of the Rear Admiral Ehrens∣child.
VIII. The Swedish Rear Adimiral Ehrens∣child Prisoner.

IX. The Muscovite Rear Admiral, being the Czar himself, with the rest of the Regiment of Brebenszki. As soon as his Majesty came un∣der the Triumphal Arch, all the Senators, Grandees and Foreign Ministers repaired there to Congratulate his Majesty upon his Victory, and the Governor of Moscow in the Name of the Em∣pire of Muscovy, Complimented him on his Bra∣very, and thank'd him for his good Services, and as an Acknowledgement thereof, declared him Vice-Admiral. They proceeded then in the Order aforesaid, and march'd into the Fort, and there was another general Discharge of the Cannon, &c. Then Prince Menzikoff took all the Foreign Ministers into his Shallop, and car∣ried them to his Palace, hefore which there was a magnificent Triumphal Arch erected on the Water adorn'd with rich Hangings, and about half an Hour after the Czar came thither, being receiv'd at the said Arch by that Prince, and then conducted in to the Palace, where a most magnificent Entertaiment was prepared, which lasted till Nine at Night. The Swedish Rear-Admiral Ehrenschild sat at Table be∣tween his Czarish Majesty and Prince Menzi∣koff; and during the Entertainment the Czar took the Opportunity to compliment that Ad∣miral on his brave Defence in the Fight, assur∣ing him several times of his particular Esteem and Affection, and that he would take care to make him as easy as the could under his Mis∣fortune. The other Swedish Officers sat at ano∣ther Table, and were used with all possible Civi∣lities, and so ended that great Solemnity.

DIV2.P: THERE was also a very Magnificent Fire-work appointed to be performed or play'd off, at the Gate of the Royal Palace. But the Engineers representing that they had not compleated the Design, and could not be ready under three or four Days, it was play'd off the Sunday after, when his Czarish Majesty went publickly to the great Church, to give Thanks for the Success of his Arms; and it was admirably perform'd, without the least Disorder or Mistake.

IT is to be noted, That this was not a Triumph for the bare taking of one Ship and some Gallies from the Swedes at the Isle of Aland; but it was upon a Conclusion of a long Series of Victories obtain'd over the Swedes; and indeed, finishing the Conquest of all the Dominions which the Swedes had possess'd on the South and East Sides of the Baltick Seas, viz. the whole Province of Livonia; of Easthonia, and of Carelia; and In∣garmania; the Town and Port of Narva; the City of Stetin; the Castle of Notteburg; the City of Wyburgh; the Isle of Aland; and the whole Country of Finland, a Province of it∣self, large enough, to be call'd a Kingdom, and seated upon the Sea Coast, for 300 Miles in Length, where it is to be noted that the strong Castle of Helsingvos, the last and only Place which the Swedes held in that Province, was taken at the relanding of the Army there; so that the whole Country was subdu'd, and the Swedes put into a terrible Fright, even in the Heart of Sweden. Nay, a Body of Muscovites had transpted themselves over the Bothnick Gulph, and had landed on the Main of Old Sweden it self, that is to say, in the Province of West Both∣nia,
where they had ravaged the Country, burnt several considerable Towns and Villages, where they had taken Uma the Capital of that Part of the Country, and burnt it to the Ground; after which, they extended Northwards to Torne, and destroy'd the Iron Works, which are very Considerable that Way; and did incredible Damage. Another Body of their Troops, ad∣vanced from Finland, North, into the Country of East Bothnia, where the Swedish General Ahren∣field Commanded, and endeavour'd to fight him; but he not daring to come to Action, retir'd North∣ward, into a remote and inaccessible, and indeed, barren and uninhabited Country, where it was not practicable to follow him, leaving the Coun∣try of East Bothnea open to the Spoil.
THESE things merrited a Triumph, as much as the Roman Generals merited a Triumph for the Conquest of the most powerful Nations they subdued.

BUT to come to the Progress of the War again, the Winter was no more past in Idle∣ness than the Summer; and the Czar an active and restless Genius, in all his great Underta∣kings, kept his Enemies the Swedes in Continu∣al Allarms, with the Rumour of an Attempt pro∣jected to pass the Bothnick Gulph in the Time of Frost, with his whole Army over the Ice; those who know the Country, and those Seas, know very well, that as the Bothnick Sea is not deep, and consequently not agitated much by Storms, and also, that there is very lit∣tle Tide, or Current there, it is the soonest Frozen of any part of the Baltick Sea; and then, as its Scituation is more Northerly than
any other part of the Baltick, lying extended to the 64th Degree of North Latitude; and it thereby infinitely colder than the rest, so it is no strange thing to find that Sea like one solid Rock of Ice, for four or five Months together, and the Country People travel∣ling over it themselves, passing and re-pas∣sing as securely as on dry Land, from the one Bothnea to the other: Hence it was no improbable thing, that the Czar might, if his Views had been that Way, have marched with his whole Army over that Sea, not excluding his Baggage, Cannon, and Waggons.

BUT tho' his Czarish Majesty thought fit to allarm the Swedes with the daily Apprehen∣sions of such an Attempt; yet, this was really none of his present View: However, it had this Effect, it continually harrass'd the Swedish Army, in Marching, and counter Marching, as their own Fears directed them; nay, it went farther, for as the Swedes had transported two several Bodies of their regular Troops to the Isle of Rgen and Pomerania, and a thind to Wisma; So that General Ducker who command∣ed there, threatned to take the Field, and ad∣vance into Holstein, and Jutland, as Count Steinboch had done, having this Advantage in such an Enterprize, viz. that he had no Army of Russians and Saxons to follow him in the Rear. The Allarm given to the Swedes in their own Country, by his zarish Majesty hovering over their Coast, as above, had obliged them to send for 7000 Men back again from Pomeren, to reinforce their Army at Home, and to de∣fend the Capital of their Kingdom.

THUS the Danes, were deliver'd at once by the powerful Fleet of the Czar, from an Ene∣my, which they dreaded in Holstein; and from a War that would have perhaps been too heavy for them, as well for the power of their Ene∣mies, as the Expence of it; for the Swedes would at least have ruin'd all the Danish Dominions on the Terra firm, by the Contributions they would have drawn from thence, and the Ravages of the open Country, from whence the capital City is furnish'd with daily Provisions.

THIS very View gave the King of Denmark an an additional Vigour in his new Design of invading , nothing could more effectually deliver him from the just Apprehensions of a Visit from Pomerania, as a Descent upon Schonen, carrying the War home into the Heart of Sweden, and finding the Swedes Employment to defend their own Towns, instead of giving them Leisure to meditate the Invasion of those Abroad.

THIS Winter the King of Sweden came from Turkey, and arriv'd Incognito at the City of Stralsund in Pomerania, and the World had great Expectations, that his coming there would give a new Turn to the Affairs of Europe; but that Prince, whose positive Temper, averse to the Advice of his best Friends, push'd him upon the most desperate, and incon∣sistent Actions, quickly made all his Neighbours easie, as to their Apprensions of his Power, for embroiling himself with the King of Prussia, and the Elector of Hanover, since King of England; he fi∣nishd his own Ruin by absolutely refusing the most honourable Proposal for Peace that could be made to him, and engaging himself in a new War to his Ruin, for he was finally besiged both by Sea and
Land, in his City of Stralsund, and at last forc'd to make his Escape in a small Vessel by Sea, which landed him in Sweden, leaving behind him all his Dominions, and all his hopes in the Empire of Germany, in which he never set his Foot af∣terwards.

AND here necessity, and the swelling of these Pages beyond Expectation too far, obliges us to break of the History. From this Period a new Scene of War was drawn out, in which the Czar of Muscovy had not only a great Share, but which ended infinitely to his Glory, and the Security of his Allies. The Swedes were push'd at their own Doors; their Country invad∣ed; the rich Copper Works, and Iron Works, on which the Commerce of their Nation de∣pended, were ruined; and to finish all, their invulnerable Monarch, as they thought him to be, was Slain; their Treasure exhausted, and they were at last obliged to yield to their Misfor∣tunes, and make a Peace inexpressibly disad∣vantagious to themselves, and in Proportion glorious to his Czarish Majesty; all which Acti∣ons remain to be Recorded, and are sufficient to make another History.

MAY some other Pen be honoured with the Narration, that the Glories of our August Em∣peror of Russia, may be handed to Posterity, in a manner suitable to his Fame; and to the Merit of the greatest Prince in all the Eastern Part of the World. Amen.
